webTitle: Diabetes drug lifts profits at SKB

fields.headline: Diabetes drug lifts profits at SKB
fields.standfirst: Leschly leaves 'on a high'
fields.trailText: SmithKline Beecham's chief executive Jan Leschly declared he was leaving the pharmaceuticals company "on a high" yesterday, after announcing a 10% increase in first-quarter profits to £562m.
fields.body:
SmithKline Beecham's chief executive Jan Leschly declared he was leaving the pharmaceuticals company "on a high" yesterday, after announcing a 10% increase in first-quarter profits to £562m.

The results, driven by strong sales of new diabetes drug Avandia, were Mr Leschly's last before he retires at SmithKline's annual general meeting next Friday.

They were complemented by a recovery at SmithKline's merger partner Glaxo Wellcome, which announced a 12% rise in first-quarter sales to £2.12bn.

Mr Leschly said the figures left the two groups on track to complete their £105bn tie-up in the summer.

Trading at both firms exceeded expectations on the stock market yesterday. SmithKline's shares jumped 29p to 877p, while Glaxo's surged 58p to close at £19.56.

SmithKline's drug Avandia was launched in the US last year and quickly benefited from the withdrawal from the market of a rival product, Rezulin, produced by the US group Warner-Lambert.

SmithKline's finance director Andrew Bonfield said: "There was some buying in by wholesalers as a result of the withdrawal of Rezulin. Because of that buying, we're ahead of our target."

More than 2.6m Avandia prescriptions have been written so far for more than 800,000 patients. The drug is considered a potential huge seller, although European regulators have restricted its use because of fears that it can cause liver damage.

Glaxo Wellcome's figures marked a turnaround from a difficult 1999 in which the company failed to deliver its promise of double-digit earnings growth.

The group's best performing products included asthma inhaler Flovent and Aids treatment Combivir.

Glaxo also benefited from a strong launch of Lotronex, a drug for irritable bowel syndrome.

Glaxo's chairman, Sir Richard Sykes, said: "This strong business performence gives us great confidence and excitement about the prospects for the combined Glaxo SmithKline business."

Planning committees from the two companies are meeting regularly to plan integration. The deal will create the world's largest pharmaceuticals corporation.

Discussions are continuing with regulators to thrash out a deal to overcome competition issues.

SmithKline has offered to sell drugs for herpes and nausea, worth an estimated £600m, in exchange for clearance from the European commission.

Mr Leschly's retirement will be marked at a dinner next week attended by senior executives from throughout Britain's drugs industry. He will be replaced by Frenchman Jean-Pierre Garnier.

Analyst Nigel Barnes of Merrill Lynch said: "These figures mean Leschly departs on a good note. It's the closing chapter of a very successful career at SmithKline."

Mr Barnes said the only weak area in SmithKline's figures was consumer healthcare, where sales rose just 4%.

The company was hit by a slowdown in sales of Nicorette chewing gum, following the launch of a new mint flavour this time last year.

Horlicks, the nutritional drink, also fared poorly with revenue down 4%.

Shareholders' meetings to approve the merger of the two companies are likely to be held in June.

webTitle: Rate rises fail to quell demand for mortgages

fields.headline: Rate rises fail to quell demand for mortgages
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The buoyant housing market, the start of the spring house-buying season and a determination to beat higher stamp duty in the Budget drove demand for mortgages sharply higher last month, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The buoyant housing market, the start of the spring house-buying season and a determination to beat higher stamp duty in the Budget drove demand for mortgages sharply higher last month, according to figures released yesterday.

Higher interest rates from the Bank of England have failed to dent enthusiasm for the property market, with gross lending increasing by almost £3bn to £10.8bn, the Council for Mortgage Lenders said.

Robust consumer confidence also spilled over into high street spending in March, with an abundance of cut-price deals driving up retail sales.

After dropping by 1.2% in February's delayed reaction to the millennium celebrations, the volume of sales rose by 0.5% on the month and was 4.6% higher than in March 1999. However, an indication of the pressure on retailers' margins was provided by the much smaller increase in the value of sales - 1.6% over the past year.

Analysts said the retail sales and mortgage lending figures were likely to underscore the Bank's concern about the strength of the domestic economy, which is sheltered from the effects of the strong pound.

The CML data showed that loans for house purchase stood at £7.2bn in March, up from £5.1bn in February and £6.2bn in March 1999. First-time buyers borrowed an average of £59,942, representing 82% of the value of their property and 2.33 times their income. For mer owner-occupiers borrowed an average £77,723, 64% of purchase price and 2.21 times income.

Michael Coogan, director general of the CML, said: "An increase in lending would normally be expected in March because of seasonal factors. But some of this year's strong rise may be attributable to home buyers completing purchases ahead of the widely expected Budget hike in stamp duty.

"While the CML expects the housing market to remain buoyant in the months ahead, the full impact of recent increases in interest rates and the abolition of mortgage interest relief has yet to be seen."

Data for retail sales from the office for national statistics showed that the price war among supermarkets is having scant impact on food sales, which have been flat over the past three months.

However, the 2.3% rise in purchases of clothes and footwear was helped by a 2.8% drop in prices over the past year, while a 2.0% annual decline in the cost of household goods corresponded with a 4.3% jump in the volume of sales in the latest three months over the previous quarter.

fields.headline: Penitence bound
fields.standfirst:
Henry IV Part I
The Swan, Stratford- upon-Avon
****
fields.trailText: After a modern-dress Richard II we now have a post-medieval Henry IV in the RSC's diverse, multi-directional history-cycle. But Michael Attenborough's decision seems entirely right. This is a play not only rooted in its period but one which offers an extraordinary dual perspective: it both looks back to Bolingbroke's sin of usurpation and forward to Hal's rejection of Falstaff and growth into kingship.
fields.body:
After a modern-dress Richard II we now have a post-medieval Henry IV in the RSC's diverse, multi-directional history-cycle. But Michael Attenborough's decision seems entirely right. This is a play not only rooted in its period but one which offers an extraordinary dual perspective: it both looks back to Bolingbroke's sin of usurpation and forward to Hal's rejection of Falstaff and growth into kingship.

The main link with Pimlott's Richard II lies in David Troughton's dazzlingly pivotal performance. A dominant Bolingbroke, he now turns into a guilt-wracked Henry IV, ever-conscious that he seized the throne by force. Yet, although first seen at prayer in penitent's gown, Troughton's king is still a brutal pragmatist who seeks to pre-empt rebellion by squashing his fractious nobles.

Troughton also gives us the anxious father aware that he is in danger of losing his son to the taverns and the fat knight: there's a great moment when his path crosses that of Falstaff in battle and he shoots him a wounded look. But it is Troughton's magnificent verse-speaking that makes this the key performance so far of the Stratford Histories.

Desmond Barrit's Falstaff is also impressive: less the jovial wit-cracker than a Christ-figure wreathed in silvery pathos who knows, from the silence that greets his pleas not to be banished, that rejection is his fate. William Houston's watchful, meditative Hal confirms the impression that he is simply biding his time in the Eastcheap taverns. And there is a dynamic Hotspur from Adam Levy who, in his evocation of the tyrannical Richard II as "that sweet lovely rose", reminds us of how military heroes re-write history.

Es Devlin's design, with its mound of smoke-filled peat, effectively embodies the idea that "the land is burning" and, even if the battle-scenes look a bit cramped in the Swan, this is a fine production that conveys Shakespeare's unparalleled ability to see history from multiple perspectives. Roll on, Part II.

In rep. Box office: 01789 403403.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Echoes of past pain
fields.standfirst:
Treehouses
Peacock Theatre, Dublin
***
fields.trailText: Despite its 20th-century content and texture, somewhere at the heart of actress-playwright Liz Kuti's odd, beautiful little play is a 19th-century novel. It begins awkwardly with the twin, intercutting monologues of two women: old Magda in her 70s, fretting in a retirement home; and Eva, a much younger woman, raking over unresolved anger after her father's funeral. These interrupted narratives prevent much sense-making at first, but they resolve into clear scenarios.
fields.body:
Despite its 20th-century content and texture, somewhere at the heart of actress-playwright Liz Kuti's odd, beautiful little play is a 19th-century novel. It begins awkwardly with the twin, intercutting monologues of two women: old Magda in her 70s, fretting in a retirement home; and Eva, a much younger woman, raking over unresolved anger after her father's funeral. These interrupted narratives prevent much sense-making at first, but they resolve into clear scenarios.

Eva tells an almost vindictive tale of her perceived betrayal at the hands of her father. After her mother had mysteriously fled the marriage, the man eventually found another lover, thus displacing Eva in his affections. Cutting across this testimony is the older woman's regretful reminiscence of events half a century ago, in Nazi-occupied Europe. When she was a girl, her father sheltered a Jewish boy whom she befriended and plotted to marry.

After a hesitant start, the piece builds into an affecting crescendo under Jason Byrne's head-on direction. The link between the two women gradually dawns, and with it, the resolution of the unpleasant little mystery of the failed marriage. There are times when, as Eva, Morna Regan's knife-keen, Ulster-accented delivery of her monologue seems to come from another play entirely - say, in her chilling Northern tones, talking of "our territory" and "recovering the clarity of my hatred".

As the older Magda, Stella McCusker beautifully manages her defeated, German-accented soliloquoys. The other actors are encouraged to speak in their own accents, by turns English and flat Dublin. In this, and the staging, the audience is asked to go along with a lot of theatrical shorthand, and the folk-tale abstraction of the writing often doesn't help. Nonetheless, engage with this well-produced play, and you will be deeply moved in several directions, not least at the way trauma can shatter across generations.

Until May 13. Box office: 00-353-1-8787 222.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Two types of beauty
fields.standfirst:
CBSO/Oramo
Birmingham Symphony Hall
****
fields.trailText: Brahms, the nostalgic classical-romantic, and Stravinsky, the sharp-edged, forward-looking iconoclast, seem to inhabit different musical worlds, and rarely turn up together in concert. But here, the combination of Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms and Brahms's German Requiem worked surprisingly well.
fields.body:
Brahms, the nostalgic classical-romantic, and Stravinsky, the sharp-edged, forward-looking iconoclast, seem to inhabit different musical worlds, and rarely turn up together in concert. But here, the combination of Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms and Brahms's German Requiem worked surprisingly well.

It was fascinating to discover how much the two works had in common. The sound of the language - Latin for Stravinsky, German for Brahms - was clearly an imaginative spring board for both composers. And both works are steeped in the musical past: Bach looms large, especially in Stravinsky's fugal second movement and in the granite-like fugue of the German Requiem.

The Symphony of Psalms started at a cracking pace. It took the Symphony Chorus, Youth Chorus and Orchestra a little while to settle into Sakari Oramo's tempo, but towards the end of the movement the energy and intensity built impressively. In the finale the al legro sections were vigorous, while the concluding hymn was ravishing.

Brahms's German Requiem doesn't always come off well in concert, particularly when it's performed with soggy reverence. Oramo didn't hurry the music along, but he shaped it so well that it kept moving, even in the slowest sections. The choral singing was firm, though the adult sopranos of the City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus weren't always as pure as the younger voices of the Youth Chorus in the Stravinsky. As for the soloists: baritone Dietrich Henschel made up in expressiveness for what he lacked in vocal presence; soprano Mary Plazas made a beautiful sound and phrased exquisitely, though she tended to sing fractionally behind the beat. But ultimately the effect was positive and thought-provoking: there's a lot more life and originality in this music than most performances would have us believe.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Speculation grows of Bradford & Bingley sale

fields.headline: Speculation grows of Bradford & Bingley sale
fields.standfirst:
Building society's value to members is falling

www.bradford-bingley.co.uk
fields.trailText: Speculation is intensifying that Bradford & Bingley, the building society due to convert to a bank in December, may instead put itself up for sale in the coming months.
fields.body:
Speculation is intensifying that Bradford & Bingley, the building society due to convert to a bank in December, may instead put itself up for sale in the coming months.

Industry analysts say that Christopher Rodrigues, the society's chief executive, is keen to invite bid approaches ahead of the planned flotation. With estimates of likely windfalls to members having been slashed as a result of the recent markdown in mortgage bank shares, there is growing concern among some at the society that it might not achieve the necessary vote in favour of conversion.

Windfalls were originally estimated at £1,000 apiece but with the banking sector having plunged in value on the stock market over the past few months, some analysts have said payouts may be worth as little as £350-£700.

One senior industry ob server said mortgage banks were out of favour, "and Bradford & Bingley would be out of favour even more as a small one. They are a nondescript medium-sized player".

He said that there was continuing opposition to the float among some sections of its membership. "A trade sale might be one of the ways of salvaging it."

There have been suggestions that American banks might be interested, in the wake of the announcement last month of a link-up with US telecommunications and IT company Alltel to provide hi-tech mortgage processing services and systems support to other lenders. Abbey National and Bank of Ireland were also yesterday named as potentially interested parties.

Mr Rodrigues has said in the past that "if someone approaches us with a serious proposition that can be properly valued, the board will consider it".

At the time, he said B&B had not received any bid approaches, and was not inviting any.

For conversion to go ahead, at least half of the society's borrowers and 75% of savers must vote in favour at the special meeting planned for mid-July.

To add to its woes, a new internet-based campaign group has joined the fight against conversion. Somewhat embarrassingly for the society, its web address is www.bradford-bingley.org.uk - almost identical to B&B's official www.bradford-bingley.co.uk site. The site is run by Bradford & Bingley Members Against Conversion, who describe themselves as "ordinary members of Bradford & Bingley building society who oppose its conversion to a PLC bank".

A society spokesman dismissed suggestions that it was set for a trade sale as "just speculation" and said B&B remained on course to float.

webTitle: Bank customers' protest outrages Church of England

fields.headline: Bank customers' protest outrages Church of England
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Church of England yesterday branded as "extreme bad taste" a stunt in which disgruntled bank customers erected a 10 ft cross outside St Paul's Cathedral.
fields.body:
The Church of England yesterday branded as "extreme bad taste" a stunt in which disgruntled bank customers erected a 10 ft cross outside St Paul's Cathedral.

A spokesman said the church was "appalled" at the action, particularly given the imminence of Easter.

But newly formed group Mutual Assistance for Investors & Account Holders (Mafia), claimed the action was simply intended to highlight the £300m of shares the Church of England owns in banks.

Mafia founder Bob Gaught, 56, a salesman from Farringdon, Oxfordshire, said the action was meant to prick the consciences of bank shareholders, including churches, to win fairer treatment.

"The cross is a very powerful symbol and we know what we are doing will shock people," he said.

"What we want is for people, Christians in particular, to think about what they are doing. The church and other shareholders must either take responsibility for the actions of banks or stop investing in them.

"The protest is not against religion, but we believe the church by its very nature has a moral and social responsibility for what it invests in."

Overcharging and the loss of businesses and homes due to unsympathetic banking procedures are among claims made by Mafia members.

Keith Winchup (pictured left), 53, of Welling, Kent, owned a car dealership in south-east London, until bank charges led to his 1997 bankruptcy, he claimed.

Mr Winchup said he was overcharged when he tried to expand the business. "My two daughters had to pull out of university because I could not afford the fees and cheques started to bounce."

A church spokesman said: "What these people are forgetting is that the Church of England led the fight against bank branch closures and our ethical investment advisory group keeps a very close eye on our investment portfolio."

fields.headline: Spectacle meets awe
fields.standfirst:
Chinese State Circus
Alexandra Palace, London
****
fields.trailText: The members of the Chinese State Circus, don't just spin one plate or half a dozen, they spin hundreds at a time. Then they spin them standing on their heads. Then they spin them standing on each other's heads.
fields.body:
The members of the Chinese State Circus, don't just spin one plate or half a dozen, they spin hundreds at a time. Then they spin them standing on their heads. Then they spin them standing on each other's heads.

I've always thought skipping was for wimps, but this puts skipping into an entirely new perspective. These people skip one on top of the other, a kind of gigantic skipping pyramid. The ground actually shakes from shock.

And that's just the easy stuff. Later on they start stretching themselves a tad. A dozen or more ride a single bicycle and, no, they don't hold on; tumblers throw themselves through hoops that get higher and higher and impossibly small; up above us, at the place where tent meets sky, others fly through the air creating stupendous geometric patterns like a human spirograph.

The level of skill is astonishing. Each member of the ensemble doesn't have one feat but many, and just at that point when the emphasis on symmetry leads to a growing feeling that, admirable though it all is, what you are really witnessing is an extremely advanced gym class with a built in wow factor, out prance the ornate gold faced lions and billowing dragons. Spectacle meets perfection in a puff of smoke and a shake of the tail.

Circus traditionalists will be in seventh heaven; those like myself who like their circus to have meaning and emotion may feel sold a little short by the rather regimented nature of the performance. But even at its most po-faced, the evening is a fascinating demonstration of the difficulty of believing the evidence of your own eyes and a jaw-dropping denial of the flesh and the limitations of the human body.

Until May 1. Then at Highbury Fields, London N5, May 3-7 and at Preston Park, Brighton, May 9-27. Box office for all venues: 07720 255 266.

fields.headline: New deal for parents
fields.standfirst: State to pay £150 a week to allow more time with children
fields.trailText: Mothers and fathers of children under five will be offered state payments of up to £150 a week to take parental leave under government proposals designed to make Britain's workplaces more family-friendly.
fields.body:
Mothers and fathers of children under five will be offered state payments of up to £150 a week to take parental leave under government proposals designed to make Britain's workplaces more family-friendly.

Every parent will be offered up to 13 paid weeks off work at an estimated cost of £500m a year in a move designed to be a centrepiece of Labour's policy on the family in the manifesto for the next general election.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is backing proposals drawn up by the Labour MP Ruth Kelly on behalf of the 101-strong Labour parliamentary women's group.

Mr Byers, who is in charge of government policy on maternity pay and parental leave, said: "This is a significant piece of work which will inform our consideration of this important area."

Government ministers are to start lobbying business to persuade them that paid parental leave will be good for firms, leading to a more contented workforce and helping them attract and keep key staff.

While ministers are keen to maintain business support for the government, they believe the scheme would help the government appeal to women voters who backed Tony Blair in the 1997 election but have since started to have second thoughts.

At a Downing Street seminar last month, Labour party strategists argued that Labour needs to trump William Hague's appeal to so-called "Florida woman".

Ms Kelly's blueprint - costed by the accountants KPMG and due to be published in a Fabian pamphlet next month - has found favour with Downing Street, where the expected arrival of Cherie Blair's fourth child next month has sharpened the debate about parental leave, and is being strongly pressed by Labour's women ministers.

The government introduced an unpaid scheme for parental leave last December, but projections indicate that, without payment, only 2% of men and 35% of women would take advantage of the offer of time off.

However, a poll conducted by ICM and sponsored by the Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust found that 97% of the 729 parents questioned would be "very interested" or "interested" in a paid scheme, and that the amount of time taken off work would increase with the generosity of the scheme.

Parents would take 1.53 weeks' leave on average at £75 a week, but this would rise to 5.1 weeks at £150 a week. Mothers said they would take more time off than fathers, but among men the scheme appealed most to those on the lowest incomes.

Ms Kelly said: "I would argue for the full £150 per week for 13 weeks. It would be affordable and have a huge impact on take-up, particularly among fathers. It's a very simple scheme and could create a climate which changes the culture.

"It would allow parents to spend more time with children and juggle the responsibilities of an increasingly complex working life."

The two ministers for women, Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell, and equal opportunities minister Margaret Hodge, are in favour of the proposal. Ms Jowell said yesterday: "Parental leave is one of the most important issues, both for labour market policy and family policy, for people in Britain today."

Pressure groups last night urged Mr Byers to take the Rowntree findings seriously. Sarah Jackson, co-chief executive of Parents at Work, said: "We know from parents who call our helpline that they cannot afford to take this leave unless it is paid. We talk to a lot of low income families who are desperate to take time off to spend with their children but cannot do so."

Christine Gowdridge, director of the Maternity Alliance, which coordinates a national coalition of campaigners under the Parental Leave Campaign, said the Rowntree research was "one more brick in the wall of ammunition in favour of paid leave".

However, the CBI gave the proposals a cool reception. It said that a survey of its members found 72% of businesses "very worried" about parental leave, ranking it as one of their leading concerns.

John Cridland, the CBI director of human resources policy, said: "Businesses have had enough of new regulations. We cannot cope with more and the more we are pressed the more negative we will get."

The ICM survey found that 40% of voters - and 43% of women - questioned would be more likely to vote for a party that promoted paid parental leave, while only 4% said they would be less likely to do so.

fields.headline: New head at the exchange
fields.standfirst:
Bankers' scourge Cruickshank is surprise choice for role of chairman
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank, the chancellor's investigator of the high street banks, is to become chairman of the London stock exchange next month at one of the most sensitive moments in its 200-year history.
fields.body:
Don Cruickshank, the chancellor's investigator of the high street banks, is to become chairman of the London stock exchange next month at one of the most sensitive moments in its 200-year history.

A surprise choice for the £350,000-a-year role - which has previously been assumed by stockbrokers - Mr Cruickshank was immediately cited as the chairman of a merged London-Frankfurt exchange if delicate talks reach fruition in coming days.

Confirming that discussions with the Deutsche Borse in Frankfurt were under way, Mr Cruickshank, who will also receive stock options, insisted yesterday that a deal had not yet been struck.

"[It's] not yet clear whether [a merger] can be agreed," said Mr Cruickshank, who has only just completed an 18-month, Treasury-backed review into competition among the high street banks.

Both exchanges have been working on creating a pan-European alliance for the past year and speculation mounted last night that they were days away from a decision.

Mr Cruickshank's appointment at this stage in the talks prompted the suggestion that he would chair a combined exchange with Werner Seifert, head of the German exchange, taking the chief executive role.

That raised questions about the future of Gavin Casey, the chief executive of the London stock exchange, although Mr Cruickshank said yesterday he "very much" looked forward to working with Mr Casey.

He acknowledged, however, that one of his tasks would be to revamp the board of the exchange, which is in the throes of demutualising - a move which had been billed as a precursor to possible mergers.

His appointment coincided with an announcement from the Treasury select committee that it would call chairman Sir John Kemp-Welch - who is leaving after six years - Mr Casey and two other senior executives to a hearing about the embarrassing breakdown in the exchange's computer system two weeks ago.

The hearing is scheduled for May 17.

Mr Cruickshank admitted yesterday it was unfortunate that the failure had taken place shortly before his appointment but played down its long-term significance.

He is taking the helm at a time when the exchange is fighting off competition from new exchanges able to establish themselves quickly because of new technology.

In the process it will be relinquishing some of its regulatory responsibilities.

At the same time the exchange is under pressure from its members, the major City firms, to reduce the cost of trading stocks across Europe with the advent of the single currency zone.

While London and Frankfurt have been working to construct a "pan-European" trading platform for months, the Paris exchange has already announced plans to create Euronext through a merger with Amsterdam and Brussels.

Angela Knight, the chief executive of Apcims, a lobby group for private client stock brokers, described the appointment of Mr Cruickshank as "interesting".

"It makes a change for somebody outside the exchange bringing to the party a new set of experiences," she said.

Despite speculation that Mr Cruickshank had been appointed to the crucial role at the behest of the Treasury, he said he first been approached about the job in January by an executive search agency.

Lean, mean tormentor with a talent for one-liners

Lean, mean and prim, Don Cruickshank presented an enormous contrast to the thickset, heavy jowled bank bosses as he waited to be grilled by a panel of MPs just two days ago.

The tormentor of the big banks for the past 18 months, Mr Cruickshank showed impatience and exasperation as the bank bosses disputed the findings of his weighty inquiry into banking competition on the high street.

The banks overcharge, Mr Cruickshank concluded, and he recommended a competition commission inquiry into the small business banking market.

These bank chief executives will no doubt be the first to raise a glass to the stock exchange this Easter weekend - relieved that the canny, scholarly Scot now has more pressing matters on his mind.

No stranger to controversy or to the public eye, the former telecommunications regulator had given nothing away about his new, and arguably highest profile role to chair the London stock exchange.

As the first outsider to head one of the City's oldest establishments, Mr Cruickshank will relish the battles around him in the boardroom, among City firms and with Europe's rival stock exchanges, to name just three.

He has already made his mark as a champion of the consumer. While the banks have been his latest prey, he caused agony among telecoms companies when he headed Oftel, the phone regulator, for the five years to 1998.

Trusted by government regardless of its political colour, he was also an important player in the campaign to bust the millennium bug this year.

His appointment to the stock exchange - on a salary of £350,000 enhanced by share options - marks his return to the private sector from the depths of Whitehall.

An accountant by training, the 57 year-old took an MBA before joining McKinsey, the management consultancy firm at which City dignitaries such as Howard Davies, the chairman of the financial services authority, and Archie Norman, the former Asda boss, also cut their teeth.

Perhaps he learned his ability for sharp, quotable one-liners during his stint on Fleet Street, where he was recognised for his "sharp, flinty look" at the Times and later at Pearson.

He subsequently moved on to Virgin, where he achieved millionaire status by floating Sir Richard Branson's empire before taking it private again.

The first to admit that his report into banking competition was "geeky", Mr Cruickshank will now be immersing himself in the works and politics of the stock exchange.

So what if he knows little about share trading? "When at Oftel, I'd only ever used a telephone," he said yesterday.

webTitle: Stick with Toffees in Mersey derby

fields.headline: Stick with Toffees in Mersey derby
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who knows a bloke who knows Hansie Cronje, shows you how to make a pretty penny.
fields.trailText: There are two ways you can look at derby games. Either as unpredictable one-offs where the normal rules don't apply and the form book is irrelevant. Or as a pure test of a team's abilities, where everyone plays out of their skin, weakness is laid bare and the best side wins. Whichever side of the fence you fall, there's no doubt that any psychological advantage in the build-up can help, and a good recent record can provide the cornerstone for a team's confidence. With this in mind it's worth paying serious attention to the blood and thunder ties in Liverpool, Bristol and the Midlands this weekend.
fields.body:
There are two ways you can look at derby games. Either as unpredictable one-offs where the normal rules don't apply and the form book is irrelevant. Or as a pure test of a team's abilities, where everyone plays out of their skin, weakness is laid bare and the best side wins. Whichever side of the fence you fall, there's no doubt that any psychological advantage in the build-up can help, and a good recent record can provide the cornerstone for a team's confidence. With this in mind it's worth paying serious attention to the blood and thunder ties in Liverpool, Bristol and the Midlands this weekend.

First-up, today's Premiership showpiece derby on Merseyside. William Hill's offer of 2-1 for a home win is way too big and should be taken. Everton have not lost this fixture over the last eight show-downs and can continue the trend by ending Liverpool's fine recent run of form. A Heskey-inspired win over Wimbledon last weekend made it five in a row for the Reds. The trouble is, they haven't actually won at Goodison for nine years and they went down at home in this season's first leg by a goal to nothing. Sander Westerveld will remember the occasion well, as he was sent off, so the side that holds its nerve and temper this time round should come away with all the points.

When you compare injury lists, Gerard Houllier may just have the edge even though he has confirmed that Robbie Fowler and Jamie Redknapp will not start. Walter Smith has admitted his concerns about Joe-Max Moore and Richard Gough but will have been cheered by the news that both David Unsworth and Abel Xavier should be available for selection. Francis Jeffers may also come into contention after his appearance in the reserve game against Newcastle on Tuesday night.

Bristol City have won their last four at Bristol Rovers and should be snapped up at 3-1 (Ladbrokes) to make it five. Despite going down in the Auto Windscreens Shield final, the Robins were steered back to winning ways at Luton on Tuesday by popular caretaker boss Tony Fawthrop. City survived a late Hatters' surge to take their unbeaten run in the League to six games and there is growing support from fans and players alike for Fawthrop to take the job manager on a permanent basis.

The Pirates, on the other hand, have jeopardised their chances of automatic promotion by taking only two points from a possible eighteen in recent games. Boss Ian Holloway will not be able to call on midfielder Simon Bryant, who missed his opportunity for a warm-up when the reserve game with Gillingham was postponed. Rob Wooleaston, a loan signing from Chelsea, is also likely to miss out.

As things lie, the Robins most definitely have the edge and can put the Pirates to the sword. Expect Scott Murray to draw first blood - he scored a blinder against Luton and can use the derby stage to add to his tally of seven goals in his 18 appearances.

Spurs broke their six-match winless streak at Filbert Street on Wednesday - but Martin O'Neill was insistent that his side didn't deserve to lose and will head to Villa Park in the knowledge that his side are unbeaten there in five trips.

The home side will find it to tough to score. Gerry Taggart has been doing a fantastic job for the Foxes at the back since Matt Elliott was switched to attacking duties and is Carling Opta's current top-rated defender. Full-back Andy Impey played a blinder against Newcastle, so take the visitors to raise their game as they have so many times this season. The widely available 4-1 looks good for a battling win.

Finally, take Barnsley to win at Wolves. After only one defeat in ten visits the Yorkshire side should repay your faith in them to continue the good run at 7-4 with Ladbrokes and William Hill.

Recommended bets

Everton v Liverpool - home win

Bristol Rovers v Bristol City - away win

Aston Villa v Leicester - away win

Wolves v Barnsley - away win

webTitle: Wenger foresees trouble on the cards

fields.headline: Wenger foresees trouble on the cards
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger was casting his mind forward yesterday to next month's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen even before he flew into France where tonight his Arsenal team set out to defend a narrow advantage over Lens. Yet the manager's problem is rooted in the past: his club's disciplinary legacy.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger was casting his mind forward yesterday to next month's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen even before he flew into France where tonight his Arsenal team set out to defend a narrow advantage over Lens. Yet the manager's problem is rooted in the past: his club's disciplinary legacy.

Wenger is worried that eight of his travelling squad - all but one of them probable starters - are one booking away from a ban which would mean missing the final on May 17. Among them are his captain Tony Adams, Martin Keown, Emmanuel Petit and Dennis Bergkamp, playing his first away game in the Uefa Cup after travelling under the Channel on Eurostar.

Wenger fears the card count will be high in such a finely balanced tie but insists that the risk "won't influence me in terms of selection. And it shouldn't change the attitude of the players at all. You can't go into the game considering that you must not get booked. You have to play your game."

In future, said Wenger, at this stage cautions "shouldn't count for the final. Yellow cards given in semi-finals should go into the next season." In these games, he argues, with so much at stake, "the intensity is higher".

fields.headline: Galatasaray arrive mob-handed
fields.standfirst: Elland Road prepares for a long, fraught night
fields.trailText: It was more like a scene from Reservoir Dogs than the build-up to a game of football. The numbing sight of Galatasaray's slack-jawed heavies in their dark suits, black sunglasses and bullet-proof vests stalking Elland Road last night, shadowing every move and staring down every suspected imposter, belonged to a different, more squalid world than so-called sport.
fields.body:
It was more like a scene from Reservoir Dogs than the build-up to a game of football. The numbing sight of Galatasaray's slack-jawed heavies in their dark suits, black sunglasses and bullet-proof vests stalking Elland Road last night, shadowing every move and staring down every suspected imposter, belonged to a different, more squalid world than so-called sport.

The Turkish champions arrived in Leeds for tonight's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg amid rigid security yesterday and immediately made it clear they would not be taking any chances during their brief but possibly turbulent stay.

They were given a police escort to the ground, where they acclimatised with a short training session as their specially recruited 11-man anti-terrorism squad patrolled the touchline and flashes from a thousand different cameras lit up the sky.

Outside, supporters' club volunteers were setting about the sombre task of removing the mountain of tributes that had accumulated for the two fans killed in Istanbul. Only a few hangers-on were milling around as the police convoy pulled through the gates and there were even fewer as they left, bodyguards in tow, for the team hotel.

"It is normal to have security. We have to take precautions, the same as every team," said the Turks' manager Fatih Terim. "With these people around we can feel comfortable there will be no problems. There is a lot of emotion and anger."

Galatasaray's Romanian defender Gica Popescu went even further: "Every day we have received dozens of faxes and emails threatening to kill us. There is more talk now of safety than the match. Our families are worried for us."

For Leeds the emphasis has been about providing a dignified front. The club have placed advertisements in sev eral national newspapers to appeal for calm among their supporters and extended the hand of friendship by inviting Galatasaray's directors to join them for dinner last night.

The offer was declined without an explanation. Earlier yesterday the Leeds manager David O'Leary had to be coerced into holding his usual press conference before giving an insight into the depths of anguish engulfing the club.

"I didn't want to do this," O'Leary said. "Over the last couple of weeks I have just tried to hide. I was worried that, if I was seen talking about it and getting my photograph taken, it would have seemed like I was milking the occasion. I didn't want to get involved in that."

On the contrary, the feeling in Leeds is that O'Leary and his chairman Peter Ridsdale have emerged with a great deal of dignity. "It has been hard for everyone," added the Irishman. "There will be a great sense of relief when the tie is over.

"I think the players will be OK but they have been so sad dened by what has happened. The city has been a gloomy place and the lads feel: 'Why should we be smiling when there are people out there going to funerals?' It has made them realise how lucky they are."

Against such a backdrop the outcome of the tie has become almost a sub-plot but the prize of a European final is something Leeds cannot afford to sniff at.

To reach a possible Copenhagen showdown with Arsenal, O'Leary's team will have to produce "something extraordinary" to overcome a 2-0 deficit from the ill-starred first leg. Galatasaray have scored in every away game in Europe this season, whereas six consecutive defeats for Leeds comprises their worst run for five years.

"There is a lot of sympathy for us right now. It's something we appreciate but it's a different matter on the field," said the Leeds striker Alan Smith. "No one is going to give us any there and we would not expect it any other way. But we are desperate to win for the two fans who died."

webTitle: 'We are genuinely sorry but it was nothing to do with us'

fields.headline: 'We are genuinely sorry but it was nothing to do with us'
fields.trailText: The small Turkish community in Leeds will stay at home tonight and cheer on Galatasaray at TV parties, after sending morale-boosting messages to the team in their closely guarded hotel.
fields.body:
The small Turkish community in Leeds will stay at home tonight and cheer on Galatasaray at TV parties, after sending morale-boosting messages to the team in their closely guarded hotel.

Reaction to the ban on away fans has been mixed: resentment alongside acceptance that the fall-out from the Istanbul murders - and two emotional funerals in Leeds this week - have created a potentially dangerous mood in the city.

"No matter how unacceptable it is, we are bound to stay at home and watch the game on TV," said Erol Karakirik, a post-graduate student at Leeds University who took flowers to Elland Road after the stabbings but will stay away tonight. "We have no intention of going where we are not wanted and welcomed. But we are worried about the safety and morale of Galatasaray's players."

He and other Turks at college or in the local restaurant trade blame parts of the British media and, to an extent, Leeds United for putting pressure on the visiting team by talking up the dangers of retaliation. But a series of incidents since the deaths of the pub landlord Kevin Speight and fibre-optics engineer Chris Loftus on April 5 have ruled out any enthusiasm for going to make the point at Elland Road.

Armed officers from west Yorkshire police were called to the Alternative Take Away and the New Sultan kebab shop in the city centre last week after violent threats to staff. Another Turkish shop owner, a Leeds United fan who has lived in the city for 12 years without racist problems, said that he had been attacked twice and spat at in the street in spite of armed police guarding his premises.

The man, who does not want to be identified for fear of reprisals, said: "We are all very scared at the moment and know that if people overhear us talking Turkish in the streets we could be injured.

"I have cancelled my ticket. I have a lot of English friends and they are trying to reassure me that everything will be OK, but how can we believe that when we don't know who we can trust any more?"

Ali Delice, the president of Leeds University's Turkish society who describes himself as "Galatasaray's greatest-ever fan", said that he had felt forced to lie when asked about his nationality for fear of being beaten up.

"I was walking along the road when two men asked me if I was Turkish," he said. "I said no and prayed that would be it. Before the stabbings I was proud to be Turkish but now I feel ashamed and embarrassed.

"There is already enough tension here at the moment and we are truly living in fear. I dread to think what would have happened if Uefa hadn't agreed to a ban."

West Yorkshire police have liaised closely with the community, which is fewer than 500-strong, and they were praised by one local shop worker, Turkan Turgay, for "doing everything they can to allay fears".

Turgay said: "We are living in a situation where groups of friends talk in English so that they cannot be recognised. We are genuinely sorry about what happened but it was nothing to do with us."

webTitle: McManaman returns to help destroy English dreams of invincibility

fields.headline: McManaman returns to help destroy English dreams of invincibility
fields.trailText: How things have changed since the last round of European competition. With Chelsea brushed aside, Leeds as good as out, Arsenal hardly secure and the European champions themselves rudely dethroned on their home patch, the smug assumption of English club superiority which had wafted through the more Anglo-centric sections of the media this past month has proved sadly hollow. The clean sweep is now in real danger of transmogrifying into a whitewash.
fields.body:
How things have changed since the last round of European competition. With Chelsea brushed aside, Leeds as good as out, Arsenal hardly secure and the European champions themselves rudely dethroned on their home patch, the smug assumption of English club superiority which had wafted through the more Anglo-centric sections of the media this past month has proved sadly hollow. The clean sweep is now in real danger of transmogrifying into a whitewash.

Still, there was one Englishman who will be wallowing in the new European order. There, insouciantly chewing at the cud as the Champions League anthem blasted into the stadium, was Steve McManaman, Scouse demon of the Old Trafford crowd.

The former Spice Boy turned grown-up athlete had run the game in Madrid, shoe-horning himself back into England's Euro 2000 reckoning. But there was little respect for that performance as he trotted to his post on the right wing, the welcome reserved for all things Liverpudlian in these parts ringing in his ears. From the first whistle residents on the other side of Manchester could tell whenever McManaman was on the ball, such was the intensity of the whistles cutting the night air.

Cat-calling, however, is rarely as effective a deterrent as sound defence. And how Macca - despite his silly assault on Roy Keane to concede a late penalty - revelled in his revenge. He had, apparently, secreted several old Liverpool colleagues around the stadium, suggesting they disguise themselves on the way in. They must have looked on in envy at the kind of space and time they were never granted in this stadium.

The warning signs were there early for United, when Roberto Carlos drifted past Gary Neville, to square for Fernando Morientes whose clever shot was saved by Raimond van der Gouw. Then the roof caved in. With McMan- aman a spectator after being floored by a waspish tackle from Paul Scholes, a bland cross from the right was turned by Keane into his own net. From that moment the gradient United had to climb steepened to Pyrenean proportions.

But this United team are nothing if not used to falling behind in European games. They knew the script: the crosses started to pepper in, Dwight Yorke was reaching them, David Beckham strode past the defence only to hit the keeper and Keane galloped on to a through-ball to draw a save of such ability from the 18-year-old Iker Casillas you wonder how anyone will score past him when he develops.

Sir Alex Ferguson thought Casillas was the difference: "Their goalkeeper was absolutely marvellous," said the United manager. "He did things that are just not normal for an 18-year-old."

The trademark United huff and puff was not blowing the house down as it does in the Premiership. Here was the irony of the United season: they have cruised the domestic league, only occasionally needing to rise to the heights; now they were playing at their peak and losing.

For once they were confronted by a side which knew how to score goals. Two supreme interventions by Raul turned the improbable into the impossible. He was ably assisted in his work by McManaman, whose grin at the finish as he accepted his colleagues' praise could have spanned the Mersey. And, though United's pride refused to allow them to surrender, by the end, despite Beckham's goal, despite Scholes's penalty, it was little more than pride they were playing for.

Meanwhile, as the removal men prepared to take the continent's premier trophy out of England, high in the Scoreboard End the tiny knot of fans from Madrid indicated the real direction things are going in Europe: with a cheery indifference to its terminal naffness, they chanted long into the night the old dirge Viva Espana.

fields.headline: United want £17m Campbell
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur declared last night they will do "everything in our power" to see off Manchester United's designs on their England centre-back Sol Campbell, whose contract expires at the end of next season.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur declared last night they will do "everything in our power" to see off Manchester United's designs on their England centre-back Sol Campbell, whose contract expires at the end of next season.

Spurs' director of football David Pleat, confirming that the champions have inquired about the £17m-rated Campbell, said: "Sol always previously discussed and signed extensions in the summer months and it is not going to be any different this summer."

fields.headline: Chelsea back on the carpet
fields.trailText: A miserable 24 hours for Chelsea was completed last night when they were charged by the Football Association with failing to control their players against Sheffield Wednesday last Saturday.
fields.body:
A miserable 24 hours for Chelsea was completed last night when they were charged by the Football Association with failing to control their players against Sheffield Wednesday last Saturday.

Several Chelsea players surrounded the referee Paul Durkin after their 1-0 defeat at Hillsborough to complain about his performance.

The FA's response comes less than a week after a £50,000 fine for Chelsea's part in a tunnel brawl with Wimbledon. As repeat offenders they could have league points deducted if found guilty, although a hefty fine would be more likely.

Middlesbrough have been similarly charged for their players' reaction to Manchester United's fourth goal at the Riverside on April 10. Boro were convinced Quinton Fortune was offside, although replays showed otherwise.

Ironically the clampdown on mass dissent towards officials was sparked by United's reaction to a penalty awarded to Boro in January. No action was taken against United.

Derby have completed the signing of Georgi Kinkladze from Ajax on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee, believed to be around £3m.

Third Division Hull City have sacked their manager Warren Joyce and his assistant John McGovern. The youth team coach Billy Russell takes temporary charge.

English hooligans convicted in Belgium and Holland during Euro 2000 can expect to be banned from travelling to international matches for up to 10 years, the home secretary Jack Straw has announced.

fields.headline: Hampshire carry Warne to victory
fields.standfirst:
Essex 201-9
Hampshire 202-5
Hampshire won by five wickets
fields.trailText: He was struck out of the ground and almost into the busy London Road. He was reverse-swept for four by a young, uncapped batsman. He failed to take a wicket and conceded 44 runs in his 10 overs.
fields.body:
He was struck out of the ground and almost into the busy London Road. He was reverse-swept for four by a young, uncapped batsman. He failed to take a wicket and conceded 44 runs in his 10 overs.

Essex showed a healthy disrespect when Shane Warne embarked upon his county career for Hampshire here yesterday, the most keenly awaited debut since Brian Lara first played for Warwickshire in 1994.

At this rate Shaun Udal will be negotiating a new contract. The Hampshire off-spinner will earn less than a third of the £150,000 the county will pay Warne this season. Yesterday, though, he was much the better bowler with two for 27.

Essex have had a few Aussies themselves, of course. Allan Border, Mark Waugh and more recently Stuart Law have worn the colours, so they were never likely to be awestruck.

Warne, who had flown in the previous day, did not appear distressed. Hampshire hired him for his contribution off the field as much as on it, and he is likely to enhance an already happy dressing room.

When Warne first played test cricket in 1991, and took one for 150 against India at Sydney, his fellow wrist-spinner Kerry O'Keeffe observed: "Overweight, slightly roundarm, no variation, can't bowl."

Much has happened since, of course, but anyone unaware of what Warne has achieved, and who turned up here yesterday, would have wanted to pump O'Keeffe's hand and compliment him on his perspicacity.

He is not quite the bowler he was when fingers, wrist and shoulder did all the work. These days he uses the whole body and a cunning brain but it should be enough to create havoc throughout the county circuit once his digits have warmed up.

The Essex batsmen, perhaps sensing that he might be more of a handful in midsummer, played him positively from the moment he came on to bowl the eighth over at 45 for two.

In only his second over he was hoiked over square-leg by Paul Prichard. Then he bowled a full toss that Ronnie Irani pulled out of the ground on his way to a creditable 50. When Stephen Peters reverse-swept that four to third man Warne, who had watched wickets tumble at the other end, might have thought this county stuff was not the pushover it had appeared.

He has called English cricket "soft" and in his autobiography three years ago he said: "There should be fewer county teams so there are more good players per team." As he works for one of the smaller clubs this now sounds like biting off the Hampshire hand that feeds him.

Warne came out of the attack after his first eight overs had cost 31. When he returned his final two went for 13.

But at least he ended on the winning side as Hampshire reached their target with five wickets and 15 balls to spare after Robin Smith (56) and Adrian Aymes (63) had added 120 for the third wicket. Dimitri Mascarenhas, with 21 in nine balls, finished it off when Hampshire briefly wobbled.

As he works for one of the smaller clubs this now sounds like biting off the Hampshire hand that feeds him. Warne came out of the attack after his first eight overs had cost 31. When he returned his final two went for 13. But at least he ended on the winning side as Hampshire reached their target with five wickets and 15 balls to spare after Robin Smith (56) and Adrian Aymes (63) had added 120 for the third wicket. Dimitri Mascarenhas, with 21 in nine balls, finished it off when Hampshire briefly wobbled.

fields.headline: Byas rides luck over misfortune
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 191-5
Yorkshire 192-5
Yorkshire won by five wickets
fields.trailText: After the Chris Lewis strike came the Leicestershire go-slow. While Lewis concentrated upon his deepening rift with the game's authorities over the match-fixing crisis, Leicestershire suffered for his absence, falling to a five-wicket defeat against Yorkshire that damaged their prospects of qualifying for the quarter-finals.
fields.body:
After the Chris Lewis strike came the Leicestershire go-slow. While Lewis concentrated upon his deepening rift with the game's authorities over the match-fixing crisis, Leicestershire suffered for his absence, falling to a five-wicket defeat against Yorkshire that damaged their prospects of qualifying for the quarter-finals.

Leicestershire struggled to gain momentum on a used pitch, collapsing to 69 for five in 28 overs before Aftab Habib and Billy Stelling, a South African qualifying for the county by his Dutch passport, remedied matters in easing conditions with an unbroken stand of 122. Stelling's half-century on debut was not pretty but it was not that sort of day.

Jack Birkenshaw, Leicestershire's coach, reserved judgment on Lewis' absence. "It is best for Chris and for the team that he doesn't play at the moment," he said.

Lewis' decision prompted Leicestershire's committeemen at the ground to hold an emergency meeting. But the man himself was mildly apologetic. "It is not a dispute with Leicestershire, it is a dispute with the cricket authorities. I have no choice but to make a stand by going on strike."

Leicestershire's ill luck did not stop there. Lacking their captain Vince Wells through injury, they also lost Phil DeFreitas, who bowled only three overs before leaving the field because of a sickness bug.

That released the pressure on Yorkshire's batsmen. David Byas, dropped at square-leg off Jimmy Ormond when only three, rarely erred again, his 71 from 116 balls ending when Jonathan Dakin bowled him round his legs.

Dakin also ran out Richard Blakey as he attempted a third run to deep backward square but Darren Lehmann stuck around long enough to take Yorkshire to the top of the North division on run-rate.

 Somerset are still winless for the season after their B&H Cup match against Glamorgan at Taunton was washed out. The umpires made four pitch inspections but hopes of a reduced 10-over slogfest were dashed by persistent drizzle.

 Inzamam-ul-Haq's valiant 67 was the highlight for Pakistan as they were held by West Indies to 197 for eight in the first one-day final at Barbados.

webTitle: Time for another tour to be stopped, Peter

fields.headline: Time for another tour to be stopped, Peter
fields.trailText: The news from Zimbabwe gets worse by the day and it wretchedly sharpens the ironies already attending the imminent tour to England by Zimbabwe's cricketers. The 18-man party had been due to touch down at Heathrow yesterday for a week's preparation before starting their opening match against Hampshire at Southampton a week from today. Suddenly they are not expected to arrive until next Tuesday.
fields.body:
The news from Zimbabwe gets worse by the day and it wretchedly sharpens the ironies already attending the imminent tour to England by Zimbabwe's cricketers. The 18-man party had been due to touch down at Heathrow yesterday for a week's preparation before starting their opening match against Hampshire at Southampton a week from today. Suddenly they are not expected to arrive until next Tuesday.

They should not even get on the plane. Lord's should call the whole thing off this morning and be done with it. Otherwise, even before midsummer, it could all turn into a nasty, embarrassing, diplomatic disaster.

British army and Foreign Office scouts are surreptitiously in situ around Zimbabwe's borders preparing the way for a host of UK citizens to flee President Robert Mugabe's deeply troubled, near-anarchic acres. Jack Straw's Home Office, at a stroke, pledges immediate and hassle-free hello-and-welcomes for anyone from Zimbabwe even with Welsh rugby's minimum requirement of one ancient British grandparent.

As anti-British frenzy continues to be whipped up, and whether the desperate despot president wins, loses, rigs or contrives (by announcing a state of emergency) to abandon the elections which are now scheduled for next month, the fact remains that his supporters, with blood on their hands already, are likely to be thirsty for more - at the very time MCC is rolling out the red carpet in front of the St John's Wood wicket-gate and inviting the Queen to shake hands with Pres Mugabe's 18 cricketing representatives in the opening test at Lord's in just 28 days' time.

Picture the rum scene: anti-British hostilities worsening, more farmers murdered and their families and neighbours fleeing in terror to every border sanctuary, Britain demanding sanctions and reparation, and Zimbabwe's flag fluttering unconcernedly in England's gentle springtime breezes on the neighbouring Lord's pavilion turret to that of the union flag. Irony, eh?

And there are many more jam-packed into this particularly top-heavy diplomatic bag. How, for instance, will Pres Mugabe's 18 players feel as the summer - and the hostility in both countries - worsens? Of the party, four are black and 14 white. How "split" will be their allegiance if any seriously provocative die is cast either way? And what about their own families left at home? Worries about Darren Gough's away-swinger will not count for much against front-page headlines of post-election chaos and lynch-law.

A specially piquant irony is that Zimbabwe was not so long ago Southern Rhodesia and British colonialism's last (always blighted) phoney dream of multiracialism. Even diehard reactionary Tories eventually agreed not to play with despotic, race-based South Africa. How say they now about playing with despotic race-based Zimbabwe?

Irony on irony, and just about the best irony of all, is that the spruce, frank and engaging figure at the helm in Whitehall, our Man from the FO itself, is none other than Peter Hain, who was, almost unbelievably, the 20-year-old anti-apartheid campaign leader who forced the abandonment of the South African cricket tour to England of 1970.

On May 14, 30 years ago, Ali Bacher's team had already assembled in Johannesburg, ready to fly. In Westminster the Home Secretary Jim Callaghan ordered Lord's to "uninvite" it. Lord's refused and cringingly hung on to their "rights" for four days before, with bad grace and to Hain's hoorays, they cravenly capitulated on May 18 - the very date that Pres Mugabe's flag is due to be run up at Lord's.

Stop the tour one more time, Pete.

fields.headline: Angry Lewis goes on strike
fields.standfirst: All-rounder says he is being made a fall guy in match-fixing scandal
fields.trailText: Chris Lewis has gone on strike in protest at what he perceives as the England and Wales Cricket Board's willingness to allow him to become a fall guy in the match-fixing scandal.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis has gone on strike in protest at what he perceives as the England and Wales Cricket Board's willingness to allow him to become a fall guy in the match-fixing scandal.

Lewis, who pulled out of Leicestershire's Benson & Hedges Cup tie against Yorkshire at Headingley yesterday, was summoned before an ECB inquiry in London on Tuesday, when he provided the names of three England players whom it had been alleged to him had taken match-rigging bribes.

But yesterday the former England all-rounder, dismayed by the implication that he had been hauled before a disciplinary hearing, declared he would not play again until the board confirmed that he volunteered the names of the players eight months ago but it refused to accept them.

"My livelihood is at stake and my life is being made a misery," Lewis said. "I will not let the ECB allow my reputation to be destroyed. I have done nothing wrong but it feels as if I am sinking. I am not playing again until the ECB give me the support I deserve."

The three "famous" England players were allegedly implicated by Ashim Kheterpal, an Indian sports promoter, during what Lewis has described as failed attempts to persuade him to become an intermediary in a £1m sting during last summer's test series between England and New Zealand.

Lewis has since received legal threats from Kheterpal and claims that the board, on being informed, beat a hasty retreat. "The board severed contact late last year when Kheterpal threatened to sue me. They rang to tell me they could not offer any assistance. They are hanging me out to dry."

Lewis cut an aggrieved and abandoned figure as he contemplated his future in Headingley's deserted rugby league stand. Rather than being commended for immediately passing details of the match-rigging approach to the authorities, he has been widely disparaged.

The ECB panel - Simon Pack, the international teams director and the man who interviewed Lewis last summer, and Gerard Elias QC, chairman of the disciplinary committee, spent half-an-hour questioning him on Tuesday and much longer labouring over a statement. It then said that Lewis had "indicated his desire to co-operate fully with the board" and that he had provided "all information in his possession".

That has not prevented Lewis being portrayed in the media as an eccentric purveyor of second-hand tittle-tattle, besmirching England's untainted reputation. Lewis believes the next England player to be approached by bookmakers might choose to keep his own counsel.

"I went to the board last August because I was offered money to fix a game. I didn't want any part of it and the board had instructed that, if you were ever approached, you should immediately report it.

"The impression has been given that I am shopping England team-mates. I have no idea whether England players have ever been involved in match-fixing and I have never accused them. All I did was report a conversation with a guy who wanted me to fix a match.

"The board were informed that three England players' names were mentioned in regard to match-fixing and receiving money. The board's representative [Pack] told me that he wasn't interested in the names because it was hearsay. I then immediately reported those names to the police.

"I told the board and the police last August this was a delicate situation and that it must not become public knowledge but it leaked out so quickly that, a few days later, I was being hounded by reporters from the News of the World."

Lewis claims that he received no payment for the first News of the World piece but admitted that he was paid a five-figure fee last Sunday.

"Thanks to Hansie Cronje, match-rigging was on the agenda again. All I did was repeat stuff that has been common knowledge for months. The system is trying to save itself but, if they don't investigate match-rigging allegations fully, then the whole thing will come crashing down."

The ECB remained painfully aware last night of the legal implications surrounding the on-going criminal investigation. Tim Lamb, the chief executive, said: "At the appropriate time we will make a full statement about the whole issue."

fields.headline: Crack on
fields.standfirst: Can't take any more chocolate? Have a (fairly) educational Easter with our guide to the joys of spring on the web
fields.trailText: Get cracking...
fields.body:
Get cracking...

The chocolate comes later. The British Egg information service can tell you what's in a hen's egg. There's also a competition to design an egg icon and win £200.

Find out what happens to the eggs that do hatch at the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry. Watch a chick hatch in QuickTime video and see how the egg develops.

Birds are not the only creatures to hatch from eggs. Erik's homepages chronicle the long incubation and joyful birth of Heidi and Sebastian's offspring. Heidi and Sebastian are pythons.

The joys of spring...

Visit an entire flock of sheep and their newborn lambs at Jacob's Sheep Farm near Seattle.

The British Nutrition Foundation reveals what makes lamb so tender.

Find out why bunnies and Easter don't mix and research the rabbit.

Shocking quantities of chocolate...

Does chocolate make you euphoric? Consult the Cadbury's Chocolate Encyclopaedia for the history of cocoa confectionery.

The British Nutrition Foundation takes a more sober view of its nutritional content. Chemistry students can find a chocolate chip cookie recipe which will be unintelligible to everyone else.

Mathematically challenged...

The mathematics of the oval is explained in the Famous Curves List.

Watch the Pope live...

The Vatican has a live transmission over the Easter period.

The Jewish festival of Passover began on Wednesday evening.

The Orthodox Easter doesn't begin until next weekend. Find out why at the Enyclopaedia Britannica.

webTitle: Police braced for violence at 'hard core' protests

fields.headline: Police braced for violence at 'hard core' protests
fields.standfirst: Fears that anti-capitalist rioters will disrupt May Day bank holiday in London  Easter roads chaos forecast to start today
fields.trailText: Up to 500 "hard core" protesters are planning to disrupt the May Day bank holiday by rioting in London during a series of anti-capitalist demonstrations and marches, police sources revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Up to 500 "hard core" protesters are planning to disrupt the May Day bank holiday by rioting in London during a series of anti-capitalist demonstrations and marches, police sources revealed yesterday.

Three forces - the Metropolitan police, City police and British Transport police - have cancelled leave for uniformed officers because of the threat, which was identified after undercover work by Scotland Yard's special branch.

While thousands of officers will be available if trouble starts, the police fear high visibility policing on the streets could be seen as provocative.

The plan is to keep many officers in reserve and deploy them in rapid reaction units as and when violence flares.

Police "spotters" will mingle with the crowds and radio for back-up if there is a repeat of the mayhem which erupted during similar protests on June 18 and November 30 last year.

The Guardian has learned that the police increased the number of closed circuit television cameras in the City following those disturbances and there is now blanket coverage in vulnerable areas.

Millennium eve apart, sources said, the police operation to deal with the demonstrations was "the biggest in 30 years".

Police anxiety about the protests was heightened by recent riots in Washington and Seattle, and the breakdown in communication between senior police officers and some of the protest groups which are known to be involved in organising events.

There was a degree of cooperation between the police and a planning committee made up of members of Reclaim the Streets, the Socialist Workers party, and the Anarchists Federation, but the group disintegrated because of political in-fighting.

"We have tried to work with groups to organise the protests, but they will not cooperate with us," said one senior officer. "We haven't heard anything from them, but we will keep trying.

"Special branch has provided us with intelligence about some of the events that have been planned, and we have been monitoring internet traffic.

One of the biggest events is expected to be the Guerrilla Gardening Action demonstration on May 1 in Parliament Square.

It is being organised by several groups, including Reclaim the Streets, and protesters are being encouraged to bring gardening equipment to plant seeds.

Last year a police officer was seriously injured when he was hit from behind by a demonstrator wielding a spade.

The officer is still off work suffering from spinal injuries.

Other events, including an anarchists' seven-a-side football tournament on April 29, will be monitored "with interest".

fields.headline: What a joke
fields.standfirst: Funny business, love and marriage, writing on the wall and the great poo debate
fields.trailText: Funny business, love and marriage, writing on the wall and the great poo debate
fields.body:
Not amused
The citizens of Sunderland were not laughing this week after a nationwide survey found them to be the most unfunny people in Britain (and that includes such notorious humour backspots as Godalming, Telford and Cheadle Hulme).

The survey took the form of a competition held in 77 branches of Yates Wine Lodge to find the nation's wittiest pub joker. "They were judged on how many jokes they told, how original the jokes were and the audience reaction," said a spokesman.

The wittiest was Carlisle, with a 20-point rating, closely followed by Newcastle and Hartlepool on 18 each. But Sunderland came last with a resounding nul points. "They just weren't funny," said the spokesman. "It was painful to witness - like watching an animal having its head slowly crushed in a vice."

People from Sunderland have reacted angrily to the result, insisting the competition paints an unfair picture of their town. "We're the funniest crowd in the world," insisted local comedian Mark Rough. "We have this great ability to laugh at ourselves."

"Well, they have to, don't they," said one visitor. "No one else does."
The Northern Echo

Mr and Mrs
Congratulations to Reg and Win Attwater, of Smallfield, in Sussex, who this week secured a place in the Guinness Book of Records as Britain's longest married couple.

Mr and Mrs Attwater, 99 and 94 respectively, tied the knot in 1925, having met at their local church, where Reg was in the choir and Win a member of the congregation.

In the 75 years since, they have never been separated, and now have four children, 12 grandchildren, 10 great-grandchildren, and one great-great-grandchild. "It's getting hard to keep track of them all," admitted Win.

Their marriage has lasted, says Reg, because they've never had a television and have kept healthy. The couple, who have lived in the same house for 50 years, have received a certificate to mark their entry in the Guinness Book of World Records.

"I'm genuinely pleased for them," said one neighbour. "Although it does make it harder to bear that my wife of 30 years has just run off with a Cypriot hairdresser." Sussex and Surrey Online

Off the wall
Exciting events near Slough, if that's not a contradiction in terms, where workmen installing a wheelchair-access ramp and toilet in a local church stumbled upon the remains of an exquisite 13th century wall-painting.

The badly-faded frescoe depicting St. Christoper with the infant Jesus, was found at the 12th century St Mary's church in Langley. English Heritage conservationists have begun slowly scraping away whitewash applied during the Reformation in order to reveal more of the image.

"Paintings like these were very common at the time," said Jeremy Hurst, rector of St Mary's. "Unfortunately time hasn't left a great deal of the original, but you can still make out the saint's face and staff."

Plans are now afoot to install a replica of the painting beside the original to give people some idea of what it would have looked like in its heyday.

"I thought a frescoe was something to do with sex outdoors," said one member of the congregation, "So I was most surprised to hear they wanted to have a picture of it hanging in the church."
Slough and Langley Observer

Talking crap
Dog-owners in Fife who allow their pets to foul the pavements could soon find themselves well and truly in the proverbial if their local council gets its way. Fife council has introduced a £40 fine for fouling, and is now pushing for powers to levy on-the-spot fines on those who allow their dogs to soil public places.

"The dog-mess situation is getting out of hand," said one councillor. "Last week I trod in four of them. It's particularly upsetting because I have congested sinuses, and don't always smell it on my shoes, which means I often go into meetings or out for dinner without wiping it off."

The council also wants to introduce a tagging system for persistent offenders (dogs, that is, not owners), and is lobbying MSPs to hold a parliamentary debate on the subject. "All they ever do is talk shit," said one dog-owner. "So it should be just the sort of thing they enjoy discussing."
Glenrothes Gazette

Letter of the week
"It has become apparent that only one thing matters to Mr Blair and that is a second term in office. I am also very much afraid that such a nakedly ambitious man has a vision of himself as the first president of Europe.

To this end he will manipulate any referendum on scrapping the pound. It would be preceded by weeks of scaremongering by the media, so much of which is conveniently dominated by those who owe him something.

This issue, of great concern to many people, could perhaps be remedied by writing to Tony - a postcard would do - threatening not to vote Labour next time.

In Torbay it might be useful to add "nor Liberal Democrat". Not only are they the most Euro-fanatic, they have for some reason allied themselves with Labour, who have a huge majority and no need of them."
Anita Moss, Torquay Herald Express
