webTitle: Ginola strike gives Spurs late tonic

fields.headline: Ginola strike gives Spurs late tonic
fields.trailText: Doctors advised George Graham to stay away from this game and until the last two minutes it looked exactly the right decision because this was exceedingly poor entertainment to place before a patient in convalescence.
fields.body:
Doctors advised George Graham to stay away from this game and until the last two minutes it looked exactly the right decision because this was exceedingly poor entertainment to place before a patient in convalescence.

Then David Ginola picked his way past a couple of tackles to shoot home and his manager had the best pick-me-up of all.

It was Tottenham's first win in six outings, though even Graham would have been hard pressed to make a case that they deserved it. Leicester had the bulk of possession and did most of the forcing but, in the absence of Stan Collymore and Darren Eadie, their attack is reliant on a central defender and ageing legs and it showed.

Spurs were hardly more sprightly themselves and, until Ginola struck, had failed to register a shot on target. Their young substitute Matthew Etherington had just sent a good chance wide of the post but, when he next delivered the ball into the goalmouth, the home team were caught napping and Ginola can generally be relied on for accuracy in and around the box. It was his sixth goal of the season.

"That's just what we needed and this will be a nice tonic for George," said Stewart Houston, Graham's deputy. "Obviously we were hurt on Saturday [Aston Villa coming back from two goals down to score four times in 12 minutes] but I felt they all warranted another opportunity tonight."

Graham's recovery from inflammation of the joints which necessitated a stay in hospital is unlikely to see him return in time for the home game with Wimbledon this weekend. This morning's telephone call from Houston can only confirm that there is scope for much improvement and Graham knows he has a busy summer ahead as he attempts to bring in the new faces his team needs.

Last night they could easily have gone down to a fourth successive reverse and were lucky that, for all Matt Elliott's improvisational powers and Tony Cottee's willingness, Leicester do not pose any health warning for defenders and Sol Campbell and Chris Perry were able to see them off without much discomfort.

After Ginola's goal both Robbie Savage and Muzzy Izzet came close from long range, which only served to underline that this was one of Filbert Street's more disappointing nights. "We were by far the better team and didn't deserve to lose," said the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill. "We were driving on and in that situation there's always a danger you could concede a goal."

Some of the problems which have dogged Spurs in recent weeks surfaced early on as Leicester found it easy to by-pass the midfield challengers, though all too often things fizzled out in the penalty area. When Savage made a forceful challenge to dispossess Ginola it raised the biggest cheer of the game. That said everything about how bankrupt the occasion had been in terms of dramatic activity to that point.

webTitle: Zimbabwe government 'deploying army' to help farm invaders

fields.headline: Zimbabwe government 'deploying army' to help farm invaders
fields.standfirst: Government deploys army to direct farm invasions - Zimbabwe Independent
fields.trailText: The government of Zimbabwe has deployed its own army officers to direct farm invasions by   war veterans and Zanu-PF supporters, a leading Zimbabwean newspaper claims today. The news comes as squatters' leaders announced a 'cessation of hostilities' - although attacks on white farmers have continued unabated.
fields.body:
The government of Zimbabwe has deployed its own army officers to direct farm invasions by war veterans and Zanu-PF supporters, a leading Zimbabwean newspaper claims today. The news comes as squatters' leaders announced a 'cessation of hostilities' - although attacks on white farmers have continued unabated.

According to a report in the Zimbabwe Independent, commanders have been appointed by the government to coordinate logistics such as providing food and supplies. It is thought they may also have provided the AK-47 assault rifles and other automatic weapons used by squatters, and government trucks to transport food.

Leaders in the region will hold a summit this weekend to discuss the deepening crisis - and the continuing war in the Congo. Presidents Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, Sam Nujoma of Namibia and Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique will meet Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, at the Victoria Falls resort.

Zimbabwe's main opposition leader has condemned the political killings in his country but said they would not intimidate his party into boycotting upcoming elections. "We are not retreating," said Morgan Tsvangirai, head of the Movement for Democratic Change.

Calling Mugabe "a deranged dictator," Tsvangirai said his recent trip abroad was meant to garner support for his movement and to look ahead to a Zimbabwe after Mugabe.

"We have to look postively beyond Mugabe. Mugabe is history," he said, shortly after arriving home from a week-long trip to Britain, South Africa and the United States.

Meanwhile, President Robert Mugabe today rejected offers of international help to tackle land reform in his country.

"We can reach our own settlement, I don't think we need help from the United Nations - this is not a United Nations issue yet," Mr Mugabe told BBC radio in a recorded interview as Zimbabwe grappled with its worst economic and political crisis since independence in 1980.

Asked if he might accept input from Britain - the former colonial power in Zimbabwe - or from the European Union to try to resolve the issue, he said: "The people in Europe don't understand how deeply this land issue touches our hearts."

Thousands of black veterans of the former Rhodesia's 1970s liberation war have occupied hundreds of white-owned farms over the past two months. Two white farmers and a police officer have been killed in clashes linked to the occupations.

Mr Mugabe said that he would not force an immediate withdrawal.

"These are war veterans who fought for the country, and the army also has war veterans in it," he said. "Would you want me to set war veterans in the army against war veterans outside the army? Do you think that would work?

"This may be a long way to a solution, but it is a much smoother way, I can assure you."

After a meeting with white farmers and leaders of the black land invaders on Wednesday, Mr Mugabe said the two sides had agreed there would be no more violence and it was therefore not necessary to send more police to the occupied farms.

The president, who has ruled Zimbabwe for 20 years, has endorsed the invasions and refused to condemn violence against white farmers, whom he accuses of colonial and racist attitudes. Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party faces parliamentary elections within the next four months and, for the first time since independence, faces the possibility of defeat.

Mr Mugabe, whose presidential term runs until 2002, has accused white farmers of bankrolling the opposition, undermining his revolution and clinging to land stolen from the people by British colonial authorities.

webTitle: The Clematis Tree by Ann Widdecombe

fields.headline: The Clematis Tree by Ann Widdecombe
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to Ann Widdecombe's debut novel The Clematis Tree
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The cynic in me expected Ann Widdecombe's debut novel, The Clematis Tree (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £9.99), to be universally panned. Fiction may be politicians' stock-in-trade, but when they set themselves up as writers they usually get short shrift. In fact, Miss Widdecombe's book avoided a critical drubbing of, say, Archer proportions, and while some critics wanted only to read the politician behind the book, others were ready to take the novel seriously.
fields.body:
The cynic in me expected Ann Widdecombe's debut novel, The Clematis Tree (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £9.99), to be universally panned. Fiction may be politicians' stock-in-trade, but when they set themselves up as writers they usually get short shrift. In fact, Miss Widdecombe's book avoided a critical drubbing of, say, Archer proportions, and while some critics wanted only to read the politician behind the book, others were ready to take the novel seriously.

The most pointedly (and personal) knocking review came from Miss Widdecombe's former Conservative colleague, Edwina Currie, whose own sex-and-shopping novels get routinely pasted in the books pages. "This is a very odd book - the product of a perceptive but warped mind," said Ms Currie, in a review in the Mail on Sunday headlined "It's life Ann - but not as we know it". "The style is almost dottily old-fashioned [and] the tweeness becomes wearisome." The absence of sex in the book seemed greatly to exercise Ms Currie. "Reading her novel, one longs for a Joanna Trollope or a Fay Weldon to take over," she concluded. "The Clematis Tree is not all bad, but it will irk readers at odds with the author's moral viewpoint and those who prefer characters made of flesh and blood." Particularly, in Ms Currie's case, flesh.

Boyd Tonkin, in the Independent, also found the tale of a young child who suffers brain damage in a road accident heavy going. "Miss Widdecombe writes a stodgy meat-and-potatoes prose, and confines her gaze to a narrow segment of the middle classes," he wrote. "She doesn't do sex, she goes in for fortitude, and she heartily approves of nuns. Hot news, eh?" He also wanted to make a short party political broadcast: "Passive and powerless himself, Jeremy [the brain-damaged boy] enables others to do good... This teaching chimes perfectly with the theme and tone of this compassionate novel. It can be beautiful 'to live for others passively', as a trigger for their altruism, comments one of Mark's not-quite-girlfriends. It hardly needs to be said that all this flatly contradicts the spiteful claptrap against asylum seekers we often hear from the woman who holds the post of Shadow Home Secretary."

Catherine Bennett, in the Guardian, also saw an opportunity to make political capital: "It is beyond Widdecombe's skill to animate her argument on the sanctity of life, but the many episodes of marital claustrophobia are written with enough energy and inventiveness to leave quite a different moral: that family life is a painful mess better viewed from the sidelines - perhaps as a spinster, like Aunt Isobel, 'a sharp-witted, worldly-wise woman who knew those around her better than they knew themselves'. Useful to know that, next time Aunt Ann gets started on family values."

Ruth Rendell, in the Sunday Times, gave the book a neat back-handed compliment: "This novel is full of dull things yet, paradoxically, it is not dull. You want to go on reading, you want to know what happens, it isn't easy to put down. And this, perhaps, is because of the moving portrait she creates of the disabled boy, and a skill she may not know she has in depicting his parents' pain. The image of lifeless Jeremy laid on the floor in front of a flickering screen, clean and fresh, dressed in new clothes, a mobile swinging above his upturned face, will not be easy to forget." Rendell's conclusion was a delight: "Widdecombe once memorably said of a certain Home Secretary that he had 'something of the night about him'. She has something of a Sunday afternoon about her, but her book is readable and, not surprisingly, she is good on the political bits."

David Sexton, in the London Evening Standard, found The Clematis Tree "an extremely strange book. It is sincere and serious. On the other hand, it is completely devoid of plausible contemporary reference ... [It] is one long course in misery, perked up only by a little crucifix waving. Joanna Trollope has been giving her fans an unprecedentedly hard time lately, with her tales of depressed farmers, crushed stepchildren and defeated adulterers. But compared to Ann, Joanna's a ray of sunshine."

Bel Mooney, in the Times, summed up the critics' contradictory responses: "On one level Widdecombe has written a clunky addition to that tradition of didactic fiction which runs back to the moral tales of the 18th and 19th centuries. On another, she has crafted a compelling story about the way a family copes with a catastrophe which is as odd and complex as its creator. "Widdecombe is no stylist, and frequently lets herself down by writing as if this were a publication of the Tractarian Society. Yet the handling of character augurs well [and] the isolation of the parents within an apparently loving family is acutely observed. The novel is far more bleakly realistic than at first it seems, and I applaud Ann Widdecombe for setting aside her own certainties to show that people may do right unwillingly, and that the fallibility and resentment of her hero are a part of the human condition."

"Can't write but can tell a story" might be a half-hearted summing up, but it could have been a lot worse. It has been suggested that Miss Widdecombe might eventually forgo politics for writing; Edwina Currie had better watch out.

Fiction may be politicians' stock-in-trade, but when they set themselves up as writers they usually get short shrift. In fact, Miss Widdecombe's book avoided a critical drubbing of, say, Archer proportions, and while some critics wanted only to read the politician behind the book, others were ready to take the novel seriously. The most pointedly (and personal) knocking review came from Miss Widdecombe's former Conservative colleague, Edwina Currie, whose own sex-and-shopping novels get routinely pasted in the books pages. "This is a very odd book - the product of a perceptive but warped mind," said Ms Currie, in a review in the Mail on Sunday headlined "It's life Ann - but not as we know it". "The style is almost dottily old-fashioned [and] the tweeness becomes wearisome." The absence of sex in the book seemed greatly to exercise Ms Currie. "Reading her novel, one longs for a Joanna Trollope or a Fay Weldon to take over," she concluded. "The Clematis Tree is not all bad, but it will irk readers at odds with the author's moral viewpoint and those who prefer characters made of flesh and blood." Particularly, in Ms Currie's case, flesh. Boyd Tonkin, in the Independent, also found the tale of a young child who suffers brain damage in a road accident heavy going. "Miss Widdecombe writes a stodgy meat-and-potatoes prose, and confines her gaze to a narrow segment of the middle classes," he wrote. "She doesn't do sex, she goes in for fortitude, and she heartily approves of nuns. Hot news, eh?" He also wanted to make a short party political broadcast: "Passive and powerless himself, Jeremy [the brain-damaged boy] enables others to do good... This teaching chimes perfectly with the theme and tone of this compassionate novel. It can be beautiful 'to live for others passively', as a trigger for their altruism, comments one of Mark's not-quite-girlfriends. It hardly needs to be said that all this flatly contradicts the spiteful claptrap against asylum seekers we often hear from the woman who holds the post of Shadow Home Secretary." Catherine Bennett, in the Guardian, also saw an opportunity to make political capital: "It is beyond Widdecombe's skill to animate her argument on the sanctity of life, but the many episodes of marital claustrophobia are written with enough energy and inventiveness to leave quite a different moral: that family life is a painful mess better viewed from the sidelines - perhaps as a spinster, like Aunt Isobel, 'a sharp-witted, worldly-wise woman who knew those around her better than they knew themselves'. Useful to know that, next time Aunt Ann gets started on family values." Ruth Rendell, in the Sunday Times, gave the book a neat back-handed compliment: "This novel is full of dull things yet, paradoxically, it is not dull. You want to go on reading, you want to know what happens, it isn't easy to put down. And this, perhaps, is because of the moving portrait she creates of the disabled boy, and a skill she may not know she has in depicting his parents' pain. The image of lifeless Jeremy laid on the floor in front of a flickering screen, clean and fresh, dressed in new clothes, a mobile swinging above his upturned face, will not be easy to forget." Rendell's conclusion was a delight: "Widdecombe once memorably said of a certain Home Secretary that he had 'something of the night about him'. She has something of a Sunday afternoon about her, but her book is readable and, not surprisingly, she is good on the political bits." David Sexton, in the London Evening Standard, found The Clematis Tree "an extremely strange book. It is sincere and serious. On the other hand, it is completely devoid of plausible contemporary reference ... [It] is one long course in misery, perked up only by a little crucifix waving. Joanna Trollope has been giving her fans an unprecedentedly hard time lately, with her tales of depressed farmers, crushed stepchildren and defeated adulterers. But compared to Ann, Joanna's a ray of sunshine." Bel Mooney, in the Times, summed up the critics' contradictory responses: "On one level Widdecombe has written a clunky addition to that tradition of didactic fiction which runs back to the moral tales of the 18th and 19th centuries. On another, she has crafted a compelling story about the way a family copes with a catastrophe which is as odd and complex as its creator. "Widdecombe is no stylist, and frequently lets herself down by writing as if this were a publication of the Tractarian Society. Yet the handling of character augurs well [and] the isolation of the parents within an apparently loving family is acutely observed. The novel is far more bleakly realistic than at first it seems, and I applaud Ann Widdecombe for setting aside her own certainties to show that people may do right unwillingly, and that the fallibility and resentment of her hero are a part of the human condition." "Can't write but can tell a story" might be a half-hearted summing up, but it could have been a lot worse. It has been suggested that Miss Widdecombe might eventually forgo politics for writing; Edwina Currie had better watch out.

fields.headline: 'Racist' doctors accused by MPs
fields.standfirst:
Race issues in the UK: special report
The Macpherson report: one year on: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors assessing patients for disability benefits are open to charges of institutional racism, according to a damning report from MPs.
fields.body:
Doctors assessing patients for disability benefits are open to charges of institutional racism, according to a damning report from MPs.

The Commons social security committee yesterday raised a string of concerns over the treatment of benefit claimants, including "cultural insensitivity" on the part of some doctors and "crude stereotyping" of some patients on ethnic grounds.

One medic working for the medical services department of the benefits agency refused a request to remove his shoes before entering the living room - also used for prayer - of an Asian client. As a result, the medical assessment was conducted in the patient's hallway.

In Avon, one doctor alluded to an Irish claimant's alleged alcoholism when there was no evidence that the man was a drinker, let alone an alcoholic.

The report concludes that the agency's medical service "could be laying itself open to the charge of institutional racism", and says that doctors who fail to improve should be sacked.

webTitle: Straw considers inquests into more Shipman patients

fields.headline: Straw considers inquests into more Shipman patients
fields.trailText: A coroner is seeking permission to open inquests into the deaths of 23 suspected victims of the serial-killing former GP Harold Shipman, it was announced today.
fields.body:
A coroner is seeking permission to open inquests into the deaths of 23 suspected victims of the serial-killing former GP Harold Shipman, it was announced today.

South Manchester coroner John Pollard said he had written to the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday seeking permission to open the inquests into the deaths of 23 elderly female patients.

Shipman was jailed in January at Preston crown court for the murder of 15 of his women patients by lethal injection of diamorphine. The CPS has decided not to proceed with charges on the 23 suspected victims, because Shipman could not be guaranteed a fair trial.

Mr Pollard said he decided to write to the home secretary after speaking at length to the investigating officers about the deaths in question. "It is my understanding that the families and relatives of these deceased are anxious for the evidence related to their deaths to be heard and tested by way of inquest," he said.

"Any coroner's inquest is a court of inquiry and not one of determining blame or liability, be that either criminal or civil," he added. The evidence that he would call, Mr Pollard stressed, would merely be to establish who the deceased were and how, when and where the deaths occurred.

Mr Pollard said that in the course of the investigation into the deaths of Shipman's patients, he had ordered a number of exhumations to take place. Nine of those formed the basis of charges against the GP.

But there were three other cases where bodies were exhumed and the police and CPS had decided not to proceed to charge. These three cases were the deaths of Sarah Ashworth, Alice Kitchen and Elizabeth Mellor.

Inquests were opened into the three deaths in 1998 but were closed for further investigations to be carried out. Mr Pollard said the police and CPS "do not intend to issue any criminal proceedings flowing from the deaths of these three ladies and I am therefore in a position where I now intend to resume the inquests touching their deaths".

He said he would be listing the cases for inquest as soon as possible and would be notifying witnesses. He added that he would inform Shipman of his right to attend the inquests, providing prison authorities were willing to let him do so.

Shipman has been investigated in relation to the suspicious deaths of nearly 200 patients. In February, police said they had enough evidence to prosecute him for the deaths of 23 more patients, but the CPS advised them not to bring further charges against him. At the time, the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, said: "There is sufficient evidence to proceed against Harold Shipman but I have reluctantly concluded that it would be wrong to proceed to a second and possibly third, trial in respect of 23 further alleged murders."

Mr Calvert-Smith said he had had to take into account the effect the enormous publicity might have upon any further trial, and that Shipman had already been sent to prison for the rest of his life.

An independent inquiry, which will be held in private, is due to begin hearing evidence in Manchester at the end of May. The inquiry will examine whether anything could have been done earlier to stop Shipman, and will report to the health secretary, Alan Milburn, in September.

But families of Shipman's victims and alleged victims have been angered by the decision to hold the inquiry in private and plan to take court action to make sure it is held in public.

fields.headline: Biography of Yaman Akdeniz
fields.trailText: Yaman Akdeniz is the founder and director of Cyber-Rights & Cyber-Liberties (UK), a non-profit civil liberties organisation set up in January 1997.
fields.body:
Yaman Akdeniz is the founder and director of Cyber-Rights & Cyber-Liberties (UK), a non-profit civil liberties organisation set up in January 1997.

He gave evidence to a trade and industry select committee on electronic commerce at the House of Commons on March 9 1999, following Cyber-Rights & Cyber-Liberties' memorandum to the committee in February 1999. He attended the OECD ministerial conference, Borderless World: Electronic Commerce, in Ottawa, Canada, in October 1998.

Akdeniz studied law at Leeds university. After graduating, he started researching the legal implications of the internet and completed his thesis on the law regarding free speech and privacy on the net in November 1998. He is expected to finish his PhD thesis on European net governance in December 2000 at Leeds, where he has been teaching "cyberlaw", a course on IT, law and society.

A list of publications written by Akdeniz is available through Cyber-Rights & Cyber-Liberties (UK).

webTitle: United undone by Real class of Raul

fields.headline: United undone by Real class of Raul
fields.standfirst:
Manchester United 2 Beckham 64, Scholes 88pen Real Madrid 3 Keane 20og, Raul 50 52
Real Madrid won 3-2 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Manchester United's possession of the European Cup was forfeited last night as Real Madrid, playing the better football and encouraged by an own- goal from Roy Keane, scored twice more, through Raul, early in the second half. David Beckham and Paul Scholes, with a penalty, reduced the margin of defeat but not the pain of it.
fields.body:
Manchester United's possession of the European Cup was forfeited last night as Real Madrid, playing the better football and encouraged by an own- goal from Roy Keane, scored twice more, through Raul, early in the second half. David Beckham and Paul Scholes, with a penalty, reduced the margin of defeat but not the pain of it.

As the sole surviving English representatives in the Champions League, United carried a not unfamiliar responsibility. Chelsea's downfall in Barce-lona the previous night, moreover, had given United not so much new lessons to learn as old ones to remember.

While the holders needed to avoid the excessive initial caution of Gianluca Vialli's team, which had handed the initiative to the opposition, they also had to guard against the sort of onrush of attacking zeal which before now had allowed opponents to steal early leads on the break here.

The absence of the injured Mark Bosnich, who had saved United from defeat at the Bernabeu, was not calculated to ease the supporters' nerves. The second choice, Raimond van der Gouw, had proved himself an adequate deputy in Europe but, as Bordeaux proved, remained accident-prone.

With Savio and Steve McManaman tending to tuck in behind Raul and Fernando Morientes, Real set out to put pressure on United's centre-backs with swift exchanges of passes. And an early low centre from Roberto Carlos on the left, which just cleared the far post, would surely have brought a goal had Raul been on the end of it.

For United, Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole were tightly marked, so much depended on Ryan Giggs and Beckham spreading the play while Keane and Scholes found opportunities to drive forward from midfield. Yet it was quite a time before United gained sufficient possession to establish any sort of attacking momentum.

In fact the goal that Old Trafford feared should have arrived in the 13th minute after Gary Neville's misreading of a high ball allowed Roberto Carlos a clear run on the left. The Brazilian's pass found Morientes but Van der Gouw easily saved a weak shot.

Neville was giving United an uncomfortable rerun of his errors during the Fifa world club championship in Rio. No sooner had Yorke's head failed to find the target after meeting Giggs's precise centre than the defender passed back straight to Roberto Carlos, who was denied a shot only by the alertness of Van der Gouw.

Worse, for United, was soon to follow. In the 20th minute McManaman found Morientes who laid a pass out to Michel Salgado. Van der Gouw had Salgado's weak cross-shot covered but Keane lunged in to block it and diverted the ball into his own net.

As Iker Casillas punched clear a shot from Yorke, blocked one from Scholes and then kept out another, from Keane, United's chances of scoring at least twice to save the tie hung in the balance.

One of the most worrying aspects for United was the fact that, although Giggs was regularly turning Real's defence on the left, they were not exploiting this advantage in front of goal. Cole was convinced that, as he rose to meet the ball under the bar Aitor Karanka reached up a hand to deflect it away. Certainly the defender tried but whether he made contact was doubtful.

With Raul shooting too high after a miscue by Stam, who then deflected a centre from McManaman dangerously close to his own net, the portents for United in the second half were not promising. Yet no one could have predicted the course of events which saw Real Madrid take a 3-0 lead by the 52nd minute.

Five minutes after the break Real caught United on the break and McManaman clipped the ball to Raul, in space to his right. This time Raul did not miss, curling a shot into the far corner.

There was time for Keane to waft a valuable chance to start saving the tie over the top before Raul scored again. With the defence nowhere Redondo reached the byline and set up the striker for a tap-in.

Then in the 64th minute Beckham reminded Old Trafford of the art of the possible by outwitting a clutch of defenders before hooking a marvellous shot high into the net. Later Casillas made a point blank save to deny the substitute Ole Gunnar Solksjaer.

 Real Madrid now meet Bayern Munich after a 3-2 aggregate win over Porto. In the last minute Jardel levelled for Porto but Thomas Linke headed the winner seconds later. Paulo Sergio scored Bayern's first.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; G. Neville, Berg (Sheringham, 62min), Stam, Irwin (Silvestre, h-t); Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole (Solksjaer, 62), Yorke.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Casillas; Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanka, Roberto Carlos; McManaman (Julio Cesar, 89), Helguera, Redondo, Savio (Geremi, 65); Morientes (Anelka, 72), Raul.

Referee: P Collina (Italy).

fields.headline: Biography of David Kerr
fields.standfirst: Chief executive, Internet Watch Foundation and company secretary, Internet Content Rating Association
fields.trailText: David Kerr was appointed as the first chief executive of the IWF in October 1996 to set up and run the organisation.
fields.body:
David Kerr was appointed as the first chief executive of the IWF in October 1996 to set up and run the organisation.

He has a masters degree in business administration, experience of policy review and management consultancy in local government and has worked in the private sector in the aircraft industry and manufacturing. In recent years he has been involved in developing public-private partnerships addressing issues such as race relations and rural services.

Kerr was appointed to IWF to implement an agreement between the UK internet industry, government and the police. He was responsible for developing one of the world's first hotlines for dealing with illegal net content with the support of the UK government, police and ISPs.

He also played a leading role in specifying a UK rating system and in promoting the development of an internationally acceptable rating and filtering scheme. He has led the Incore project commissioned by the EU to make recommendations on the approach to rating and filtering from a European perspective which is reporting in mid-2000.

The ICRA, a not-for-profit consortium of global net players, was set up to deliver an international rating system. Kerr has also participated in the experts network set up by the Bertelsmann Foundation to consider issues of self-regulation of internet content, which made recommendations to the Internet Content Summit in Munich in September 1999 and was jointly run by Incore.

fields.headline: Behaviour, Belly clutching and Biancocelesti
fields.trailText: LEEDS MAKE ADVERT PLEA
fields.body:
LEEDS MAKE ADVERT PLEA

Leeds United have placed full-page adverts in tabloid newspapers which appeal for calm at their Uefa Cup match against Galatasaray tonight. The adverts, headlined 'Tonight must be about football', include a plea in both English and Turkish from Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale for good behaviour.

"Whatever the result I ask everyone to ensure their visit to Elland Road is safe," says Ridsdale. "It is important that all of us take the opportunity to show the world that we will not allow the futility of violence and personal injury to cast a shadow over football in this country."

Meanwhile Leeds boss David O'Leary has admitted that there is an air of depression among the players in the run up to the game. "I just think they've been so saddened with what happened in Istanbul and with the funerals over the last couple of days," he said. "But the whole city has become a gloomy place and the players feel that. They've been upset and they feel why should they be smiling when everybody is down - and you also feel how lucky you are."

EVERYBODY LOVES A LOSER

Last night's Big Cup action caused the world to spin off its axis as Manchester United scored fewer goals in a football match than the other team they were playing in it. Obviously, with news as stunning as this, it'll take a while for the nation to pick themselves up off the floor - either because they're totally gutted or they're still curled up in a belly-clutching ball, guffawing like a banshee. Luckily, the Fiver took a less emotional view - we were watching the snooker on the other side anyway - and is up and about to report on United's reaction to their Big Cup exit.

"It's bitterly disappointing," said one-man disaster zone Roy Keane. "Hopefully we will be back next year and we can put it right," he promised, surprisingly gaining the Fiver's sympathy. "It won't be difficult to pick ourselves up because we've got a championship to win," he proudly concluded. What a sweetheart!

"We've always gone on the premise that if you win a game, you forget about it and go on to the next one," explained Teddy Sheringham, who has never made any reference to the events of last May at all, anywhere, ever. "This will be no different. We've got to win the League now and it would be a travesty if we lost that," he bravely claimed. The little soldier!

As you can see, everyone at Old Trafford is obviously in a state of shock - even Alex Ferguson was sensationally caught on camera being magnanimous in defeat. Like a small spoilt child who is fed up with their bloody old Tamagotchi and wants a special Pikachu edition Pokemon instead or they'll be sick all over their remote-control Buzz Lightyear, Lazio simply must have all the best players in the world. Salas. Simeone. Veron. Want. Want. Want. It is perhaps this character trait which has led them to purchase the skilful and excellent Brazilian footballer Rivaldo from Barcelona for a world-record £31m.

According to respected Italian sports paper Gazzetta Dello Sport, the Rome giants have responded to being humiliated in Big Cup by offering Rivaldo a five-year contract worth at least £3m-a-year. fields.headline: The case for regulation
fields.standfirst: David Kerr, chairman of the Internet Watch Foundation, opposes the motion that "this house believes any attempt by government to police the internet is unworkable and a threat to civil liberties"
fields.trailText: This addresses fundamental issues for the future of the internet. The Internet Watch Foundation, IWF, is at the heart of the debate as it was set up by internet service providers, or ISPs, to help police criminal content - primarily child pornography - and avoid a threat to civil liberties.
fields.body:
This addresses fundamental issues for the future of the internet. The Internet Watch Foundation, IWF, is at the heart of the debate as it was set up by internet service providers, or ISPs, to help police criminal content - primarily child pornography - and avoid a threat to civil liberties.

There are demonstrably workable means for government to police the internet but the means are very different from those used in older media: they should be through partnership and co-regulation with industry rather than authoritarian enforcement.

The British government and law enforcement agencies were perhaps the first to realise they would achieve their objectives by working with ISPs. There is now an established pattern of public reporting of suspect content through a hotline, followed by a notice and take-down procedures to remove content regarded as illegal. The hotline has been used as a model in Europe, the United States and Australia.

Labelling and filtering addresses the threat of content that is potentially harmful to children. E-commerce poses big problems but the size and economics of the market make willing partners of government, industry and law enforcement in the effort to provide safe trading.

In each of the emerging areas of concern governments are increasingly obliged to rely on co-regulatory means of operation. The net's architecture allows individual users to choose how they use it. Most have an offshore option to avoid unreasonable restraints, so government policing in the forms suggested pose little threat to civil liberties.

The greatest danger to civil liberties arises if governments do not learn how to achieve adequate regulation by new means and are panicked into imposing authoritarian measures. My conclusion contradicts the motion: there is a severe threat to civil liberties if governments do not find workable ways to police the internet.

webTitle: MI5 papers cast new light on Hitler's last days

fields.headline: MI5 papers cast new light on Hitler's last days
fields.trailText: A first-hand account of Hitler's last days, released today, paints a dramatic picture of a "broken" and paranoid Führer blaming all around him for the imminent collapse of the Nazi regime as shells from Red Army guns rained on Berlin.
fields.body:
A first-hand account of Hitler's last days, released today, paints a dramatic picture of a "broken" and paranoid Führer blaming all around him for the imminent collapse of the Nazi regime as shells from Red Army guns rained on Berlin.

The account, kept secret in MI5 files for more than 50 years, was given by General Gottlieb Berger, a senior SS officer, to British interrogators after the war was over.

Berger, who saw Hitler on April 22 1945, eight days before he committed suicide, was asked how Hitler had died. He replied: "I presume he blew himself up, but he was just as likely to have had a stroke, as he raved like a madman on the 22nd when he spoke to me. He was completely finished, a broken man."

Berger described how he went with Heinrich Himmler, one of Hitler's close confidants, to Berlin. The SS chief tried to persuade Hitler to escape. Berger, according to the MI5 transcript of his interrogation, was furious.

"I told him that it was out of the question and that he could betray the German people, and that it was very easy - he didn't utter a word - to put a bullet through one's head or to take one of those pills or tubes issued, which worked instantaneously," he told MI5.

Berger described how Hitler started raving. "Everyone has deceived me," he recalled Hitler saying. "No one has told me the truth; the armed forces have lied to me; finally, the SS has left me in the lurch."

The general went on: "Then his face went bluish-purple, I thought he was due for a stroke at any minute." He said Hitler was showing signs of having suffered a stroke on the left side of his body.

webTitle: Lord Haw Haw's flight to Germany

fields.headline: Lord Haw Haw's flight to Germany
fields.trailText: Lord Haw Haw, the Nazi sympathiser who broadcast anti-British propaganda from Germany, slipped out of Britain days before the outbreak of war under the noses of MI5, documents released today show.
fields.body:
Lord Haw Haw, the Nazi sympathiser who broadcast anti-British propaganda from Germany, slipped out of Britain days before the outbreak of war under the noses of MI5, documents released today show.

William Joyce - who earned his nickname by his blend of Irish brogue and cockney he tried to disguise as a "public school" voice as he delivered his propaganda broadcasts beginning with the phrase "Germany calling" - had made no secret of his pro-Nazi views.

MI5 files reveal that the security service intercepted a letter from Joyce to a suspected German spy announcing his intention to leave Britain.

A secret memo warned he was "quite willing to take action inimical to this country in order to further the campaign against the supposed 'world Jewish conspiracy'" and recommended he should be detained in the event of war.

Joyce first came to MI5's attention as an outspoken supporter of Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists.

A 1937 intelligence report argued that Joyce's "irritability of manner" suggested that his "inner man" felt his talents had not been properly recognised and that he secretly regarded Mosley as a "conceited popinjay".

Joyce subsequently set up his own pro-Nazi organisation - the National Socialist League.

MI5 intercepted his correspondence, including letters he exchanged with Christian Bauer, a German journalist expelled from Britain for suspected espionage.

They were particularly concerned about "somewhat cryptic messages" from Bauer for his brother Quentin who worked at the Air Ministry and who shared Joyce's pro-Nazi views.

On July 20 1939 - in a letter opened by MI5 - Joyce wrote to Bauer to tell him Quentin was planning to travel to Berlin in early September. On September 1, the police special branch was despatched to arrest him, only to discover that he had escaped a few days earlier.

Though born in the US, the son of a naturalised Irish-American father, he studied at the London School of Economics. After the war he was sentenced to death for treason - the courts ruled that despite his background, Joyce held a British passport.

One of Joyce's tasks in Germany was to persuade British prisoners of war to join the fight against Bolshevism. According to MI5 files released today, the number of recruits to what were called the Legion of St George and the British Free Corps were never more than 60.

The files list the estimated number of foreigners who joined the Waffen SS, including up to 14,000 Frenchmen, 34,000 Belgians (both Flemish and French-speaking Walloons), up to 28,000 Dutch, and 8,000 Danes.

webTitle: How MI5 agents vetted 'flood of aliens'

fields.headline: How MI5 agents vetted 'flood of aliens'
fields.trailText: Thousands of refugees have "flooded" into Britain. There are complaints about the lack of "adequate machinery" to meet the "unforeseen contingency". A detention centre has been set up to "check and carefully sift" them.
fields.body:
Thousands of refugees have "flooded" into Britain. There are complaints about the lack of "adequate machinery" to meet the "unforeseen contingency". A detention centre has been set up to "check and carefully sift" them.

In language with an eerie contemporary resonance, MI5 documents released today at the public record office show how "aliens" - as they were then called - were vetted and controlled during the second world war.

Sir David Petrie, head of the agency, proudly told the foreign secretary, Anthony Eden, how by the late summer of 1940 "practically every potentially dangerous person, whether British or foreign, had been swept into the net". He added: "The subsequent gradual process of release led to a complete ticketing and labelling of those whom it was thought safe to discharge."

But, he added in his memo written in 1944, "a new complication arose from the great number of totally unknown alien refugees who flooded into this country after Hitler had overrun western Europe".

Sir David went on: "No adequate machinery existed to meet this unforseen contingency [of] thousands of refugees in all classes" coming to Britain. Some had come to continue the fight against German occupation of their country. But Sir David warned: "There were many others of a different calibre, who came to this country primarily for their own good and with no particular loyalty to anyone."

He explained to Eden how MI5 had set up a London detention centre early in 1941 at the Royal Patriotic School in Wandsworth, south London.

"Fortunately", he said, "no harm seems to have resulted." Indeed, he concluded that "the great majority have been perfectly innocent".

fields.headline: Blair called to jury
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's claim to be just another ordinary guy was reinforced today when he received a call for jury service in the morning post.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's claim to be just another ordinary guy was reinforced today when he received a call for jury service in the morning post.

Addressed to Anthony C Blair at 11 Downing Street, where Mr Blair lives with wife Cherie and their three children, it brought a summons from the jury officer at Southwark Crown Court, London, requiring his attendance at 9.15am on June 12. Mr Blair would face a fine if he did not turn up without having a valid excuse.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said that it appeared that Mr Blair's name had been chosen at random by computer from the electoral register.

Unlike thousands of unwilling jurors before him, Mr Blair will not have to contrive an artful excuse in order to avoid days sitting in judgment of his peers as he excluded from service twice over - both as an MP and a barrister.

Law lords may be able to pass judgment in courts and legislation in the Lords, but the separation of powers in the UK dictates that MPs, barristers, peers and clergy are all disqualified from jury service.

A spokesman at the lord chancellor's department said that as far as it was aware it was the first time a jury summons had been issued to a prime minister.

"The computer doesn't discriminate when it selects people. The onus is on the individual to indicate whether or not they are going to be able to perform the task," he said.

fields.body:
The internet is thought to offer unlimited free speech and democracy. But censorship is increasing - and becoming more visible in the UK. Internet content faces censorship from public bodies, the internet service providers, or ISPs, and private regulatory bodies such as the Internet Watch Foundation.

Following the judgment in the Demon case, ISPs have been under pressure to take down internet content which allegedly carries defamatory content under the defamation act 1996.

Several examples of this new trend of internet censorship have been witnessed in Britain.

Jim Hulbert's website, which criticised some judges and the Lord Chancellor's department, was taken down in November last year following a "notice" sent to a Hull-based ISP.

In February this year the Portia website, dealing with miscarriages of justice, was taken down by an ISP following a "notice" from the solicitors of the Police Federation.

And the website of the Campaign Against Censorship of the Internet in Britain was removed from its British ISP's servers and re-allocated to a server in the US. This followed a complaint by Laurence Godfrey, whose case with Demon Internet was discussed on the website.

Outcast magazine's website was also censored after lawyers acting for another publishing company claimed "an article might be published on the site at some point in the future, and that such an article might be critical of their client".

UK laws force ISPs to simultaneously be the defendant, judge and jury. Holding an ISP responsible for content published by third parties or by its customers has serious implications for the preservation of freedom of expression. This is censorship by the back door and must be resisted. Appropriate action for the government would be to take the ISPs out of the chain of liability.

In January, the government-supported Internet Watch Foundation announced that it would apply its self-regulation approach to racism on the internet. The IWF's move raises important questions of transparency and accountability, as it is not a public body. Removal of objectionable - though legal - content from the internet without due process would certainly amount to censorship.

But we should not forget that those who need protection from censorship are mostly those who present the ideas that offend, shock or disturb. "Such are the demands of that pluralism, tolerance or broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society," as the European Court of Human Rights has stated several times in its judgments. If the UK is to become the best place for e-commerce, it should also offer the best protection for individual rights and liberties.

webTitle: 'Great Escape' PoWs shot on Hitler's orders

fields.headline: 'Great Escape' PoWs shot on Hitler's orders
fields.trailText: The execution of 50 allied prisoners of war, most of them British, in 1944 - immortalised by the film the Great Escape - was personally ordered by Hitler against objections from senior officers in the German army, according to MI5 documents released today at the public record office.
fields.body:
The execution of 50 allied prisoners of war, most of them British, in 1944 - immortalised by the film the Great Escape - was personally ordered by Hitler against objections from senior officers in the German army, according to MI5 documents released today at the public record office.

They contain a graphic account of how Hitler and key figures in his high command, including Hermann Göering, head of the Luftwaffe, Heinrich Himmler, head of the SS, and Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel ordered the captured escapers to be shot, dismissing out of hand suggestions it would be in breach of the Geneva convention.

Interrogated by British intelligence officers after the war, General Major Adolf Westhoff, the German officer responsible for prisoner welfare in the camps, described how an "excited and nervous" Keitel summoned him after the break-out of prisoners - including 76 RAF officers - from Stalag Luft III on the Polish-German border in March 1944.

"Gentlemen, this is a bad business," said Keitel who had been personally blamed by Göering in Himmler's presence. He added: "These escapees must be shot. We must set an example."

Keitel was told: "That's out of the question. Escape isn't a dishonourable offence. That is specially laid down in the convention."

According to Westhoff, Keitel replied: "I don't care a damn. We discussed it in the fuhrer's presence and it cannot be altered."

Westhoff told his interrogators that all those killed had been shot by police or Gestapo before his troops had even seen them. "We were faced with a fait accompli."

In his testimony, Westhoff spoke of the "honour" of British officers. He claimed he had told the Nazi leadership that "the English in particular only escape for the fun of it ... They have their escape committee in the camp. No one is allowed to escape without informing the escape committee."

He described how the bodies of the 50 prisoners shot by the Gestapo were burned and their ashes returned to the camp. "For the burial, the PoWs arranged with the protecting power that they should be allowed to erect a nice monument, which they made themselves," he said.

Westhoff said he chose not to tell his superiors about the monument, fearing it would "give rise to more difficulties".

Westhoff told his interrogators that Keitel gave detailed instructions for the publication of a list of names of the prisoners who were shot "as a warning".

He said Keitel himself "refused to put anything in writing". However, there was enough evidence against him for the judges at the Nuremberg war crimes trials to sentence him to death. Twenty-one members of the Gestapo involved in the shooting were tried and executed after the war.

The story of the escape was made into a film in 1963 starring Steve McQueen, Richard Attenborough, James Garner, Donald Pleasance, and James Coburn.

fields.headline: Former minister in secrecy protest
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A former government minister will today put pressure on Jack Straw by releasing documents of his own meetings with the Irish government that would be remain secret for 30 years under the freedom of information bill.
fields.body:
A former government minister will today put pressure on Jack Straw by releasing documents of his own meetings with the Irish government that would be remain secret for 30 years under the freedom of information bill.

Lord Dubs, the former Northern Ireland environment minister, will use documents on road safety obtained by the Guardian under the Irish freedom of information act to argue that the home secretary must rethink his ban on the release of policy documents under the bill.

The former minister intends to brandish the documents during today's House of Lords second reading debate on the bill, with Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister, already anticipating a rough ride on Labour's contentious legislation.

Revolts are expected over proposals to allow Cabinet ministers to veto the release of information; refuse to publish the facts behind policy making; and keep secret information obtained during criminal investigations.

Mr Straw looks certain to capitulate in one area, by deciding that no council leader or mayor can override Elizabeth France, the new information commissioner, if she orders the release of documents.

Lord Dubs intends to show fellow peers policy and briefing papers on a meeting he had in 1998 with the Irish transport minister, Noel Dempsey, to tighten up road safety measures between the republic and Northern Ireland.

The papers - released by the Irish - reveal that Dublin was proposing to introduce a United Kingdom penalty point system for motoring offences to cut road accidents.

The high death toll and serious injuries on both sides of the border made road safety an issue in Anglo-Irish talks.

Lords Dubs said yesterday that the government should consider "whether some policy papers outside areas like national security should be released unless they cause substantial harm".

webTitle: Bank set to cool high-spending, high-earning economy

fields.headline: Bank set to cool high-spending, high-earning economy
fields.standfirst: We're earning more and spending more - so the Bank of England will not be able to resist raising interest rates, argues Guardian columnist Victor Keegan. But does it have to?
fields.trailText: We're earning more and spending more - so the Bank of England will not be able to resist raising interest rates, argues Guardian columnist Victor Keegan. But does it have to?
fields.body:
Today's figures for retail trade put the problems of the economy in a nutshell. The volume of spending in the shops rose 0.5% last month and by 4.6% in the year to March.

This, according to conventional wisdom, is much too fast to be sustainable for any length of time without rekindling inflation and will put further pressure on interest rates. It follows Wednesday's figures showing average earnings rising at an eight-year high of 6%. People are earning too much and spending too much - so it's time to slap on the brakes.

Or is it? Look at the details of the spending figures and you find that while the volume of spending has gone up by 4.6% over the year, the value (which is what is important for inflation) has risen by only 1.6%. In other words, shops can't make price increases stick, despite the sharp rise in purchasing power.

This unusual phenomenon was reflected in the inflation figures earlier this week, which showed that the underlying increase in prices was only 2.0% for the year. Why isn't inflation rising when there is so much money sloshing around?

There are several reasons. Globalisation, the strong pound (which makes imports cheaper) and the effects of the internet. The knowledge that people can buy cheap imported alternatives or search the web for better bargains is preventing shopkeepers from raising their prices.

For the moment this has produced a nirvana of high earnings and low prices. We could be entering a long period of low prices. But we may never be given a chance to know.

The trouble is that there is usually a time lag before high wages force prices up - and that's what the Bank of England is worried about. It is under a legal obligation to prevent the underlying rise in prices from exceeding 2.5%, and as there is a time lag of up to 18 months before rises in interest rates affect the economy it isn't tempted to take chances.

The Bank will probably ignore the fact that the 6% rise in earnings is exceptional (buoyed up by one-off city bonuses and the effects of the minimum wage on hotels and catering). Stand by for another increase in interest rates - internet or no internet.

webTitle: Microsoft admits to late handheld start

fields.headline: Microsoft admits to late handheld start
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft expressed its regret and frustration over its failure to push into the fast-growing market for handheld computer devices yesterday as it launched a Pocket PC with several new features.
fields.body:
Microsoft expressed its regret and frustration over its failure to push into the fast-growing market for handheld computer devices yesterday as it launched a Pocket PC with several new features.

Steve Ballmer, president and chief executive of Microsoft, said he acknowledged its failure to recognise that the market for handheld devices was going to explode.

"I regret the fact that we are not further ahead in this marketplace," he told an New York audience gathered to see the company's new product.

In fact, the Pocket PC - launched yesterday in association with four hardware manufacturers and a total of 350 partners in 17 countries - will compete against the Palm Pilot, which is the market leader for handheld electronic organisers.

IDC, the research group, expects the market for mobile organisers to grow from around 6m at present to 67m in four years.

Palm, the industry pioneer in the United States, has about 80% of the market against Microsoft's 10%.

Mr Ballmer said the company had improved its earlier versions to make them "thinner, smaller, with lighter weight and better battery life than ever before".

But the new machines were also designed to cope with the expected growth in wireless web demand. Wireless "is the most mission-critical thing as we look at the growth in this category over the next five to 10 years".

Mr Ballmer is credited with spearheading Microsoft's push to diversify away from the personal computer industry it already dominates. Yesterday's launch included no mention of Microsoft's legal woes.

The US Justice Department is to file its proposed remedies on the company's market dominance next week.

These proposals could take into account the fact that rivals are still complaining about Microsoft's behaviour.

There have been complaints, for example, that Microsoft is still using its stranglehold over personal computers to gain access to other markets, such as network servers.

Such behaviour was at the heart of the government's lawsuit against the company.

Analysts have been more upbeat about the new Pocket PC than they were about the two earlier versions.

Ben Waldman, a vice-president in Microsoft's research group, referred yesterday to the standard industry "joke" that the Seattle-based firm always took three attempts to get new products right.

"Two versions are too many, but we have tried very hard to learn from our mistakes," he said.

Among a raft of new features on the machines to be launched in Britain and the United States today was an ability to read ordinary handwriting when scrawled across the screen.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Fragrances
Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fragrances
fields.body:
Buying perfumes on the net should be as easy as choosing the size of the bottle. But the experience doesn't quite match up to an afternoon spent in Harrods or Harvey Nichols, and many manufacturers have been less than happy for their fragrance to be sold on the net.

www.theperfumeshop.com launched earlier this month with around 300 fragrances to buy online - approximately two thirds of the range available in the company's high street stores. It's great if you want to check out prices or buy some of the "exclusive" fragrances available only through the Perfume Shop, but many of the better known brands aren't available yet; Calvin Klein is one exception - you can buy Contradiction, CK One and Obsession. The absence of a proper search facility - or a list detailing precisely which products can be bought online - is an oversight on a site that prides itself on size.

www.ovs.net is a small fragrance discounter with a limited product range, but some reasonable prices: Emporio by Armani 50ml eau de parfum (£21.25); Joop 50ml eau de toilette (£29.75); Miss Dior 50ml eau de toilette (£31.02).The site is hardly the last word in web design, but nervous shoppers should be reassured by the site's membership of the Which web trader scheme.

www.scentpacking.com is an altogether more sophisticated affair. There are around 200 products and the discounts are good. Before you get too carried away though, do read the terms and conditions, which warn that you may be liable for any tax or duty charged on import. Searching is straightforward and the range includes newer fragrances such as Romance by Ralph Lauren (50ml eau de toilette, £27.95), Allure for Men (50ml eau de toilette, £22.95) and L'Eau d'Issey (50ml eau de toilette, £33.95). If you're not happy with your purchase, there's a 100% money-back guarantee.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...an Easter egg
fields.trailText: ...an Easter egg
fields.body:
Celebrate Easter with Big Bertha, a chocolate egg that weighs 13kg (2st). Confectioner Charbonnel et Walker has made Bertha by hand from dark chocolate an inch thick and iced her with spring blossoms and chocolate piping. And her vital statistics? She's 58% cocoa, 60cm (2ft) tall and 45cm round the middle and she will set you back a mere £445. After cracking her open with an axe, you might be disappointed to find she's not filled with Charbonnel's champagne truffles. Don't panic, you can buy a box of eight for £6.50.

You are, of course, paying for the name. Charbonnel et Walker has an illustrious history, having provided soft centres to the Queen, the House of Lords, British Airways first class and the "acting profession", notably Noel Coward, John Gielgud and his aunt Ellen. The firm was founded in 1875 by Madame Charbonnel who, legend has it, was mistress to Edward VII before he became king. Staff keep scrupulous records of clients' preferences in case friends wish to surprise them with a bonbon casket.

Easter slimmers should opt for Big Bertha's skinnier sibling, Little Bertha, who weighs just 8kg (17lb). She's still a big girl though, standing 50cm (20in) high, and she will set you back £355. Call Charbonnel et Walker on 020-7491 0939. Then call your dentist.

webTitle: TVs, madam? They're next to the baked beans

fields.headline: TVs, madam? They're next to the baked beans
fields.standfirst: Supermarket shoppers can now buy DVD players, videos, even fridges along with the cornflakes. As Tesco and Asda extend their ranges of electrical goods,  Helen Jones asks whether it will mean a better deal for consumers
fields.trailText: Supermarket shoppers can now buy DVD players, videos, even fridges along with the cornflakes. As Tesco and Asda extend their ranges of electrical goods, Helen Jones asks whether it will mean a better deal for consumers.
fields.body:
What's in your trolley following a trip to the local supermarket? Bread and milk? Fruit and veg? Perhaps the odd television or a computer?

In the past couple of years supermarkets have increasingly focused on non-food products such as clothing, perfume and now, electrical goods because they offer far better profit margins than can be charged on food.

Tesco has launched seven electrical stores-within-stores and plans to roll out 50 more in the next year. Meanwhile, Asda, now owned by US retailer Wal-Mart, which has a strong track record in selling electrical goods, is to launch a hypermarket chain called Supercentre in July. It will introduce new product categories and extend the George clothing brand into housewares, toys and books. It will also sell computers and software, small electrical goods, and, possibly, white goods such as fridges and freezers.

Asda already has special promotions on TVs, videos and DVD players and there are bargains to be had. It claims to offer the best-value DVD player in Britain at £177.99 - that's £1.01 cheaper than the DVD player on sale at Tesco.

"Supermarkets are very opportunistic about electrical retailing," says Mike Godliman, a retail analyst. "They usually get a certain line in and sell it as a one-off promotion. It's all about unbeatable deals that draw in consumers to buy a DVD player or whatever, and then turning them into loyal customers."

Tesco started selling electrical goods in 1998 and sold a healthy 10,000 DVD players at £179 in a week. "It's been amazingly successful," says Simon Soffe of Tesco. "We can sell them cheaper because our margins are much lower than high street electrical retailers."

It's an issue that concerns the Radio, Electrical and TV Retailers Association, Retra. "The products on offer in supermarkets are to entice people in. The supermarkets are not trying to make serious profit margins from them," explains Retra chief executive, Fred Round.

If the supermarkets aren't interested in making big profits from electrical goods, does that make it a good deal for consumers? Well, up to a point.

Unlike high street electrical stores such as Dixons or Comet supermarkets may not have products available when it suits you. As Soffe explains: "We buy an allocation of computers, for example, from a manufacturer such as Fujitsu or Siemens-Nixdorf and we sell them very fast."

If you don't buy quickly, then stocks are likely to have run out and the offers - which Asda calls WOWs - are rarely repeated. Once offers have gone, that's it - consumers can't plan to buy a product next month when there is a bit more space on the credit card.

Another problem is that many products are only available at the larger stores which have sufficient shelf space. Tesco is trying to address this by launching "cyberzones" within its stores where customers can order anything from books to fridges through Tesco's internet site. Customers will also get free access to the entire web and not just Tesco's site.

Supermarkets are working on an opportunistic basis, striking deals with manufacturers as and when they can, which means the range of goods on offer is limited. If you are looking for something in particular, you may be better off going to your local electrical retailer.

"At the end of the day we offer customer choice with a much wider range of products available. And a lot of our prices are equivalent if not better than in the supermarkets," says Dixons. Asda is selling a Bush DVD 2000 for £177.99 and while Dixons does not sell that particular product it says that its equivalent own-brand product costs £169.35.

If you want a leading brand name you may also be disappointed. Asda's TVs and videos are supplied by German manufacturer Schneider - hardly a household name in the UK. Tesco's DVD players are made by Wharfedale.

The lack of top brand names is not necessarily the supermarkets' fault. Just as the makers of designer perfume, Levi jeans and Calvin Klein felt supermarkets weren't an upmarket enough environment for their brands, it's the same with some manufacturers of electrical goods. "We have sold some big brands such as Amstrad TVs, for example, but some famous brands have an issue about supplying us," says Soffe.

Perhaps the biggest issue is one of service. Both Dixons and Retra say that consumers who buy electrical goods at supermarkets don't receive the sort of expert advice they would get from a specialist on the high street.

But Tesco insists consumers know what they want. "They have often done their research either by reading magazines or on the internet and don't want a sales pitch," says Soffe.

If electrical goods develop faults within a year, Tesco customers will be offered a full refund or exchange. The company also set up a dedicated help line with Fujitsu when it sold a batch of its computers. "That meant that consumers who had queries about setting up their PCs could talk straight to the experts."

Not all consumers' needs are the same, explains consumer consultant Paul Edwards. "Some require assistance and so if they want to buy a computer they will go to PC World or wherever. But lots of people are confident about making these types of purchases and trust big name supermarkets like Tesco. If they can buy their car insurance or other financial services at the supermarket then buying a telly is no problem."

And it's convenient, adds Edwards. "People lead such busy lives but if you buy your TV from the supermarket along with your cornflakes there are no problems with parking and you don't need to make another trip. Besides they are offering some great bargains."

fields.headline: Want to work for Wisden?
fields.trailText: The award-winning Wisden Cricket Monthly is looking for an assistant editor, following the departure of Simon Briggs, who has joined The Daily Telegraph.
fields.body:
The award-winning Wisden Cricket Monthly is looking for an assistant editor, following the departure of Simon Briggs, who has joined The Daily Telegraph.

The job is based at our office in west London (Latimer Road tube). It involves commissioning, a certain amount of writing, and a lot of copy-editing and page-passing. It may well involve some writing and editing for wisden.com as well.

The successful applicant will have plenty of ideas, a cool temperament, good computer skills, an ear for language, an eye for detail and a passion for cricket.

Some experience is essential, whether in magazines, newspapers or on the web, but evidence of talent and drive is just as important. Visual sense is an advantage.

Please send a CV, an example or two of your work, your comments on the May issue of WCM and a covering email or letter to wisden@johnbrown.co.uk or by post to Tim de Lisle, editor, WCM, 136 Bramley Road, W10 6SR. Please mark the envelope or subject box ASSISTANT EDITOR.

If you don't have experience, you may be able to get some through our work-experience scheme. Please send a CV, an example or two of your work, your comments on the May issue of WCM and a covering email or letter to wisden@johnbrown.co.uk or by post to Tanya Aldred, assistant editor, WCM, 136 Bramley Road, W10 6SR. Please mark the envelope or subject box WORK EXPERIENCE.

Wisden is an equal-opportunities employer.

webTitle: Blair and Ahern talks fail to kickstart peace process

fields.headline: Blair and Ahern talks fail to kickstart peace process
fields.trailText: The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, admitted this afternoon that there had been "no fundamental breakthrough" in his talks with Tony Blair over the stalled Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, admitted this afternoon that there had been "no fundamental breakthrough" in his talks with Tony Blair over the stalled Northern Ireland peace process.

Earlier hopes that the second anniversary of the Good Friday agreement might revive the process have been dashed, although Mr Ahern expressed "confidence" that positive developments would emerge after Easter.

After two hours of talks in Downing Street with the British prime minister, Mr Ahern said that they had made "some progress" in their discussions. He told reporters: "It does give me confidence, on the other side of Easter, we can make progress. It is not going to be easy. We don't have a simple resolution."

Mr Ahern said their talks had been aimed at finding a way to restore self-government in Northern Ireland, which was suspended in February by the secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, following the IRA's failure to decommission its arms.

The British and Irish governments were agreed on the way forward, but they had to win the support of the Northern Ireland parties, Mr Ahern added.

The Taoiseach played down the IRA's traditional Easter statement, issued last night, in which it made no mention of the crucial decommissioning issue. "I don't see a lot in that," he said. "It doesn't make life easier for us."

Both British and Irish officials had been keen before today's meeting to play down the prospect of any major developments.

Earlier, Mr Blair had stressed that there were still "tremendous opportunities" for Northern Ireland, but he also said he was "frustrated" at the failure to make political progress. Attention will now focus on talks between the two governments and the Northern Ireland parties which are due to resume after the Easter break. Mr Blair's official spokesman said the prime minister also felt there was "reason to be optimistic" about the prospects for the peace process.

But he acknowledged that there would have to be further talks between the two governments and the parties before they could be brought to the negotiating table together.

webTitle: Soaring pay sparks loan rate rise fear

fields.headline: Soaring pay sparks loan rate rise fear
fields.trailText: The prospect of a fifth rise in interest rates since last autumn loomed larger yesterday after falling unemployment and huge City bonuses left Britain's pay packets rising at their fastest rate for almost eight years.
fields.body:
The prospect of a fifth rise in interest rates since last autumn loomed larger yesterday after falling unemployment and huge City bonuses left Britain's pay packets rising at their fastest rate for almost eight years.

The CBI and TUC urged the Bank of England to show restraint after the news that average earnings grew at an annual rate of 6% in the three months to February as the jobless total reached its lowest level since March 1980.

But with the Bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee already toying with the idea of pushing up borrowing costs, analysts said yesterday that the tightness of the labour market made a rate rise next month more likely.

Figures from the office for national statistics showed the steady decline in the number of people out of work and claiming benefit towards the million mark having an impact on earnings, particularly in private-sector service jobs, where earnings are growing by 6.9%. Claimant count unemployment dropped by 7,700 to 1,148,800.

However, the effect of shrinking dole queues has been compounded in recent months by the size of City bonuses and one-off payments to key workers over the new year.

Seasonally adjusted annual average earnings were rising at 4.9% in November, but jumped to 5.5% in December and 5.9% in January.

According to the ONS, earnings were still on a rising trend, even when bonuses and overtime payments were stripped out. They were growing at 5.1% in February, up from 3.8% a year earlier.

The Bank's rule of thumb is that earnings growth of 5% or more puts the government's 2.5% inflation target at risk, because only half the increase in pay packets is justified by greater efficiency, with the rest coming from higher prices.

Kate Barker, chief economist at the CBI, said the Bank should avoid a hasty move. "Although the headline figure is up slightly, the slow increase in February alone is encouraging and the MPC should hold its nerve.

"With inflation firmly under control, and in the light of CBI pay data showing that settlements were flat in the first quarter, there is no justification for putting up interest rates."

The TUC's general secretary, John Monks, joined the call for interest rates to be pegged at their current level of 6%. "The fall in unemployment is welcome, but the threat of major job losses in the manufacturing sector remain.

"With inflation at historic lows and average earnings growth starting to moderate, the Bank should give a clear signal at its next meeting that interest rates have peaked," he said.

Evidence from the Consumers' Association provided some signs that the four increases in base rates might already be having an effect.

Its quarterly consumer trends survey found a drop in consumer confidence, with 68% "very" or "fairly" confident about the prospects for their household's financial circumstances over the next year, down from 74% in January.
