fields.headline: Not quite all about football
fields.standfirst: Northern editor Martin Wainwright assesses the pre-match mood in Leeds
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright assesses the pre-match mood in Leeds.
fields.body:
"Tonight must be all about football," Peter Ridsdale repeated all morning like a mantra, adding a brave version in Turkish with its multiple "K" sounds and soft vowels, for good measure. No one on the streets of Leeds would openly disagree with the Leeds United chairman, but the fine words do not tell the whole story.

As in any competitive sport, let alone a hugely-publicised, money-drenched one like international football, tonight is all about trying to win as well. Every move in the ballet of reactions and counter-reactions since the stabbing to death of Chris Loftus and Kevin Speight on 5 April has had a competitive edge to it. Short of a vow of silence, it could not be otherwise.

Thus the Yorkshire Evening Post, which has played a straight but inevitably gold, blue and white-tinted game throughout the controversy, announces today that "Every Fan in England Wants United to Win". Chatting to early-lunchers by the news-stand on Park Row, that feeling is echoed immediately after concern that everything should be peaceful tonight. "We want to thrash them" was repeated again and again - standard hopes for a Uefa Cup semi-final but potentially disastrous if rival Leeds and Galatasaray fans meet.

The West Yorkshire police operation is based on making sure that doesn't happen, largely by keeping any overt Galatasaray supporters away from the ground. There will be some. Aggrieved local fans of the Turkish champions are very few in number but they have made pained protests on local radio, they have legitimate tickets (from United's allocation) and they will turn up.

A couple I spoke to made no bones about how quiet they will be, however. "We're ready to cheer for Leeds if that's the way not stand out," said one, a long-term resident in a small town near Leeds who has never before encountered anti-Turkish feeling. A couple of very nasty remarks have driven him twice to deny his nationality in the aftermath of the Istanbul killings. Inevitably he doesn't want his name known.

Unauthorised Galatasaray fans are very unlikely to get to Elland Road; 15 Turks were even sent back home when the official flight arrived at Leeds-Bradford airport because they were not on the police-agreed manifest of the plane which brought the Turkish team and their ridiculously sinister-looking minders. Galatasaray didn't help by making such a deal of these bodyguards - supposedly the ones who muscled round President Clinton on his recent visit to Turkey.

It is an unsporting shame that at the last minute Galatasaray turned down an invitation to attend the official United welcoming banquet. This has not endeared them to locals, especially as Ridsdale was at the comparable function in Istanbul when he got word of the murders. The Turkish team have promised, however, to wear black armbands tonight and that has won back a little respect.

The acid test, all agree, will be policing and behaviour in Leeds' pub and club-infested centre after the game, particularly if United get knocked out of the competition. The few Turkish-owned businesses - mostly restaurants and cafes - will get extra protection, and although the game will be screened across the city, most venues are banning visitors who wear club shirts or other obviously partisan gear.

Leeds is nervous but also aware of an opportunity, which has been bolstered by a trouble-free night for Galatasaray at their team hotel (Leeds players had threatening calls in their bedrooms the night before the first-leg match in Istanbul.) Tonight's match, said Assistant Chief Constable Paul Garvin, could at best be a great tribute to Loftus and Speight, and a way to link the name of Leeds with generosity and fair play.

webTitle: Who's been polishing the cabinet crystal ball?

fields.headline: Who's been polishing the cabinet crystal ball?
fields.standfirst: The latest cabinet reshuffle prediction has Peter Mandelson returning from Northern Ireland to head up Labour's election campaign. Political editor Michael White, ponders where such tales originate
fields.trailText: The latest cabinet reshuffle prediction has Peter Mandelson returning from Northern Ireland to head up Labour's election campaign. Political editor Michael White, ponders where such tales originate.
fields.body:
Where do cabinet reshuffle stories come from? Certainly not from Tony Blair or his prime ministerial predecessors, except on very rare occasions. The one member of the government who actually does decide who's up and who's down - or out - is usually far too busy to give the media much time until the reshuffle deadline looms.

Gossip in the Westminster corridors, sometimes lubricated by lunch or that extra half of bitter, is the usual source. Envy, ambition, malice, all play their part too. It is the very stuff of political manoeuvre.

The latest reshuffle flurry emerged on page one of the Sun on Thursday morning, under the byline of the formidable Trevor Kavanagh, the paper's political editor. Peter Mandelson would return from Belfast in July unless ''there are clear signs'' that the Northern Ireland peace process is reviving, he predicted.

Since the Sun scenario had Mr Mandelson returning to the cabinet office to mastermind the election strategy in tandem with Gordon Brown, that would mean another move for Mo Mowlam or her final departure from government. Ann Taylor, the chief whip, would be sacked, the paper also predicted.

All perfectly reasonable speculation for a journalist and a minister or party official over lunch. But is it true? Some of it certainly. It is known that Messrs Brown and Mandelson will run the election. That does not mean the NI Secretary will have to give up his current job to do it.

If the peace process is still stalled, he will have time on his hands and can easily commute between Millbank and Belfast. He can't be seen to leave another job with his tail between his legs (as he did when he quit the trade post over his mortgage problems in December 1998), some MPs murmur.

And he certainly can't assume he will replace Robin Cook at the Foreign Office unless he has a solid achievement to warrant it. As for the other ministers tipped for the black spot by the Sun, both have enemies, although they also have friends - especially Mo, the lorry drivers' pin-up.

Ms Mowlam is widely thought to be dissatisfied with her present role, ready to quit and write her memoirs. But would Mr Blair drop his most popular minister just before the expected May 2001 election? Probably not. Would he promote Patricia Hewitt (to keep up the gender balance) or Charles Clarke to any vacancies, as predicted?

Both Hewitt and Clarke are clever former aides to Neil Kinnock, who finally became MPs in 1997 and have risen fast up the Labour career ladder. Good tips for after the election, but not before, unless Mr Blair has good reason. A ''moment of madness on Clapham Common" or mortage misdemeanour - would do it, but at present, there's no pressing need to rock the boat.

Some senior ministers have told the prime minister that he should either stage his last pre-election reshuffle soon, so as to quell fruitless intrigue of the kind that caused grief in 1999, or he should shuffle ministers (junior as well as cabinet) as and when circumstances dictate; a sort of rolling low-key reshuffle technique.

But Mr Blair has his mind on other things at present. Northern Ireland, President Putin, a disturbing rise in the rate of pay settlements. And, of course, the Blair babe - due on May 24, two days after a crucial deadline in Belfast.

The solution to the mysterious origin of the latest Mandelson reshuffle gossip may lie in the speech he made on Europe at Canary Wharf this week - reminding people that he is pro-European, predicting that a Euro-boom is coming and that Britain will have to make a choice on the single currency sooner or later. This is nothing controversial, except perhaps to the more paranoid Euro-sceptic tabloids, but is enough to raise his profile.

Some cynics at Westminster assume that Mr Mandelson himself placed the day's speculation with Mr Kavanagh. That may be too cynical, although such things do happen. Others look for the names of senior ministers NOT mentioned in the Sun and assume it was mischief-making by one of them.

A cautionary tale on which to end. Many years ago, the late David Wood, then political editor of the Times, wrote a column that started: ''One of these days the prime minister (Harold Macmillan) is going to put his hand on the foreign secretary's (Selwyn Lloyd) shoulder and say 'enough is enough.'

It cause a sensation, not least because Selwyn Lloyd was at a ''Big Three'' summit in Geneva. Downing St denied it, everyone denied it, Wood was derided by his colleagues. The publicity ensured that Selwyn Lloyd survived. And who was Wood's source? In a rare breach of White's First Law of Reshuffles, it was Harold Macmillan himself.
fields.bodyText: Where do cabinet reshuffle stories come from? Certainly not from Tony Blair or his prime ministerial predecessors, except on very rare occasions. The one member of the government who actually does decide who's up and who's down - or out - is usually far too busy to give the media much time until the reshuffle deadline looms. Gossip in the Westminster corridors, sometimes lubricated by lunch or that extra half of bitter, is the usual source. Envy, ambition, malice, all play their part too. It is the very stuff of political manoeuvre. The latest reshuffle flurry emerged on page one of the Sun on Thursday morning, under the byline of the formidable Trevor Kavanagh, the paper's political editor. Peter Mandelson would return from Belfast in July unless ''there are clear signs'' that the Northern Ireland peace process is reviving, he predicted. Since the Sun scenario had Mr Mandelson returning to the cabinet office to mastermind the election strategy in tandem with Gordon Brown, that would mean another move for Mo Mowlam or her final departure from government. Ann Taylor, the chief whip, would be sacked, the paper also predicted. All perfectly reasonable speculation for a journalist and a minister or party official over lunch. But is it true? Some of it certainly. It is known that Messrs Brown and Mandelson will run the election. That does not mean the NI Secretary will have to give up his current job to do it. If the peace process is still stalled, he will have time on his hands and can easily commute between Millbank and Belfast. He can't be seen to leave another job with his tail between his legs (as he did when he quit the trade post over his mortgage problems in December 1998), some MPs murmur. And he certainly can't assume he will replace Robin Cook at the Foreign Office unless he has a solid achievement to warrant it. As for the other ministers tipped for the black spot by the Sun, both have enemies, although they also have friends - especially Mo, the lorry drivers' pin-up. Ms Mowlam is widely thought to be dissatisfied with her present role, ready to quit and write her memoirs. But would Mr Blair drop his most popular minister just before the expected May 2001 election? Probably not. Would he promote Patricia Hewitt (to keep up the gender balance) or Charles Clarke to any vacancies, as predicted? Both Hewitt and Clarke are clever former aides to Neil Kinnock, who finally became MPs in 1997 and have risen fast up the Labour career ladder. Good tips for after the election, but not before, unless Mr Blair has good reason. A ''moment of madness on Clapham Common" or mortage misdemeanour - would do it, but at present, there's no pressing need to rock the boat. Some senior ministers have told the prime minister that he should either stage his last pre-election reshuffle soon, so as to quell fruitless intrigue of the kind that caused grief in 1999, or he should shuffle ministers (junior as well as cabinet) as and when circumstances dictate; a sort of rolling low-key reshuffle technique. But Mr Blair has his mind on other things at present. Northern Ireland, President Putin, a disturbing rise in the rate of pay settlements. And, of course, the Blair babe - due on May 24, two days after a crucial deadline in Belfast. The solution to the mysterious origin of the latest Mandelson reshuffle gossip may lie in the speech he made on Europe at Canary Wharf this week - reminding people that he is pro-European, predicting that a Euro-boom is coming and that Britain will have to make a choice on the single currency sooner or later. This is nothing controversial, except perhaps to the more paranoid Euro-sceptic tabloids, but is enough to raise his profile. Some cynics at Westminster assume that Mr Mandelson himself placed the day's speculation with Mr Kavanagh. That may be too cynical, although such things do happen. Others look for the names of senior ministers NOT mentioned in the Sun and assume it was mischief-making by one of them. A cautionary tale on which to end. Many years ago, the late David Wood, then political editor of the Times, wrote a column that started: ''One of these days the prime minister (Harold Macmillan) is going to put his hand on the foreign secretary's (Selwyn Lloyd) shoulder and say 'enough is enough.' It cause a sensation, not least because Selwyn Lloyd was at a ''Big Three'' summit in Geneva. Downing St denied it, everyone denied it, Wood was derided by his colleagues. fields.headline: Self-defence and the law
fields.standfirst:
What are your rights of self-defence if someone breaks into your home?

Life for farmer who shot burglar
Do not make him a hero
fields.trailText: What are your rights of self-defence if someone breaks into your home?
fields.body:
The concept of self-defence has existed for centuries under common law. It allows a person to use reasonable force to defend himself from attack, prevent an attack on another person and defend his property. It also exists under statutory law.

Section 3 (1) of the Criminal Law Act 1967 states: "A person may use such force as is reasonable in the circumstances in the prevention of crime, or in effecting or assisting in the lawful arrest of offenders or suspected offenders or of persons unlawfully at large."

The self-defence argument has been accepted in the protection of property. In one case, the accused fired a gun through a hole in the door which was made by his landlady who was attempting (wrongly) to evict him from his home. The landlady was injured. Lord Hewart CJ said the accused was in the same position as a man who was defending his home and that such actions could be lawful.

But the most important aspect of the self-defence argument is whether the accused used "reasonable or proportionate" force.

In the frequently cited Palmer case, Lord Morris said: "If there has been an attack so that the defence is reasonably necessary, it will be recognised that a person defending himself cannot weigh to a nicety the exact measure of his necessary defensive action. If a jury thought that in a moment of unexpected anguish a person attacked had only done what he honestly and instinctively thought was necessary, that would be most potent evidence that only reasonable defensive action had been taken."

Under the law, if the court finds that the accused used excessive force then his argument of self defence will fail and he will be guilty of the offence charged - which is what happened with the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin, who opened fire on a gang of burglars who had entered his home. He was found guilty of murder, although he plans to appeal.

The judge in the Martin case, Mr Justice Owen, said: "The law is that every citizen is entitled to use reasonable force to prevent crime. Burglary is a crime, and a householder in his own home may think he is being reasonable but he may not be reasonable and it can have tragic consequences."

webTitle: Powell and Pressburger: The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp

fields.headline: Powell and Pressburger: The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp
fields.trailText: I choose [this] not because it is perfect. Rather, it stands out because at the time of its making during the second world war it raised so many awkward questions that Winston Churchill even tried to have it banned. It typifies Powell's unorthodox approach to the conventions of British film-making, and it was the film that one American critic has called "the British Citizen Kane"
fields.body:
I was once asked to provide a tribute to Michael Powell at the Cannes film festival. It was at short notice - Dirk Bogarde had cried off - and my audience was extremely distinguished. Powell himself was there, and I took my courage into my hands and said that there were a good many people present from the British film industry who had once done their best to decry the work of Powell, one of Britain's most justly celebrated film-makers.

It was after the making of 1960's Peeping Tom, Powell's most controversial film, that he was attacked not only by the industry but by most of the British critics. Even before that, however, his extraordinary capacity to make utterly British films - but with some of the imagination and sensibility of Bunuel - made him more suspect than contemporaries such as Hitchcock, David Lean and Carol Reed. His achievement, mostly in partnership with the writer and producer Emeric Pressburger, was immense, and his reputation is now finally secure, thanks in part to the consistent advocacy of Americans such as Martin Scorsese .

It would be perfectly in order to choose any of five or six of their films to present among one's personal best. I choose The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp not because it is perfect. Rather, it stands out because at the time of its making during the second world war it raised so many awkward questions that Winston Churchill even tried to have it banned. It typifies Powell's unorthodox approach to the conventions of British film-making, and it was the film that one American critic has called "the British Citizen Kane". But in truth it is more of a tribute to the paradoxical nature of the British character.

The film uses flashbacks to trace the lives of a young British officer and his German counterpart from the time when, as young men, they fight a duel in the Berlin of 1902 right up to the middle of the second world war. By then, Roger Livesey's Major General Clive Wynne-Candy VC has become a Blimpish old buffer (the character is based upon the cartoonist Low's Colonel Blimp). Then, Anton Walbrook's gallant German officer arrives as a sad refugee from the Nazis. The two are now fast friends, even though Candy lost his one true love (Deborah Kerr) to the German. Kerr also plays the other two women in Blimp's life, neither of whom are ultimately obtainable. It is this that gives the film its romantic and elegiac, if pessimistic edge.

Churchill's reaction was furious. He is said to have stormed into Walbrook's dressing room when he was appearing in a West End play demanding: "What's this film supposed to mean? I suppose you regard it as good propaganda for Britain." But the film, although it mourns the death of the Blimps of Britain with their old-fashioned virtues of decency and generosity, admits the necessity of their demise. We should, it suggests, finally leave the past but never forget its better aspects. This was interpreted as "black-hearted bitterness against Britain" in some quarters but, when the film was revived during the British Film Year of 1985, it received almost unanimous acclaim, although several critics mistakenly praised its recognition of a time when there was pride in being British. The truth is that it is the emotional tensions in Powell's work that renders it exceptional.

All this would be as nothing had Powell not been, admittedly much aided by Pressburger, a film-maker of great technical and imaginative ability. He could shape his stories with such flair that you could not recognise a cliche even if it stared you in the face. Admittedly Colonel Blimp is too long, but Powell's almost expressionist use of colour (aided by cinematographer Jack Cardiff), his feeling that fantasy often holds more truth than reality and his generosity of spirit towards both his central characters triumphs over the film's flaws. So too does the magnificent performance of Livesey as Blimp, a part once scheduled for Olivier who would surely have made into more of a parody. It's a great British film, and there haven't been too many of those.

webTitle: Blair declares his support for Frank Dobson

fields.headline: Blair declares his support for Frank Dobson
fields.trailText: The shape of the mayoral contest is now becoming clear.
fields.body:
The shape of the mayoral contest is now becoming clear.

There is no real desire to have the Conservatives back. People's memories aren't that short.

People now know why there are real doubts about the suitability of Ken Livingstone - doubts about policy, doubts about statements he has made, doubts about what he stands for. And every day people realise more and more that being Mayor of London is actually a very serious job. It is a policy job with real power and influence over London.

The real frustration in this contest is that despite the power of the Mayor's job, it has become a policy free zone.

Ken Livingstone says he will have a Green as his deputy but what will that mean for London? What policies has he agreed with his new partners?

Mr Norris says he wants to privatise the tube. But what is cost of that, what delay would it cause to vital work?

On transport, probably the most important issue in this election, there is still nowhere near enough focus on what the alternatives put forward by the candidates would mean.

There would be three main effects of the public sector bond scheme advocated by Ken Livingstone.

First it would mean delay. The tube needs investment now, not at some dim and distant date in the mists of time. The negotiations for the government's PPP plans are well underway. Ken Livingstone would call a halt to the whole thing if he had his way and hold back investment, possibly for years in the future.

Secondly, Ken Livingstone's proposals are a millstone of debt for London.

The independent report from the London Business School said just a couple of weeks ago that "The investment and maintenance costs over the first 15 years of the PPP are likely to be at least £2.3bn less than with bond financing."

And third, he wants the fast introduction of congestion charges to pay for his proposals - his manifesto may have left the figure out, but the cost to drivers will be 35 per day or £100 a month.

Delay, debt, congestion charges - it is a cost that Londoners should think long and hard about before casting their votes on the 4th of May.

Then there is the Conservative candidate.

The first thing he has tried to do is drop any mention that he is a Conservative. The Party that dare not speak its name. He told Time Out "I'm not standing for the Conservative Party" but however much he may try to hide it or run away from it, I have to remind Steve Norris that he is William Hague's Conservative candidate in this election.

We know what he would do for London because he's been here before as transport minister for London. He once said the jubilee line extension would be "the greatest achievement of my time in office."

The JLE has of course improved the underground but it turned out to be two years late; it was £1.9 billion over budget; its endless cost overruns meant the rest of the tube lost out on desperately needed investment; and it had to be sorted out by this government.

Overpriced, overdue and starved of investment. That was the London underground when Steve Norris was in charge.

That's the past. But in the future the Conservatives would privatise the tube and bring to London Rail Privatisation Mark II. Mr Norris said only a few months ago, "Full privatisation is the best alternative"

It is the wrong policy for three reasons:

First, like public sector bonds, privatisation would also delay new investment in the tube.

Second, Londoners would not want those parts of the underground such as safety, the running of the trains and ticketing placed in private hands. What we plan is increased investment in what remains a public service.

And thirdly, under the Tory plans privatisation is also a means to remove funds from London. The Tory manifesto at the last election said the proceeds from privatisation would not all be spent in London. They said "The majority of the remaining surplus from privatisation will be channelled into additional support for transport investment in London and elsewhere in the country".

So the choice on transport - the key issue in this campaign - is clear. Under the Conservatives London will get delay and privatisation. Under Ken Livingstone London will get delay and massive debt. With Frank Dobson and New Labour London will get the fast investment and value for money needed to create a world class underground for a world class city.

And I believe that the closer we get to polling day, the more people will turn to Frank.

If you want money into the tube fast you will turn to Frank.

If you want a candidate who will work with the police and the people of London to fight crime you will turn to Frank.

If you want a candidate who will tackle the poverty and social division that still exists in too many parts of London, you will turn to Frank.

And if you want a candidate who can represent London on the world stage, again you will turn to Frank.

So my message today is, when it comes to the issues that matter, turn to Frank.

fields.headline: Disability benefits
fields.standfirst: There are 8.7m disabled people in Britain. Patrick Barkham finds out what the government is doing for them.
fields.trailText: There are 8.7m disabled people in Britain. Patrick Barkham finds out what the government is doing for them.
fields.body:
Why are MPs concerned about disability benefits?
The social security select committee has found flaws in a private company's provision of eligibility tests for disability benefits. Sema, a company with no previous experience of medical examinations, took on the £300m contract in 1998. The MPs' report suggests that "standards are coming second to profitability". It found that the contract has an "in-built incentive" to issue more "paper" approvals for benefits claims and carry out fewer actual tests. It also criticises the lack of professionalism in the way doctors have carried out some of the tests.

What is the government doing about it?
MPs are now asking the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, to renegotiate the contract with Sema to improve its efficiency. The government may well do so. Disability benefits have risen four-fold since 1980, and the government remains concerned that each week 3,000 people move from sick pay to incapacity benefit, of whom 90% will never return to work.

What is the government doing for disabled people?
The government is torn between its desire to hold down disability costs while being seen to be an effective champion of disabled rights. Labour's manifesto did not dare broach the subject. But soon after it took office in 1997, it identified disability benefits as the target of reforming cost-cuts. However, the government points to a range of measures showing its commitment to providing disabled people with benefits, rights and job opportunities.

 Benefits: In January, the government announced two small improvements in disabled-benefit provision, worth £5.5m a year to 52,000 people. People who live in local authority homes and pay their own way will become entitled to the disability living allowance or attendance allowance, while those who spend time in hospital for respite care will be eligible for daily allowances from the day they leave hospital, instead of having their daily allowance docked by the benefit office.

 Rights: It has just launched the £11m disability rights commission, the equivalent of the commission for racial equality. The commission will work to "promote the equalisation of opportunities for disabled persons" and enforce the 1995 disability discrimination act, which makes it illegal for employers to limited access on grounds of disability (although companies with under 15 employees - covering 90% of the workforce - are exempt).

 Jobs: According to government statistics, disabled people account for nearly a fifth of the working-age population in Britain, but for only about one eighth of all in employment. More than 1m of the 2.6m disabled people out of work want to work, and the government's "new deal" for the disabled (NDDP) aims to find disabled people "relevant and appropriate employment opportunities". The disabled person's tax credit was also increased in this year's budget.

What isn't it doing?
 Last year's cutting of disability benefit in the government's welfare reform and pensions act proved controversial, with the biggest revolt to date by Labour MPs against the government. The eligibility criteria for incapacity benefit was tightened to discourage new claimants. A means test was also introduced for incapacity benefit, which claws back the £66.75-a-week benefit from people with private pensions or insurance payments, even if they are living below the poverty line (defined as half average income).

 The government went ahead with cuts, despite the fact that soon after it emerged that the department of social security saved £1.7bn in 1998/99 through underspending. The largest area of saving, even before the benefit cuts, was in disability benefits, where £754m was left unspent. This suggests that the government's much hyped pre-reform fears about the "spiralling costs" of disability benefits, were unfounded.

 The government's minimum wage has, unintentionally, had an adverse effect on disabled people's employment, according to the charity Mencap. An estimated 1,000 people with severe learning disabilities have lost their part-time jobs or had their working hours cut because employers refused to pay the £3.60 minimum wage for their work.

Are disabled people getting a better deal?
As the work of the disability rights commission will highlight, most of the problems disabled people incur are a result of prejudices in a wider society. But the work of the government is very much part of this. From this month all benefit claimants, including the disabled, must attend, on demand, compulsory interviews with a personal adviser under a streamlined benefits gateway called One. If they do not, they risk having their benefits removed. The government says it will not make disabled people work if they cannot, but its compulsory, controlling approach towards benefits, and the insensitivities of means-testing and eligibility-testing by private providers, are likely to deter some disabled people from claiming what is rightfully theirs.

A means test was also introduced for incapacity benefit, which claws back the £66.75-a-week benefit from people with private pensions or insurance payments, even if they are living below the poverty line (defined as half average income).  The government went ahead with cuts, despite the fact that soon after it emerged that the department of social security saved £1.7bn in 1998/99 through underspending. The largest area of saving, even before the benefit cuts, was in disability benefits, where £754m was left unspent. This suggests that the government's much hyped pre-reform fears about the "spiralling costs" of disability benefits, were unfounded.  The government's minimum wage has, unintentionally, had an adverse effect on disabled people's employment, according to the charity Mencap. An estimated 1,000 people with severe learning disabilities have lost their part-time jobs or had their working hours cut because employers refused to pay the £3.60 minimum wage for their work. Are disabled people getting a better deal? As the work of the disability rights commission will highlight, most of the problems disabled people incur are a result of prejudices in a wider society. But the work of the government is very much part of this. From this month all benefit claimants, including the disabled, must attend, on demand, compulsory interviews with a personal adviser under a streamlined benefits gateway called One. If they do not, they risk having their benefits removed. The government says it will not make disabled people work if they cannot, but its compulsory, controlling approach towards benefits, and the insensitivities of means-testing and eligibility-testing by private providers, are likely to deter some disabled people from claiming what is rightfully theirs. fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Terminator series in trouble after Cameron pulls out, Elian TV-movie in the offing, Meg Ryan in talks with Oliver Stone, William Shatner to star with Sandra Bullock in Miss Congeniality, and Scary Spice to hit our screens again
fields.body:
 The third instalment in the Terminator series looks in the direst trouble after James Cameron, director of the first two movies, absolutely-positively confirmed that he will not be returning for a third bite at the cherry. "Not gonna do it," Cameron quipped brusquely to reporters at a film premiere this week, and his insistence leaves the project up in the air. Up until recently, original star Arnold Schwarzenegger was enthusiastic about reprising his role as the indestructible agent of vengeance, and assured journalists that the film would shoot this year. But his involvement was always on the assumption that his old friend Cameron was behind the camera. With Cameron gone, it seems certain that Arnie will bail out too.

 The tragicomic shenanigans of Cuban kid Elian - currently caught in a tug of war between the US government and Castro's Cuba - has always had the look and feel of a TV-movie about (one of those duff ones, with lots of weeping histrionics and over-egged orchestration). No surprise, then, to learn that CBS is rumoured to be planning to immortalise the tale on celluloid just as soon as a decision is reached. If you can't wait that long, eager Elian buffs can check out a more satirical take on his story (featuring Gary Glitter, apparently) online at www.fatcent.com.

Casting couch

 Meg Ryan is in talks with Oliver Stone to star as an international aid worker opposite Kevin Costner in the director's next project, Beyond Borders. The director reputedly is desperate for Ryan to fill the part abruptly vacated by original choice Catherine Zeta Jones, after the actress became pregnant by husband Michael Douglas. Ryan is also poised to commit to another role vacated by its original star if she signs up to a starring role in the legal-eagle thriller Criminal Conversation that was initially written for Nicole Kidman. Beyond Borders begins shooting next month. Criminal Conversation (which will be produced by Tom Cruise) could go before the cameras immediately afterwards.

 William Shatner is the last piece in the Miss Congeniality jigsaw. The former Star Trek star has signed to co-star as a beauty-pageant MC in Castle RockÍs all-star comedy-thriller. Shatner joins star Sandra Bullock (playing an undercover FBI agent), Michael Caine and Matt Dillon. Miss Congeniality begins shooting in two weeks time.

 Undeterred by the train-wreck horror that was Spice: The Movie, Mel B (aka Scary Spice) is to star in the Brit-pic, Rusty, about a brassy working-class Yorkshire lass who finds wealth and fame in swinging London town. It's like they saw her life and put it on screen...

fields.headline: Passover
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about Passover, the Jewish religious holiday, on the net.
fields.trailText: 1. Today is the first day of Passover, the Jewish religious holiday commemorating the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt during the reign of the Pharaoh Ramses II.
fields.body:
1. Today is the first day of Passover, the Jewish religious holiday commemorating the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt during the reign of the Pharaoh Ramses II.

2. Pesah, to give it its Hebrew title, is named after the passing over of the Israelites' homes when God undertook the slaugter of the first born.

3. That was the last of the 10 plagues that had afflicted the Egyptians with - among other punishments - frogs, hail, locusts and rivers of blood.

4. Moses then led the Israelites from Egypt to the edge of Canaan, the promised land. Moses never reached it. He died overlooking Canaan from Mount Pisgah.

5. Passover begins each year on the 15th night of the Jewish month of Nissan. In Israel, it marks the beginning of the harvest season.

6. The most striking observation is the removal of Chametz (foods containing yeast) from the home. This is to remember the Israeli slaves who had to flee Egypt without waiting for their bread to rise.

7. Chamtez must be sold to a non-Jew or destroyed, and the same goes for the utensils used to cook it. The sedentary - those who themselves will not rise - can sell their chamtez online.

8. Matzah, an unleavened bread, is eaten. It is used in passover recipes as part of the Seder, a strictly ordered feast on the first two nights of the holiday.

9. The Haggadah (a recital) is read on the Seder night to recall the Passover story.

10. Passover lasts eight days until April 27. Next year it will begin on April 8.

fields.headline: Obituary: Edward Gorey
fields.standfirst: He created in words and pictures a surreal late-Victorian world of sudden death, threatening visitors and country-house mystery
fields.trailText: Edward Gorey, who has died aged 75 from an apparent heart attack, was known for often macabre drawings and picture-stories which gained him a worldwide cult following. More than 50 of his chapbooks are collected in the omnibus volumes Amphigorey (1972), Amphigorey Too (1975), and Amphigorey Also (1983); there are perhaps 40 more.
fields.body:
Edward Gorey, who has died aged 75 from an apparent heart attack, was known for often macabre drawings and picture-stories which gained him a worldwide cult following. More than 50 of his chapbooks are collected in the omnibus volumes Amphigorey (1972), Amphigorey Too (1975), and Amphigorey Also (1983); there are perhaps 40 more.

Although these stories frequently and wittily show children or other hapless victims coming to undeserved death, Gorey insisted there was no morbid relish involved. "I see no disparity between my books and everyday life... I write about everyday life." The everyday life of Gorey's art tends to happen in a pastiched late-Victorian or Edwardian England, coloured by the favourite reading matter of his college days (notably Ronald Firbank, Evelyn Waugh and Ivy Compton-Burnett) and a lifelong fondness for Agatha Christie.

Many American readers suspected Gorey of being English, but he was born in Chicago of a Roman Catholic newspaperman father and an Episcopalian mother. After high school he attended the Chicago School of Art for a term. After three years as a wartime clerk in the US army - largely in the Utah desert - he went to Harvard, where he majored in French. He then worked for the art department of Doubleday Anchor Books .

His first picture-book was The Unstrung Harp; or, Mr Earbrass Writes a Novel (1953), a lovingly tongue-in-cheek study of a lugubrious Edwardian novelist grappling with inspiration, distraction, publishing's eternal truths, and "the unspeakable horror of the literary life."

In the very popular The Doubtful Guest (1957), a country-house family resembling one of Compton-Burnett's is dismayed by the uninvited Guest, a mournful, furry, inexplicable creature in white tennis shoes. The finely detailed ink drawings have rhyming captions, concluding:

It came 17 years ago - and to this day

it has shown no intention of going away.

Fascination with surrealism came to the fore in The Object-Lesson (1958), whose story tumbles through artful non-sequiturs while the artwork shows increased mastery of balance and design. This led to Edmund Wilson's 1959 New Yorker appreciation of the early books - Gorey's first major critical notice. Later the Doubtful Guest was developed into a more disturbing, eyeless being with long rubbery arms, known as Figbash and partly echoing Max Ernst's protean figure Loplop. Other recurring Gorey icons are cats and the armless, featureless Black Doll; other acknowledged influences include Chinese, Japanese and Symbolist art.

Many books followed, often subverting existing forms; a favourite technique was to inject unimproving material into the Victorian template of a moral or instructive alphabet. The Gashlycrumb Tinies (1963) celebrates 26 doomed tots:

A is for Amy who fell down the stairs

B is for Basil assaulted by bears...

Much is done by implication; we see Amy only in flight and Basil merely menaced. In the ostensibly pornographic The Curious Sofa (1961) - transparently by-lined Ogdred Weary - all the frightful decadence happens out of sight, and our imaginations are set unhealthily working. The same restraint makes his one truly morbid work endurable: The Loathsome Couple (1977) distantly echoes the Moors murders. Elusiveness and a sense of unstated connections became a trademark. The Other Statue (1968) presents a country-house tragedy with tantalising clues, but not enough of them, or too many.

Gorey's Agatha Christie homage The Awdrey-Gore Legacy (1972) is not so much a detective story as an illustrated comic tool kit for assembling a Christie-style plot, but the framing material suggests another and odder mystery. The artist himself was always ready with helpful explanations. "Oh, I know that the books are about something, not what they seem to be about... but I don't know what that other thing is."

One influence from personal life was that from 1957 to 1982, Gorey attended every performance of the New York City Ballet. Hence the tragicomic ballerina's tale The Gilded Bat (1966), the sunnily in-jokey ballet vignettes of The Lavender Leotard (1973), and drawings of unlikely performances: "Sarah Blotter interpreting Wurmkast's Twelfth (the 'Apocalyptic') Symphony, Oklahoma City, 1904."

In that quarter-century of ballet attendance Gorey became notorious for vast fur coats as favoured by his characters, complemented by white tennis shoes. Other authors whose works he illustrated include Samuel Beckett, John Ciardi, TS Eliot (Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats), Edward Lear (The Jumblies, The Dong with a Luminous Nose), Saki, and Muriel Spark (The Very Fine Clock). He also drew new pictures for Aesop's fables and the Brer Rabbit stories.

Gorey successfully took his design skills to the theatre, a highlight being his melodramatically sinister sets and costumes for the 1977 Broadway production of Dracula; this brought him a Tony Award for costume design. Gorey Stories, a musical revue based on his work, played both off and on Broadway in 1978. Other honours were a 1972 American Institute of Graphic Arts award for the design of Amphigorey, World Fantasy Awards for artwork in 1985 and 1989, and an International Horror Guild art award in 1999.

Later works of note include The Raging Tide: or, The Black Doll's Imbroglio (1987), whose absurdist images of Figbash and other squabbling surreal creatures have spoof multiple-choice links - "If this doesn't make you apprehensive, turn to 19. If it does, turn to 17." - and The Haunted Tea-Cosy (1997), whose subversion of Dickensian uplift begins when an enormous beetle announces itself as the Bahhum Bug.

Flaunted eccentricities apart, Gorey was secretive about his personal life. The Reuters report of his death ends with what might easily have been the final caption in one of his own spare, bleak picture-stories, with the Black Doll brooding over disaster: "It was not clear if there were any survivors."

webTitle: United undone by Real class of Raul

fields.headline: United undone by Real class of Raul
fields.standfirst: Beckham 64, Scholes 88pen ¦ Keane 20og, Raul 50 52
fields.trailText: Manchester United 's possession of the European Cup was forfeited last night as Real Madrid , playing the better football and encouraged by an own- goal from Roy Keane, scored twice more, through Raul, early in the second half. David Beckham and Paul Scholes, with a penalty, reduced the margin of defeat but not the pain of it.
fields.body:
Manchester United 's possession of the European Cup was forfeited last night as Real Madrid , playing the better football and encouraged by an own- goal from Roy Keane, scored twice more, through Raul, early in the second half. David Beckham and Paul Scholes, with a penalty, reduced the margin of defeat but not the pain of it.

As the sole surviving English representatives in the Champions League, United carried a not unfamiliar responsibility. Chelsea's downfall in Barce-lona the previous night, moreover, had given United not so much new lessons to learn as old ones to remember.

While the holders needed to avoid the excessive initial caution of Gianluca Vialli's team, which had handed the initiative to the opposition, they also had to guard against the sort of onrush of attacking zeal which before now had allowed opponents to steal early leads on the break here.

The absence of the injured Mark Bosnich, who had saved United from defeat at the Bernabeu, was not calculated to ease the supporters' nerves. The second choice, Raimond van der Gouw, had proved himself an adequate deputy in Europe but, as Bordeaux proved, remained accident-prone.

With Savio and Steve McManaman tending to tuck in behind Raul and Fernando Morientes, Real set out to put pressure on United's centre-backs with swift exchanges of passes. And an early low centre from Roberto Carlos on the left, which just cleared the far post, would surely have brought a goal had Raul been on the end of it.

For United, Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole were tightly marked, so much depended on Ryan Giggs and Beckham spreading the play while Keane and Scholes found opportunities to drive forward from midfield. Yet it was quite a time before United gained sufficient possession to establish any sort of attacking momentum.

In fact the goal that Old Trafford feared should have arrived in the 13th minute after Gary Neville's misreading of a high ball allowed Roberto Carlos a clear run on the left. The Brazilian's pass found Morientes but Van der Gouw easily saved a weak shot.

Neville was giving United an uncomfortable rerun of his errors during the Fifa world club championship in Rio. No sooner had Yorke's head failed to find the target after meeting Giggs's precise centre than the defender passed back straight to Roberto Carlos, who was denied a shot only by the alertness of Van der Gouw.

Worse, for United, was soon to follow. In the 20th minute McManaman found Morientes who laid a pass out to Michel Salgado. Van der Gouw had Salgado's weak cross-shot covered but Keane lunged in to block it and diverted the ball into his own net.

As Iker Casillas punched clear a shot from Yorke, blocked one from Scholes and then kept out another, from Keane, United's chances of scoring at least twice to save the tie hung in the balance.

One of the most worrying aspects for United was the fact that, although Giggs was regularly turning Real's defence on the left, they were not exploiting this advantage in front of goal. Cole was convinced that, as he rose to meet the ball under the bar Aitor Karanka reached up a hand to deflect it away. Certainly the defender tried but whether he made contact was doubtful.

With Raul shooting too high after a miscue by Stam, who then deflected a centre from McManaman dangerously close to his own net, the portents for United in the second half were not promising. Yet no one could have predicted the course of events which saw Real Madrid take a 3,0 lead by the 52nd minute.

Five minutes after the break Real caught United on the break and McManaman clipped the ball to Raul, in space to his right. This time Raul did not miss, curling a shot into the far corner.

There was time for Keane to waft a valuable chance to start saving the tie over the top before Raul scored again. With the defence nowhere Redondo reached the byline and set up the striker for a tap-in.

Then in the 64th minute Beckham reminded Old Trafford of the art of the possible by outwitting a clutch of defenders before hooking a marvellous shot high into the net. Later Casillas made a point blank save to deny the substitute Ole Gunnar Solksjaer.

* Real Madrid now meet Bay ern Munich after a 3,2 aggregate win over Porto. In the last minute Jardel levelled for Porto but Thomas Linke headed the winner seconds later. Paulo Sergio scored Bayern's first.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw G. Neville, Berg (Sheringham, 62min), Stam, Irwin (Silvestre, h-t) Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs Cole (Solksjaer, 62), Yorke.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Casillas Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanka, Roberto Carlos McManaman (Julio Cesar, 89), Helguera, Redondo, Savio (Geremi, 65) Morientes (Anelka, 72), Raul.

Referee: P Collina (Italy).

webTitle: Blair accuses Livingstone of £5 car toll

fields.headline: Blair accuses Livingstone of £5 car toll
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today renewed his backing for Frank Dobson in the London mayoral race and attacked Ken Livingstone's plans for a congestion charge which he claims could cost drivers £100 a month.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today renewed his backing for Frank Dobson in the London mayoral race and attacked Ken Livingstone's plans for a congestion charge which he claims could cost drivers £100 a month.

The prime minister also claimed that Mr Dobson's support would rise as soon as the media focused on policies rather than personalities - at the same time as Labour was launching an election broadcast nicknamed Frank: the Movie, which focuses on the candidate's personal qualities.

Mr Livingstone's proposals for funding the tube with a bond scheme would mean delays and a "millstone of debt" for London, Mr Blair claimed. He said Mr Livingstone's introduction of congestion charges would cost drivers £5 per day, or £100 a month.

The prime minister's claim came on the day the London chamber of commerce, the RAC and the Freight Transport Association issued a joint warning of an "angry backlash" if congestion charges were brought in before significant improvements were made to public transport.

"While we do not oppose congestion charging in principle, motorists should be given high-quality public transport alternatives before it is put in place," said the chamber of commerce's chief executive, Simon Sperryn.

Mr Livingstone, the former Labour MP and independent mayoral candidate, responded by claiming that the government's public-private partnership (PPP) for the modernisation of the underground, backed by Mr Dobson, could cost £100m in consultants' fees alone.

"The PPP consultants' gravy-train shows once again how vital it is that the future of the underground should be decided by London," Mr Livingstone said.

Mr Dobson is the only candidate from the main parties not to back Mr Livingstone's call for "London" - and not the government - to decide future funding arrangements for the tube.

Lending his support to Mr Dobson's ailing campaign - a poll last week put him third on 15%, behind Mr Livingstone and the Tory candidate, Steven Norris - Mr Blair claimed that once the media "start looking at these policy questions there is only one candidate in this election".

"Frank is not a media candidate," he added. "He is not a showbusiness candidate, but he is a 24-hour-a-day man. He is the guy who will work night and day for these policies. He has never changed in the 20 years I have known him."

Mr Dobson also mounted a fierce personal attack on Mr Livingstone. "Strip away the chat-show talk, the gesture politics and the smarming up to every group he meets and you see what Londoners increasingly are seeing - that the emperor has no clothes."

The Liberal Democrat candidate, Susan Kramer - who was not mentioned by Mr Blair or Mr Dobson - said that Labour still had not explained how they would finance their Underground modernisation programme. "On the tube, Frank Dobson promises radical improvement by 2010, but he won't tell us how he will pay for it," she said.

The four minutes of Frank: the Movie focus squarely on Mr Dobson as an individual, in an effort to illustrate his message that he would be his own man as mayor and not a Downing Street placeman, as his critics claim.

The film is shot in a deliberately "amateur" style, mixing wobbly video footage with blurred, unposed still-photos, in order to present Mr Dobson as an unpolished, straight-talking candidate.

Intercutting between snapshots of London streets and footage of the candidate speaking straight to camera, the broadcast outlines Mr Dobson's policies on transport, jobs, playgrounds, health and drugs.

Following press reports that he has been encouraged to swear in order to show his passion, Mr Dobson uses the word "damn" in a pre-watershed broadcast, when talking about the tube. The word "Labour" is not spoken, and appears on screen only once.

The broadcast will be shown in the London area tomorrow on BBC1 and ITV, following early evening news programmes.

fields.headline: Famine threatens 10 African states
fields.trailText: Aid agencies may be hesitant about using the word "famine" to describe food shortages in the arid Ogaden region but they are convinced that a humanitarian disaster is looming in the Horn of Africa.
fields.byline: David Gough in Gode and Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Aid agencies may be hesitant about using the word "famine" to describe food shortages in the arid Ogaden region but they are convinced that a humanitarian disaster is looming in the Horn of Africa.

Unless the international community immediately steps up deliveries of food and medicine and ensures that supplies arrive in quantity in the drought-stricken refugee centres before July - when, if the rains come, the roads will be impassable - between 8m and 12m people face starvation.

Famine always arrives slowly. Crops fail, wells dry up and villages' few edible reserves are progressively exhausted. With nothing left to eat, families migrate in search of fresh pasture, turning themselves into refugees. First, the most vulnerable - children and the elderly - and then adults succumb to dehydration and malnutrition-related illnesses such as diarrhoea and TB.

That inexorable sequence of events, seen in the famines of 1984-85, may explain why the crisis appears to unfold in slow motion. Discerning exactly when a famine threatens is complicated by the abject poverty of countries constantly living at the edge of their resources. "In a normal year, 50% of children are malnourished," said Charles Walker of Oxfam.

The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation has warned that drought is spreading and famine now threatens pockets of land in 10 countries: Ethiopia, Eritrea, Burundi, Djibouti, Kenya, Rwanda, Somalia, Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania.

If the west loses interest, as aid agencies fear, the prophecy of disaster may be fulfilled.

One fact, above all, illustrates their anxieties: it takes on average two to three months from emergency food supplies being pledged by donors to their reaching the starving in Gode.

The World Food Programme, the UN agency charged with preventing mass starvation, has already drawn comparisons between events leading up to the 1984-85 famine and this year's crisis.

Fifteen years ago the preconditions also included prolonged failure of the seasonal rains and war.

This time Ethiopia is engaged in a border dispute with Eritrea which has taken 500,000 soldiers to the fronts. There are also counter-insurgency campaigns in the Ogaden itself and near the Somali border.

The war, as well as dominating the attention of the government in Addis Ababa, has added to the problems in maintaining the extended food pipeline from the west.

Ethiopia is landlocked and ships no longer able use the large ports in the Eritrea because of the war are docking at untried facilities in Djibouti and Somaliland.

"The war and the famine are competing for the same resources," said a western diplomat in the Ethiopian capital. "There have definitely been incidents when food aid has not been used as the donors intended."

But the war should not lull western governments into expressing their disapproval through disengagement, Oxfam insists.

"The conflict cannot be used as an excuse for not giving humanitarian aid," Mr Walker said. "People are dying, they can't be used as political levers."

What has added to the sense of impending crisis is the shortfall of food reserves from last year. After the last famine, the Ethiopian government agreed to keep a reserve of 300,000 tonnes. Last year, Oxfam maintains, the European Union promised 150,000 tonnes. Extra food was taken from the reserve in anticipation of the shipment, but only 75,000 tonnes arrived.

Karl Harbo, the EU's delegate in Addis Ababa, denies that the community failed to keep its promises. "The EU has irrevocably pledged 540,000 metric tonnes over the next 12 months, of which 430,000 will be shipped by the end of this year," he said.

But like aid workers, he believes the situation may deteriorate before it gets better. "I won't be surprised if in a few months we see the same thing happening in the north as we are now seeing in the south."

So far the nomads of Ogaden and a few other districts have suffered most. The fear is that the more densely populated northern highlands of Wollo province are next in line.

Catherine Bertini, the WFP director who visited the region last week, said that her aim now was "to make sure that what has happened to these children in Gode doesn't happen anywhere else in Ethiopia".

Ethiopia is one of the poorest countries in the world: 45% of the population live on less than $1 a day. Life expectancy is only 43 years, the fifth lowest among the world's 189 countries. Since 1985 its population has risen from 45m to 64m.

"This is potentially the worst it has been since the famine of 1984-85," said Lynn Geldof, who works in Unicef's office in Geneva but spent four years in the region. "The elements are in place for it to become a widespread famine."

fields.headline: British journalistic blunders
fields.trailText:
"Julian Dicks West Ham United is everywhere. It's like they've got eleven Dicks on the field."
Metro Radio Sports Commentary
fields.body:
"Julian Dicks West Ham United is everywhere. It's like they've got eleven Dicks on the field."
Metro Radio Sports Commentary

Listener: "My most embarrassing moment was when my artificial leg fell off at the altar on my wedding day."
Simon Fanshawe:"How awful! Do you still have an artificial leg?"
Talk Radio

Interviewer: "So did you see which train crashed into which train first?"
15-year-old: "No, they both ran into each other at the same time."
BBC Radio 4

Presenter to paleontologist:"So what would happen if you mated the woolly mammoth with, say, an elephant?"
Expert: "Well in the same way that a horse and a donkey produce a mule, we'd get a sort of half-mammoth.
Presenter: "So it'd be like some sort of hairy gorilla?"
Expert: "Er, well yes, but elephant shaped, and with tusks."
GLR

Robert Kilroy-Silk: "Did you mean to get pregnant?"
Girl: "No. It was a cock-up."
Kilroy

Grand National winning jockey Mick Fitzgerald: "Sex is an anticlimax after that!"
Desmond Lynam: "Well, you gave the horse a wonderful ride, everyone saw that."
BBC

Jon Snow: "In a sense, Deng Xiaoping's death was inevitable, wasn't it?"
Expert: "Er, yes."
Channel 4 News

"As Phil De Glanville said, each game is unique, and this one is no different to any other."
John Sleightholme BBC1

"If England are going to win this match, they're going to have to score a goal."
Jimmy Hill, BBC

"Beethoven, Kurtag, Charles Ives, Debussy: four very different names."
Presenter, BBC Proms, Radio 3

"Cystitis is a living death, it really is. Nobody ever talks about it, but if I was faced with a choice between having my arms removed and getting cystitis, I'd wave goodbye to my arms quite happily."
Louise Wener [of Sleeper] in Q Magazine

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Contact sport

Uncommunicative communications companies seem fated to remain a fixture on this page. Localtel had the honour of coming top in Oftel's recent list of most-complained-about telecoms companies. Among its winning traits were the difficulty in getting through to customer services and failure to reply to letters. Peter Gladman from Kent found amusement in the company's slogan "Customer service lies at the heart of our company" because for five months he phoned, faxed, posted and emailed his complaints and never received a word in return. When he has secured a human in customer services he's told he cannot talk to anyone in authority and someone will call him back. They never do. "All I want is for someone who is in a position to help a customer to ring me," he says.

 "You can't speak to anyone in head office," an operator tells Consumer. "Leave your details and someone will call you back." Surprisingly, they do. "We've had problems with oversubscribed services and an overloaded billing system," admits a spokesman. "We have now opened two new call centres." He has personally resolved Gladman's problem.

The immortal account

Alex Hall of London has meanwhile been an unwilling customer of Telnet Residential, a telecoms company based in Cheshire. When he moved home last September he was unable to get through on the customer service line and sent emails, faxes and letters terminating his account. Telnet was having none of it, and helped itself to £25.30 two months after he had moved. Hall cancelled his direct debit instruction and eventually wrested the money back. But the bills keep on coming.

 "This is one of the most unbelievable mistakes I've seen," cries a Telnet spokesman. "Somebody changed Mr Hall's address on the database but forgot to change the phone number, so whenever the user of his old line made a call, we'd bill Mr Hall." Hall has now been freed and duly grovelled to.

Mercury failing

Mobile phones create even bigger headaches (in both senses). Alan White has also been receiving bills for an account he doesn't have. In his case One2One is the culprit. "I am not a customer of this company. I don't even have a mobile, yet the bills keep coming and every time I ring I'm told someone will call me back. They never do and I'm worried my credit rating will be affected."

 One2One says the phantom account was set up last November and suspended three days later. "But he continued to receive bills," says a spokeswoman, "because he had to send in the bills he'd received because we can't rely on people saying that their account was not set up by them." Such is the logic of big business! The in-house fraud department is investigating.

Conflicting signals

Oxford student Jonathan Sacerdoti would happily pay his One2One bills if that enabled him to make calls. But while his mobile works fine in London, he says he's unable to get a decent line among the dreaming spires. One2One informed him that he was, on the contrary, enjoying excellent reception.

 "There are a couple of areas that need boosting and we have embarked on an investment programme in the Oxford area," says a spokeswoman. Prospective buyers are advised to log on to www.one2one.co.uk and enter their postcode to find out what sort of reception they can expect.

Will pay, can't pay

A Lloyd of London bought himself a prepaid phone from BT Cellnet last summer and found he was unable to top up his balance with his credit card. Cellnet blamed a faulty handset and dispatched a replacement which, despite promises to the contrary, was programmed with a new phone number. However, the balance has still not been transferred from old phone to new and Cellnet has now decided too much time has elapsed for the debit to be traced.

 Consumer has slightly more luck after one phone call, but sadly the only remedy seems to be to refund the £70 Lloyd spent on the phone. Cellnet says the cheque's in the post and apologises for the torturous saga.

webTitle: Relief for EU as Spain signs up to Gibraltar deal

fields.headline: Relief for EU as Spain signs up to Gibraltar deal
fields.standfirst: New cooperation frees European legislation block
fields.trailText: The Spanish government yesterday welcomed the deal it had reached with Britain over Gibraltar, a source of dispute between the two countries for almost 300 years.
fields.body:
The Spanish government yesterday welcomed the deal it had reached with Britain over Gibraltar, a source of dispute between the two countries for almost 300 years.

But the Spanish foreign minister, Abel Matutes, cautioned that the latest settlement did not mean that Spain had abandoned its claim to Gibraltar. "It does not address the sovereignty question," he said.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said he hoped it would "improve the climate of dialogue" over the tiny outpost of 28,000 people which Britain has held since the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713.

"We've achieved it without surrendering a single dot on our commitment that Gibraltar is British territory," Mr Cook said.

Gibraltar, usually unhappily caught between the two, also expressed contentment with the new arrangements. Gibraltar's chief minister, Peter Caru ana, told a special meeting of the assembly yesterday that the agreement would allow co-operation between the Gibraltar and Spanish police to help fight crime.

Spain, which has launched military actions over the centuries aimed at winning back the Rock, had become alarmed that Gibraltar had shown signs of increasing autonomy. At present it is a British overseas territory.

Anxious to prevent direct ties between Gibraltar and the European Union, Spain had stacked up a series of obstacles, and had been blocking EU directives. It had also refused to deal directly with the local authority in Gibraltar.

Almost all these problems have now been resolved. The settlement, which Britain and Spain have been negotiating behind the scenes for the last eight months, means that:

· Gibraltarian documents, diplomatic contacts and financial and judicial decisions that extend outside its territory have to be rubber-stamped by Britain, an authority Spain recognises.

· Gibraltarians, who faced problems travelling around Europe, will now have their identity cards accepted.

· Spain will also recognise identity cards issued to Gibraltar residents, after the local authority agreed to clarify the territory's status on the cards.

· The Spanish police, who had accused Gibraltar of being a haven for traffickers, will work more closely with the Gibraltar police.

· Marriages and divorces in Gibraltar will be recognised throughout the European Union.

· Banks and other financial institutions in Gibraltar will be able to spread their services throughout the European Union.

· To get round Spanish objections to direct links with Gibraltar, communications between Gibraltar and Spain will be conducted between a "post-box" at the Foreign Office in London.

The big remaining problem is over the lack of any representation by Gibraltar in the European parliament.

The Rock of ages

1939-45 - Civilian population is evacuated. Rock is key point in fight against U-boats.

1967 - Gibraltarians vote 12,000 to 44 to stay in UK.

1969 -Closure of frontier and all direct communication with mainland. New constitution granted by UK.

1973 - Gibraltar joins the EEC with Britain.

1985 - Frontier gates fully reopen.

fields.headline: As if by magic...
fields.standfirst: Fancy throwing a glamorous dinner party but haven't got time to shop? Well, help is at hand. Gourmet cookery kits can now be ordered over the internet   and delivered straight to your door. Jess Cartner-Morley puts one to the test
fields.trailText: There is a delicatessen not too far from where I live where the lasagne is legendary. The secret? They make it in your own dish, so it looks like you cooked it. All you have to do is drop off your favourite ovenproof dish in the morning, pick it up on the way home from work and then heat it up. Sneaky, yes, but also surely a symptom of the new habit of staying in the office until what used to be called suppertime, and then expecting to have time to knock up a chichi meal for your friends.
fields.body:
There is a delicatessen not too far from where I live where the lasagne is legendary. The secret? They make it in your own dish, so it looks like you cooked it. All you have to do is drop off your favourite ovenproof dish in the morning, pick it up on the way home from work and then heat it up. Sneaky, yes, but also surely a symptom of the new habit of staying in the office until what used to be called suppertime, and then expecting to have time to knock up a chichi meal for your friends.

One forward-thinking delicatessen can't fill an ever-widening gap in the market, but maybe the internet can. Leapingsalmon.com, the brainchild of Cambridge graduate net entrepreneurs James Marshall and Peter Kenyon, is cooking to go: an upscale takeaway/dinner party hybrid, which blends the laziness of ordering in with the look-aren't-I-clever benefits of cooking.

All you have to do is log on to the website by 12 noon (or the day before, if you're out of central London), choose a dish (say, melanzane and taleggio ravioli in a butter and pine kernel sauce), part with around £15 to £20 via credit card, and a "coolbag" will be delivered - to your office by 6pm, or your home between 6pm and 7.30pm.

The coolbag (in boy-friendly steel grey; one tester observed, "You could say you were carrying your hard disk in it") arrives ready for you to take home, and contains all the ingredients you need - even things like butter, lemon, sugar, and a recipe to make the meal in less than 30 minutes.

Given a fridge stuffed full of gorgeous fresh produce, knocking up a meal in 30 minutes is no problem, but there are always days when stocks run low through lack of time. The truly time-saving part of the leapingsalmon.com idea is being able to produce food (or more specifically, food that isn't pasta and tomato sauce) without having to shop.

For me - and I'd hazard a guess that this is normal - the difference between everyday supper and dinner-party food is that the former revolves around whatever is in the fridge, whereas the latter revolves around what I think everyone would like to eat. But when time constraints mean that food will have to be bought on the way home from work, or at lunchtime, any recipe which requires an ingredient that Sainsbury's aren't likely to have in stock has to be struck off the list.

The words "now available in many specialist stores" have me turning the page double quick. Moreover, the idiot-proof tone of the leapingsalmon.com recipes give the impression that the target customer is the type who thinks a well-stocked larder means having two bottles of Absolut vodka.

So on test day, I bypassed the tetchy after-work supermarket crowds and arrived home an hour earlier and considerably less frazzled. Leapingsalmon.com grades its meals from easy to difficult, so I had opted to try out an easy recipe (chargrilled salmon in lemon and watercress sauce with spinach roulade, roasted peppers and new potatoes) and a difficult one (roast breast of duck in caramelised red onion and port sauce with French beans, carrots, and mashed potato infused with truffle oil).

Dinner a la leapingsalmon. com is a totally different kettle of fish to "proper" cooking. It felt more like a chemistry experiment than making supper. There were endless tiny plastic boxes: the meat was pre-sliced, the vegetables trimmed, the creme fraiche measured out. All the difficult bits had been done - the salmon kit contained ready-made stock, wine and cornflour mixture, while the duck featured a tub of port gravy.

In fact, the most taxing moment of the whole enterprise was brought upon myself when I took all the boxes for both meals out of the coolbags, then couldn't work out which tubs went with which recipe.

Once I had that licked, it honestly couldn't have been easier. In fact it was so easy that I got a bit bored. The duck was actually no more difficult than the salmon - for example, the mash with truffle oil was a matter of tipping the ready-made mash into a saucepan and stirring in the oil. The chopping board barely had a walk-on part. Each meal was ready in well under the 30 minutes promised. When it came to the moment of reckoning, the duck looked pretty on the plate, I thought, what with the restaurant-esque caramelised onions and the pretty, leafy baby carrots, although my testers (who knew I hadn't "really" cooked it) were less than overawed.

The salmon, on the other hand, looked decidedly underwhelming: calling it chargrilled is a bit misleading - unless you have a griddle pan (and it doesn't seem to me that these kits are aimed at the griddle-owning cook) it is baked instead.

The duck and salmon themselves were very good quality, although it was the sugar-sweet carrots and crunchy French beans served with the duck that garnered the highest praise. The pre-prepared mash didn't fool anyone. "A bit like space food," commented my eagle-eyed testers. The duck was undoubtedly a suitably impressive meal for £19.90 (for two generous portions) and 25 minutes' work.

The salmon, however, had an air of the emperor's new clothes - the spinach roulade was too pointlessly fancy for my taste and the sauce was bland. Salmon and potatoes are always a winner, but at £16.70 for the kit you are clearly paying way over the odds for two salmon fillets, a box of new potatoes, some butter and lemon. But if you really don't have time to go to the supermarket (or you truly need a recipe to boil new potatoes) the mark-up might be worth it to you.

I can't pretend I thought it was as entertaining or as satisfying as really cooking. The ingenuity required for cooking - working out timings, experimenting, making a last-minute plan B when a sudden inexplicable shortage of a crucial ingredient occurs - is part of the fun. What's more, this kind of hand-holding seems to reinforce the illusion that cooking is something terrifically difficult, which it's not. But for occasions when you want to get home at 7.15pm and have time to get changed, tidy the house and produce a dinner-party looking meal by 8pm, you can't argue with it.

A few tips if you're planning to do the leapingsalmon. com thing and pretend you've been slaving at the stove all day. Decant the ingredients into bowls. You run the risk of looking a bit over-organised and Blue Peter-ish, but otherwise the plastic tubs will give you away straight off. And if your fridge is totally bare, try a little decoy shopping to flesh out this Masterchef persona: at least, make sure there's milk and bread.

And guys, if you're hoping your new-found Jamie Oliver-type talent will win you points in the eyes of the laydeez - one gets the feeling this is the market where the kit will find its greatest fans - at least make sure you can stretch to breakfast in bed.

The online gourmet cookery shops

www.toptable.co.uk
The biggest online restaurant service in the UK- and it's free. Backers Gary Rhodes and Alex Ferguson have persuaded leading culinary lights to set aside their best tables for site users, and while you pay in full when you eat, you save on phone calls. Most of the 500-odd restaurants are in London, with nods to Manchester and Leeds, but a European service looms.

www.book2eat.com
This booking service doesn't go for the big names, but offers an excellent (free) recommendations service. Booking is via grids, which show alternatives if they can't find the table or time you specify. London only.

www.leapingsalmon.co.uk
See above.

www.roomservice.co.uk
Roomservice's dinner-suited couriers transport restaurant-prepared dishes to your door within the hour, from kitchens as diverse as Babe Ruth's and Veeraswamy. Delivery is £4 per restaurant, with a minimum spend of £10 for each you pick from.

www.lobster.co.uk
A site that offers chocolate and champagne, as well as food you can actually live on, including, of course, the eponymous crustacean (from £7.50). Same-day delivery in London, or the next nationwide, for £4.95.

www.cheesemongers.co.uk
Paxton and Whitfield, the UK's oldest cheesemongers, sell a sample of their range online, including gift packs with port thrown in (from around £30); £7.50 delivery.

www.hamper.com
Clearwater hampers offer classic hampers - picnic staples, moving up to smoked salmon, port and stilton - from around £20, and more; add £4 for delivery.

www.fortnumandmason. co.uk
Classy site with a limited range. Go for champers and hampers; "carriage" is £5 per delivery. An online "shopping assistant" displays your order details while you browse, making it easier to keep a grip on your spending.

www.morel.co.uk
Morel Bros, Cobbett and Son have been online since 1996, and in the fine foods business for nearly 200 years before that, so it's all good stuff, if not a speedy service - 10 working days in the UK. Delivery is £3.95 standard, plus a £7.95 "perishables" charge if you succumb to any of the fish, meat, cheeses, or sticky puddings on display.

www.smokedproduce.co.uk
Simon MacDonald's award-winning food comes direct from his traditional-style smokery in the Scottish Highlands. Smoked everything, from salmon to ostrich to cheese, plus recipes.

www.goodfooddirect.co.uk
A plain, functional online delicatessen that offers just what it says. Products are selected from specialist suppliers and shipped to you within seven days (48 hour-delivery is possible, but costs £9.99, rather than the standard £3.95).

www.vegnet.co.uk
"Ultra-fresh" fruit, veg and salad from this Lancashire-based company, who boast "cheapest prices". Most of the produce is home-grown. Bulk shopping is best as delivery starts from £8.99 and decreases with bigger orders.

www.deliceavenue.com
A French site, although there's an English version, and a currency converter if you don't fancy paying in francs or euros. There's a tour of French gastronomy, plus "catering corner", which helps you to compose a gourmet feast. To your door in three days.

www.neuhaus.co.uk
Jean Neuhaus claims to sell the finest Belgian chocolates. They are grouped into collections priced from £16.25, including delivery.
