webTitle: Question: What do you save by buying booze online (apart from shoe leather and arm muscle)? Answer: Up to 15%

fields.headline: Question: What do you save by buying booze online (apart from shoe leather and arm muscle)? Answer: Up to 15%
fields.standfirst: Claire Phipps surfs the net in search of liquid refreshment
fields.trailText: Who buys wine on the internet, anyway? Online grocery shopping, I can understand - it saves you from the trolleys and the queues and the carrier bags that split. But off-licences are fairly calm, fairly safe places. Pop in for a bottle or two, scan the special offers, but plump for the chardonnay; boring, I know, but it slips down easily and it's never, well, wrong.
fields.body:
Who buys wine on the internet, anyway? Online grocery shopping, I can understand - it saves you from the trolleys and the queues and the carrier bags that split. But off-licences are fairly calm, fairly safe places. Pop in for a bottle or two, scan the special offers, but plump for the chardonnay; boring, I know, but it slips down easily and it's never, well, wrong.

Still, I log on in the interest of research and wonder where to start. There are a few names that I know, more that I don't, and there are some that are vaguely familiar from the shop shelves I pass on the way to the chardonnay. I know nothing about wine, but would never admit this in the local offie. Online, this isn't a problem.

If you're someone who does know their wines, then you can dive right in. There are vintage charts, tasting notes . . . just tap in your favourite wine producer and 12 bottles of their finest will hit the doorstep the next day. Some sites will even plan a cellar for you, and ensure that you're always stocked up on the essentials.

Berry Bros and Rudd, established in the 17th century, is one of several wine merchants who are offering the fruits of their expertise online. Their website, established in 1995, was designed to cater for their customers abroad. A relaunch last year is seeking to attract buffs and novices alike, and now 75% of their customers are from the UK.

"We're trying to make it more accessible," explains BBR's Nicolle Croft. "There is a lot of information plus reports online, but we also have a dedicated internet shop manager, who answers emails from customers. The personal touch is still really important."

I'm discovering this to be true on my trek through the sites. Faced with literally thousands of bottles to choose from, recommendations, bestseller lists and customer comments are a lifeline: if so many net shoppers are plumping for the 1998 Domaine Balland Sancerre, I might just give it a try.

Nicolle Croft agrees that online ordering has encouraged people to be more adventurous in their choice of tipple: "Ordering from the comfort of your own home, there's no need to feel embarrassed or intimidated. And the fact that we are well established, and we've got the royal warrants, gives people that security. We fulfil what we promise." However, it's not just fine drinking that I'm looking for online. Wine sites abound, and can cover almost every conceivable taste, but beer is another matter.

Click to enjoyment.co.uk, the site launched by the off-licence group that owns the Thresher and Wine Rack chains, and you'll find it's great on wines, OK on spirits, but passes on the pints. "The only competition we have at the moment is the supermarket sites," says Will Amies, marketing director of lastorders.com, which can oblige with crates of lager (and stout and cider and bitter). "We're not specialist, we're populist. People want booze delivered to their door - they don't want to have to lug crates home from the off-licence. And we do the brands they know."

So, what do you save by buying online, apart from your arm muscles? Up to 15% is the answer. Unlike food sites, alcohol e-tailers are falling over themselves to cut prices. I make a mental note of those sites that offer refunds if I manage to find the same wine cheaper on the high street (while doubting that I'll be able to remember the labels correctly). And, having been tempted into the world of online booze, it's refreshing to find that most of the orders arrive, carefully packaged, the next day.

"It is actually a viable alternative to the shop," says Amies, although Croft recounts a story of a customer who visited the London BBR shop before ordering online, "just to feel safe". Almost uniquely in e-shopping, the "safety" factor works both ways: online alcohol sales rely on the companies being able to trust their customers. Lastorders warns on its entrance page that shoppers must be over 18, and the Drinks Direct site refuses to accept Switch cards.

"Most under-18s don't have access to credit cards, and we've had not one reported incident of an underage shopper," says Amies.

Most sites warn that deliveries will not be made if the recipient appears to be underage. AmiVin.com even carries a health warning, cautioning against excessive consumption of its wares.

Even the UK's licensing laws, currently poised for an overhaul, don't present too many difficulties for the sites; shoppers can buy online at any time of day or night, says Croft. The limitations are logistical, rather than legal: delivery times are restricted to hours determined by couriers and the post office.

So, no problems at all then? Well, Amies confides, there was a tricky moment when Lastorders got its licence in Edinburgh. "They came round to hammer up the licence that usually goes above the pub door, but nobody knew where to put it. Above our servers?"

"The only competition we have at the moment is the supermarket sites," says Will Amies, marketing director of lastorders.com, which can oblige with crates of lager (and stout and cider and bitter). "We're not specialist, we're populist. People want booze delivered to their door - they don't want to have to lug crates home from the off-licence. And we do the brands they know." So, what do you save by buying online, apart from your arm muscles? Up to 15% is the answer. Unlike food sites, alcohol e-tailers are falling over themselves to cut prices. I make a mental note of those sites that offer refunds if I manage to find the same wine cheaper on the high street (while doubting that I'll be able to remember the labels correctly). And, having been tempted into the world of online booze, it's refreshing to find that most of the orders arrive, carefully packaged, the next day. "It is actually a viable alternative to the shop," says Amies, although Croft recounts a story of a customer who visited the London BBR shop before ordering online, "just to feel safe". Almost uniquely in e-shopping, the "safety" factor works both ways: online alcohol sales rely on the companies being able to trust their customers. Lastorders warns on its entrance page that shoppers must be over 18, and the Drinks Direct site refuses to accept Switch cards. "Most under-18s don't have access to credit cards, and we've had not one reported incident of an underage shopper," says Amies. Most sites warn that deliveries will not be made if the recipient appears to be underage. AmiVin.com even carries a health warning, cautioning against excessive consumption of its wares. Even the UK's licensing laws, currently poised for an overhaul, don't present too many difficulties for the sites; shoppers can buy online at any time of day or night, says Croft. The limitations are logistical, rather than legal: delivery times are restricted to hours determined by couriers and the post office. So, no problems at all then? Well, Amies confides, there was a tricky moment when Lastorders got its licence in Edinburgh. "They came round to hammer up the licence that usually goes above the pub door, but nobody knew where to put it. Above our servers?"

fields.headline: A tale of two shoppers
fields.standfirst: Justine Roberts describes the trials and tribulations of doing her supermarket shopping online. Opposite: the family who fell in love with buying groceries on the web
fields.trailText: There are quite a few advantages to our new house - at least, there will be, when the builders have finally taken their leave and I can reclaim my worldly goods from storage. One of the least anticipated was discovering that by moving a few hundred yards along the road we've propelled ourselves into the catchment area for Tesco Direct.
fields.body:
There are quite a few advantages to our new house - at least, there will be, when the builders have finally taken their leave and I can reclaim my worldly goods from storage. One of the least anticipated was discovering that by moving a few hundred yards along the road we've propelled ourselves into the catchment area for Tesco Direct.

No longer would I have to listen enviously to friends describing how nice young men in blue and white vans dropped bags of freshly packed groceries at their doors. Now I too could summon the supermarket to my doorstep at the touch of a button or two. No more wrestling with defective trolleys, no more bribing compliance from my 18-month-old twin daughters with half the crisp counter and no more discovering decaying avocados nestling in a dark corner of the car weeks later.

Surely online shopping was the embodiment of Tony Blair's new Britain: efficient, convenient and hi-tech? Well, yes and no. Grocery shopping online, although not as testing as a heaving supermarket on a Saturday mid-morning, nevertheless has its frustrations.

For a start, it takes a long time. Much longer than I thought it would. In Tesco's case, its somewhat sluggish site seems as if it's in dire need of a double espresso. Maybe it feels that way because I'm more used to buying books from super-slick Amazon - a pastime that can empty your savings account faster than you can say: "Add to basket."

Conversely, on the Tesco site I regularly take a good hour to spend £29.50. One reason is that, every so often, you lose connection and have to log in again. When this first happened I was sure the carefully selected contents of my basket had disappeared into to cyberspace to curdle and decay, but happily they were waiting for me on my return, minus the most recent addition of disposable cutlery.

There were other downsides that I hadn't anticipated. Namely, no facility to rummage at the back of the babyleaf salad selection to haul out one wearing next week's sell-by date or, for that matter, any way of picking the least eccentrically shaped Maris Pipers.

Also, although the site does offer information on some of the goods on offer, including ingredients and nutritional facts, it doesn't provide any cooking instructions. Given that my kitchen currently consists of a microwave, a kettle and toaster, this is crucial information. If the three-bean vegetarian chilli comes in a foil container, it's no good to me. What's more, I suspect that when my kitchen re-emerges from its reconstructive surgery, I'll be just as anxious to know if the macaroni cheese on offer is suitable for home freezing. All these things you can read on the packet in the shop, but not online.

A further limitation, for now at least, is that net shopping is no good for bargain hunters. If you're one of those people who only buy the stuff that's three for the price of two, or promising 4,000 club card points, then, for the moment, it seems you are destined for actual, rather than virtual, shopping.

And if you're just downright short of ideas or not particularly hungry, you're probably better off hopping in the car. They haven't yet produced virtual aisles and there's a distinct lack of pictures. As someone who's recently been plunged into the business of web publishing, I understand Tesco's dilemma all too well: mouth-watering pictures would be great, but would slow down the site even more. Nevertheless, a five-word description of an iced ring doughnut is never quite as enticing as seeing one in the flesh. Consequently, I never seem to buy quite enough in one "trip", which, given the flat fiver delivery charge, is very unsound economics.

Despite the limitations of the service, however, I find myself drawn back week after week. I wouldn't say settling down in front of the Compaq with a nice glass of Rioja and the kids safely tucked up in bed is the most thrilling way to spend an evening, but I've had a lot worse. Next day, usually pretty much on cue (you choose a two-hour delivery slot), up roll those nice young men in their blue and white van, and with them comes a real sense of achievement. Not only have I done the groceries, but I too am modern, efficient and hi-tech.

And just think: soon you'll be able to do it anywhere, from your mobile phone. In bus queues, in dentists' waiting rooms, at the theatre. And there's no doubt that shopping sites will get faster and faster, as chips become ever more powerful and servers more reliable. With all the time this will free up, I'll have to find something else to do. Maybe I'll go to the shops.

 Justine Roberts runs www.mumsnet.com, a website offering product recommendations, chat and advice for parents of 0-10s.

'My nightmare is over'

The family trip to the supermarket used to be torture for Jonathan Rogers. But now that he's discovered online shopping, there's no turning back

I used to quite enjoy going to the supermarket. When you're single and there's a Tesco Metro nearby open until 10pm, it's not too bad at all. Most of my groceries fitted into two bags, and being able to shop late at night seemed one of the best things about living in the city. And there was always the outside chance of meeting your soulmate among the broccoli and iceberg lettuce.

Then (not at a supermarket, I should add) I met my girlfriend Lindsay and her 14-month-old son Kiran. Suddenly I was no longer shopping for a partner.

What used to be a gentle trip - a magazine here, some butter there - became a full-on nightmare. Shopping with a child is a race against the clock; you have to be quick otherwise he gets bored and throws a tantrum, which is a cue for disapproving glances from childless shoppers. It's certainly not a pleasure, and after you have all the shopping you'll need for the next week, you are confronted with several queues from hell to choose from - and believe me, you will make the wrong choice.

The express checkout is a distant memory. And the grief doesn't stop there; the miserable checkout staff, the struggle home with cheap bags and swollen fingers - the list goes on and on. So when a friend of mine told me about Tesco Direct, I was more than ready to listen.

You choose all your groceries online, and the store picks them out for you and delivers them to your door for just £5. It sounded too good to be true. Surely, I assumed, they were bound to supply you with the wrong items, fob you off with less-than-fresh food and, following the proud tradition of British deliveries, make you wait in all day on a Saturday.

However, the desire to palm off my aisle misery on to someone else was too great and £5 didn't seem much for that kind of peace of mind, so I went for it. With Kiran distracted by the Teletubbies, Lindsay and I navigated through the virtual store, got what we wanted, and paid by credit card. After this, we were given a selection of delivery dates and a choice of two-hour periods on those dates. The food duly arrived on time, it was fine, and I was converted.

The store had got all the items right, and those that were out of stock were replaced with the next best thing (pink grapefruits became red, that kind of thing). Furthermore, we were able to order Thomas the Tank Engine ham slices for Kiran without the public humiliation. Another plus point was that, when shopping online, you tend to stick to a list, and so avoid buying those superfluous items that you convince yourself you absolutely have to have when you're there in person.

Not being able to see what you're buying is a disadvantage, but the descriptions are good, and after a million trips you tend to know what everything looks like anyway. The store you choose from is the biggest in the area, so the selection is immense; mine is Colney Hatch, a huge hypermarket with 5,000 car spaces. A far cry from my Stroud Green Road Tesco Metro days.

The only problems we have experienced are the usual ones associated with the internet - if you are logged on at the same time as too many other people, the servers can be slow. But at least when this happens you can put a record on, or make a coffee. And the one time I had to call the support line, I was given excellent and friendly advice by someone who had clearly gone to a different charm school from his till-operating colleagues. I have also been sent software that allows you to shop offline, thus saving on phone bills.

Despite all this, internet shopping hasn't won me over completely. I still have anxieties, for example, about giving personal details over the web. (My girlfriend, meanwhile, is a serial online shopper who, she assures me, has never been ripped off.) There are still certain things I would prefer to buy in person, such as records and clothes. But for something soul-destroying like weekly food shopping, the net is a life-saver. Now, if only Ikea could do the same thing.

The online supermarkets

www.tesco.co.uk

The giant among online grocers, with more customers than any of its rivals. More than 100 stores, most in the south-east, currently take part in the TescoDirect scheme; by the end of the year, 90% of the population should be within reach of the electronic aisles. Choose from 20,000 product ranges - in-store special offers apply - and arrange a two-hour delivery slot. Some stores deliver on Sundays.

www.sainsburys.co.uk

Sainsbury's Orderline service offers around 15,000 of its in-store ranges online, although it's mostly customers within the M25 who are benefiting at present. The service will be shifting out of stores to dedicated picking centres this year, bringing it to more shoppers outside London. Next-day delivery is available; it costs £5 a pop.

www.waitrose.com

Companies, rather than individuals, must sign up to this scheme, which charges nothing for delivery. No need to stay in waiting for the van either, as they drop the groceries at the office. Those without a car - or, indeed, a workplace - must make do with wine or fresh organics, which WaitroseDirect will send straight to your door within 48 hours.

www.budgens.co.uk

In a rebuff to the trend to serve south-east shoppers, Budgens Direct started its online service in its Runcorn heartland. The usual two-hour delivery slot applies, though customers must pay for groceries on arrival. Office deliveries, too; these don't incur the normal £5 charge.

www.marks-and-spencer.co.uk

Not with the front-runners in the online shopping race, but offers a range of wines for home delivery, with the trademark returns policy. Gorgeous pictures of food abound on the site, though, and bosses recently announced their intention to expand to include some of their luxury food ranges. www.icelandfreeshop. com A pioneer of home shopping, and the only one to claim a nationwide service, covering 97% of the population. Delivery is free, but you must spend a minimum of £40 and live within 10 miles of a store (three miles within the M25). GM-free, too.

www.asda.co.uk

Ventured into online shopping last year with asda@home in Croydon and Watford, but there are no details on their website.

www.co-op.co.uk

Big on banking, but short on food: stay-at-home shoppers are currently restricted to wines or domestic appliances.

www.safeway.co.uk

Still trialling EasiOrder in Basingstoke; a palm-sized organiser compiles and sends lists to the store.

www.24-7.co.uk

The online arm of Somerfield, not yet fully operational, promises 5,000 product lines and a large organic range, plus ordering through interactive TV.

www.foodferry.co.uk

Chuck away the loyalty cards, as foodferry will take your list and shop everywhere, and even unpack your groceries for you. Next-day delivery; London only, though.

www.freshfood.co.uk

The UK's biggest online organic store, with more than 4,500 lines. The owners promise that you can do your weekly shop here, so start with one of their boxes - fresh produce, meat or fish - and take your pick from the greens on offer. Delivery costs a fiver, and is only on Thursdays, though you can set up a regular food drop.

www.organicsdirect. co.uk

This site offers a box scheme which will see prime fruit and veg arriving on your doorstep from only £12.95 including delivery. No meats yet, but breads, dairy and booze are covered. For an even speedier service, Londoners can try www. organicdelivery.co.uk.

webTitle: Judge rules that Elian must stay in US - for now

fields.headline: Judge rules that Elian must stay in US - for now
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzales case
fields.trailText: A US appeal court yesterday blocked Elian Gonzalez's repatriation to Cuba pending a legal hearing next month about his future, and suggested that the six-year-old shipwrecked Cuban might even have the right to apply for asylum, against his father's wishes.
fields.body:
A US appeal court yesterday blocked Elian Gonzalez's repatriation to Cuba pending a legal hearing next month about his future, and suggested that the six-year-old shipwrecked Cuban might even have the right to apply for asylum, against his father's wishes.

The decision by the panel of three judges in Atlanta was heralded as a victory by the boy's Miami relatives and their backers in the anti-communist Cuban exile community who have fought to keep him in the United States.

But the ruling was a blow to the attorney general, Janet Reno. She has staked her authority on a edict from the justice department awarding custody of Elian to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who flew to Washington from Cuba two weeks ago for the expected reunion.

Ms Reno said yesterday: "The court's order does not preclude me from placing Elian in his father's care while he is in the United States."

The decision does not technically block any such attempt to remove the boy from his temporary Miami home. But it loaded any removal with extra political risk by questioning the rationale for such a move.

"It appears that never have INS [Immigration and Naturalisation Service] officials attempted to interview plaintiff [Elian] about his own wishes," the judges wrote. "It is not clear that the INS, in finding plaintiff's father to be the only proper representative, considered all of the relevant factors - particularly the child's separate and independent interests in seeking asylum."

The court pointed out that under US legislation there was no minimum age for asylum applicants. It ruled: "Not only does it appear that plaintiff might be entitled to apply personally for asylum, it appears that he did so."

The comment seemed to refer to a videotape made by Elian's Miami relatives last week in which the boy demanded to be allowed to stay in the US.

Several child psychologists said Elian appeared to have been coached and expressed concern about his mental state, but Cuban exiles said the video was a desperate attempt to ensure that his voice was heard.

Ms Reno said yesterday that the video of the "wonderful little boy" made her very sad.

"It is so important that all of us turn off the TV lights, stop writing on your papers, start thinking about a little boy and getting his life to some permanent resolution," she added.

The Atlanta ruling was greeted with jubilation in Miami's Little Havana, where Elian's US relatives have been looking after him since the shipwreck which claimed the life of his mother and 10 other Cuban migrants.

Since Elian was rescued by two fishermen in November, he has become the focal point of the struggle between Fidel Castro's government in Havana and the 800,000-strong exile community in Miami.

Standing in front of a cheering crowd, Lazaro Gonzalez, Elian's great-uncle, declared that he would continue his legal struggle so that Elian "can remain where his mother wanted him to be, in a free country".

Kendall Coffey, a lawyer for the Miami relatives, told the crowd outside the house that the ruling "raised very substantial questions about the contention that a child does not have asylum rights".

In March, a Florida court ruled that Elian's fate was an immigration issue and therefore fell under the jurisdiction of the INS. Lawyers for the Miami relatives appealed against that ruling, and the appeal is due to be heard in the 11th circuit court in Atlanta on May 11.

Last week, when it seemed that Ms Reno was poised to act to enforce the INS ruling, the Miami lawyers sought the emergency injunction from the Atlanta court to prevent Elian from being taken out of the US.

It was that injunction which was upheld yesterday.

The ruling placed Ms Reno in a difficult position. A final appeal court decision on Elian could take months and even then the case could be taken to the supreme court. If she waited for so long to enforce her decision to reunite father and child, her authority and credibility would be called into question.

Gregory Craig, the lawyer for Juan Miguel Gonzalez, argued yesterday that there was nothing in the ruling which "undermines or weakens this father's legal and moral claim that he be given immediate custody of his son".

He said that the US government was under an obligation to enforce a reunion without delay, adding that, if it failed to do so, any further psychological trauma suffered by Elian would be its responsibility.

"It is unconscionable to wait one day longer," Mr Craig told reporters in Washington.

But Mr Coffey, speaking for the Miami relatives, appealed to the government to "respect the rule of law" and to do nothing to disrupt the legal process while an appeal was pending.

It was not clear yesterday what action Ms Reno would take. Hours before the decision was made she reiterated her belief that "it's important that the time comes quickly that he is returned to his father in a safe way with as little disruption as possible".

But with the determination of the Cuban exiles redoubled by yesterday's court decision, it was difficult to see how Ms Reno could extract Elian without a serious confrontation on the streets of Little Havana.

The battle for Elian

November 25 1999 Elian Gonzalez is found on an inner tube off Fort Lauderdale

November 26 US Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) turns Elian over to relatives in Miami

November 28 Juan Miguel Gonzalez petitions US government for return of son; Miami exiles portray boy as "child victim" of Fidel Castro

December 6 Elian's sixth birthday; Cubans march on US mission in Havana

December 10 Relatives file political asylum claim for Elian; millions rally in Cuba

January 5 INS says Elian should be returned to Cuba

January 10 Florida family court rules Elian should stay with Miami relatives until a hearing to decide if he would be harmed by returning home

January 12 Attorney general Janet Reno rejects court ruling

January 19 Miami relatives file federal lawsuit to block Elian's return to Cuba

January 26 Grandmothers see Elian in Miami

March 22 US district judge rules INS has authority to return boy to father

April 6 Juan Miguel Gonzalez arrives in Washington to reclaim Elian.

April 7 Ms Reno meets father, vows quick return of child

April 12 US government orders relatives to give up Elian

fields.bodyText: A US appeal court yesterday blocked Elian Gonzalez's repatriation to Cuba pending a legal hearing next month about his future, and suggested that the six-year-old shipwrecked Cuban might even have the right to apply for asylum, against his father's wishes. The decision by the panel of three judges in Atlanta was heralded as a victory by the boy's Miami relatives and their backers in the anti-communist Cuban exile community who have fought to keep him in the United States. But the ruling was a blow to the attorney general, Janet Reno. She has staked her authority on a edict from the justice department awarding custody of Elian to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who flew to Washington from Cuba two weeks ago for the expected reunion. Ms Reno said yesterday: "The court's order does not preclude me from placing Elian in his father's care while he is in the United States." The decision does not technically block any such attempt to remove the boy from his temporary Miami home. But it loaded any removal with extra political risk by questioning the rationale for such a move. "It appears that never have INS [Immigration and Naturalisation Service] officials attempted to interview plaintiff [Elian] about his own wishes," the judges wrote. "It is not clear that the INS, in finding plaintiff's father to be the only proper representative, considered all of the relevant factors - particularly the child's separate and independent interests in seeking asylum." The court pointed out that under US legislation there was no minimum age for asylum applicants. It ruled: "Not only does it appear that plaintiff might be entitled to apply personally for asylum, it appears that he did so." The comment seemed to refer to a videotape made by Elian's Miami relatives last week in which the boy demanded to be allowed to stay in the US. Several child psychologists said Elian appeared to have been coached and expressed concern about his mental state, but Cuban exiles said the video was a desperate attempt to ensure that his voice was heard. Ms Reno said yesterday that the video of the "wonderful little boy" made her very sad. "It is so important that all of us turn off the TV lights, stop writing on your papers, start thinking about a little boy and getting his life to some permanent resolution," she added. The Atlanta ruling was greeted with jubilation in Miami's Little Havana, where Elian's US relatives have been looking after him since the shipwreck which claimed the life of his mother and 10 other Cuban migrants. Since Elian was rescued by two fishermen in November, he has become the focal point of the struggle between Fidel Castro's government in Havana and the 800,000-strong exile community in Miami. Standing in front of a cheering crowd, Lazaro Gonzalez, Elian's great-uncle, declared that he would continue his legal struggle so that Elian "can remain where his mother wanted him to be, in a free country". Kendall Coffey, a lawyer for the Miami relatives, told the crowd outside the house that the ruling "raised very substantial questions about the contention that a child does not have asylum rights". In March, a Florida court ruled that Elian's fate was an immigration issue and therefore fell under the jurisdiction of the INS. Lawyers for the Miami relatives appealed against that ruling, and the appeal is due to be heard in the 11th circuit court in Atlanta on May 11. Last week, when it seemed that Ms Reno was poised to act to enforce the INS ruling, the Miami lawyers sought the emergency injunction from the Atlanta court to prevent Elian from being taken out of the US. It was that injunction which was upheld yesterday. The ruling placed Ms Reno in a difficult position. A final appeal court decision on Elian could take months and even then the case could be taken to the supreme court. If she waited for so long to enforce her decision to reunite father and child, her authority and credibility would be called into question. Gregory Craig, the lawyer for Juan Miguel Gonzalez, argued yesterday that there was nothing in the ruling which "undermines or weakens this father's legal and moral claim that he be given immediate custody of his son". He said that the US government was under an obligation to enforce a reunion without delay, adding that, if it failed to do so, any further psychological trauma suffered by Elian would be its responsibility. "It is unconscionable to wait one day longer," Mr Craig told reporters in Washington. But Mr Coffey, speaking for the Miami relatives, appealed to the government to "respect the rule of law" and to do nothing to disrupt the legal process while an appeal was pending. It was not clear yesterday what action Ms Reno would take. Hours before the decision was made she reiterated her belief that "it's important that the time comes quickly that he is returned to his father in a safe way with as little disruption as possible". But with the determination of the Cuban exiles redoubled by yesterday's court decision, it was difficult to see how Ms Reno could extract Elian without a serious confrontation on the streets of Little Havana. webTitle: IRA's Easter statement takes a cautious line

fields.headline: IRA's Easter statement takes a cautious line
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA last night issued a typically neutral Easter statement, affirming commitment to a permanent peace and blaming the government and Ulster Unionists for the state of the peace process in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The IRA last night issued a typically neutral Easter statement, affirming commitment to a permanent peace and blaming the government and Ulster Unionists for the state of the peace process in Northern Ireland.

Its statement, published in today's An Phoblacht, or Republican News, made no mention of decommissioning, and marked no shift in strategy. But it ruled nothing out as the fight to save the Good Friday agreement continues.

Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the Irish premier, will follow up Tuesday night's discussions in Dublin with talks in London today. They are close to agreeing proposals.

The IRA's statement was released hours after Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, said Mr Blair had to change his approach if the agreement, now two years old, was to survive. He meant that the government should restore the power-sharing executive immediately.

Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, suspended devolved government after 72 days two months ago after David Trimble, Ulster Union ist leader, threatened to quit as first minister.

The IRA last night trumpeted its two ceasefires. The first lasted for 18 months from September 1994, ending with the Canary Wharf bomb. Its second cessation, still in force, began in July 1997. The IRA said it had contributed to the creation of a climate to facilitate the search for a durable peace settlement.

Easter statements rarely signal any shift in the IRA's approach. They are designed more for the consumption of its supporters.

webTitle: Rape of sisters by war veterans raises pressure on whites to flee

fields.headline: Rape of sisters by war veterans raises pressure on whites to flee
fields.standfirst:
Farmer tells of ordeal suffered by wife and sister-in-law
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The gang rape of two white sisters in Zimbabwe yesterday by war veterans who attacked the family farm increased pressure on white Zimbabweans to flee the country.
fields.body:
The gang rape of two white sisters in Zimbabwe yesterday by war veterans who attacked the family farm increased pressure on white Zimbabweans to flee the country.

Brendan Jowett, 28 and living on Chedgelow farm three miles from Harare airport, was beaten senseless by five war veterans who stormed into the house and raped Mr Jowett's 25-year-old wife, Tonia, and her 18-year-old sister, Laura.

Mr Jowett said Tonia went to the veranda at about 9pm to pick up a tea tray she had left outside. "She saw this man and ran round the side of the house but when she tried to scream, he grabbed her around the throat.

"About four others came in through the door for me. Two of them held me, one of them hit me repeatedly in the face with a brick till I went down," Mr Jowett said.

"They were threatening me with a knife as well. They told me not to make any noise. At the same time they were strangling me. They held my throat until I stopped moving," he said.

The men then tied Mr Jowett up with electric cables, talking among themselves about whether or not to kill him.

"They took my wife through to the bedroom and they tied her feet and hands behind her back and they gagged her. They found Laura in the spare room and they only tied her arms and legs behind her.

"She was hiding in the cupboard, but they found her pretty quickly," said Mr Jowett.

"They kept on asking her who she was going to vote for. She told them she didn't know any party."

The men then raped the sisters. "I could hear them," he said.

The men then ransacked the house, loading a Mazda pickup truck.

Mr Jowett then said one of the men found a bottle of furniture oil and started to spread it all over the furniture inside the house and over Tonia. They then tried to set light to the oil but it did not catch.

"They were questioning Laura, they held a pellet gun to her head, saying they would shoot her if she didn't speak," said Mr Jowett.

The men then kicked Mr Jowett to see if he was still alive.

He said one of the men offered to stab him to make sure that he was dead.

The men spent another hour loading up their truck with loot.

"Tonia was first up. She managed to get her hands out of the braces they tied her with because they were elasticised. Then she called to me.

"At that stage I didn't answer. I wasn't sure if people were still there.

"Tonia ran through to Laura, then untied her. Tonia thought I was probably dead, but she came back and found I was alive. She undid me.

"I knew what was going on around me.

"They really tied me up tight, I had no feeling in my hands and my feet," Mr Jowett added.

Mr Jowett, his wife and sister-in-law then stole out of the back of the cottage, climbed a fence and walked the three miles to Zimbabwe's international airport.

fields.headline: Rover report predicts jobs catastrophe
fields.standfirst:
Rover jobs 'catastrophe'

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The West Midlands faces economic catastrophe, with the loss of up to 19,000 well-paid jobs, according to the first official study of the impact of BMW's sell-off of the Rover Longbridge plant.
fields.body:
The West Midlands faces economic catastrophe, with the loss of up to 19,000 well-paid jobs, according to the first official study of the impact of BMW's sell-off of the Rover Longbridge plant.

Economists fear the impact could spread well beyond the area and that jobs will go within months. They hold out little hope of those made redundant by Rover and its suppliers finding similar work.

A draft report to be discussed today by an emergency taskforce set up by Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, admits the West Midlands faces a "major shock".

The leaked 40-page document, which has been seen by the Guardian, says manufacturing jobs are already falling, vacancies are down and employment growth has slowed.

"We therefore believe that it will be extremely difficult for the regional economy to rapidly absorb any large-scale run down of Rover activity at present," it says.

"The immediate prospects of Rover workers finding jobs in similar sectors do not look favourable."

The bleak assessment will be presented next Wednesday to Mr Byers, who is under growing pressure to boost the £129m aid package earmarked for the region.

Taskforce members meeting at Aston University today will be told that those whose jobs are threatened earn an average of £25,000, a fifth more than the area's average wage.

Rover is the region's economic linchpin, supporting 50,000 jobs - 8% of manufacturing - with local shops, pubs, cafes and suppliers to the company's suppliers at risk.

The company spends £735m locally and the study says: "The potential economic impact from restructuring of the Rover Group will create a major shock to the regional - and potentially national - economy. It needs more than a sticking plaster response."

Venture capitalists Alchemy, who are believed to have offered £50m for the plant, could take control of Longbridge within six weeks and impose immediate job cuts as it renames Rover the MG Car Company and concentrates on far fewer sports models.

A rival bid headed by the former Rover chief John Towers would save more jobs but BMW is not enthusiastic and doubts remain over its financial backing.

The upper estimate of 19,000 job losses across the region is based on an assumption that Longbridge's output is dramatically slashed.

Although Alchemy, BMW's favoured successor, boasts ambitious plans to build new models it is expected to concentrate initially on the low-volume MG sports car and cease production relatively swiftly of the Rover 25 and 45 saloons.

"In 1999 around 190,000 units were produced at Longbridge," the report says. "If all car production at Longbridge fell to 100,000 units per annum, the region could face job losses of around 11,000 jobs.

"If production fell to as little as 35,000 units per annum then regional job losses could amount to 19,000 jobs. We believe that the impact of the changes at Rover could fall into this range."

The report was drawn up by Advantage West Midlands, the region's economic development agency. Half of Longbridge's 9,000 workforce live in Birmingham and 24,000 people in all depend on the Rover Group for their livelihood.

The taskforce has been told to devise schemes to retrain workers, diversify suppliers, regenerate land and property and tackle the social consequences of the redundancies.

A £12m fund to advise suppliers on how to find new markets has been set up.

A senior source close to the taskforce said last night: "The problems faced in the West Midlands are immense and will require an unprecedented response.

"Now we know how big those problems are, we can get stuck in immediately instead of waiting for the economy to melt down."

fields.headline: Anger at Prescott 'escape'
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night protested that the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has escaped censure over his rent controlled, union owned flat because of a loophole in the way the financial affairs of ministers are regulated.
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night protested that the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has escaped censure over his rent controlled, union owned flat because of a loophole in the way the financial affairs of ministers are regulated.

As the Commons standards and privileges committee delayed its own verdict on a report submitted by the parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, Mr Prescott's Tory shadow, Archie Norman, wrote a protest letter to Lord Neill's commission on standards in public life.

Mr Prescott's long-standing arrangement with the RMT union, of which he was once a paid official, gives him use of a flat in Clapham, south London, for £220 a month - well below the market rate.

Though the arrangement has long been known at Westminster it was not declared in the register of MPs interests. Mrs Filkin is said to have agreed with complainants that it should have been, but is said to have told the standards committee that no deliberate attempt had been made to hide it from the public. The committee has postponed its own verdict until next month.

Mr Prescott does not live in the flat because he has a government flat in Whitehall. One of his sons is said to live there.

In a separate development, a cross-party alliance of peers last night threatened to block Lord Neill's plans to extend the Commons regulation of members' private financial interests to the Lords.

Tory peers are "up in arms" about tighter rules which might require them to be more open about their financial interests.

webTitle: Blair rejects attack on Whitehall's rising costs

fields.headline: Blair rejects attack on Whitehall's rising costs
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday launched a withering attack on William Hague, lampooning his attempts to criticise increased government running costs as "Hague-onomics" which relied on distorted statistics.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday launched a withering attack on William Hague, lampooning his attempts to criticise increased government running costs as "Hague-onomics" which relied on distorted statistics.

In some of their bitterest exchanges in the Commons, the prime minister rounded on Mr Hague after the Tory leader accused him of allowing spending on the running of government departments to spiral out of control.

Ministers had spent £633m more than their original estimates in the last year, with the costs of Downing Street increasing by 23%. Mr Hague said: "This is a government where more money is spent each year on spin doctors, political advisors, bureaucracy - nowhere more so than in 10 Downing Street ... On its own figures [this government] spends £2bn more and spends it on pen pushers not on police, on bureaucrats not on teachers, on spin doctors not on real doctors. Isn't that why this is a government that taxes so much more and delivers so much less?"

Brandishing a Treasury document, Mr Hague said that the Department of Trade and Industry had increased its spending by £114m over the past three years, while the Lord Chancellor's department had seen costs rise by £100m. "Where has the Lord Chancellor spent £100m?" Mr Hague joked. "He can't have spent it all on wallpaper in the Lord Chancellor's department."

The prime minister accused Mr Hague of distorting the figures, insisting that costs had fallen in real terms. "This [is a] pathetic attempt because Hague-onomics is beginning to be found out," Mr Blair said. "By the time we get through with them in the next general election, your economic policy will be in ruins along with your party."

The prime minister reminded Mr Hague that public funds to support the Opposition had increased threefold.

"All I can say is on value for money terms, if you are getting three times the amount of Short money [official money for running the Opposition office], you should get better advice than you got then to ask these questions again," Mr Blair said.

The prime minister said that the only increases were good news for voters. "The numbers of nurses under this government is up," Mr Blair said. "The number of doctors is up. The number of teachers are up as well. The only thing that is going down is the Tory party."

The exchanges between Mr Blair and Mr Hague were good parlimentary knockabout two weeks ahead of next month's local government elections.

But both leaders were disingenuous in their interpretation of the Treasury's figures on the government's running costs. Mr Hague was right to point out that spending by some departments has increased. Overall spending, however, has only increased in real terms by 1.4% - hardly the dramatic rise criticised by the Tory leader.

The prime minister misled MPs because his claim that spending has fallen in real terms is based on last year's figures. Government running costs last year amounted to £14bn, which is less than the £14.3bn in real terms spent by the Tories in their last year in office. However, government spending for this year is expected to rise to £14.5bn, which is 1.4% more than the Tories spent in their last year.

webTitle: Rail crash firms fight over blame

fields.headline: Rail crash firms fight over blame
fields.standfirst:
Claim and counter-claim on Paddington liability

Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The rail industry yesterday became embroiled in a bitter internal fight over who should bear the responsibility for the Paddington rail crash in which 31 people died and 227 were injured.
fields.body:
The rail industry yesterday became embroiled in a bitter internal fight over who should bear the responsibility for the Paddington rail crash in which 31 people died and 227 were injured.

The two train companies involved, Thames Trains and Great Western, have both lodged claims against Raitrack, while Railtrack has issued a counter claim against Thames Trains.

The bitter conflict is a legacy of privatisation when British Rail was split off into more than 100 companies. Whenever a major incident took place, BR immediately accepted responsibility, and legal experts have constantly warned of problems since the break-up.

Railtrack said the action was "an insurance claim" to recover costs of clearing the wreckage and added: "This is part of the legal process."

It denied that it was an attempt to influence the outcome of Lord Cullen's inquiry into the accident, which opens next month.

Great Western confirmed that it had issued a liability notice against Railtrack. "This is an automatic legal process and does not have any effect on claims lodged by passengers or those involved with the tragedy." Thames Trains declined to comment in advance of the inquiry.

The crash is estimated to have cost more than £20m, and Lord Cullen's inquiry is likely to blame many factors for the worst rail crash since the Clapham tragedy 12 years ago.

Some key sections of evidence are being assembled, including a report from the health and safety executive that a section of track badly out of alignment could have affected on-train safety equipment.

The equipment could have indicated to the Thames driver, Michael Holder, that he was approaching a green signal rather than a red.

The report has already been challenged by Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, who said that he had not been provided with any scientific information about the HSE's theory.

Lord Cullen's inquiry will be the most important statement about the railway industry since privatisation and will cause the government to reconsider key safety aspects.

One of the results could the setting up of a separate rail safety body.

Group 4, the security firm, yesterday joined a group of bidders for one of the rail franchises.

It is one of six contenders for the franchise run by Stagecoach-owned South West Trains. It is also bidding for Central Trains in the Midlands and the proposed Trans Pennine Express between Sheffield and Manchester.

A Group 4 spokeswoman said: "We are new to the rail business but have experience in raising private investment and the transfer of people."

webTitle: Blair comfortable with the new age Tories

fields.headline: Blair comfortable with the new age Tories
fields.trailText: For what it's worth, Tony Blair "won" prime minister's question time yesterday, and so sent his MPs off for Easter feeling as jolly as any group of people who know that they are going to spend most of the next fortnight canvassing door to door in the local elections. ("So Channel 5 is fuzzy, is it? I'll tell the council.") It is hard to know exactly why.
fields.body:
For what it's worth, Tony Blair "won" prime minister's question time yesterday, and so sent his MPs off for Easter feeling as jolly as any group of people who know that they are going to spend most of the next fortnight canvassing door to door in the local elections. ("So Channel 5 is fuzzy, is it? I'll tell the council.") It is hard to know exactly why.

Looking at the text of what he said one finds no dazzling shafts of repartee, no knock-down conclusive arguments, few good jokes. Yet his backbenchers deemed him to have been victorious, and as far as they are concerned, that's all that matters.

It helps that the prevailing wisdom is that William Hague has been besting Mr Blair over the past few weeks. The general view is that Mr Hague may have as much political judgment as a pop-up toaster, and that his shadow ministers possess the charisma of mini chicken kievs, but at least he wins the tussle in the chamber. Yesterday he didn't.

The Tories did not help their cause. Nick St Aubyn botched a potentially damaging question in which he linked the anguished hand-wringing over Zimbabwe with the friendly, tea-and-finger-sandwiches reception for the Russian president.

"Are you comfortable with President Putin, whose actions in Chechnya to win votes dwarf anything yet tried by the Mugabe regime? If you are still comfortable with him, why should any of us feel comfortable with you?"

What is this new age jargon? And from a Tory? Can you imagine Churchill addressing the British people at the darkest hour in our history, and saying, "Hi, everyone! I really want you to feel comfortable with me, and with where I'm coming from." The Germans would have ripped us to pieces before we'd finished the first spliff.

Labour MPs wanted to assail the Tories over their idea of "reception centres" for asylum seekers, or "prison camps" as Gerald Kaufman called them. (Will Mr Hague really score by positioning himself to the right of Jack Straw? There isn't an awful lot of room there. And does he guess how the pictures of pitiful wide-eyed imprisoned children will play on TV?)

Mr Hague, by contrast, wanted to talk about hidden government spending. The cost of running 10 Downing Street had risen by 23% in a year when inflation had been only 2%. The cost of running the lord chancellor's office had risen by £106m. "He can't have spent it all on wallpaper!"

Mr Blair flannelled at first. The argument was pathetic, he said. "The percentage costs of government are in fact lower than when you were in office," he added, somewhat improbably.

Then he added: "You're simply dealing with cash money, not real terms, as you know perfectly well" - a sentence that may have some meaning hidden in it, rather in the way that a great sculpture is hidden inside the stone, though in that case as in this, most of us lack the skill to extract it.

At this point, the Labour benches were uneasy. Mr Blair was responding to the Tory leader with his usual mixture of outright abuse and meaningless patter. Then suddenly he turned it round.

"You have had a three-fold increase in your opposition Short money!" (Short money, named after the ex-Labour minister Ted Short, helps fund all the minority parties.)

"So," he continued triumphantly, "when you get to your feet for the third time, you can offer us your first spending cut!"

Labour MPs, smelling victory, cheered like Millwall fans on Prozac. The fact that the rise was from £1m to £3m, just half of 1% of the extra money for Whitehall, was forgotten in the euphoria.

webTitle: Yes TV defies the 'corporate bullies' as image suffers

fields.headline: Yes TV defies the 'corporate bullies' as image suffers
fields.standfirst:
Chatroom
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Last Friday the directors of Yes Television received a letter from Kingston Communications, its partner in a pay-TV operation in the telecom company's home of Hull.
fields.body:
Last Friday the directors of Yes Television received a letter from Kingston Communications, its partner in a pay-TV operation in the telecom company's home of Hull.

Market rumours had begun to circulate that the deal was set to fall apart following the termination of an agreement Yes had in place to provide video on demand services to cable company NTL.

The letter reassured Yes that Kingston had no intention of bringing the venture to an early conclusion - it has until June to run. But there was a chilling pay-off line.

"The fact that we may become direct competitors as acknowledged in your recent prospectus makes it more difficult than would otherwise be the case to contemplate a longer term relationship."

Kingston had also put Yes in the humiliating position of issuing a statement clarifying that no substantive talks for a longer term relationship had taken place.

As the letter arrived in the central London offices of Yes, all hell was breaking loose in New York. Wall Street was experiencing one of its worst ever white-knuckle rides - prompting the decision to put the company's £800m flotation, which had been due at the beginning of this week, on ice. The combined events made it hardly the most auspicious start to life in the public eye.

Yes, which aims to offer services including pay TV, video on demand and high speed internet access, yesterday issued a supplementary flotation prospectus detailing the changes to its operations.

At the publication of its original prospectus it had only three existing businesses: one with NTL, one with Kingston and a third to supply video on demand services to Irish telecoms group Eircom.

Pricing and allocation of shares in the offer have now been put back to "no later" than 22 May. The head of marketing at Yes, Steve Garvey, admits the issues with NTL and Kingston have been bad publicity for the company.

Privately, one insider believed that without the combined effect of Kingston and NTL, take-up of shares by institutions would have been 30% higher - although it was still oversubscribed.

But the company remains defiant, and says it has enormous prospects to develop its broader package, Total Television, across the networks of BT after they have been upgraded for broadband use and opened for competition next year.

Mr Garvey maintains that the two deals are of marginal importance in the larger picture. "Nothing has changed with regard to our business model, which is just as valid as it ever was," he said.

"There is still a very British thing about not being too ambitious but we believe we have a very strong product. People are more sceptical than we had expected and it's up to use to prove them wrong."

He said a deal signed in the past week to work with Norway's Telenor was "100 times more significant" than the existing trials with NTL.

The key for Yes is a three month contract to trial video on demand and internet service in parts of west London in a co-branded effort with BT. Yes cannot show conventional broadcasting over BT's networks until a ban on doing so is lifted next year.

By mid-summer, it hopes to have signed a telecoms partner to take the business forward next year with the full Total Television package. But it still has to sign carriage agreements with the channel providers, including the likes of BSkyB and Flextech.

For some potential investors there are too many uncertainties. A fund manager at one institution which declined to subscribe to the offer said: "We are believers in the whole idea of convergence - the idea of the television becoming an interactive portal offering the entire package of services the consumer would want. But Yes may have come to market too early."

Yes believes it has been the victim of corporate bullies and said the events of the past two weeks only prove to underline its threat.

webTitle: New radio links will bypass BT and cable

fields.headline: New radio links will bypass BT and cable
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The new auction of radio spectrum is best seen as a way of breaking BT's monopoly grip on transmission to the home or office and speeding up internet penetration rates.
fields.body:
The new auction of radio spectrum is best seen as a way of breaking BT's monopoly grip on transmission to the home or office and speeding up internet penetration rates.

It will open up the final miles between users and their local telephone exchange - the "local loop" now dominated by BT.

Ministers hope the new technology will speed up broadband access to the internet at speeds capable of carrying video.

BT controls access to over 90% of homes through its hold on the local loop.

The government has already announced that BT's competitors can install their own ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) equipment in local exchanges to gain access to the local loop.

But unlike the new radio spectrum, ADSL only offers high speed transmission in to the customer's equipment and not out.

Using 28Ghz (gigahertz) wireless links could, in theory, provide access hundreds of thousands of times faster than the standard 56k modem used in home computers, although the actual speeds depend on the number of customers using the system at the same time.

Telecom companies will soon have two ways of bypassing BT's monopoly. Which they use will depend on the speed and the services they want to offer. Many companies do not believe there is a big market for two-way video, so they may opt for ASDL.

But cable companies will be able to reach their customers without digging up the roads for the final few miles from their main network links.

Later this year the government will also auction 40Ghz licences that will offer even faster two-way access to the internet.

Nobody yet knows whether there is a vast consumer market for broadband products - it will be a case of suck it and see.

webTitle: Jury split over GM crop destroyers

fields.headline: Jury split over GM crop destroyers
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The controversy over genetically modified foods intensified last night after a jury failed to decide if 28 Greenpeace protesters had broken the law when they pulled up £750-worth of GM maize on a government-funded site.
fields.body:
The controversy over genetically modified foods intensified last night after a jury failed to decide if 28 Greenpeace protesters had broken the law when they pulled up £750-worth of GM maize on a government-funded site.

In the first case of its kind, the jury of six men and six women cleared the pressure group's executive director, Lord Melchett, and 27 fellow activists of stealing the crop when they uprooted it at Walnut Tree Farm, near Lyng, Norfolk, in July last year.

But, after 7 hours of deliberation, the jury at Norwich crown court admitted it was unlikely to reach a decision on whether they were guilty of criminal damage.

The environmentalists, who pleaded not guilty to both counts, had argued they had a "lawful excuse" since they were acting to protect other maize crops and the environment from genetic "contamination" via GM maize pollen.

The jurors were discharged and the crown was given a fortnight to consider applying for a retrial. The activists came from as far afield as Edinburgh and Aberdeen, and included a Baptist minister, beauty therapist and two teachers.

Speaking on behalf of the group, Lord Melchett, a hereditary peer and former Labour junior minister, said: "We were delighted that the jury didn't find that any of us had been dishonest in any way. We feel vindicated.

"We feel very pleased that the crown weren't able to prove the charge of criminal damage. We think this should send a strong message to Tony Blair about the future of field trials."

The old Etonian, who has a 890-acre, largely organic farm at Hunstanton, Norfolk, added that there was "huge public opposition" to GM trials, with one Norfolk farmer pulling out of the controversial farmscale programme this week and the crop at the centre of the case being banned in Austria during the criminal trial.

He added that the trial, which the protesters hoped would not be repeated, had placed a huge strain on them. But he insisted: "We were proud to stand together and if it takes a few more weeks or even another trial, of course we will defend what we did."

The failure of the jury to come to a decision was described by William Brigham, the farmer whose crop was uprooted, as "not as bad as a not guilty verdict which would have set a precedent".

There was no reaction from Aventis, the German-based agro-chemical firm formerly known as AgrEvo, which owns the crop, and to which the protesters intended to return the maize.

The government last night refused to be drawn on the case but insisted it remained committed to funding a four-year programme into GM trials, which is costing the taxpayer over £1m a year.

Eight days before the Greenpeace raids on July 26 last year, 400 demonstrators descended on another farm, at Watlington, Oxfordshire, and ripped up a 25-acre crop of GM oilseed rape. The previous August, two women caused £605,000 worth of damage on a farm at Totnes, Devon.

Lord Melchett, 52, had written to AgrEvo asking that the crop be destroyed and, a fortnight before the raid, attended a "very moving" public meeting, where the villagers of Lyng voiced their fears.

The 28 protesters, who boast 18 degrees between them, did not fully succeed in their bid to cut down the crop. For no sooner had they broken into the field, at 5am, then Mr Brigham arrived on the scene.

Eight days before the Greenpeace raids on July 26 last year, 400 demonstrators descended on another farm, at Watlington, Oxfordshire, and ripped up a 25-acre crop of GM oilseed rape. Lord Melchett, 52, had written to AgrEvo asking that the crop be destroyed and, a fortnight before the raid, attended a "very moving" public meeting, where the villagers of Lyng voiced their fears. fields.headline: A sinister crime
fields.standfirst:
John Ware is dismayed as the defence secretary and the country's top policeman seem to be at odds

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The most sensitive police inquiry ever undertaken in Northern Ireland was sabotaged by British soldiers themselves who burnt down the inquiry's offices, alleges Martin Ingram, a former army intelligence officer. The policeman in charge of that inquiry was Sir John Stevens, now Metropolitan police commissioner. He has also let it be known privately that he strongly suspects arson, and I can now shed more light on this extraordinary affair.
fields.body:
The most sensitive police inquiry ever undertaken in Northern Ireland was sabotaged by British soldiers themselves who burnt down the inquiry's offices, alleges Martin Ingram, a former army intelligence officer. The policeman in charge of that inquiry was Sir John Stevens, now Metropolitan police commissioner. He has also let it be known privately that he strongly suspects arson, and I can now shed more light on this extraordinary affair.

Back in January 1990, Sir John was deputy chief constable of Cambridgeshire. On the night of the fire his officers were preparing to arrest Brian Nelson, a full-time salaried agent in a covert military intelligence group called the Force Research Unit. Nelson had been helping loyalist death squads to assassinate suspected IRA terrorists.

Yet how has the present defence secretary responded to Mr Ingram's revelations? Instead of investigating his message, Geoff Hoon seems to want to shoot the messenger by threatening Ingram with official secrets act charges and refusing to lift an injunction stopping him from revealing further details. Apparently Mr Hoon cannot identify any "public interest which demands publication of such material".

Admittedly the evidence from Mr Ingram - a pseudonym - is hearsay. He says he saw two members of the army's "covert means of entry" unit in a bar used exclusively by the Intelligence Corps at Thiepval barracks in Northern Ireland. In this intimate atmosphere, there was some slack talk. Ingram and colleagues seated round his table were told the two soldiers had been brought over from the Army's special intelligence wing at Ashford in England to destroy Stevens's offices in the heavily guarded police authority's premises outside Belfast. Sir John and his team have suspected such arson for 10 years.

For soldiers trained to break into military installations in the eastern bloc, the Northern Ireland police authority building, housed in a disused tobacco factory and guarded by middle-aged police reservists and civilians, may not have presented the ultimate challenge. According to Ingram, the team had assistance from a "friendly" RUC man. On the night of the fire, four RUC reservists were on duty with three civilians.

At 6am the following day, Nelson was to be arrested in "Operation Wheel", so called because he was its hub. Other loyalist paramilitaries were some of its spokes, all feeding bits and pieces of leaked security force information to Nelson who collated it on his home computer into "P" or personality cards on IRA targets. He then passed these to gunmen to help them trace and identify their quarry.

One Army file, dated August 4 1988 states: "6137's appointment enables him to make sure that sectarian killings are not carried out but that proper targeting of (P)IRA members takes place prior to any shootings." Another, dated December 30 1988, says: "6137 is in a posi tion to see that correct targeting is carried out and that sectarian murders are avoided."

Targeting the enemy for assassination may have had a flawless military logic but it was, of course, a flagrant breach of the criminal law. The files suggest Nelson was involved in many conspiracies to murder, attempted murders and murders, including the deaths of at least two young fathers of six children who were not involved in terrorism.

I knew Brian Nelson and met him the day before he was due to be arrested. That very night he fled to England because, we now know, he had been tipped off. Army files show that they had given Nelson regular anti-interrogation briefings in case he was arrested. His handlers thought that burning down Stevens's offices meanwhilewould buy them "a little bit of time to construct an alternative cover story", according to Ingram.

That night, Stevens's team worked late. At about 10pm, their office's passive infrared alarms were set and the doors locked by the last group of detectives to leave.

At around 11.05pm, four officers returned to file away papers. As they approached the staircase they smelt burning. The seat of the fire was a few inches beyond the partition wall next to a stack of computer paper and a locked filing cabinet containing exhibits and statements. As one of the former senior officers said: "Of all the offices, of all the police stations, the fire starts right next to the heart of our investigation."

S arah Bynum, then a detective constable, tried to raise the alarm but to no avail. When she smashed her shoe against a red, wall-mounted alarm, there was silence. She went down one flight of stairs and found a second alarm. Again she smashed it with her shoe. Again, silence. Inside the Stevens offices, computers were melting like Dali paintings; files marked secret, exhibits - everything - was destroyed. Bynum now sprinted down a long corridor to the RUC guardroom where she found RUC reserve constable William Corry. She told him to call the fire brigade but he replied: "The phones are down." Barefoot, Bynum then ran "like hell" back up to the first floor where she found an empty office with a phone and dialled 999.

Approximately 17 minutes passed between the time Stevens's officers discovered the fire and the first tenders arriving. At 11.35pm the guardroom telephone that had been dead 25 minutes earlier, came back to life. Bynum noticed that the guardroom clock had stopped at 10.50pm.

The phones that didn't work and the fire alarms that didn't ring weren't the only pieces of equipment to malfunction. The infrared alarms installed by the RUC failed to send a signal back to Belfast Regional Control as they were supposed to.

In charge of the investigation into the fire was the RUC's detective superinten dent, Alan Simpson, but his report played down arson: "Bluntly put," he wrote, "there is the suggestion of treachery afoot. As the fire occurred within a secure police complex, this view is to the detriment of the reputation of the RUC and is made without regard to the objective evidence." Simpson said that five of the RUC and civilian security officers had all alibied each other. The remaining two, "whose precise whereabouts cannot be confirmed", were patrolling the grounds.

However, Simpson's report was regarded by the Stevens team as less than thorough. It made no mention of the failure of the wall-mounted alarms; it suggested the infrared system failed because its beam had been obscured by smoke even though, according to a forensic scientist, the full system wasn't able to be tested since bits of it were "believed to have been discarded" at the crime scene. Simpson also found "nothing sinister" about the guardroom telephone having failed because that "often happens". Although Simpson said he "hesitated" to point an accusing finger, a young female constable who had smoked two or three cigarettes in the office that night was tacitly blamed. She categorically denied she had been careless, pointing out that when she smoked she sat at her desk across from the seat of the fire. Also, both she and the other three officers with whom she left say they neither saw nor smelt any smoke.

Nelson was eventually arrested and charged with several counts of conspiracy to murder though none of the classified files, suggesting that the army had recruited him to refine the targeting of Ulster Freedom Fighter death squads - or the true scale of his involvement in assassinations, emerged during the brief hearing. As the peace process falteringly continues, some of the families have been campaigning for a public inquiry into this aspect of Ulster's dirty war. Perhaps the authorities would better serve the public interest by getting to the bottom of this with Mr Ingram on board rather than pursuing him as a common criminal.

john.ware @bbc.co.uk. The author is a reporter for BBC Panorama.

fields.headline: 'This is not racism, it's politics'
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe's victims: a township mourns in the shadow of outcry over farm attacks

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Tichaona Chiminya was a reserved man but when he talked politics he could breathe fire.
fields.body:
Tichaona Chiminya was a reserved man but when he talked politics he could breathe fire.

His friends describe him as retiring but he knew how to hold a crowd.

"When he was addressing people about democracy he spoke with a certain intensity," says one of his peers in Zimbabwe's main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

On Saturday evening he was driving with another MDC supporter, Talent Mabika, when his car was stopped by supporters of President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party. They were carrying clubs, sticks and iron bars.

They dragged both him and Ms Mabika into the road, clubbed them to death and then set their bodies alight. His family had planned to bury him yesterday but his body was so charred that the funeral parlour needed an extra day to treat it. They hope to lay him to rest later today.

In the meantime his father's house in the township of Highfield, near Harare, plays host to displays of defiance and grief. In the front garden MDC supporters toyi-toyi (protest dance) to the chant: "MDC is for the masses".

With T-shirts proclaiming "land to the people, not to the politicians" they shuffle and jive in an apparently endless circle around a drum. They rise and fall with the beat, their open palms - the symbol of the MDC - held high. When they get tired they sit on sofas underneath the lemon tree.

In the back garden family members are grieving: women prepare dinner in tears; others simply sit, in the arms of friends and neighbours, and stare into space. The weeping is sober and persistent.

Chiminya's father-in-law stands by the kitchen door, trying to maintain a dividing line between the personal and political. "To you this is about politics," he says. "To me it is about my daughter's husband."

That line is occasionally breached. A weeping relative will dry their eyes and shuffle past the vegetable patch to join the demonstrators.

Chiminya was not only a husband and son-in-law but also the father of a daughter of 15 and a son of 11. Once the national organiser of the Chemical Workers Union, he had recently been appointed the driver for the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai.

Few of these details emerged when he was killed. Chiminya was one of at least six black Zimbabweans - five MDC supporters and one policeman - who died in the violence that has engulfed the country over the past two weeks.

He was murdered on the same day as David Stevens, the first white farmer to be killed, but while the Stevens murder triggered headlines of impending civil war, the lives of Chiminya and Mabika earned little more than a footnote in reports of the day's violence.

MDC supporters say that the portrayal of recent events in the country as a racial war is precisely what Mr Mugabe was hoping for. With interest rates, unemployment and inflation all high and only a month before elections are due, opposition leaders regard the land invasions as a bloody sideshow.

"This is not about racism but about politics," says Remus Makuwaza, an executive member of the MDC. "The government is trying to divert attention away from its political and economic problems so it has targeted a minority."

White Zimbabweans make up just 1% of the population but own the vast majority of the best farmland, which was taken from the indigenous people over many decades.

Most Zimbabweans, including many whites, agree that there must be land reform. Few, including most blacks, believe the government is going about it in the right way.

Polls suggest Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF remains the single most popular party but little of that popularity is rubbing off on Mr Mugabe. The MDC has been gaining ground, holding rallies around the country.

"We have been independent now for 20 years," says Kitizo, a young man who lives in Harare and refuses to give his full name for fear of reprisal. "So of course we cannot continue with such a small group of people owning so much land when so many in rural areas have nothing. But we should not be killing them. We need democracy also."
