fields.headline: Hillary returns campaign donation
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton's team for her New York senate seat campaign has returned a $22,000 (£14,000) contribution from a businesswoman who has been linked by investigators to a convicted drug-trafficker.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton's team for her New York senate seat campaign has returned a $22,000 (£14,000) contribution from a businesswoman who has been linked by investigators to a convicted drug-trafficker.

"The contribution was inappropriate," said Howard Wolfson, Mrs Clinton's campaign spokesman.

The donation came from Vivian Mannerud, whose company runs charter flights between Cuba and Miami.

Ms Mannerud has been linked by congressional investigators to Jorge Cabrera, who admitted last year smuggling 2,700kg (6,000lb) of cocaine into the US and was jailed for 19 years and fined $1.5m.

She is said to have promised Cabrera an invitation to a fundraising dinner in honour of the vice-president, Al Gore, five years ago in return for a donation of $20,000 to the Democratic party.

It is alleged that the cheque he wrote was drawn on an account which held his profits from drug-smuggling.

The party returned the contribution, but not before Cabrera had been invited to a White House Christmas party, where he was photographed with Mrs Clinton and Mr Gore.

Three weeks later Cabrera was arrested at a Florida warehouse and accused of drug-smuggling.

A picture of him with the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, was found in his briefcase, and he tried to make a deal for leniency in return for implicating the Cuban government in drug-dealing.

Ms Mannerud, who has never been charged with any offence, said that she believed that Cabrera was a fisherman and did not know that he had served more than three years in jail for drug-related crimes.

She also said that she did not remember mentioning that a contribution could earn him an invitation to the Gore dinner in Miami.

Ms Mannerud was in the news three months ago when she volunteered ago to fly Elian Gonzalez - the Cuban boy at the centre of a bitter custody battle - back to Havana on a private jet.

Mrs Clinton's standing in the polls has improved recently because of the way the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani - her rival in the senate race - is regarded as having mishandled the affair of the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man outside a bar.

The Rev Al Sharpton, a black civil rights activist, is running a series of demonstrations against the New York police department, with one protest each day this week.

Yesterday's demonstrations was held on Wall Street.

On Tuesday night Mr Sharpton and 26 other protesters were arrested after attempting to burst into a Broadway theatre where a performance of The Phantom of the Opera was being given. On Monday 15 people were arrested at the first protest.

Mr Sharpton said that Easter week had been chosen for the protests because "a lot of tourists come to New York at this time and they need to go home knowing that there is outrage in this city".

fields.headline: Zimbabwe: what the papers say
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Daily Telegraph
fields.body:
Daily Telegraph

This declaration of war is directed at a section of the population who are overwhelmingly Zimbabwean citizens; who earn some 40% of the country's export earnings; and who provide a livelihood for about 16% of the 12.5m population.

It is made by a man whose mismanagement of the economy has left it with soaring rates of interest, inflation and unemployment, and debts amounting to about a third of gross domestic product.

Independent

As opposition to his regime has strengthened, Mr Mugabe has tightened his bonds with the army - preparing the way for some form of coup d'état.

If Mr Mugabe prevails and the white farmers surrender, he will boast of having corrected an injustice ... Or his rhetorical war on whites turns into a shooting war, leading to a state of emergency and indefinite postponement of the elections.

Either way, Mr Mugabe wins in the short term; the loser will be Zimbabwe.

The Times

The weekend murders in Zimbabwe were a watershed; a wilfully manufactured crisis, which almost all Zimbabweans had hoped could be contained, could now spiral out of control. Mr Mugabe has set a course towards anarchy and economic collapse from which there is no easy exit. He scorns external mediation; but he needs it badly.

The Express

The crisis highlights the west's powerlessness to force change. Once again, Robin Cook's "ethical" foreign policy is left looking impotent in a country divided by racial tension. It is time Mr Cook stepped up Britain's efforts. The Commonwealth and other diplomatic measures should be used to unite as many nations as possible - in condemnation of Mugabe's regime.

webTitle: The man with a hold over Mugabe

fields.headline: The man with a hold over Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
'Hitler' Hunzvi squatters' army gives former doctor unusual political muscle

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The great mystery is who is in charge: Robert Mugabe or Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi?
fields.body:
The great mystery is who is in charge: Robert Mugabe or Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi?

Two years ago veterans of Zimbabwe's independence war were neglected, sidelined and ripped off; they were ripe for politicisation. Mr Hunzvi, a multilingual medical doctor, is the man who gave it to them.

The men and women who fought for liberation from white rule played a major role in putting Mr Mugabe into power by securing the vote in rural areas.

He returned the favour by failing to pay their pensions or deliver the lands he promised, and by allowing his cronies to steal what little was earmarked in the budget for the freedom fighters.

Mr Hunzvi, 49, for less than altruistic reasons, was willing to fight the war veterans' battle for recognition and justice.

Mr Hunzvi took his cut, no doubt believing he had earned it for brokering the deal. Just to ensure the cards were not all in one hand, Mr Mugabe briefly had the war veterans' leader detained on corruption charges.

From there, a working relationship was established. The war veterans got their recognition and money and Mr Mugabe got the private army that is spearheading Zanu-PF's campaign to cling to power.

Mr Hunzvi has played one card especially hard - race. He is particularly combative about Zimbabwe's white minority. "The white farmers have two options: to hand over the land and leave or to stay and see what land we leave them," he said. "The whites are foreigners, they are British! They should go back to Britain. We don't need them here. They can all go."

Mr Hunzvi, who took the nickname "Hitler" during the independence struggle, also shows no remorse.

"All revolutions require violence," he said recently. "I am like Napoleon Bonaparte, Che Guevara or like Adolf Hitler himself. They are figures no one could stop and who led a revolution. Now no one can stop the revolution we have started."

Yesterday Mr Hunzvi was convicted of contempt of court for not ordering the veterans to vacate the farms they have illegally occupied but he remains defiant. "I cannot tell my followers to go against the orders of President Mugabe," he said. "The president says we must stay and he is going to redistribute the land.

"I'm very happy. We will be intensifying our efforts to redistribute the land to the Zimbabwean people. Our people are not squatters on commercial farms, they are Zimbabweans on Zimbabwean land. That is the land that we went to war for and we are going to stay on that land."

webTitle: Hundreds join queue for a passport out of the chaos

fields.headline: Hundreds join queue for a passport out of the chaos
fields.standfirst:
Reluctant families check nationality

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: They arrive in family groups of two or three, clutching folders containing birth and marriage certificates, passports and personal documents - scraps of paper that embody their hopes and fears about the future of Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
They arrive in family groups of two or three, clutching folders containing birth and marriage certificates, passports and personal documents - scraps of paper that embody their hopes and fears about the future of Zimbabwe.

They are the hundreds of anxious Zimbabweans who are flocking to the British high commission in Harare to apply for or renew British passports in the wake of the murders of two white farmers this week.

The queues stretch through the passport office foyer to the lifts. At the busiest times the lines start in the ground floor lobby. Women and teenagers, businessmen and farmers are coming to the British consular office to confirm they have the right to residence in Britain.

"I never thought I would be doing this but the events of the last few days have been unsettling," said Lorna Coleman, whose composure could not quite conceal her anxiety. "Our family decided to take precautions. For safety's sake we want to get our British passports in order. I'm bringing the documentation for myself, my husband and my two sons."

The Colemans have farms in the Concession area, 80 miles north of Harare. "We have had four visits from people who call themselves war veterans. We've been hassled and had death threats," said Mrs Coleman. "It is frightening."

A Zimbabwean citizen, Mrs Coleman has never had a British passport, but she believes she will qualify because her mother was British and her husband was born in the UK.

"At independence we felt black and white could live together and go forward in great strength," she said. "To see that crumble, to see things become so violent, is very distressing."

Because of the two killings, in which supporters of President Robert Mugabe besieged two farms and then killed the farmers, she said many people were leaving agricultural areas for the safety of Harare.

"I know many wives are leaving but I don't want to go. I still have work to do," said Mrs Coleman, 62. She keeps poultry and sheep on the farm. "One of my biggest worries is what will happen to our staff. We have 70 people working for us and their families live on our property. I take that responsibility seriously. I don't want to abandon them."

Nervously straightening the documents in her folder, Mrs Coleman said she still did not want to leave Zimbabwe. "I don't even like to think about it, but we felt it was necessary to start making contingency plans," she said.

It is estimated that well over 20,000 Zimbabweans, most of them white, have the right to British passports. About 14,000 are already registered at the high commission and more are coming in each day.

"I don't think most people are planning to leave immediately," said the British high commissioner to Harare, Peter Longworth. "Recent events have made them think about their futures and they want to know what their options are."

Mr Longworth said the killings and intimidation on white-owned farms concerned the British government, as well as the farmers.

"This is a situation we have been worried about from the start of the invasions," said Mr Longworth. "Now it has taken on an inevitability as the situation escalates - when law and order are not being applied, when police are not doing their job. We are worried. Getting the land invasions to end and getting a return to the rule of law is an essential part of the recipe for stability."

Max Daillecourt, a 41-year-old businessman, was renewing his British passport at the commission. "My whole life is in this country, and my savings, too," he said. "Everything I've worked for is here. I don't want to go but nobody in this queue wants to go. But if things become unbearable, then I want to know I have someplace else to go."

webTitle: Mr Del Monte says yes to cholesterol lowering juice

fields.headline: Mr Del Monte says yes to cholesterol lowering juice
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Neutraceuticals battle it out with organic produce for the wallets of the health conscious
fields.trailText: Eat yourself healthy - it is the ultimate dream for every overindulger. Slurp a yoghurt to suppress your appetite, sip a fruit juice to cut your cholesterol level and finish off with a dairy product to aid your digestive system.
fields.body:
Eat yourself healthy - it is the ultimate dream for every overindulger. Slurp a yoghurt to suppress your appetite, sip a fruit juice to cut your cholesterol level and finish off with a dairy product to aid your digestive system.

Products that are chemically enhanced to improve health or cut the chance of chronic degenerative diseases are among the fastest growing sectors of the food business.

So-called functional foods - or nutraceuticals - are piling up ready for health-conscious shoppers.

A survey published yesterday by research group Mintel shows the British as increasingly aware of the health implications of what they eat. More than four in 10 adults now claim to limit the fat in their diet - up seven percentage points in just two years - while the number of consumers choosing to restrict their sugar intake has risen from 32% to 37% in 10 years.

A health education authority survey last year found 77% of adults using low-fat milk, 54% having cut their intake of fried food, 30% monitoring their salt intake and about half using low-saturate cooking oils or low-fat margarines.

Low-salt, low-fat and sugar free products, however, are not functional foods. They are health friendly foods - and the market is already vast.

The new health-enhancing nutraceuticals make direct claims about the impact they can have - such as "reduces cholesterol by 10%" - and they are growing rapidly.

Some have been developed by drug companies - like the Aviva range from Swiss group Novartis - while others are the products of biotech operations and food companies.

Scotia, for example, last year started test marketing Olibra, an appetite-suppressing yoghurt, in Sweden, while Heinz is promoting the lypocene in its ketchup as reducing the risk of cancer.

Last month Novartis set up a joint venture functional food company - to be named Altus Foods - with Quaker Oats. The Norwegian Nutri-Pharma biotech group this week announced a link with the American fruit and juices company, Del Monte, to produce a range of cholesterol-lowering fruit juices.

The juices will contain Nutri-Pharma's Abacor - a combination of soya protein and soya fibre said to lower cholesterol levels by 15-20% in four months.

So far, according to the accountancy company PwC, there are 102 functional foods and drinks on the market in nine European countries, and 65% of them are dairy-product related - such as Nestlé's LC1 pro-biotics dairy products range and the cholesterol-lowering Benecol spread.

Unsurprisingly, the biggest market for functional foods so far is the United States.

In 1998 American consumers bought £9bn worth of nutraceuticals while the market in Europe was just £830m. In the US 46% of functional foods are contained in cereals, 30% in drinks and just 12% in dairy products.

By the end of this year the European market is expected to top £2bn, with the US having grown to £11bn.

American producers face fewer regulatory hurdles be fore making medical claims on their packaging.

In Europe, all EU member countries have their own rules - and they vary widely.

British regulations prevent any claims about treating or curing illnesses unless a product has a licence under the Medicines Act.

But according to Mintel, which has calculated that sales of functional foods in Britain topped £250m last year, preventative claims can be made. "It is generally accepted", says Mintel, "that health promoting claims [like 'helps lower cholesterol'] rather than disease prevention claims [like 'helps prevent heart disease'] can be made - provided the claims are underpinned with sound science and not misleading."

Neil Sutton of PwC believes price to be the most important driver. He says that functional foods will have to be marketed at lower premiums than they are at present.

Benecol, for example, costs approximately four times the price of a normal spread - and Sutton says it is unlikely to become a mass market prod uct in Britain until that premium is eroded.

There are other problems, too, at least in the domestic market. Mintel's research shows that 80% of British consumers do not believe the health claims made by food manufacturers.

British shoppers, says Mintel, have been all but won over by the claims of organic food - which by definition has no additives - as the healthiest way to eat, while functional food is based on additive enhancements.

The two sectors, organic and functional, are competitors - and organic has a head start.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A clear signal of higher British interest rates did little to dent the market yesterday and a late surge on the back on US hi-tech stocks helped propel the FTSE index 110.9 points higher to 6,184.9.
fields.body:
A clear signal of higher British interest rates did little to dent the market yesterday and a late surge on the back on US hi-tech stocks helped propel the FTSE index 110.9 points higher to 6,184.9.

Given that it was selected telecom, media and technology issues that hauled the index upward, the "don't panic" investment fraternity may have allowed themselves a pat on the back after the close of business last night. In fact, the generally poorer performers on both sides of the Atlantic were the "old economy" stocks widely expected to do well in what had been forecast as a cataclysmic week.

All the broader FTSE indexes closed firmer, but also off highs, with the Techmark 100 index reducing earlier strong gains to just 38 points as the Nasdaq fell back again. London shares started strongly, boosted by a bounce in telecom, media and technology following Nasdaq's sharp overnight recovery.

A batch of positive earnings reports after-hours from the likes of Intel and IBM also provided British technology issues with a lift.

As the morning session progressed, the early shine was taken off the market by rising concerns about the outlook for interest rates.

After Tuesday's slightly above-forecast inflation report, yesterday's weaker than expected March average earnings figures were offset by hawkish comments from the Bank of England MPC's latest minutes.

Blue Circle was the most active blue chip issue after Lafarge raised its offer to 450p per share, up from its original 420p bid, and moved to buy 20% of the British group's stock in the market.

Amvescap was the biggest gainer on the FTSE 100 leaders board, advancing 92p to 824p after reporting strong first-quarter figures.

Among other financial issues, Woolwich gained 10p to 320p. Lloyds TSB rallied 15p to 640p after its move to impose a smaller than expected 50p charge on cash machine transactions for non-customers.

Technology issues remained in focus. Sage Group was the main technology highlight, up 65p at 677p, boosted by positive comment from Merrill Lynch. ARM Holdings was also active in its new form following the group's share split. It added 28p to 662p.

Bid speculation provided other pockets of interest. Cable & Wireless remained in demand, up 52p at £10.01, as news that Deutsche Telecom has renewed its right to issue new shares triggered a revival of vague takeover talk. Emap also remained in demand - up 38p at £11.38 - as speculation persisted that Yahoo! was lining up a bid.

webTitle: Talks fail to give hope of peace

fields.headline: Talks fail to give hope of peace
fields.standfirst:
First reports of rape give hollow ring to vow on violence

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe's meeting yesterday with leaders of Zimbabwe's white farmers failed to offer them any hope of an early resolution to the crisis, and last night the first reports of rape raised the political temperature among whites.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe's meeting yesterday with leaders of Zimbabwe's white farmers failed to offer them any hope of an early resolution to the crisis, and last night the first reports of rape raised the political temperature among whites.

Mr Mugabe said war veterans would not be asked to vacate land they have already occupied while a programme is formulated to deal with the issue of land resettlement. However, all sides agreed to refrain from violent action.

Earlier in the day the man held to be leader of the veterans' movement, "Hitler" Hunzvi, was convicted of contempt of court for continuing to support the occupations despite a court order last month. He left the court for the president's office in defiant mood.

"The position of the president cannot be challenged by anyone else," Mr Hunzvi said outside the court. "He says they [the war veterans] must stay on the farms and that he will redistribute the land. I cannot act against that order."

Following his meeting with Mr Mugabe, however, he adopted a more conciliatory tone. "Hostilities should cease and we should work towards a solution," he said.

But even as the talks were taking place in the capital, Harare, the veterans stepped up their campaign of land invasions elsewhere.

A Commercial Farmers Union representative said members had counted at least 350 men arriving in buses in Matabeleland, about 250 miles south-west of Harare.

"It looks like they're organising a strike onto farms at the weekend. We expect Easter will be a horrible time," he said.

The unfolding state-sponsored violence continued across the country yesterday. Two white women were beaten and raped at Chedgelow farm, near Harare airport.

The farms on the road leading to the airport have been overrun by poor city-dwellers seeking plots for homes. Chedgelow farm was invaded and the two women were taken captive, beaten and raped. Speaking after their ordeal the women said the invaders accused them of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) as they were raped.

A policeman and two white farmers have been killed since thousands of veterans of Zimbabwe's war of liberation began an occupation of hundreds of white-owned farms in February, pushing Zimbabwe to the brink of anarchy.

Following the two murders of white farmers, hundreds of farming families have left their properties. At least 100 white farmers moved off their properties in the southern Matabeleland region after the murder on Tuesday of Martin Olds. Nearly 50 moved off their farms in the Macheke Virginia area of central Zimbabwe last weekend following the killing of David Stevens. Scores more farming families have abandoned their farms across the country.

"After these two killings, our farmers are frightened," said an official with the farmers' organisation. "Farmers who have been threatened, farmers who have had violence, are worried. They fear they could be next and so they are moving off until things settle down."

The MDC catalogued more than a dozen attacks on its members as well as ordinary citizens in the past week. The attacks were carried out by war veterans, members of the central intelligence organisation and supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF.

webTitle: Bottleneck End of duty free sales slows Eurotunnel traffic

fields.headline: Bottleneck End of duty free sales slows Eurotunnel traffic
fields.trailText: Eurotunnel announced yesterday that the abolition of duty free sales has led to a sharp drop in the number of people taking their cars on the Channel tunnel shuttle service.
fields.body:
Eurotunnel announced yesterday that the abolition of duty free sales has led to a sharp drop in the number of people taking their cars on the Channel tunnel shuttle service.

The number of cars, motorcycles and caravans car ried in the first three months of the year fell 17% to 591,095 from the same period last year.

The company blamed the end of duty free and the price rises necessary in its wake. It is raising prices this summer to between 5% and 19% higher than in 1999. Fares for a car and its passengers will start at £44, going up to £399 during peak times.

But Eurotunnel said that it had increased its market share for car traffic across the Channel from 59% last year to 61%.

There has also been an in crease in the number of trucks using the tunnel. Almost 264,000 travelled between January 1 and the end of March, up 42% from the same period in 1999.

The increase raised Eurotunnel's share of the cross-Channel truck market, which it has struggled to dominate in the face of competition from the ferries, from 38% to 46%.

March was a record month for the freight shuttles with 98,157 trucks, while a daily record of 4,156 trucks was set on March 29.

The surge came after Eurotunnel increased its capacity from seven freight shuttles to 10 last year.

Overall, net revenues fell just 1% to £126.3m, a figure that Eurotunnel claimed showed that it had succeeded in overcoming the problems of the withdrawal of duty free.

fields.headline: Focus  Enic
fields.trailText: Enic, the sports and media investment group, has turned a loss of £331,000 for the last half of 1998 into a profit of £14.5m for the same period last year, helped by the stock market performance of Autonomy Corporation.
fields.body:
Enic, the sports and media investment group, has turned a loss of £331,000 for the last half of 1998 into a profit of £14.5m for the same period last year, helped by the stock market performance of Autonomy Corporation.

The sale of a £10.2m stake in Autonomy, the Easdaq-listed software company which Enic backed at the seed capital stage, helped offset the £2.8m loss in Enic's enter tainment division. In 1998 the division made a profit of £1.3m. Enic still holds 1.5m Autonomy shares, worth about £108m.

Chairman Howard Stanton said trading in the Warner Brothers Studio stores Enic operates had been difficult, but that recent weeks have shown signs of improvement. "We continue to take action at every level within the business to improve the overall performance of the business and have already made changes to the entire management team, as well as refocusing buying procedures," he said. The late opening of a new theme restaurant located in Las Vegas also hit trading projections.

Mr Stanton said Enic would aim to build on its success in new media investment. The company is in the process of buying Victor Chandler International, the offshore betting organisation based in Gibraltar. Due diligence has taken longer than expected, Mr Stanton said.

Enic has also taken a £5m stake in Paradigm Media Investments, an Aim-listed media investment vehicle. Joe Lewis, the Bahamas-based currency dealer who backed Enic, is also a shareholder.

Enic shares closed up 19p at 212p.

webTitle: Prescott fails to quell air traffic rebellion

fields.headline: Prescott fails to quell air traffic rebellion
fields.standfirst:
Labour leadership alarmed at size of revolt over part-privatisation

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott last night failed to quell a potentially lethal revolt among Labour MPs over his £500m plans for partial privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system - despite a last-minute attempt to adopt a more conciliatory tone.
fields.body:
John Prescott last night failed to quell a potentially lethal revolt among Labour MPs over his £500m plans for partial privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system - despite a last-minute attempt to adopt a more conciliatory tone.

More than 60 MPs are now poised to reject the deputy prime minister's preferred model for modernisation of the national air traffic control service (Nats) when the bill resumes its passage through the Commons on May 9-10.

Almost 100 MPs have signed a hostile Commons motion. If the rebels can woo 20 more supporters they believe they can force ministers to back down and change the scheme or postpone the part-sale. "The sale of mobile phone licences could be worth £25bn to the Treasury, this is only worth £500m or £600m. Is it worth it?" said one MP.

After bad-tempered exchanges in private with backbenchers over the controversial proposals - in which neither side backed down - Mr Prescott yesterday published a dismissive response to criciticisms made by the all-party Commons transport committee.

His tone was described as "peevish" by Labour colleagues. They even revealed that the government's response - withdrawn soon after it was posted on the internet - had been redrafted at the last minute to moderate its harsh language.

It emerged later that Mr Prescott's statement has been rewritten at least three times by officials.

MPs said the changes were the result of Mr Prescott's meeting with MPs where he had "tried to crack heads together", without success. "He was very defensive, in pure bluster mode," said one.

Declaring himself deeply disappointed by the report, Mr Prescott said: "I do not accept the committee's conclusion that the PPP (public-private partnership) was the worst possible option, given its unwillingness to accept evidence to the contrary. In particular, the committee fails to take account of the unique set of safeguards for safety and public accountability."

The official response again defended PPP - which will see 51% of Nats sold off to the private sector - against the two rival models, both of which are preferred by many Labour MPs. One would turn Nats into an independent publicly-owned corporation like the Post Office, the other would make it a non-profit trust like the Canadian system. Each would allow private sector management skills to be deployed.

Mr Prescott's critics, led by his former deputy, Gavin Strang, have voiced concerns about safety for passengers in Britain's crowded skies.The RAF and the unions are also opposed to the Prescott option.

They say the private sector will have "complete operational control" and could sell the assets on.

Mr Prescott argues that PPP would deliver the major investment Nats needed, allow Nats to sell its expertise overseas and expand into other markets as global air traffic systems consolidate.

Government whips are increasingly concerned at the situation. They say that apart from section 28, this is the one big issue which could divide Labour MPs this summer.

The government's worries were demonstrated yesterday when Lord Macdonald, transport minister, refused to take questions at an air industry lunch where he made a speech backing the privatisation.

webTitle: Sit vac: cleaner required for Augean stables

fields.headline: Sit vac: cleaner required for Augean stables
fields.standfirst: Changes at the exchange
fields.trailText: A new chairman is expected to be ushered in to the troubled stock exchange this morning - and not before time. The London market is in transition. One of our grandest financial institutions is feeling the white heat of technological change and old-fashioned commercial competition.
fields.body:
A new chairman is expected to be ushered in to the troubled stock exchange this morning - and not before time. The London market is in transition. One of our grandest financial institutions is feeling the white heat of technological change and old-fashioned commercial competition.

Its business model has been torn into shreds.

The new man - or maybe woman - will need gravitas and grace, as well as being a tough negotiator and an experienced diplomat.

The job, beefed up from the non-executive role at present held by John Kemp-Welch, will be announced just as unconfirmed merger talks with the upstart Deutsche Borse in Frankfurt enter their most delicate phase.

There have been reports that the Germans will end up owning of half the new entity, and the source of these reports - the Wall Street Journal - suggests that they are true. There are no prizes for guessing how this is going down among some of the City's older hands.

Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley - London's three biggest market players, which also happen to be American - are rumoured to be the driving forces behind the tie-up with Deutsche Borse.

It started as a plan to create a pan-European stock exchange in which London clearly had a leading hand, but appears to have become a takeover plan after squabbling broke out.

Big firms such as these want to cut the costs of dealing, and more importantly settling, shares to the levels now seen in the US. One way quick route towards this is through consolidation.

The new boss will have to call on all his or her gravitas to help the exchange scramble to restore its battered reputation in the City after its disaster two weeks ago, when share dealing started at 3.30pm - the time most share dealers were thinking of packing up and going home.

Such fiascos cannot be allowed to happen again.

By rights, the chairman of the stock exchange is a position which aspiring City grandees should be ready to kill for. But the last 14 disaster-strewn years has ensured that it is a job that many of the most suitably talented and experienced candidates dare not even touch.

We must simply hope that today we are pleasantly surprised.

Buy euros

The resignation of an Italian prime minister is not unusual event, so at first glance it is hard to see why foreign exchange dealers should choose yesterday to dump the euro, sending it to a new lifetime low against the dollar.

There have been 57 Italian governments since the end of the second world war. The loss of another one does little to change the outlook for strong growth and a sensible macroeconomic policy in the eurozone.

In truth, the markets have been looking for an opportunity to sell the euro since the weekend's G7 meeting in Washington - which failed to offer anything in the way of support, verbal or otherwise.

Yesterday's shenanigans in Rome, together with a threat from Austria's far right leader, Jörg Haider, to withdraw from the EU, were too good an opportunity for dealers to miss. But there was no real logic in the move.

The economic fundamentals continue to favour a recovering Europe, not the US, which at some stage must reach the sunset of an extraordinary upswing.

The US stock market may have stabilised in the last couple of days after last Friday's heavy losses. But the threat of a reaction to higher interest rates is still there - witness yesterday's US trade figures. The commerce department data showed imports outstripping exports by a record $29bn, despite a rebound in the world economy boosting year on year export growth. Just as last week's news of a sharp rise in core inflation can be seen as evidence of domestic demand getting out of control, so too can a widening trade deficit.

Excess domestic demand, running way ahead of domestic supply, is being met by goods from abroad, thus providing the US with an inflation safety valve. But the trade gap cannot go on widening for ever. Sooner or later the foreign investors at present paying the US's soaring import bill will get nervous, putting the dollar at risk of a big sell-off.

A weaker dollar would sharply increase imported inflation, which is already showing, forcing the Federal Reserve to respond with higher interest rates, possibly much higher than the market is anticipating.

In the short term, the euro may continue to languish and need to be propped up by further rises in interest rates. An increase at next week's meeting of the European Central Bank seems a sure bet. But in the medium to long term, the euro is most definitely the currency to buy, not sell.

fields.headline: Byers warns TV hire chain
fields.standfirst: Box Clever ordered to freeze charges and drop upgrade fees
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, has imposed strict pricing restrictions on Radio Rentals and Granada to ensure that a planned £1bn merger of their rental chains does not restrict access to new hi-tech televisions.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, has imposed strict pricing restrictions on Radio Rentals and Granada to ensure that a planned £1bn merger of their rental chains does not restrict access to new hi-tech televisions.

Mr Byers has ordered the two companies to freeze rental charges for at least five years, and to drop administration fees for customers who want to upgrade to new models.

Unless the companies agree to the conditions Mr Byers will refer the tie-up to the Competition Commission.

"Rental is an important option for particular groups in society, including the elderly," Mr Byers said.

He wanted to ensure that the new company, Box Clever, did not exploit such groups.

Box Clever will have more than 900 shops, dwarfing any other high street television rental chains.

Radio Rentals and Granada insisted they were unconcerned by the restrictions.

Roger Mavity, chief executive of Granada Technology Group, said: "The direction this is pointing is towards trying to protect existing customers. We're very sympathetic towards that.

"As far as the draft undertakings are concerned, we're very happy.

"But as far as the detail is concerned, we haven't had a chance to look at it closely."

The two companies will negotiate details with the office of fair trading. There will also be a consultation period in which interested parties can offer their views.

One such party, Age Concern, gave the measures a cautious welcome yesterday. A spokesman said: "We're glad that Stephen Byers has raised this concern about elderly people. We'll be looking in detail at whether these undertakings will be adequate."

The rental market has been declining in recent years but it is likely to become a crucial battleground as the new generation digital televisions gain in popularity.

Many customers are likely to rent equipment with the intention of upgrading as new models arrive.

At present, Radio Rentals and Granada charge an administration fee of about £20 for each upgrade in addition to increasing the hire rate.

The companies argue that although Box Clever will command a dominant position in rentals, it will have only 7% of the overall market for supplying televisions.

Mr Mavity said: "We're much smaller businesses than the likes of Dixons and Comet. We're the underdogs and we're very keen to close that gap."

Granada and Radio Rentals announced they were to combine their rental outlets in December. The deal is backed by private equity group WestLB.

webTitle: Newscom results to trigger bidding war

fields.headline: Newscom results to trigger bidding war
fields.trailText: The way is now clear for a bidding war to break out over regional newspaper group News Communications & Media (Newscom).
fields.body:
The way is now clear for a bidding war to break out over regional newspaper group News Communications & Media (Newscom).

Three potential buyers - Newsquest, Johnston Press and Trinity Mirror - are waiting in the wings for Southampton-based Newscom. Their putative bids were cleared by the competition commission earlier this month, but the three have been holding off for Newscom's latest financial figures, published yesterday, before renewing overtures.

John Dux, Newscom chief executive, said a series of meetings with the potential bidders had been scheduled for the next few days.

"The process is now up and running and will lead towards any of the three formalising their offers toward the end of the month," he said. "We will then be able to consider our options - one of which would be to remain independent. It is all pretty civilised."

Newscom is Britain's eighth largest regional newspaper group, with 120 titles, including the South Wales Argus and the Hampshire Chronicle. Its shares yesterday climbed 100p to £16.50, giving the business a market value of £379m.

Newsquest, which is owned by Gannett, the US publisher, was the first to throw its hat into the ring last November.

Mr Dux said that he accepted the rationale for consolidation in the regional newspaper industry. "Obviously our view was we would have liked to have been the ones at the helm of a larger group, but you have to be realistic," he said.

Newscom reported a 76% increase in pre-tax profits to £7.9m in the first quarter, on the back of strong advertising and cost cutting. Turnover was £37.1m.

"It's a bit of double edged sword," Mr Dux added. "We are doing the business which is reflected in our numbers but at the same time that makes you attractive to buyers."

"The process is now up and running and will lead towards any of the three formalising their offers toward the end of the month," he said. "We will then be able to consider our options - one of which would be to remain independent. It is all pretty civilised." Newscom is Britain's eighth largest regional newspaper group, with 120 titles, including the South Wales Argus and the Hampshire Chronicle. Its shares yesterday climbed 100p to £16.50, giving the business a market value of £379m. Newsquest, which is owned by Gannett, the US publisher, was the first to throw its hat into the ring last November. Mr Dux said that he accepted the rationale for consolidation in the regional newspaper industry. "Obviously our view was we would have liked to have been the ones at the helm of a larger group, but you have to be realistic," he said. Newscom reported a 76% increase in pre-tax profits to £7.9m in the first quarter, on the back of strong advertising and cost cutting. Turnover was £37.1m. "It's a bit of double edged sword," Mr Dux added. "We are doing the business which is reflected in our numbers but at the same time that makes you attractive to buyers."

fields.headline: Lafarge grabs 20% of Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Lafarge, the French building materials group, yesterday bought 20% of Blue Circle Industries in a dawn raid within an hour of increasing its bid for the British cement company from £3.4bn to £3.65bn.
fields.body:
Lafarge, the French building materials group, yesterday bought 20% of Blue Circle Industries in a dawn raid within an hour of increasing its bid for the British cement company from £3.4bn to £3.65bn.

Bertrand Collomb, Lafarge's chief executive, said he would not increase the 450p offer further except in the unlikely event of a counterbid.

The Blue Circle board immediately rejected the new offer, saying that it fell well short of the company's true worth.

Mr Collomb launched a vigorous attack on Blue Circle's bid defence, saying the company had promised more than it could deliver.

He claimed Blue Circle would not be able to deliver promised 20% savings worth more than £100m within two years, nor solve problems with its Malaysian operations.

He dismissed the proposed cost saving operation as "a consultant's dream without much explanation".

Mr Collomb said that the Blue Circle directors were inviting shareholders to "a world of wonderland where every wish is satisfied very easily and quickly" - and that things were different in the real world.

The Lafarge chief said that Blue Circle's share price, profits and earnings per share over the past four years had been disappointing compared with other companies in the sector.

The Blue Circle board's plan to return £800m to shareholders would leave the company with no room for manoeuvre for at least two years, he said.

Blue Circle's chief executive, Rick Haythornthwaite, said: "Throughout this bid Lafarge has sought to denigrate Blue Circle's prospects in order to buy the company on the cheap."

He said was not not concerned about the 20% bought by the French group. "Just over 10% was held by arbs, and there was only 10% of loose holders, which is not unusual in our sector."

If Lafarge was able to lift its holding to 29%, Blue Circle would have to listen harder to its other shareholders, he said. "We are not going to fly in the face of what shareholders want."

Blue Circle, which has been under siege since early February, has issued five defence documents. Mr Haythornthwaite said: "We are winning the argument.

"The analysts have had chapter and verse from us on all the points raised by Lafarge and have acknowledged the strategy is sound.

"It is a strategy of a newly reinvented company over the past three years. This is about quality of earnings and growth going forward."

Lafarge has European commission approval for its bid, but is still awaiting the green light from American and Canadian authorities.

He said the group was limited to taking a 20% stake in Blue Circle under Canadian competition regulations. Discussions about disposing of two Canadian plants, seen as essential for clearance from the north American authorities, were well advanced.

webTitle: Capital lifts cash bid to win control of Border

fields.headline: Capital lifts cash bid to win control of Border
fields.trailText: Capital Radio won control of Border Television yesterday by increasing its cash offer which valued the business at £151m, in a strike against the rival suitor Scottish Radio Holdings.
fields.body:
Capital Radio won control of Border Television yesterday by increasing its cash offer which valued the business at £151m, in a strike against the rival suitor Scottish Radio Holdings.

Capital lifted the cash alternative in its bid from £13 to £14 a share, securing the 9.7% stake in Border held by Edinburgh Fund Management and adding to irrevocable agreements already covering 25.3% of the shares.

Richard Findlay, Scottish Radio's chief executive, conceded defeat: "Capital's offer is a very high one and more than we are prepared to pay."

The company will more than cover the cost of the bid by taking the cash offer for its 351,000 Border shares.

Capital is understood to have been encouraged to lift its offer by securing the sale of Border's TV assets to Granada for £50.5m over the weekend.

The cash alternatives on the table became key because the continued volatility of the stock market caused the share offers to fluctuate wildly in value.

Capital's offer of 92 new shares for every 100 in Border remains on the table. After an 8% increase in the Capital share price to £13.05 yesterday the paper offer valued Border shares at £12 each. The Border share price closed 62p higher at £13.75.

webTitle: Blair tries to raise Mugabe pressure

fields.headline: Blair tries to raise Mugabe pressure
fields.standfirst:
Commonwealth and UN resist push for greater involvement

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair, the prime minister, condemned the murders in Zimbabwe as barbaric yesterday, as he insisted Britain was pursuing "every avenue", including the Commonwealth and the UN, to put pressure on President Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, the prime minister, condemned the murders in Zimbabwe as barbaric yesterday, as he insisted Britain was pursuing "every avenue", including the Commonwealth and the UN, to put pressure on President Robert Mugabe.

But the Commonwealth and the UN were yesterday resisting pressure to become directly involved. Other parts of the international community, too, including African states, showed a reluctance to be drawn in.

The exception was Nigeria, whose president, Olusegun Obasanjo, sent an envoy to Mr Mugabe expressing concern about the breakdown of law.

Mr Blair was urged in the Commons by the Tory leader, William Hague, to press for a Commonwealth delegation to be sent to Zimbabwe to persuade Mr Mugabe to uphold the rule of law. He added that suspension of Zimbabwe from the Commonwealth should be considered.

The prime minister stressed that a meeting with Commonwealth ministers was scheduled for May 2 at which action could be discussed. He said the government was in touch with African leaders, but added: "It is important that the action we take helps people in Zimbabwe and does not make the situation worse for them."

The main thrust of government policy is to ensure Mr Mugabe honours his commitment to hold a general election next month.

Although the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, has used harsh language in condemning Mr Mugabe, the government has avoided calls for sanctions and suspension from the Commonwealth.

A boost for this approach was came yesterday when Harare set a date, April 27, for a meeting in London between a delegation of its ministers and the British government to discuss land reform.

British ministers have been trying for the last week to increase international pressure on Mr Mugabe, but about the only supporter so far has been Nigeria. Its envoy briefed the foreign secretary Robin Cook yesterday on his talks with the Zimbabwean president.

The foreign office said Mr Cook had also spoken early yesterday to the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, who then called Mr Mugabe to express concern about the violence.

However, Mr Annan said yesterday that Mr Mugabe was taking steps to defuse, not inflame, the crisis, despite his denunciation of white farmers. Mr Annan said he was encouraged that Mugabe had agreed to send the delegation to London next week, adding that "we should all encourage efforts at dialogue".

"My sense is he's taking the situation in hand and taking steps to defuse it and I've encouraged him to do that," Annan told reporters.

Mr Cook welcomed Mr Annan's intervention and news of the London meeting: "I'm encouraged by the outcome. We appear to have got an agreement from President Mugabe to return to dialogue."

Ahmed Fawzi, director of the UN office in London, played down the part the UN could play. He said the UN considered it an internal crisis and would not send observers unless invited by Zimbabwe.

"I believe it's very important to involve regional organisations such as the SADC (South African Development Community) and eventually the Commonwealth to play a role before the UN becomes involved," he said.

The Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon, was also cautious about going beyond condemning the violence: "The deaths that have occurred in Zimbabwe - both white people and African people - are just appalling."

But he declined to comment on Mr Mugabe's denunciation of white farmers as "enemies of Zimbabwe".

"Election campaigns in any country create their own tension," he said.

fields.headline: Royal Bank rules outmass closures
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland will cut 9,000 jobs by year-end after buying NatWest but will spare its branch network of a mass closure programme.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland will cut 9,000 jobs by year-end after buying NatWest but will spare its branch network of a mass closure programme.

Royal Bank, which is retaining the NatWest name on the high street, also intends to close NatWest's grand Lothbury headquarters in the City by June and is looking for a buyer for the property.

Making a progress report after its first 30 days at the helm of NatWest, Royal Bank acknowledged for the first time that Don Cruickshank, head of the chancellor's banking review team, had wanted its £18bn acquisition of NatWest to be subjected to a full-blown competition investigation. In the event, the acquisition, which succeeded after a bitter tussle with Bank of Scotland, was not referred to the competition commission.

Sir George Mathewson, deputy chairman of Royal Bank, also revealed an ambitious goal to boost pre-tax profit to £5bn "as soon as possible," overtaking Lloyds TSB and matching HSBC's levels of profitability in the process.

Combined with NatWest, Royal Bank made pre-tax profits of £3.2bn last year, more than Barclays but less than Lloyds TSB and HSBC. However, the bank's market capitalisation is lower than all three and Fred Goodwin, chief executive of Royal Bank, make it clear the bank would now launch a charm offensive on the City and investors to try to boost its share price.

Mr Goodwin said the bank had increased its £1bn estimate for cost savings after its first month inside NatWest to £1.3bn, including inflation and new initiatives, but admitted that the cost savings would cost £60m more than had been expected.

Part of the higher cost of achieving the savings over a three year period was because there were "reasonably expensive individuals to get rid off," Mr Goodwin said.

In the light of the recent closure of 171 branches by Barclays, Mr Goodwin played down the possibility of achieving cost saving through branch closures and insisted that NatWest and Royal Bank branches would remain side-by-side on the high street, although he admitted that branches would be closed from time to time.

Mr Goodwin insisted there was "not an intention to harmonise the two brands".

Royal Bank refused to disclose how many people had left since the takeover but said it had been in negotiations with the unions about harmonising the severance terms for NatWest and Royal Bank staff. The 9,000 jobs to be cut by the end of the year will mean the bank will achieve half of its 18,000 reduction from the 94,000 workforce within seven months.

fields.headline: £520bn Tokyo banking merger
fields.trailText: Japan's wave of financial mergers continued yesterday when Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi and Mitsubishi Trust and Banking announced plans to integrate their businesses under a single holding company to create the world's fifth-largest banking group.
fields.body:
Japan's wave of financial mergers continued yesterday when Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi and Mitsubishi Trust and Banking announced plans to integrate their businesses under a single holding company to create the world's fifth-largest banking group.

Two of BTM's subsidiaries will join the alliance by October, and two insurers are considering doing likewise. The new venture, tentatively named Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, will hold combined assets of 87 trillion yen (about £526bn).

Mitsubishi Trust and BTM have faired better than most during the Japanese banking crisis, and were thought unlikely to tie the knot.

Analysts said the banks would not necessarily see their increase in assets matched by improved profitability.

But BTM said the new holding company would enable the banks to offer better quality services. BTM is expected to concentrate on conventional banking, while Mitsubishi Trust will focus on pension funds, securities and asset management.

Stock market reaction was mixed. BTM's shares fell 5.29 % to close at 1468 yen, while Mitsubishi Trust, which analysts say stands to benefit more from the alliance, shares rose 8.62 % to 958 yen.

webTitle: Bob the Builder in Atlantic crossing

fields.headline: Bob the Builder in Atlantic crossing
fields.trailText: Bob the Builder and his friends Scoop, Dizzy and Muck are about to cross the Atlantic. The television production company which owns the cartoon characters, Hit Entertainment, has signed a licensing deal for Hasbro to produce a range of soft toys, vehicles, games and electronic products in north America. Hasbro, which makes Tonka trucks and Monopoly board games, expects the toys to be on the shelves by autumn 2001.
fields.body:
Bob the Builder and his friends Scoop, Dizzy and Muck are about to cross the Atlantic. The television production company which owns the cartoon characters, Hit Entertainment, has signed a licensing deal for Hasbro to produce a range of soft toys, vehicles, games and electronic products in north America. Hasbro, which makes Tonka trucks and Monopoly board games, expects the toys to be on the shelves by autumn 2001.

Hasbro illustrated its determination to strike a deal when chairman Alan Hassenfeld plus four executives arrived for a meeting with Hit all dressed as Bob the Builder.

The show will be shown five times a week in the US from next year. Chief executive Peter Orton said that the combination of such television exposure, a strong consumer products performance in the UK and Hasbro's marketing expertise raised the prospects of Bob the Builder becoming a major brand in the US.

Analysts believe the deal could net Hit around £19m. The company already has a deal with Mattel to sell toys based on its character Angelina Ballerina.

"Hit now has two of the world's largest toy companies endorsing and distributing its products which can only help the value of the characters themselves," said Celia Leaberry, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Bob the Builder television series are now sold in 88 countries, with 100 associated merchandising products on sale in the UK, contributing to a recent 46% increase in the company's interim profits to £2m.

fields.headline: Groucho repels
fields.standfirst: Club says no to takeover
fields.trailText: The Groucho Club, the Soho hangout favoured by media types, has received a hostile takeover approach from a syndicate led by a 29-year-old Old Etonian.
fields.body:
The Groucho Club, the Soho hangout favoured by media types, has received a hostile takeover approach from a syndicate led by a 29-year-old Old Etonian.

Benjamin Fry, one of the founders of K-bar, the nightclub company which also owns the Livebait fish restaurant chain, says his £9m offer to buy the club has been rejected by its chairman and largest shareholder, Tony Mackintosh.

Mr Fry has now written directly to the Groucho's 315 shareholders, who include Steve Martin, Janet Street-Porter, Ken Follet and Lord Archer, offering them £2.30 per share in cash.

Much of the success of his bid will depend on gaining acceptances from the Groucho's two largest shareholders - Mr Mackintosh, who owns 20%, and his business partner Tchaik Chassay. Mr Fry says that he held six months of discussions with Mr Mackintosh about making a bid before the latter called off talks.

Mr Mackintosh said yesterday: "I acknowledge there have been a number of discussions with Benjamin Fry about collaborations on various things but that is all I am prepared to say right now."

Mr Fry says he wants to merge the Groucho's properties with his own two London hotels. He also plans to open a Groucho club in Los Angeles.

The club's latest joint venture, Groucho Saint Jude's in Glasgow, above left, is expected to record a loss this financial year after higher than expected building costs and some disappointing trading.

"The current approach to the company's development could, in my opinion, leave both ultimately at the mercy of the liquidator," Mr Fry said.

The Groucho company was established as part of a a business expansion scheme in 1984. The first shares were issued at 29p each, and now trade at 150p. No shares have been traded since September last year. The hostile offer represents a premium of more than 50% on the present market price.

In the 24 weeks to November 14 1999, the company made a pre-tax profit of £250,000 on turnover of £2.4m.

fields.headline: Court win for RAC pensioners
fields.trailText: Solicitors acting for hundreds of retired members of the Royal Automobile Club who missed out on payouts of £34,000 a head in last year's sale of its breakdown service won a victory yesterday.
fields.body:
Solicitors acting for hundreds of retired members of the Royal Automobile Club who missed out on payouts of £34,000 a head in last year's sale of its breakdown service won a victory yesterday.

The pensioners argue that the committee and directors of the club had no right to engage in sale negotations and were prohibited from selling the club under the rules laid down when the club was first set up.

The directors had negotiated a sale of the breakdown service to the US services company Cendant, but when the government banned that deal on competition grounds the service was sold to Lex.

Lord Nourse gave the pensioners leave to appeal against an earlier judgement striking out the action.

Stephen Alexander of solicitors Class Law, which is representing the pensioners and others excluded from the payouts, said: "This is a matter of public importance. The fight very much goes on."

fields.headline: Directors split over euro
fields.standfirst: Breakaway group calls on leaders to end open support for anti-European group
fields.trailText: A row erupted yesterday in the Institute of Directors when a breakaway group accused the leadership of running a misleading campaign against Britain joining the single European currency.
fields.body:
A row erupted yesterday in the Institute of Directors when a breakaway group accused the leadership of running a misleading campaign against Britain joining the single European currency.

In a letter to George Cox, the IoD's director general, the disaffected fellows said leading figures in the institute were letting down British business by actively supporting the Business for Sterling group, which is campaigning against the euro.

The letter was sparked by the growing frustration among pro-European business leaders that some IoD figures have openly aligned themselves with anti-Europeans.

Ruth Lea, the IoD's head of policy, is a member of the national council of Business for Sterling and regularly speaks out against the euro. The former Thatcherite cabinet minister, Lord Young of Graffam, who has been the IoD's president since 1993, is a driving force behind the anti-European group.

In their letter the business leaders said they were "genuinely concerned" by the IoD's consistently anti-European message.

"Despite the contrary views often promulgated by the IoD leadership in London, British business maintains an open mind on the euro with most companies supporting the idea of joining in principle," the letter said.

"Indeed, this broad majority view is represented clearly in the IoD's own recent NOP opinion poll which shows that 67% of firms support the principle of British membership of the single currency."

The letter, which was co-ordinated by Stephen Pollock-Hill, the chair of the IoD's Hertfordshire branch, called on the London leadership to end its links with Business for Sterling. "Now is the time for the IoD to adopt a more thoughtful and balanced position on an issue of such critical importance to the business community and the country as a whole," the letter said.

The pro-European Business in Europe group said that the letter showed that the IoD's London leadership was failing to represent the views of its members. Simon Buckby, campaign director of Britain in Europe said: "The IoD's formal and informal links with Business for Sterling are in opposition to belief of the majority of firms surveyed by the IoD who do not want to campaign against British membership of the single currency."

The row within the IoD came as Peter Mandelson said that the government would not rush into membership of the euro.

In a rebuff to business leaders who have called for Britain to join the currency zone, the Northern Ireland secretary said that there were "no shortcuts to sustainable stability and success".

His remarks came after the head of Nissan in Britain said that Britain should join the euro because the high value of the pound was damaging exports. Mr Mandelson's speech was also designed to damp down speculation about a cabinet division over the euro, with a pro-European faction led by himself and Robin Cook calling on the prime minister to sign up to the euro in the near future.

Ruth Lea, the IoD's head of policy, last night defended its position on the euro, saying that most IoD members were opposed to British membership of the single currency.

"We are not anti-European - we are all for staying in the EU," Ms Lea said.

"We are simply saying that Britain should not join the euro for the foreseeable future because the economic conditions are not yet right."

fields.headline: Mid-air collision kills three
fields.trailText: Three people, including a child, were killed last night when a plane which was seen performing acrobatics collided with another light aircraft in mid-air.
fields.body:
Three people, including a child, were killed last night when a plane which was seen performing acrobatics collided with another light aircraft in mid-air.

Police said that an investigation had been launched into the crash near Harlow, Essex, in which both male pilots and the child died instantly.

Both planes were believed to have been approaching the North Weald air field before the crash.

An Essex police spokesman said: "They were in collision and crashed to the ground. The exact cause is not known at this stage as it is obviously very early days. A full investigation is already under way."

A spokesman for the civil aviation authority said: "The two aircraft that crashed were a two-seater Cessna 150 and a single-seater Yak 50. They crashed near to North Weald airfield which is in a very rural environment."

Some debris came down near Mill House Farm, close to Harlow Common, according to eyewitnesses.

One said: "There are bits everywhere. The stuff was all coming down on the yard where I work. It hit one of the chaps on the head but he is not badly hurt. There are definitely fatalities over there, judging by the twisted and mangled wreckage."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Post Office buys Cashtec
fields.body:
Post Office buys Cashtec

The Post Office has bought a 49% stake in Cashtec, a private company which installs and services cash machines in Britain.

The Post Office, which is due to install cash machines in about 3,000 post offices over the next two years, paid £7m for the stake. The move comes at a time when post offices are increasingly providing basic banking services for a number of large banks, including Barclays and Lloyds TSB, which are closing rural branches.

The Post Office already has its own business distributing coins and notes to post offices, which are among the country's largest handlers of cash.

M&S decides to keep Kings

Marks & Spencer has taken its US supermarket operation Kings off the market after failing to attract a good offer for the chain.

The 25-strong New Jersey chain, was put on the market as "non-core" last September, but the struggling M&S group has been unable to find a buyer and will now retain ownership.

"Valuations for US food retailers have declined markedly since the company announced its intention to sell," said M&S. "We do not believe that present conditions allow a price for Kings that reflects either the financial performance of the existing operations or the potential for future growth".

A spokesman said: "Kings is profitable and getting more so, so we are going to keep it". Last year it made a £10m profit on sales of £254.5m.

German banks quash talk

Two of Germany's largest banks yesterday tried to quash rumours that they were vulnerable to takeover even by each other.

Dresdner, fresh from the collapse of its merger with Deutsche Bank, insisted it had the full support of its 22% shareholder Allianz, the insurance group, indicating it was under no pressure to enter another deal.

Meanwhile, Commerzbank, cited as a potential partner for Dresdner, said that a Dutch-based holding company now held 9.9% of shares, which it said would stabilise its shareholder base.

Ford to offload plant to Getrag

Ford Motor will start talks with Getrag of Germany on the sale of a 50% stake in one of its gearbox plants in Blanquefort, France, Cologne or Halwood in Britain, Ford France spokesman Roland Especelle said yesterday.

"The Ford Motor Company board has agreed that talks be begun with Getrag concerning three European sites that manufacture mechanical gearboxes," Mr Especelle said.

He said the plan was part of a global restructuring operation aimed at returning to an acceptable profit level.

He said Ford and Getrag would set up a joint venture from which Ford would be obliged to source its gearboxes for at least 10 years.

According to details of the plan posted on a notice board at the Blanquefort facility, a total of $650m (£411m) would be invested to develop new gearboxes for the European market.

webTitle: East end turns out for Charlie

fields.headline: East end turns out for Charlie
fields.trailText: The east end of London turned out in force yesterday for the funeral of Charlie Kray, elder brother of the infamous Kray twins, who died in prison earlier this month aged 73.
fields.body:
The east end of London turned out in force yesterday for the funeral of Charlie Kray, elder brother of the infamous Kray twins, who died in prison earlier this month aged 73.

Hundreds lined the route taken by the hearse and 23 limousines to St Matthew's church, Bethnal Green, where friends and family joined for a 50 minute service before driving to Chingford Mount cemetery for his burial, next to his brother Ron, mother Violet and son Gary, who died in 1996 aged 44.

The surviving Kray twin Reg, 66, who is serving a life sentence for murder, was given leave from Wayland prison, in Norfolk, to attend. He was handcuffed to a prison officer throughout.

His appearance drew shouts of "free him" and chants of "Reggie" from many in the crowd who broke into spontaneous applause.

Before the service Reg Kray moved up the aisle smiling and shaking hands with some of the 250-strong congregation, including old friends and associates.

Speaking to reporters about his brother, he said: "He was a very friendly person. The friendliest of people.

"I'm sure everyone gathered here today would like to see everyone more friendly to each other, more so than they are."

Paula Meek, a former top less model and a close friend of Charlie Kray, said: "He was a very nice, kind, warm man who knew how to enjoy himself. He will be missed."

Among the many floral tributes were a pair of boxing gloves made from red and white carnations. Alongside them was the message "sent by Friends from C Wing, HMP Parkhurst", where Kray died while serving a 12-year sentence for masterminding a cocaine smuggling plot.

Eileen Sheridan-Price, a friend of the Krays who met them after winning the 1958 Miss UK competition, was among the congregation.

She said: "Reg seemed fine, calm and glad to see so many people he knew. He shook my hand and thanked me."

As the coffin arrived at the church Shirley Bassey's song As Long As He Needs Me was played.

A poem recorded by Reg Kray was also heard in the church . It said: "Do not stand at my grave and weep. I am not there. I do not sleep."

webTitle: Financial adviser cheated clients to fund luxury living

fields.headline: Financial adviser cheated clients to fund luxury living
fields.trailText: A financial adviser who helped fund his delusions of grandeur by pocketing the life savings of clients was jailed for nearly four years by Judge Valerie Pearlman at Southwark crown court, south-east London yesterday.
fields.body:
A financial adviser who helped fund his delusions of grandeur by pocketing the life savings of clients was jailed for nearly four years by Judge Valerie Pearlman at Southwark crown court, south-east London yesterday.

Timothy Cray, prosecuting, said Jeremy Robertson's dishonesty seemed to have arisen out of his need to upgrade himself from financial adviser to broker to fit with the City environment he worked in.

"The hallmarks of that environment were living in a way that involved trips abroad, having plenty of cash to hand, eating in good restaurants, running a car such as a Porsche and matters like that."

It was the crown's case that Robertson, 42, used some of his ill gotten gains to maintain that lifestyle, with the rest variously funded by his £60,000 a year salary, loans and excessive credit card spending.

Those defrauded included his sister's husband. All were reimbursed by the companies he worked for.

Judge Pearlman, jailing him for three years and 10 months, told Robertson, of Greenwich, south-east London: "You abused the trust of your clients."

She added: "You diverted their funds into your personal bank and building society accounts and investment policies which you controlled by way of false documentation and bogus identities."

She accepted that, although he had misappropriated almost £350,000, £175,000 had been repaid - but only because people asking for their cash were paid with funds from other customers.

Robertson, a father of two whose wife has left him, now works as a minicab driver. He pleaded guilty to 15 counts of furnishing false information and 10 of procuring the execution of a valuable security by deception.

webTitle: Italian PM falls - currency sinks again

fields.headline: Italian PM falls - currency sinks again
fields.trailText: The euro sank to a new low against the US dollar yesterday as investor confidence stuttered in the wake of the Italian government's resignation.
fields.body:
The euro sank to a new low against the US dollar yesterday as investor confidence stuttered in the wake of the Italian government's resignation.

The decision of prime minister Massimo d'Alemas to quit prompted dealers to dump the currency despite news of another record US trade deficit.

The euro fell as low as 93.59 cents, surpassing the previous record low of 93.9.

Earlier, the US commerce department reported that the trade deficit for February rose to a record high of $29.2bn (£18.4bn), mainly due to higher oil import prices, which climbed to their highest level since the Gulf war nine years ago.

The dollar dipped briefly but recovered as news of the Italian government's resignation spread.

US commerce secretary William Daley said: "The US trade deficit is very high and is likely to remain so in coming months as our economy continues to outperform the economies of our major trading partners.

"At this point it is still economically sustainable."

Analysts said the trade figures reinforced expectations of further US rate rises to curb booming demand and prevent inflation rising. They were not far enough out of line with expectations to upset the jittery US equities market.
