fields.headline: Taking James home
fields.standfirst: Victor and Donna-Maria Barker's 12-year-old son was one of 29 people killed in the Omagh bomb. Today they will bring his body back to England. John Mullin reports Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Victor and Donna-Maria Barker's 12-year-old son was one of 29 people killed in the Omagh bomb. Today they will bring his body back to England.
fields.body:
As the sun rises over Buncrana in County Donegal this morning, Donna-Maria Barker will stand the saddest of vigils in the St Mary's churchyard just outside the town. She will be overseeing the exhumation of her 12-year-old son, James. Grave-diggers, screened from view, will lift him and place his coffin in the undertaker's hearse. He will return to his bedroom in the beautiful bungalow on Neds Point Road before beginning the long trip by road and air home to Ottershaw, Surrey.

He has never been to the family's new house in England, but will stay until Saturday morning, when, after a short, intimate service, he will be re-interred in a tiny, tranquil graveyard.

Buncrana has never seen anything quite like this before, and his parents' unorthodox approach to their son's burial is the chatter of the town. Opinion is divided, though sympathy is overwhelming for the English family who came in search of a dream.

James Barker was one of 29 people murdered in the Omagh bombing of August 15 1998, the single worst atrocity of the Troubles. Some include the heavily pregnant Avril Monaghan's unborn twins in the death toll, and say that there were 31 victims.

The Real IRA, dissident republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement, assassinated Catholics as well as Protestants in the County Tyrone town. They even managed to claim the life of a Mormon.

James had regarded the 11 months exploring the shores of Lough Swilly as the best of his life. He was mad about Chelsea football club, but he also wore the Irish Republic's green shirt with pride. His big sister, Estella, even now sneaks into his bedroom at night so she can sleep with it. Her mother finds it in her bed each morning, and takes it back to James's room. Nothing is ever said.

As Donna-Maria, 43, and her children, Erin-Esther, 21, Estella, 15, and five-year-old Oliver-Tristan accompany James today, she will reflect on the tragedy of a three-year-old vision. After school finishes in June, she vows never to set foot again in Ireland. They are selling their unfinished house.

She brought her three youngest children to rural Ireland in September 1997 to escape the home counties rat-race. Their new life was, for a time, the idyll she imagined.

Her husband Victor, 43, a solicitor based in Chertsey, Surrey, is a workaholic who rarely takes a break. They compromised on a holiday home across the Irish border from Derry, where she was brought up.

"Then I had the bright brainwave," says Donna-Maria. "Rather than use it as a holiday home, I suggested I should move over with the children. It was just so much a better quality of life and I thought it would be fantastic for them to grow up in the tranquillity of the place. We agreed, and Victor would come over every three weeks or so.

"Two weeks before James died I was having coffee with my mother. I remember saying to her: 'Nothing can spoil this. This is heaven.' "

Erin-Esther, who works with British Airways, stayed in England with Victor, while the others settled into their new lives. Estella loved her boarding school in Belfast, and James, a keen athlete, flourished at Foyle and Londonderry Preparatory school.

"It really was fabulous," says Donna-Maria. "James loved it. He had the type of freedom he could never have had in Surrey."

The day before he died, James spent an afternoon fishing with Victor in a boat on the lough. James sat on his dad's knee, telling him how much he loved it in Ireland. But he said he was sad he was unable to see more of him.

The Barkers had bought the house from a family who hosted Spanish pupils arriving in Buncrana each year on an exchange visit. The organisers called to check if the new owner would again take a student.

Estella was studying Spanish, and Donna-Maria figured it a good idea. They were joined by Uki Baselga, whose brother, Fernando, 12, stayed with a family nearby. He became inseparable from James.

They were shopping in Omagh after an organised bus visit to the Ulster-American Folk Museum just outside the town when the massive car bomb exploded. Fernando was killed outright, along with Spanish teacher Rocio Ramos, 23, and Sean McLoughlin, 12, and eight-year-old Oran Doherty, both from Buncrana.

James was blown on to a roof. He lived for more than three hours as doctors vainly pumped 18 pints of blood into him.

Donna-Maria thought the museum was in Belfast. Her mother was reassuring her on the phone at 6.47pm, the time James died, and it was only when her mum appeared at St John's restaurant in nearby Fahan at 10.30pm that she realised something was seriously awry.

There then followed a nightmare as they tried to secure information. They decided to head for Omagh, and were eventually guided to the town's leisure centre at 3.30am. It was to be four more hours before they learned the worst. They were the last of the bereaved to be told.

Donna-Maria says: "The other families had each other. We were on our own. We were total strangers.

"James was covered in a green blanket with a white handkerchief-sized cloth over his head. A man all in green with three-quarter wellies on him pulled it back.

"James had his head towards me, to the right. He had a huge bandage on his head. His face was blood-stained and very badly bruised.

"His eyes were wide-open and looking towards me. He had the most beautiful emerald eyes, dancing, smiling eyes, and I had never realised the exact shade of them until then.

"I went towards him to put my arms around him, and I remember the man in the green outfit started forward. I looked up and said: 'I am not going to hurt my boy. I just want to hold him.' I remember kissing his lips. He was so cold. He was so cold."

They had never been to Omagh before, and got lost on the way home. Hanging on the clothes line in the sunlight was James's Chelsea top.

She found a poem he had just written to Victor after reading an old school report of his father, who had gone to Eton. His dad had come second in German, the only time he was ever anything other than first.

Entitled For the Future, it was written in pencil on a sheet of A4 paper, and concluded with his flourishing signature, it was one of several scrunched-up drafts. She laid it beside him in his coffin.

He spoke in the note of working as hard as his father to become a lawyer himself, and said that he wanted to give Victor a rest. After he had studied, his father would teach him until he was ready, and then, he said, he would take over "the joint".

Donna-Maria pulls out photographs of her son in his coffin, his eyes ever so slightly open, his chin crudely stitched, and his face badly marked. His hair is terribly singed.

It contrasts painfully with local artist Ken Canning's portrait of him above the fireplace, fair-haired and freckled face with his head tilted at his trademark angle.

"He was a beautiful, beautiful boy," says Donna-Maria. "He had real special qualities, so helpful, well-mannered, and always smiling. A woman who was a camp leader on a trip he was on last year wrote to me saying how he had stood out so much among 100 boys. One lady told me how he played with her little daughter on the beach to let her relax and read her book, and then went all the way back for her when she realised she had forgotten her glasses.

"An old farmer came to say how James would wait for him as he went for a walk each day and have a long adult conversation with him. He said that he came to hope James would be there, and he always was."

Donna-Maria is in tears constantly, but she says she has never seen her husband cry. He admits he had tried to lose himself in work. He is prominent in trying to bring the Omagh bombers to book. The RUC and Garda say they know who was responsible, but believe it unlikely they will amass the evidence to secure convictions.

Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, recently wrote to Victor to say he would refuse to assist investigations because of the RUC's involvement. He cited historical and contemporary reasons.

Bertie Ahern, taoiseach, has agreed to a broadcast appeal for more information just before the second anniversary. Tony Blair, meanwhile, is still sitting on the fence, enraging Victor.

"We were an ordinary hard-working family, trying to do the best for our children," he says. "Our grief is the same as all the families.

"Where you come from and what you do is nothing to do with suffering. It is indiscriminate. It is indescribable."

While memories of the atrocity may be fading elsewhere, they run deep in Omagh. It could hardly be any other way, says Michael Gallagher, who lost his son Aidan, 21, with the catalogue of bomb hoax calls which are still driving shoppers from the town.

The first false warning came exactly a week after the massacre. There have been more than 100 since, some using the Real IRA's recognised codeword. There are, says Gallagher, no words to describe the mindset of those carrying them out.

The Barkers had planned to stay to see the Omagh bombers caught. But they decided to leave two months ago, after the murders in Tandragee, Co Armagh, of David McIlwaine, 18, and Andrew Robb, 19.

It was inconceivable to leave James behind in a graveyard where Irish tricolours will fly over republican graves this weekend to mark the 1916 Easter Rising. Donna-Maria says she wants him to be close.

"They are lovely people in Ireland," she says. "I really hope there is lasting peace. But I am just not happy here any more. I feel so guilty for making the decision to move here. People say time is a great healer, but it is nonsense. The pain is so intense. We have paid a high, high price for our dream."
fields.bodyText: As the sun rises over Buncrana in County Donegal this morning, Donna-Maria Barker will stand the saddest of vigils in the St Mary's churchyard just outside the town. She will be overseeing the exhumation of her 12-year-old son, James. Grave-diggers, screened from view, will lift him and place his coffin in the undertaker's hearse. He will return to his bedroom in the beautiful bungalow on Neds Point Road before beginning the long trip by road and air home to Ottershaw, Surrey. He has never been to the family's new house in England, but will stay until Saturday morning, when, after a short, intimate service, he will be re-interred in a tiny, tranquil graveyard. Buncrana has never seen anything quite like this before, and his parents' unorthodox approach to their son's burial is the chatter of the town. Opinion is divided, though sympathy is overwhelming for the English family who came in search of a dream. James Barker was one of 29 people murdered in the Omagh bombing of August 15 1998, the single worst atrocity of the Troubles. Some include the heavily pregnant Avril Monaghan's unborn twins in the death toll, and say that there were 31 victims. The Real IRA, dissident republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement, assassinated Catholics as well as Protestants in the County Tyrone town. They even managed to claim the life of a Mormon. James had regarded the 11 months exploring the shores of Lough Swilly as the best of his life. He was mad about Chelsea football club, but he also wore the Irish Republic's green shirt with pride. His big sister, Estella, even now sneaks into his bedroom at night so she can sleep with it. Her mother finds it in her bed each morning, and takes it back to James's room. Nothing is ever said. As Donna-Maria, 43, and her children, Erin-Esther, 21, Estella, 15, and five-year-old Oliver-Tristan accompany James today, she will reflect on the tragedy of a three-year-old vision. After school finishes in June, she vows never to set foot again in Ireland. They are selling their unfinished house. She brought her three youngest children to rural Ireland in September 1997 to escape the home counties rat-race. Their new life was, for a time, the idyll she imagined. Her husband Victor, 43, a solicitor based in Chertsey, Surrey, is a workaholic who rarely takes a break. They compromised on a holiday home across the Irish border from Derry, where she was brought up. "Then I had the bright brainwave," says Donna-Maria. "Rather than use it as a holiday home, I suggested I should move over with the children. It was just so much a better quality of life and I thought it would be fantastic for them to grow up in the tranquillity of the place. We agreed, and Victor would come over every three weeks or so. "Two weeks before James died I was having coffee with my mother. I remember saying to her: 'Nothing can spoil this. This is heaven.' " Erin-Esther, who works with British Airways, stayed in England with Victor, while the others settled into their new lives. Estella loved her boarding school in Belfast, and James, a keen athlete, flourished at Foyle and Londonderry Preparatory school. "It really was fabulous," says Donna-Maria. "James loved it. He had the type of freedom he could never have had in Surrey." The day before he died, James spent an afternoon fishing with Victor in a boat on the lough. James sat on his dad's knee, telling him how much he loved it in Ireland. But he said he was sad he was unable to see more of him. The Barkers had bought the house from a family who hosted Spanish pupils arriving in Buncrana each year on an exchange visit. The organisers called to check if the new owner would again take a student. Estella was studying Spanish, and Donna-Maria figured it a good idea. They were joined by Uki Baselga, whose brother, Fernando, 12, stayed with a family nearby. He became inseparable from James. They were shopping in Omagh after an organised bus visit to the Ulster-American Folk Museum just outside the town when the massive car bomb exploded. Fernando was killed outright, along with Spanish teacher Rocio Ramos, 23, and Sean McLoughlin, 12, and eight-year-old Oran Doherty, both from Buncrana. James was blown on to a roof. He lived for more than three hours as doctors vainly pumped 18 pints of blood into him. Donna-Maria thought the museum was in Belfast. Her mother was reassuring her on the phone at 6.47pm, the time James died, and it was only when her mum appeared at St John's restaurant in nearby Fahan at 10.30pm that she realised something was seriously awry. There then followed a nightmare as they tried to secure information. They decided to head for Omagh, and were eventually guided to the town's leisure centre at 3.30am. It was to be four more hours before they learned the worst. They were the last of the bereaved to be told. Donna-Maria says: "The other families had each other. We were on our own. We were total strangers. "James was covered in a green blanket with a white handkerchief-sized cloth over his head. A man all in green with three-quarter wellies on him pulled it back. "James had his head towards me, to the right. He had a huge bandage on his head. His face was blood-stained and very badly bruised. "His eyes were wide-open and looking towards me. He had the most beautiful emerald eyes, dancing, smiling eyes, and I had never realised the exact shade of them until then. "I went towards him to put my arms around him, and I remember the man in the green outfit started forward. I looked up and said: 'I am not going to hurt my boy. I just want to hold him.' I remember kissing his lips. He was so cold. He was so cold." They had never been to Omagh before, and got lost on the way home. Hanging on the clothes line in the sunlight was James's Chelsea top. She found a poem he had just written to Victor after reading an old school report of his father, who had gone to Eton. His dad had come second in German, the only time he was ever anything other than first. Entitled For the Future, it was written in pencil on a sheet of A4 paper, and concluded with his flourishing signature, it was one of several scrunched-up drafts. She laid it beside him in his coffin. He spoke in the note of working as hard as his father to become a lawyer himself, and said that he wanted to give Victor a rest. After he had studied, his father would teach him until he was ready, and then, he said, he would take over "the joint". Donna-Maria pulls out photographs of her son in his coffin, his eyes ever so slightly open, his chin crudely stitched, and his face badly marked. His hair is terribly singed. It contrasts painfully with local artist Ken Canning's portrait of him above the fireplace, fair-haired and freckled face with his head tilted at his trademark angle. "He was a beautiful, beautiful boy," says Donna-Maria. "He had real special qualities, so helpful, well-mannered, and always smiling. A woman who was a camp leader on a trip he was on last year wrote to me saying how he had stood out so much among 100 boys. One lady told me how he played with her little daughter on the beach to let her relax and read her book, and then went all the way back for her when she realised she had forgotten her glasses. "An old farmer came to say how James would wait for him as he went for a walk each day and have a long adult conversation with him. He said that he came to hope James would be there, and he always was." Donna-Maria is in tears constantly, but she says she has never seen her husband cry. He admits he had tried to lose himself in work. He is prominent in trying to bring the Omagh bombers to book. The RUC and Garda say they know who was responsible, but believe it unlikely they will amass the evidence to secure convictions. Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, recently wrote to Victor to say he would refuse to assist investigations because of the RUC's involvement. He cited historical and contemporary reasons. Bertie Ahern, taoiseach, has agreed to a broadcast appeal for more information just before the second anniversary. Tony Blair, meanwhile, is still sitting on the fence, enraging Victor. "We were an ordinary hard-working family, trying to do the best for our children," he says. "Our grief is the same as all the families. "Where you come from and what you do is nothing to do with suffering. It is indiscriminate. It is indescribable." While memories of the atrocity may be fading elsewhere, they run deep in Omagh. It could hardly be any other way, says Michael Gallagher, who lost his son Aidan, 21, with the catalogue of bomb hoax calls which are still driving shoppers from the town. The first false warning came exactly a week after the massacre. There have been more than 100 since, some using the Real IRA's recognised codeword. There are, says Gallagher, no words to describe the mindset of those carrying them out. The Barkers had planned to stay to see the Omagh bombers caught. But they decided to leave two months ago, after the murders in Tandragee, Co Armagh, of David McIlwaine, 18, and Andrew Robb, 19. It was inconceivable to leave James behind in a graveyard where Irish tricolours will fly over republican graves this weekend to mark the 1916 Easter Rising. Donna-Maria says she wants him to be close. "They are lovely people in Ireland," she says. "I really hope there is lasting peace. But I am just not happy here any more. I feel so guilty for making the decision to move here. People say time is a great healer, but it is nonsense. The pain is so intense. We have paid a high, high price for our dream."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tribunal frees Bosnian Serbs
fields.body:
Tribunal frees Bosnian Serbs

Two Bosnian Serbs on war crimes charges were due to be released yesterday until their trial begins because they have been in custody for too long, the UN tribunal in the Hague said.

Miroslav Tadic, 62, and Simo Zaric, 51, have been held since surrendering in February 1998. Their trial has been delayed by a co-defendant's complaints.

They are accused of persecuting Bosnian Croats and Muslims when Serbs ethnically cleansed the Bosanski Samac region. Reuters, the Hague

131 die in Asian plane crash

The Philippines suffered its worst air disaster yesterday when an Air Philippines plane crashed in a foggy coconut grove near Davao, killing all 131 people on board, officials said.

The Boeing 737-200 from Manila was unable to land on its first approach to Davao because another plane was on the runway. It crashed on Samal island while preparing for a second approach. AP, Samal

US state backs gay rights bill

A bill that would create the closest thing in the United States to gay marriage won final approval in Vermont's state senate yesterday.

The bill, which now returns to the state house of representatives, would enable gay couples to form "civil unions", entitling them to about 300 rights and benefits available under state law to married couples. AP, Montpelier, Vermont

Massacre trial opens in Aceh

A landmark human rights trial in Indonesia's strife-torn Aceh province opened yesterday with 24 low-ranking soldiers and a civilian charged with killing 57 unarmed villagers.

The trial, which was adjourned until Saturday, is seen as a bid by Indonesian leaders to placate Aceh's 4.1m people after years of brutal treatment by the military. AP, Banda Aceh

Mbeki defends Aids policies

In a letter endorsing South Africa's policies on Aids, President Thabo Mbeki told world leaders that imposing a western solution on the "uniquely African catastrophe" of fast-spreading HIV infection would be absurd and illogical.

In the letter, made public yesterday by the Washington Post, he defended the country's contacts with scientists who argue that Aids is not caused by HIV. AP, Johannesburg

Poll annulment sparks riots

Riots swept Sarvestan in southern Iran after a decision by the electoral watchdog to annul the results of February's local elections, newspapers reported.

People attacked the courthouse, set tyres alight and blocked a road. Reuters, Tehran

webTitle: Overseas visits cancelled to save Bush's blushes

fields.headline: Overseas visits cancelled to save Bush's blushes
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush is abandoning plans to make a series of image-boosting overseas trips later this year, including one to Britain, because his advisers fear that his tendency to make foreign-policy gaffes may turn them into a public relations embarrassment for his US presidential campaign.
fields.body:
George W Bush is abandoning plans to make a series of image-boosting overseas trips later this year, including one to Britain, because his advisers fear that his tendency to make foreign-policy gaffes may turn them into a public relations embarrassment for his US presidential campaign.

Mr Bush was to have made up to three foreign trips in May and June to help burnish his image as a statesman and to get to know the world leaders with whom he will have to work if he wins the White House, including Tony Blair. But the trips to Europe and Asia have now been dropped from his schedule, and he is likely to make only one overseas journey between now and the November 7 election, to Latin America.

Officially, his campaign team says the European trip has not yet been formally abandoned, but his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, confirmed yesterday that it was now "most unlikely", because of scheduling difficulties. Diplomatic sources on both sides of the Atlantic confirm that they no longer expect to see Mr Bush in Europe before the election.

At the heart of the decision to scale back Mr Bush's planned international exposure is thought to be the belief, especially among some of his Texas-based advisers, that the trip could turn into an embarrassing media ordeal which could diminish Mr Bush's credibility in the contest with his Democratic opponent, Vice-President Al Gore.

In the past, US presidential hopefuls have made something of a point of being photographed on the international stage at this point in the political calendar, in the belief that such contacts go down well with the voters back home as well as being a helpful investment for future understanding and cooperation.

Mr Bush's predecessor as the Republican challenger, Bob Dole, made such a trip at the end of 1994, during which he met the then British prime minister, John Major, in Downing Street, and other leaders.

But, reflecting the changed priorities of modern campaigning, Mr Bush's advisers have decided to play safe and remain in control of their man's candidacy back home rather than risk things spinning out of control in the relatively unfamiliar environment of an overseas visit.

Instead of visiting Europe and Asia, Mr Bush is now expected to make only the visit to Latin America - probably to Mexico and other central American states - which he will use to try to strengthen his appeal among US Latino voters, a constituency which he has cultivated as governor of Texas.

Mr Bush will meet the Mexican president, Ernesto Zedillo, next week when the two men are scheduled to attend a border bridge opening ceremony in Laredo, Texas.

The advisers believe that Mr Bush would have been likely to face demonstrations in some European capitals on such issues as capital punishment, gun control and the environment, though such events would not necessarily be seen as a political disadvantage to him.

Their main anxiety was thought to be the risk that Mr Bush might be ambushed by the travelling US media, or even by their European counterparts, into committing another in the series of gaffes which plagued his early efforts to present himself as a qualified leader of the free world.

Mr Bush has still not fully lived down his failure to name a number of foreign leaders when a Boston television journalist surprised him last year with an on-camera "pop quiz" about the leaders of India, Pakistan, Taiwan and Chechnya. Though Mr Bush has subsequently made generally well-received keynote speeches on defence and foreign affairs, he remains dogged by the view that, on these issues at least, he is lost without his cue cards.

Plans for Mr Bush to visit Europe had been under active discussion between his advisers and diplomats in several European capitals for several months.

The trip was thought likely to take place once Mr Bush had wrapped up his party's presidential nomination - which he did in March - and before the Republican convention in Philadelphia in late July. Mr Bush himself confirmed to the Guardian in November that this was his intention.

Though no itinerary had been finalised, London was always near the top of the list of likely stops, and the prime minister issued a formal invitation to Mr Bush late last year.

Other stops discussed in the Bush camp included Belgium, where Mr Bush was to have met Nato and European Union officials; Germany, because of its importance; Spain, where the governor's proficiency in Spanish could be exploited; Ireland, always a tempting stage for an American politician running for office; and Poland, where Mr Bush hoped to address post-cold-war east-west issues and make a pitch to the largely Catholic Polish-American vote.

In spite of his unusual personal and political closeness to President Clinton, Mr Blair has made several private moves in recent months to open channels of communication with Mr Bush. Even though a pre-election meeting between the two men will not now take place in Europe, an encounter in the US has not been ruled out.

Mr Gore, who is well known in many foreign capitals because of his eight years as vice-president, has no plans to make any campaign-related foreign visits before the election.

The world according to George Jr

'When I was coming up, it was a dangerous world, and you knew exactly who they were. It was us versus them, and it was clear who them was. Today, we are not so sure who they are, but we know they're there'

'The only thing I know about Slovakia is what I learned first-hand from your foreign minister, who came to Texas'

To a Slovak journalist in June 1999. Bush had actually met Janez Drnovsek, the prime minister of Slovenia

'If the East Timorians decide to revolt, I'm sure I'll have a statement'

Quoted by Maureen Dowd in the New York Times, June 16 1999

'Keep good relations with the Grecians'

Quoted in the Economist, June 1999

'Kosovians can move back in'

CNN Inside Politics, April 1999

fields.headline: 'Mafiaboy' charged with cyber-terrorism
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old boy has been charged with two counts of computer mischief for crippling the CNN website and 1,200 related sites in a cyber attack, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old boy has been charged with two counts of computer mischief for crippling the CNN website and 1,200 related sites in a cyber attack, police said yesterday.

His computer name was "Mafiaboy", but he cannot be identified under Canadian law.

Cyber attacks against CNN, Yahoo!, eBay, Amazon, ETrade and other major web sites in February inconvenienced millions of users and raised questions about internet security.

The apparently coordinated attacks overloaded the sites with a barrage of messages generated by hackers.

Inspector Yves Roussel of the Royal Canadian Mounted police said the boy had boasted in internet chat rooms about what he had done. The boy was released on bail conditions that included not connecting to the internet.

The investigation conducted jointly by the RCMP, the FBI and US justice department was continuing, Mr Roussel said. "Wherever they are, hackers will be investigated and arrested."

But Rick Broadhead, an internet consultant, said cyber attacks would continue. "We shouldn't feel any more safe because of this arrest," he said. "It is a new form of terrorism called cyber terrorism. I really believe it won't go away."

A spokesman for the FBI said the damage caused by international hacking could run to hundreds of millions of dollars.

The attacks involved placing tools on middleman computers and remotely ordering them to overwhelm the victim site with fake traffic.

Three computers have been identified as middlemen in the February attacks: a computer at the University of California, Santa Barbara; a router at Stanford University; and a home business computer in the area of Portland, Oregon. Investigators say that dozens, even hundreds, of middlemen computers were used in the attacks.

Mr Roussel said the "denial of service attacks" require a high-capacity computer network capable of transmitting large volumes of data to targeted computers.

webTitle: Actor warns Labour leadership of trouble at grassroots

fields.headline: Actor warns Labour leadership of trouble at grassroots
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Actor Tony Robinson, who played hopeless henchman Baldrick in TV's Blackadder, yesterday announced he is to run for a seat on the Labour party's ruling executive and issued a warning that grassroots activists feel ignored and let down by the party leadership.
fields.body:
Actor Tony Robinson, who played hopeless henchman Baldrick in TV's Blackadder, yesterday announced he is to run for a seat on the Labour party's ruling executive and issued a warning that grassroots activists feel ignored and let down by the party leadership.

Mr Robinson, a long-time Labour supporter and activist, called on ministers and MPs to forge new links with their party on the ground or risk a membership slide and a growing refusal among members to campaign in local and national elections.

He also warned that the party's Millbank headquarters was failing to heed grassroots concern over the "rigging" of internal ballots which saw the selection of Welsh assembly leader Alun Michael - now replaced - and London mayoral contender Frank Dobson.

Tony Blair should apologise for the London selection process as he had done over the party's manoeuvrings to block would-be Welsh leader Rhodri Morgan, Mr Robinson said, and Labour should pledge to use a true one member, one vote system for all internal elections.

The 53-year-old actor, who as vice-president of Equity has been involved in controversial reforms of the actors' union, is running for one of six members' seats on Labour's ruling national executive committee (NEC). Despite Mr Robinson's tough talk, he is part of a group of six candidates favoured by Millbank HQ.

Mr Robinson, an active party campaigner who has run for council elections in his home town of Bristol, yesterday said he was speaking as a critical friend of the government. "It's like the adverts used to say about BO - someone has to speak when even your best friend won't tell you."

The 53-year-old actor, who as vice-president of Equity has been involved in controversial reforms of the actors' union, is running for one of six members' seats on Labour's ruling national executive committee (NEC). Despite Mr Robinson's tough talk, he is part of a group of six candidates favoured by Millbank HQ. Mr Robinson, an active party campaigner who has run for council elections in his home town of Bristol, yesterday said he was speaking as a critical friend of the government. "It's like the adverts used to say about BO - someone has to speak when even your best friend won't tell you."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: • Strange goings-on at the Daily Mail, which seems to be in retreat from its usual splenetic frenzy on right-wing causes like asylum seekers and section 28. Management at the paper have been rattled by the hostile response from readers over its asylum rantings, and staff are unhappy to find themselves targeted by protests.
fields.body:
 Strange goings-on at the Daily Mail, which seems to be in retreat from its usual splenetic frenzy on right-wing causes like asylum seekers and section 28. Management at the paper have been rattled by the hostile response from readers over its asylum rantings, and staff are unhappy to find themselves targeted by protests.

One group of section 28 protesters made it past security into the newsroom and nearly got into editor Paul Dacre's office. Another group demonstrated against the Mail's asylum line outside its Kensington HQ, taking photos of journalists as they entered. The grim siege mentality has made senior staff think again - so let's all pray for a kinder, gentler Mail.

 Now here's a fascinating story of a vote rigging scandal that had party members quitting in disgust after Frank Dobson became the official Labour candidate. No, not the mayoral nomination, but a shady chapter from Dobbo's past that shows the old boy's always found it hard to win nominations without a leg-up. Back in 1978, when Dobbo was going for the Labour nomination in the Holborn and St Pancras South constituency, the most popular candidate for the safe seat was journalist Chris Mullin (now MP for Sunderland South). But at the last minute Mullin was cut from the shortlist (after rumours put about that he wasn't a unionist) and replaced by an unknown.

Guess what? Dobbo won, to no one's amazement, while the unknown got no votes. Some members were so angry at the dirty tricks - said to be cooked up by Labour HQ - that they refused to support Dobbo. The Camden Journal of July 7 1978, reported: "St Pancras branch of the party has already agreed not to support Dobson either but to canvass for Labour candidate Ken Livingstone in Hampstead." You really couldn't make it up.

 Meanwhile, the Tory party seems to have no such qualms about incurring the wrath of the electorate over its plans to herd refugees into what can only correctly be called prisons. But do these plans really go far enough, one is compelled to ask? If the Tory party had any spine it would demand a return to deportation of national undesirables, as in the good old days of the 18th century. Since we can't ship white trash like Jonathan Aitken and Neil Hamilton to Australia any more, what about the Falklands as a dumping ground?

 My colleague Matthew Norman rings from France, but it's impossible to hear him driving at 127mph with the windows wound down in the silver 328i touring car lent by BMW. He calls back later from a Calais hypermarche. "It's a beautifully engineered piece of kit," says Matthew. "Say what you like about them laying waste to the West Midlands, you've got to hand it to the Hun when it comes to making great cars." Jo Slater, BMW's able press officer, is phlegmatic about the small scrape along one side. "Good thing I didn't give him a better one," she quips. Indeed.

 Fez's off to His Royal Highness King Mohammed VI of Morocco, for the sweeping liberal reforms introduced just nine months into his reign. These include having his limo stop at traffic lights. Well, it's a start.

 With two weeks to go until the London mayoral elections, there is still plenty of time to order one of the Diary's exclusive Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirts, as modelled by big stars like Tom Robinson and Michael Winner and available in L or XL sizes. Just £7.50 (including postage) from the Guardian Diary, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, will secure the clothing item that has become easily the most talked about white T-shirt with a picture of Frank Dobson on the front. (Make cheques payable to the Guardian Media Group.) Tom Robinson can be heard wearing his on Radio 4 at 11.30am today, in his new series on English ballads.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A misprint involving the French monarch Louis XIV appeared on page 22 yesterday in a commentary about asylum seekers. The piece harked back to Britain's protection of "Huguenots persecuted by Louise XIV". Birthdays, page 18, April 17, listed Sirimavo Bandaranaike, 84, as Sri Lanka's former prime minister. She actually holds that post now, having been appointed in 1994 by her daughter, President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga. Her previous terms were 1960-65 and 1970-77.

Some readers have been in touch to say we often use Scandinavia/Scandinavian incorrectly. To clarify, the term has gained wide use as covering not only the occupants of the Scandinavian peninsula (Norway and Sweden), but also a cultural area that includes Denmark, Finland, and Iceland and the Faeroe islands. Britannica and Collins Dictionary reflect the wider definition, and this is likely to go on appearing in the Guardian. "We are not touchy about it," said the London embassy of Iceland, where the first day of summer is celebrated today. The embassy suggests that the best term of all is Nordic.

An article on genius spawned correspondence in which Thomas Carlyle has twice been credited (Letters, page 17, April 17 and page 21, April 18) with the saying that genius is 10% inspiration, 90% perspiration. webTitle: 'McCain for running mate' sets a poser

fields.headline: 'McCain for running mate' sets a poser
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush set American political tongues wagging yesterday with the apparently unprompted suggestion that he would consider making the Arizona senator John McCain his vice-presidential running mate in the November presidential election.
fields.body:
George W Bush set American political tongues wagging yesterday with the apparently unprompted suggestion that he would consider making the Arizona senator John McCain his vice-presidential running mate in the November presidential election.

His comment came during a campaign visit to Michigan, where Mr McCain trounced the Texas governor in February's Republican primary before abandoning his quest for the White House last month. Mr McCain has consistently ruled out the possibility of being the number two on anyone's ticket.

"I know he's said he's not interested, but until I talk to him and find out how interested he is, I'll give him consideration," Mr Bush said at a news conference at Dearborn, outside Detroit. "I just need to look him in the eye and visit with him on that."

"Talk like this is always flattering, whether it's from Governor Bush or [the Minnesota governor] Jesse Ventura," a spokesman for Mr McCain said. "However, Senator McCain has made it more than clear that he is not interested in being vice-president."

Bush-watchers suspect that the unprompted mention of Mr McCain may not have been entirely spontaneous, not least because Michigan's Republican governor, John Engler, a strong Bush backer, echoed his comments yesterday in a separate television interview. It has also been seen as a possible ploy to build support in Michigan.

Mr Bush has made a habit of mentioning possible vice-presidential candidates as he tries to reunite his party after a bitter primary season. As well as Mr McCain, he has mentioned his former rival Elizabeth Dole, the Pennsylvania governor Tom Ridge, and the New Jersey governor Christine Todd Whitman as possibilities.

On the other hand, Mr Bush is under pressure to mend some fences with Mr McCain, who won wide support from the independents and Democratic swing voters the candidate needs to attract in November.

The two men have arranged their first meeting since the primary season on May 9 in Pittsburgh.

The vice-presidential nomination will be one of the many items on the agenda, as will the role Mr McCain will play in the Republican national convention in Philadelphia in late July and early August and Mr Bush's willingness to adopt some of Mr McCain's ideas for campaign finance reform as part of the party platform.

Mr Bush is expected to announce soon that he has asked the former US defence secretary Dick Cheney to head a committee to examine a range of possible Republican vice-presidential nominees.

webTitle: Drugs supremo accuses veteran journalist of defamation

fields.headline: Drugs supremo accuses veteran journalist of defamation
fields.trailText: The United States anti-drugs czar, Barry McCaffrey, is waging a different kind of war to those which have dominated his past and present careers: one against a journalist he accuses of writing an article containing "alarming and defamatory allegations" which reduced his wife to tears.
fields.body:
The United States anti-drugs czar, Barry McCaffrey, is waging a different kind of war to those which have dominated his past and present careers: one against a journalist he accuses of writing an article containing "alarming and defamatory allegations" which reduced his wife to tears.

The retired general said on Tuesday that the veteran investigative journalist Seymour Hersh, who won a Pulitzer prize for his exposure of the My Lai massacre during the Vietnam war, is spreading false stories about his military career while researching an article intended for publication in the New Yorker magazine.

General McCaffrey has written to the magazine's editor, David Remnick, and other news organisations alleging that Mr Hersh has been conducting defamatory interviews filled with false allegations, according to reports published in the Washington Post and issued by US news agencies yesterday.

Among the allegations, the Associated Press reported, are claims that troops led by Gen McCaffrey killed Iraqi prisoners of war and committed other crimes which were covered up by the US army during the Gulf war; that he committed several unspecified felonies during his Vietnam era service; and that he "acted inappropriately" in developing the Clinton administration's proposed $1.6bn (£1bn) anti-drugs aid plan for Colombia.

Part of Mr Hersh's investigation of Mr McCaffrey concerns allegations that the 24th Infantry Division was, while under the general's command, involved in war crimes against Iraqi prisoners of war at Tallil air force base in 1991.

Mr McCaffrey wrote a memo last Friday in which he defended himself against the allegations.

"I've gotten calls from dozens of friends over the last three months reporting a series of accusations by Mr Hersh, ranging from bike theft at age 11 to atrocities in the Gulf war," Gen McCaffrey told the agency.

"They are defamatory and sort of frightening to my friends and family."

Mr Hersh said he would not comment on an article which has not yet been published.

He has written to Mr McCaffrey's office, however, rejecting the general's suggestion that the interviews for the article were designed to impugn him.

"Your allegations are wrong," Mr Hersh said in his letter.

"I am simply going about my business, as I have for the past 35 or so years, asking questions, listening to answers and trying to verify and assess what I've been told."

The New Yorker's head of editorial came down squarely behind the veteran journalist.

"I have complete confidence in Sy Hersh," Mr Remnick told the Washington Post.

"Remember, we haven't published a thing yet."

Mr Hersh, 63, has acquired an awesome reputation as a intensely thorough investigative reporter, one that remains intact.

Last year he interviewed more than 100 people for another New Yorker article, which questioned whether the US had bombed the right target in 1998 when it attacked an alleged chemicals factory in Sudan following the embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.

But his reputation took a knock three years ago when his book on the Kennedy family, The Dark Side of Camelot, had to be changed at the last minute after it became clear that Mr Hersh had been conned by a source who had sold him phoney papers supposedly documenting a pay-off to the film star Marilyn Monroe.

webTitle: Breton separatists blamed for fatal blast

fields.headline: Breton separatists blamed for fatal blast
fields.trailText: Militant Breton separatists, believed to be linked to the Basque separatist group ETA, are thought to be behind a powerful bomb blast that tore through a McDonald's restaurant near the town of Dinan yesterday, killing a young woman employee and badly damaging the building.
fields.body:
Militant Breton separatists, believed to be linked to the Basque separatist group ETA, are thought to be behind a powerful bomb blast that tore through a McDonald's restaurant near the town of Dinan yesterday, killing a young woman employee and badly damaging the building.

The French interior ministry confirmed that the 10am explosion at the restaurant's drive-in window was a criminal attack, and linked it to a makeshift bomb found and defused outside a post office in the Breton capital, Rennes, at about the same time.

The ministry added that the three sticks of dynamite used to make the Rennes bomb were part of a cache of nearly eight tonnes of high explosive stolen in September from an engineering company's warehouse in the nearby town of Plévin.

Although five tonnes of explosives have been recovered, some of the dynamite has been used in a string of bombings by ETA and a shadowy Breton independence movement, the Armée Révolutionnaire Bretonne (ARB).

The head of the Paris public prosecutor's anti-terrorism division, Irène Stoller, flew to the region to lead the investigation into the incidents which, if carried out by the ARB, will be the first fatality in four recent bombings claimed by the group.

The ARB's previous attack, in January, badly damaged the town hall in La Baule, on the southern coast of Brittany. Other recent bombings by the group, which is believed to have little more than a dozen active members, have wrecked the tax collection offices in Cintagebelle - the constituency of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin - and the town hall of Belfort, where the interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, is mayor.

"Nothing can justify the recourse to violence and the multiplication of violent acts with fatally tragic consequences," Mr Chevènement said.

fields.headline: Sympathy as D'Alema bows out
fields.trailText: Massimo D'Alema's resignation speech ended in a sound Italians never heard during his 18 months in power: a rasp of emotion. Aloof, arrogant and clever, his style alienated voters even as his centre-left government delivered results.
fields.body:
Massimo D'Alema's resignation speech ended in a sound Italians never heard during his 18 months in power: a rasp of emotion. Aloof, arrogant and clever, his style alienated voters even as his centre-left government delivered results.

Mr D'Alema, 51 today, made history as Italy's first ex-communist prime minister. He dreamed of making Italy a "normal country" with stable government, but never succeeded in controlling his fractious coalition partners.

His efficiency was rarely doubted but a prickly, sarcastic personality was admitted even by his wife, Linda Giuva. "When he applies himself to something he can be really unpleasant," she said.

Born in Rome, he rose through the ranks of the Communist party and in 1994 was catapulted to the leadership.

The Democrats of the Left swept into power in 1996 as part of a centre-left coalition headed by Romano Prodi. When an internal convulsion bounced Mr Prodi from the premiership in 1998, Mr D'Alema filled the vacuum.

Yesterday's resignation gives his government a chance to rally round a new leader. That and his unexpected show of emotion earned Mr D'Alema an unfamiliar response: sympathy.

webTitle: Scramble on for new Italian PM

fields.headline: Scramble on for new Italian PM
fields.trailText: Italy's centre-left government was scrambling for a new leader last night after the prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, resigned following his coalition's crushing defeat in the regional elections.
fields.body:
Italy's centre-left government was scrambling for a new leader last night after the prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, resigned following his coalition's crushing defeat in the regional elections.

Coalition leaders were struggling to agree on a successor who could unify their seven parties and resist the opposition's clamour for an immediate general election.

President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi will meet political leaders today and tomorrow to decide whether the centre-left should try to form a new government.

If a candidate is not found Mr Ciampi can call an election or appoint a non-political caretaker to lead until the scheduled elections in April 2001.

Mr D'Alema, Italy's first ex-communist prime minister, will remain in office until a new government is formed.

He resigned in a 20-minute speech to the senate, but appealed to fractious colleagues to revive the alliance that has ruled Italy for 18 months.

Mr D'Alema had offered to resign on Monday but the president asked him to first test the feelings of parliament. When the prime minister's coalition partners threatened to defect unless he quit he realised there was no chance of winning a confidence vote.

Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate who leads the centre-right opposition, sniffs blood after sweeping the north and key regions in the south. He has declared the government illegitimate and will lobby the president to dissolve parliament.

The left, reeling after misjudging the electorate's appetite for Mr Berlusconi's anti-immigration policies, knows it must choose a candidate quickly, but in-fighting between the eclectic group of greens, social democrats, hardline communists and former Christian Democrats could stymie compromise.

The most likely candidates are the treasury minister Giuliano Amato, a former socialist prime minister, and Antonio Fazio, governor of the Bank of Italy. But each has enemies who may prefer risking electoral annihilation rather than submit to their leadership.

Mr Fazio, a Catholic, repels leftwingers by his opposition to divorce and abortion. Several months ago he was spoken of as a minister in a future Berlusconi government.

Mr Amato, who served under the disgraced Christian Democrat prime minister Bettino Craxi, is also seen by the left as suspect. One option being considered is to appoint one of them as a caretaker and then change to the other just before going to the polls.

"We are thinking about the possibility of a government to last until the end of the legislature led by Mr Amato, in order to build a strong leadership to go into the 2001 elections which could be that of Mr Fazio," a source said.

Another possible candidate is Antonio Bassolino, a charismatic former mayor of Naples, who singlehandedly staved off the right by winning the Campania region. But a southerner is not considered an astute choice to reconquer the north.

Bookmakers were offering 50-50 odds on the centre-left uniting in time to form Italy's 58th government since the end of the second world war.

Mr D'Alema, 51 today, has been buffeted by internal dissent since he was appointed 18 months ago. He survived numerous crises, but finally succumbed after the regional elections, in which the government lost two regions.

Coalition leaders were struggling to agree on a successor who could unify their seven parties and resist the opposition's clamour for an immediate general election. President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi will meet political leaders today and tomorrow to decide whether the centre-left should try to form a new government. If a candidate is not found Mr Ciampi can call an election or appoint a non-political caretaker to lead until the scheduled elections in April 2001. Mr D'Alema, Italy's first ex-communist prime minister, will remain in office until a new government is formed. He resigned in a 20-minute speech to the senate, but appealed to fractious colleagues to revive the alliance that has ruled Italy for 18 months. Mr D'Alema had offered to resign on Monday but the president asked him to first test the feelings of parliament. When the prime minister's coalition partners threatened to defect unless he quit he realised there was no chance of winning a confidence vote. Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate who leads the centre-right opposition, sniffs blood after sweeping the north and key regions in the south. He has declared the government illegitimate and will lobby the president to dissolve parliament. The left, reeling after misjudging the electorate's appetite for Mr Berlusconi's anti-immigration policies, knows it must choose a candidate quickly, but in-fighting between the eclectic group of greens, social democrats, hardline communists and former Christian Democrats could stymie compromise. webTitle: Sitcom is not what the doctor ordered

fields.headline: Sitcom is not what the doctor ordered
fields.trailText: The BBC said yesterday that it was committed to developing successful new sitcoms after it emerged a recent series starring Jemma Redgrave was one of the least watched comedies in BBC1's history.
fields.body:
The BBC said yesterday that it was committed to developing successful new sitcoms after it emerged a recent series starring Jemma Redgrave was one of the least watched comedies in BBC1's history.

Viewing figures for Cry Wolf, set in a London GP's surgery, fell from 7.6m to 1.3m between its first episode on March 6 and the end of its run.

The failure of Cry Wolf is a disappointment for its creators, Laurence Marks and Maurice Gran, responsible for such hits as Shine on Harvey Moon, Goodnight Sweetheart and Birds of a Feather. Confirming the figures, a BBC spokeswoman said it was unlikely that Cry Wolf would be recommissioned.

Cry Wolf stars Redgrave as Dr Wolf, who becomes pregnant after a one-night stand with her new colleague Dr Hook, played by Peter Egan. It ran for five weeks.

The show was one hailed by the controller of BBC1, Peter Salmon, as part of his strategy to replace "net-curtain comedies". He said: "I am the net-curtain comedy killer, the man who took out a contract on suburban sofas, knitted pullovers and will do for some of the dreary 1950s scenarios that have infected too many comedies."

fields.headline: 'Road rage' crash kills boy
fields.trailText: A baby boy has died and four other members of his family were seriously injured after their car careered off a motorway in a suspected road rage incident.
fields.body:
A baby boy has died and four other members of his family were seriously injured after their car careered off a motorway in a suspected road rage incident.

Six-month-old Robbie Millar, from Port Glasgow, died in hospital yesterday after the incident on the M8 near Paisley on Tuesday evening.

His parents, Craig and Mary Millar, and brothers, Sean, nine, and Steven, seven, were seriously injured in the incident.

Strathclyde police have launched a hunt for the driver of a bluish/purple "family style car", possibly a Renault Megane Scenic, which left the scene. The car is thought to have been driven by a man who was accompanied by a woman.

A police spokesman said that the Millar family had been driving on the motorway at around 7.25pm when there was an incident with another car along a five-mile stretch of the carriageway between Port Glasgow and the Gryffe bridge. As a result, the Millars' Rover 214 went out of control, careered down an embankment and hit a tree.

Firefighters had to cut the family from the wreckage and paramedics, helped by a passing motorist, administered first aid.

Robbie was taken to Yorkhill children's hospital in Glasgow with head injuries. His father, Craig, 28, and mother, Mary, 27, were taken to the Royal Alexandra hospital, in Paisley, where both were said to be stable. Mr Millar is said to have severe back injuries and his wife has injuries to her head and neck. Sean has leg injuries and Steven stomach injuries. Both are recovering in Yorkhill.

webTitle: Great Ormond Street wins battle over will

fields.headline: Great Ormond Street wins battle over will
fields.trailText: A housekeeper who persuaded an elderly widow suffering from Alzheimer's disease to sell her £300,000 home to her for £50 was branded a liar and ordered to hand back the house by a high court judge yesterday.
fields.body:
A housekeeper who persuaded an elderly widow suffering from Alzheimer's disease to sell her £300,000 home to her for £50 was branded a liar and ordered to hand back the house by a high court judge yesterday.

As a result of the ruling, Great Ormond Street hospital for children will now receive a £200,000 bequest under the terms of the will left by the 76-year-old widow after her death in April 1997.

The judge found that Lily Morris, who had severe dementia, had fallen under the "undue influence" of her full-time carer and cleaner Pauline Rushin and Mrs Rushin's daughter, Caroline Billinge, 27, who convinced her to hand over the £300,000 Derbyshire farm house to Mrs Rushin and make other gifts, including a Porsche and a BMW.

Mrs Morris, a retired nurse who once worked at Great Ormond Street hospital, had left the bulk of her estate to the hospital in her final will, but in February 1996 she signed an agreement leaving her house to her housekeeper in return for £50 and a promise she would be looked after for the rest of her life.

Mr Justice Rimer set aside the agreement on the grounds that Mrs Morris did not have sufficient mental capacity to enter into such a contract, saying the mother's and daughter's evidence had been "untruthful and unconvincing".

The judge said he had "the gravest doubts" as to whether the widow had acted of her own free will in signing the agreement with the housekeeper, adding: "I regard the whole course of events leading up to it as redolent with grounds for suspicion."

The widow, who died by strangulation when her clothing was accidentally trapped in a stair lift, embarked on a "quite irrational" spending spree in the months before her death, the judge said. He viewed her gifts to the mother and daughter "with the greatest suspicion".

In a case brought by the hospital's trustees, the judge set aside the "highly imprudent" house transfer and the other gifts to the housekeeper and ruled they formed part of the widow's £400,000 estate - to which the hospital is entitled to a half-share.

Mrs Rushin, of Kniveton, Derbyshire, and her daughter had contested the case, arguing that the affection between them and Mrs Morris prompted her to make the gifts of her own free will. They denied her mental health had deteriorated.

But Mr Justice Rimer said Mrs Morris had been "isolated" from her own family by the two women.

Mrs Rushin's name was also added as a co-signatory to Mrs Morris's building society account, containing more than £66,000. From then on, up to £3,000 a month was withdrawn from the account in cash. Other payments included £5,700 for Mrs Rushin to buy a Peugeot 405, and £16,185 to enable Ms Billinge to buy a BMW. The balance of the account at Mrs Morris's death was £19,000.

The judge cancelled the house transaction and the gifts and loan for the car purchases and declared that the £19,000 was part of the estate.

Mrs Rushin and her daughter will have to pay the estimated £100,000 legal costs.

webTitle: Express wins appeal over disclosure of source

fields.headline: Express wins appeal over disclosure of source
fields.trailText: The Express newspaper yesterday won an appeal court battle to protect the identity of a source who had handed over a confidential document containing legal advice on Sir Elton John's financial affairs.
fields.body:
The Express newspaper yesterday won an appeal court battle to protect the identity of a source who had handed over a confidential document containing legal advice on Sir Elton John's financial affairs.

Three judges overturned an earlier decision which had ordered the paper to disclose its source. They said the incident was a one-off which should not be used to erode the right of reporters to protect their sources.

During the original hearing at the high court in London, Mr Justice Morland was told that a draft of a barrister's written opinion, which had been discarded at his chambers, found its way to the Express journalist Rachel Baird.

After making notes about the document, Ms Baird tore it up, put the pieces in an envelope and asked a colleague to dispose of them. They ended up in a Soho dustbin.

When Ms Baird telephoned Sir Elton's lawyers for a comment on the information she had gained, they immediately obtained an injunction banning publication.

The injunction remains in force.

Mr Justice Morland had ruled that the newspaper should disclose its source because that person presented a "very real and continuing danger to the interests of justice, threatening the confidentiality of legal professional privilege".

"Balancing the competing interests of justice and of investigative journalism, in the exercise of my discretion in my judgment I do not consider it disproportionate to order, and do so order, the defendants to disclose the identity of the source."

Express Newspapers, the paper's editor Rosie Boycott and journalist Rachel Baird appealed, arguing that the paper had a "public interest" defence under the contempt of court act.

Giving his judgment yesterday, the master of the rolls, Lord Woolf, said that Mr Justice Morland was "clearly wrong" to conclude that the desire to identify the source overrode the need to protect that person.

There was a "prime need" to protect the source "in the interest of ensuring a free press in a democratic society", he said.

 The hospital which houses Moors murderer Ian Brady yesterday won a high court order directing the Mirror newspaper to reveal the source who handed over confidential records on the killer.

Ashworth hospital in Maghull, Merseyside, took the action over publication of a series of verbatim extracts from a diary that logged Brady's moods, actions and words.

webTitle: Teachers plan to sue over disruptive pupils

fields.headline: Teachers plan to sue over disruptive pupils
fields.standfirst: Blunkett warned social inclusion will lead to spate of court cases
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, was warned yesterday of a flood of litigation from teachers injured by disruptive pupils who are no longer being expelled from schools because of the government's social inclusion policy.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, was warned yesterday of a flood of litigation from teachers injured by disruptive pupils who are no longer being expelled from schools because of the government's social inclusion policy.

The Association of Teachers and Lecturers said it was already preparing 13 negligence suits against local education authorities that allegedly failed to protect staff from the foreseeable dangers of returning troublemakers to the classroom.

The cases are being taken on behalf of teachers claiming £1.5m in damages for injuries received when they were assaulted by pupils, or during attempts to restrain them.

One was a newly qualified teacher who had to hide in a cupboard to escape a secondary pupil who hit her and chased her round the school.

But the union's legal officers said there was likely to be a surge in numbers of cases brought by teachers and the parents of children injured by violent classmates.

A survey of 31 branch secretaries showed unanimous concern that disruptive behaviour was making it harder for children to learn.

Most thought behaviour had deteriorated since the government set targets to reduce permanent exclusions by a third by 2002.

Three in four said schools did not get adequate support for dealing with pupils at risk of exclusion and 71% said teachers did not get enough help with handling violent, abusive, disruptive pupils, or those who bully other pupils.

"Students now believe they can be rude, abusive, violent, cast false allegations, set off fire alarms and the school will accept them back," said one.

"Being sworn at is something that happens so regularly in school that the teachers don't bother with it any more," said another.

Martin Pilkington, the association's head of legal services, said local education authorities had a duty of care to staff and pupils.

Under health and safety regulations, they should conduct risk assessments before allowing pupils with a history of disruptive behaviour to return to the classroom.

"If teachers are physically injured, they can commence proceedings for negligence against the LEA."

Cases could also be brought by parents of children who have been injured by other pupils. And there might be grounds for legal action against loss of educational opportunities caused by the disruptive behaviour of classmates, he said.

Jennifer Bangs, the association's president, told the conference of "the hour upon hour of energy-draining, confidence-sapping work that goes into containing and maintaining those youngsters whose behaviour is persistently antisocial."

The social inclusion policy was laudable, but teachers could not be expected to solve all society's ills.

Children with learning difficulties and behavioural problems were often better served in special schools where places had been cut on grounds of cost.

"Not to marginalise them, not to exclude them, but to acknowledge candidly that in a civilised society caring for the many often means making specific ... provision for the few," said Ms Bangs, a teacher at West Park community school in Derby.

The association issued a four-point action plan calling for:

 stronger emphasis on behaviour management during teacher training;

 behaviour management courses for teachers this year;

 early intervention strategies to nip misbehaviour in the bud among the under-fives;

 support centres to help schools with behaviour problems.

Peter Smith, the association's general secretary, said: "Teachers do believe social inclusion is a good thing, but they want to make sure youngsters get the proper specialist support they are entitled to."

Mr Blunkett is expected to tell teachers next week at the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers conference in Llandudno that the social inclusion policy is not meant to permit violence in the classroom.

Education department sources said the government was funding 400 units for disruptive pupils.

Everyday violence

Examples of school violence reported to the conference:

 At an unnamed Nottingham secondary school, pupils removed part of the roof and poured hot pitch into the classroom below during a lesson. Only one of the culprits was punished by a short period of exclusion.

 At another Nottingham secondary school, teachers were advised to get as many of their pupils as possible into the classroom at the start of the lesson and then to lock the door.

 A newly qualified woman teacher had to hide in a cupboard to escape from a pupil who had assaulted her and then chased her round the school.

webTitle: Pop star claims hollow victory in cash battle

fields.headline: Pop star claims hollow victory in cash battle
fields.standfirst: 'It's morally disgraceful that Phil Collins [above] has gone this far over a pittance'   Defendants' solicitor
fields.trailText: Multi-millionaire pop star Phil Collins yesterday won almost £250,000 in a high court battle over royalties with two impoverished members of his former backing band, only to be told he would never collect most of the money owed.
fields.body:
Multi-millionaire pop star Phil Collins yesterday won almost £250,000 in a high court battle over royalties with two impoverished members of his former backing band, only to be told he would never collect most of the money owed.

The judge ruled that the singer had overpaid the horn players a total of £244,000 in royalties because of an accounting error, but made it clear that the two men, who have no other regular income, will not have to repay any of the money "out of their own pockets".

In his ruling Mr Justice Jonathan Parker awarded the pop star's company, Philip Collins Ltd, only half of the amount sought from trumpeter Louis Satterfield, 51, and trombonist Rahmlee Davis, 63, because the overpayment had not been their fault.

The judge, who at the start of the case commented that the amounts in dispute were "not much", said it was "highly regrettable" that the matter had not been resolved before it came to court.

Collins, who is believed to be worth £300m, had never attempted to compel the two men to pay back the overpaid royalties, asking only for all future payments to be stopped. But the judge said it was "highly improbable" that the future royalty payments of about £12,500 a year each would ever cover the sum owed to the pop star. In practice, Collins would "only recover a small part of the amount to which he is entitled".

Davis and Satterfield, who had played with Jackie Wilson, Aretha Franklin and Chuck Berry, were founder members of the Phenix Horns, who performed with the 1970s group Earth Wind and Fire. Despite helping Phil Collins launch his solo career in 1979 after leaving Genesis, the court heard that the two men were now penniless, with Satterfield living on benefits while Davis had been forced to pawn his musical instruments.

The two men performed on several successful Phil Collins albums, including Face Value in 1981, and But Seriously in 1989, for which they received session and touring fees. They also appeared on Serious Hits Live, recorded during the singer's 1990 tour, for which they received royalties worth hundreds of thousands of pounds.

But those royalty payments were terminated in 1996 when the chief accountant at Philip Collins Ltd realised the horn players had been paid royalties for all 15 tracks on the album, despite playing on only five songs. He wrote to them explaining they had each been overpaid $345,000 for worldwide sales of the album and £29,000 for sales in the UK.

Davis, from California, and Satterfield, from Chicago, began proceedings against Collins in California in 1997 claiming they were entitled to full royalties and damages, and accusing the star's company of being "oppressive, fraudulent and malicious".

But this action was suspended to allow Philip Collins Ltd to bring a case in London after the US court ruled that the pair's contracts were signed under English law.

Yesterday the judge ruled that the pair should only have been paid on a pro rata basis for the five tracks on which they performed. But he said the Phenix Horns had "made an important contribution to the success of the albums on which they performed" and criticised the way in which they were informed of the decision to cease royalty payments as leaving "a great deal to be desired".

The question of costs will be decided at a further hearing, but Davis and Satterfield were represented by lawyers working on a no win, no fee basis.

The horn players' solicitor, Franco Barone, of Rakisons, described the ruling as "a judgment of Solomon". He said: "I think it's morally disgraceful that Phil Collins has gone this far over what is, for him, a pittance when my clients have no other regular source of income."

He wrote to them explaining they had each been overpaid $345,000 for worldwide sales of the album and £29,000 for sales in the UK. Davis, from California, and Satterfield, from Chicago, began proceedings against Collins in California in 1997 claiming they were entitled to full royalties and damages, and accusing the star's company of being "oppressive, fraudulent and malicious". But this action was suspended to allow Philip Collins Ltd to bring a case in London after the US court ruled that the pair's contracts were signed under English law. Yesterday the judge ruled that the pair should only have been paid on a pro rata basis for the five tracks on which they performed. But he said the Phenix Horns had "made an important contribution to the success of the albums on which they performed" and criticised the way in which they were informed of the decision to cease royalty payments as leaving "a great deal to be desired". The question of costs will be decided at a further hearing, but Davis and Satterfield were represented by lawyers working on a no win, no fee basis. The horn players' solicitor, Franco Barone, of Rakisons, described the ruling as "a judgment of Solomon". He said: "I think it's morally disgraceful that Phil Collins has gone this far over what is, for him, a pittance when my clients have no other regular source of income."

fields.headline: Ooh, you are awful
fields.trailText: TV's Naughtiest Blunders | The Naked Chef | ER
fields.body:
It can be hard work watching shows like TV's Naughtiest Blunders (ITV). You know you should be doing something worthy, like giving blood or watching Channel Four. You also know what to expect - a parade of reporters being goosed by geese, drenched by tidal waves and menaced by random grannies. Clips that Dennis Norden has been recycling for such a long time that few in the nation can remember what he did before. Plus, if you're lucky, more recent footage of Grant Mitchell forgetting to grunt, a few examples of why Judy should never have married Richard, and Rolf Harris wiping wallaby wee from his glasses. The whole thing, you know, cost 45p to put together and yet, like the sucker you are, you can't help watching.

So, as if to ease our consciences, ITV pretended this one was a whole new incarnation. They left Norden in cold storage, and fronted the outfit with one Steve Penk - who resembled a wax model of Ray Liotta, and probably cost less to hire. Mr Penk promised us a rare treat - all the "naughty" bits that the censors never normally pass. He failed to explain why the censors had made an exception on this occasion. Possibly they were on strike. But those expecting grainy footage of Richard Whiteley performing a Countdown conundrum upon Carol Vorderman were misled.

We kicked off with Jim Bowen saying "piss". Twice. The show then descended into utter depravity, as Caroline Quentin said "arse", a cherubic Blockbusters contestant confused "organism" and "orgasm" and that champion of liberal values, Jim Davidson, spent 20 minutes trying to pronounce "dyke" without wetting his strides. Censors, whoever you are, please return to your desks. All is forgiven.

Chaps watch cookery programmes, but chaps also seem to reserve a special category of contempt for Jamie Oliver, alias The Naked Chef (BBC2). Firstly, because he's right up there with Mr Darcy and Ralph Fiennes on the list of Thinking Women's Crumpet. Secondly, because no chap can understand why. The boy can cook. He can knock out a gourmet fry-up in the twinkling of an eye, as we saw last night. He does so with a degree of panache - doesn't care a fig for weighing scales, and his idea of chopping nuts is to wrap them in a towel and batter them senseless against the sideboard. Less bearable, though, is the studied routine that comes as an obligatory side-order. The please-adopt-me eyes and goofy observations, such as "Gotta get the real crunchy boys" (Jamie on apples) and "Mate, if you served this up to the Queen, like, she'd love it." The nation has been assured that Jamie is a salt-of-the-earth Essex boy, not a trust fund in sight. Perhaps so, but this daffy, slightly stoned persona still looks like an act. In student bars across the land, thousands of bright lads are performing just the same number as part of their seduction routines. The difference is, of course, that Jamie has real talent. This means he'll probably be with us for decades - so chaps had better swallow their bile.

This week's helping saw Jamie whipping up a midnight feast for his distinctly upmarket sweetheart and a selection of young heiresses. The fry-up was the crowning glory. "I call it Midnight Pan-fried Breakfast 'cos I make it at midnight, an' I make it in a pan, an'..." Pause. Scratches head. Boyish grin. "... an'... it's breakfast. Sort of." Bless.

Last night was a Valentine's Day double bill for ER (C4). But hearts and flowers were fairly thin on the ground. While the staff celebrated the occasion with a desultory boogie, Dr Carter and his doe-eyed protégée Lucy Knight were carved up by a knife-wielding schizophrenic. They lay on the ground, gushing blood, limbs twitching in time to the techno beat coming from the party. In the second half, when the hapless pair were discovered, there was plenty of running about, a large quantity of bleeping machinery and lots of breathless lines like "Gimme eight migs of atropine bp 80 over 20 systolic..." Lucy had almost gasped her last before anyone spoke in a language approximating English. And then it was to ask, "Is she making urine?" She was. And she continued to do so for another episode, before turning blue. At least, in the weepy epilogue, no one said "She was too young to die". This would have been a gross understatement. Lucy was patently too young for a paper round.
