webTitle: Watchdog will tackle bias against disabled people

fields.headline: Watchdog will tackle bias against disabled people
fields.trailText: Disabled people still face shameful discrimination in all areas of their day-to-day lives, ministers said yesterday at the London launch of the disability rights commission to protect and promote their rights.
fields.body:
Disabled people still face shameful discrimination in all areas of their day-to-day lives, ministers said yesterday at the London launch of the disability rights commission to protect and promote their rights.

Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, said it was shameful that they had been denied the same rights as the rest of the population for so long.

"The DRC will be a step upwards in the quality of life for disabled people, a step forward for those looking to change their practices, a helpful step for those prepared to change, a guiding step for those reluctant or unconvinced of the need to change and a warning step to those opposing change," she said.

Bert Massie, chairman of the DRC, and a wheelchair user, said disabled people face discrimination and a raw deal in society, but the DRC had been established to transform that situation. It was a milestone in achieving full civil rights.

"The commission has a challenging but hugely exciting task," he said.

"In tackling that task, and working in partnership, we shall achieve it - we will be making history."

He rejected the suggestion that the body would simply be used for taking legal action against employers. "We will fight with the force of argument and if that does not work we will try the argument of force," he said.

The DRC will give disabled people a body of equivalent status to the equal opportunities commission and the commission for racial equality. It is made up of 14 members representing a wide range of interests including disabled people, business, trades unions and voluntary sectors as well as Scotland and Wales. Ten of the commissioners are disabled.

Among its members is Evelyn Rank-Petruzzietto, a woman with learning disabilities. Her appointment has been seen as a breakthrough for Britain's 1.2m people with a learning disability, who have complained of being marginalised as "mentally handicapped".

The DRC will provide a helpline for disabled people and employers, legal advice and support for individuals, as well as policy advice to government and others.

One of the first tasks of the commission will be to consult on a draft statutory code of practice requiring those who provide goods and services to the public to make their premises accessible to disabled people.

James Strachan, chief executive of the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, and another commissioner of the DRC, said: "This launch marks an historic milestone in ending discrimination against disabled people.

"By providing not only detailed advice and support but also, where necessary, by enforcing the law, DRC will help to improve the lives of millions of people."

webTitle: Life for Gulf veteran who shot fiancee

fields.headline: Life for Gulf veteran who shot fiancee
fields.trailText: An army doctor and former SAS trooper who machine-gunned his fiancee to death in a pub car park started a life jail sentence yesterday after a judge dismissed his Gulf war syndrome defence as spurious.
fields.body:
An army doctor and former SAS trooper who machine-gunned his fiancee to death in a pub car park started a life jail sentence yesterday after a judge dismissed his Gulf war syndrome defence as spurious.

Thomas Shanks, a consultant anaesthetist and holder of the Military Medal, reverted fatally into a calculating killer, a jury at Sheffield crown court decided, after nurse Vicky Fletcher jilted him for another man.

But his conviction for murder - instead of manslaughter which he had admitted on grounds of personality changes caused by Gulf war service as a captain in the Royal Army Medical Corps - was by a 10-2 majority verdict and came after a previous trial ended in deadlock.

Shanks, 49, showed little emotion at the verdict and sentence.

The family of Ms Fletcher, who was 26 years younger than Shanks and previously brought assault charges against him, welcomed the fact that "justice has at last been done." The shaven-headed doctor told police that he could not bear the thought of Ms Fletcher with another man, the court heard.

On the night of May 7, 1998, knowing she was drinking with her new partner at a pub near the hospital in Pontefract, West Yorkshire, at which he and Ms Fletcher worked, he cleaned and loaded the AK47 and put it into the boot of his car with a baseball bat, axe and knife. After confronting the nurse at one pub and scuffling with David Griffin, the 47-year-old who had taken his place, he tailed them to the Lamplighters pub in Castleford.

He told the court that what followed was unreal and "like being in a video", but witnesses described his behaviour as cool and controlled.

Shanks went briefly on the run but gave himself up near Glasgow after phoning his former wife, Julie, who had been placed under police guard with their nine-year-old daughter Jodie.

Shanks was one of nine children of a labourer who died of an epileptic fit. After his mother took to drink, Shanks ran away, and joined the army at 17.

The SAS changed everything - evidence from an anonymous colonel described him as exceptionally brave and honest - and on discharge he took O and A levels and qualified as a doctor at Birmingham University. But the court heard there had always been a darker side to him, including an incident when he head-butted a policeman after being arrested for drunken driving.

Problems grew after he was stabbed by skinheads in Birmingham during medical training, and became pronounced on his return from call-up as a RAMC doctor in the Gulf, the court heard.

Ray Bristow, a warrant officer who served with Shanks in the Gulf, said he had visited the doctor in prison and was convinced Gulf war syndrome had affected him.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Royal Wedding | The Addams Family | Let Him Have It | The Wicker Man
fields.body:
Royal Wedding

(Stanley Donen, 1951)

11.20am, TCM

This should have been a marvellous musical. The story, screenplay and lyrics are by Alan Jay Lerner (who did the same job on An American In Paris), it has a European location and it stars Fred Astaire. Unfortunately, Fred's powers were diminishing (or maybe he was just bored) and his co-star Joan Powell (lll) is no Vera Ellen. The best number is Fred's dancing on the ceiling routine. But the rest of the London-set story, full of fake cockneys and fog, is a letdown.
Rebecca Carroll

The Addams Family

(Barry Sonnenfeld, 1991)

11.15am, 4.20pm, Sky Premier

The kooky, spooky Addams family, out of the New Yorker comic strip and 60s TV series, are just as hilariously bizarre on the big screen, thanks to inspired casting - Anjelica Huston's Morticia, Raoul Julia's Gomez, Christopher Lloyd's Uncle Fester and, of course, Christopher Hart's hand as Thing. Macabre buffoonery.

Let Him Have It

(Peter Medak, 1991)

12.10am, Sky Cinema

Christopher Eccleston plays Derek Bentley, the 19-year-old epileptic with a mental age of 11 who was hanged in 1952 for the shooting of a policeman. His 16-year-old friend, Chris Craig (Paul Reynolds) had fired the gun, but was too young to be executed. The court decided that when Bentley, already under arrest, shouted: "Let him have it, Chris", he meant "shoot", not "hand over the gun".

The Wicker Man

(Robin Hardy, 1973)

1.45am, FilmFour

Policeman Edward Woodward goes to a remote Scottish island to find a missing girl, but uncovers ancient pagan rites - and wild, wild women such as Britt Ekland, Diane Cliento and Ingrid Pitt. Anthony Shaffer's intelligent screenplay slowly stokes up the sinister, erotic atmosphere. As the deluded Woodward's suspicions grow, the tone changes from mildly comic to horrific, and with old devil Christopher Lee presiding as local laird, it's hardly surprising the sergeant becomes a basket case.

fields.headline: The Price is Right
fields.standfirst:
Which will be the theme of John Hughes' next film?
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Which will be the theme of John Hughes' next film?
fields.body:
Teenage angst ...............1/3

Road movie ....................7/4

Geeks becoming cool .....7/2

Murder/mystery ...........50/1

John Hughes, über-80s kids director, is back. He's in talks with producer Joe Roth for what will be his first movie since Curly Sue. Hughes was to teen movies what Spielberg is to the kids, but given that teen movies have changed since he was last in charge of a film, what can we expect from this legend of a man? We asked Ladbrokes analytical guru Ed Nicholson to hazard a guess.

"Teenage movies (and TV shows) have changed since his last foray into the subject", says Ed. "It's no longer the case that movies survive on storylines around white middle-class youths rebelling against society - Hughes' Ferris Bueller's Day Off being a classic example. Nowadays, teenage angst films centre on why the oppressor's feeling oppressed, and what's happened in their dark mysterious past to make them act as they do.

"Some up-and-coming productions include plots about partying at college, geeks, school losers, teens on the rampage and the downfall of cute students. Rumours about Hughes' film, tentatively titled New Port South, seem to go along these darker lines - unknown actors and even an ex-porn star have been mentioned in the cast. Some say it'll be a darker version of Hughes' The Breakfast Club.

"Hughes' 21-year-old son has written the script, which should add a new perspective. Some film journalists suggest Hughes may be directing a murder movie (with teenagers). That's possible, given that the viewing public seem to want "blood" rather than "cute" at the moment.

"Road movies will always reach the big screen and heavy symbolism is always popular - he may be thinking of taking this route. Rumours are rife that the film will centre upon a high-school road trip from Chicago to California. Geeks becoming cool has been done to death. It's popular, but surely a man such as Hughes won't regress?"

webTitle: We share the blame for Zimbabwe

fields.headline: We share the blame for Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst:
The British debt to the people of Zimbabwe runs into billions
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The British establishment is poorly qualified to lecture Robert Mugabe about racism. The government's condemnation of the murders of two white Zimbabwean farmers contrasts oddly with the blandishments with which it greeted Vladimir Putin, responsible for the deaths of thousands of Chechens.
fields.body:
The British establishment is poorly qualified to lecture Robert Mugabe about racism. The government's condemnation of the murders of two white Zimbabwean farmers contrasts oddly with the blandishments with which it greeted Vladimir Putin, responsible for the deaths of thousands of Chechens.

Just as it revealed that Zimbabwe's white refugees are welcome, for "reasons of ancestry", to settle here permanently, it announced that it would expel 3,000 Kosovan Albanians.

While the newspapers devoted hundreds of column inches to the horrible killings of the two white farmers, they scarcely mentioned the equally horrible killing of the black foreman who worked for one of them. The dispute between London and Harare is a dispute between racists.

Like Jack Straw and William Hague, Mugabe is using racism as a cheap means of winning votes. But while he has made life miserable for Zimbabwe's white population, he has also compromised the survival of millions of blacks. He is destroying the very cause he claims to espouse: Robert Mugabe has become the enemy of land reform.

The recent land seizures mirror the thefts which first enabled the whites to control so much of Zimbabwe's economy. In the 1890s, Cecil Rhodes and the settlers he led first cheated and then forcibly dispossessed the Shona and the Ndebele. The whites stole their land, their cattle and, through taxation, their labour.

When they rebelled against these impositions, the blacks were cruelly suppressed and their leaders were hanged. From 1930, blacks were forbidden to own land outside the barren and crowded "reserves". Even the cities were secured by the settlers: native people were confined to rented property in peripheral townships.

As has been reported, the laws have changed, but the distribution of land has scarcely altered: some 7m blacks still inhabit the sterile wastes of the old reserves. Some of the white farmers claim that if they were to lose control of the land, Zimbabwe would starve, but any visit to a British supermarket shows that this is nonsense.

Much of Zimbabwe's most fertile land is used to grow not necessities for the hungry, but luxuries for the sated: mange tout, radicchio, french beans and tobacco. Redistribution would enable the poor to support themselves and to produce staple crops for the landless: all over the third world it is smallholders who keep their own countries fed.

Land reform in Zimbabwe is an urgent necessity. But by manipulating the distribution programme to secure his own survival, Mugabe is keeping his people hungry. He is, however, not solely to blame for its failures.

The 1979 Lancaster House agreement, which oversaw the transition to majority rule in Zimbabwe, ensured that the Zimbabwean government could use local currency only to buy land from farmers who were willing to sell. If it were to expropriate their property, it would have to compensate them with scarce and precious foreign exchange.

The agreement bound the country to a programme of land reform whose implementation would have cost billions. Having hinted that we would pay for it, our government handed over only a fraction of the money required - £44m - to make it happen.

Had a sterner settlement been struck, or had Britain been more generous, there might not have been a land distribution problem. Our meanness, compounded perhaps by an unwillingness to undermine the white economic hegemony, perpetuated Zimbabwe's racial segregation.

Mugabe, unable to oversee a full and fair redistribution, acquired an excuse to turn land into a gift, deployed as political imperatives demanded. When the Lancaster House agreement expired, he changed the constitution to allow the government to make compulsory purchases in Zimbabwe dollars, but he used the new power to reward his friends and purchase his enemies.

If our politics are to be distinguished from Mr Mugabe's, then we must extend to Zimbabwe's blacks the munificence we have offered the whites.

The government's condemnation of the murders of two white Zimbabwean farmers contrasts oddly with the blandishments with which it greeted Vladimir Putin, responsible for the deaths of thousands of Chechens. While the newspapers devoted hundreds of column inches to the horrible killings of the two white farmers, they scarcely mentioned the equally horrible killing of the black foreman who worked for one of them. fields.headline: Gym'll fix it
fields.standfirst: Modern men, it seems, are in crisis: dejected, depressed, emasculated by women's strides towards equality. But are they really, as a new book suggests, fighting back by flexing their pecs?  Cosmo Landesman  examines the evidence
fields.trailText: Modern men, it seems, are in crisis: dejected, depressed, emasculated by women's strides towards equality. But are they really, as a new book suggests, fighting back by flexing their pecs?  Cosmo Landesman  examines the evidence.
fields.body:
It used to be that the modern male, with his passion for hair gels, facial scrubs and designer suits, was dismissed as something of a narcissus. That was a decade ago. Now the big news from America is that the modern male has moved on from designer suits to steroids, from facial masks to the pursuit of serious muscle. The narcissistic peacock has been replaced by a new generation of male neurotics suffering from what is being called The Adonis Complex.

That is the name of the latest "sensational" book from the States, based on research by three psychologists, which argues that modern men have an unhealthy obsession with their body image. Where once men got a sense of self-worth and esteem through the workplace, now they're working out in gyms and guzzling down steroids in hot and dangerous pursuit of the perfect body. According to one of the book's authors, Dr Harrison Pope: "Millions of men are suffering shame, self-doubt and embarrassment because of this damaging emphasis on body image."

The question is: has this book really managed to capture a neglected aspect of the crisis of masculinity or is it symptomatic of a growing victim culture, in which to make money with a book you simply manufacture a malady and give it a catchy name like The Adonis Complex? Don't be fooled into thinking that this is just some silly American preoccupation at which we can poke fun. At a time when suicide rates, depression levels and use of steroids are on the increase for young British males, many commentators here are saying the kind of things that are found in The Adonis Complex.

A central claim of the book is that today it is men, even more than women, who suffer from anxiety about the state of their bodies. The authors cite surveys that reveal that 38% of American men want bigger pecs, while only 34% of women want bigger breasts. And when it comes to acne anxiety, young male teenagers are more worried than females.

It seems we men are also victimised by what Naomi Wolf once called The Beauty Myth. Supposedly, the media and movies are awash with images of men with superb muscular bodies. All those stars with their bulging biceps and supermodel babes - with such images of perfection, is it any wonder young men feel inadequate?

But do they? Of course it was always a mistake to assume that anxiety about "body appearance" was something exclusive to women. Ever since the invention of the teenager in the late 50s, adolescent males have been spending more of their time in front of the mirror and more of their income on products that promise to make them more attractive.

The grooming boom that really began in the 80s has been, on balance, a good thing. What woman wants to be involved with some fat, greasy, smelly slob of a man who never makes the effort to look nice? And, yes, there are times when a man looks in the mirror and wants to weep at the gruesome blob he's become and wishes he could swap bodies with Brad Pitt.

But that's not some serious desire that dominates a man's life, as the authors of The Adonis Complex would have us believe. Go to any gym and you will see men who work hard at getting the perfect body. But most men are more modest in their body ambitions: instead of a longing for a perfection they know is impossible to attain, they would be quite happy to settle for more hair, less fat, fewer wrinkles and some muscle. Mr Average Bloke does not want to be an Andonis; just good-looking enough to get the girl of his dreams.

What gives The Adonis Complex its controversial edge is its claim that men are turning to muscle because it is the one area in which they can be superior to women. "Women can now fly combat aircraft, run multinational companies and have eliminated every last male bastion," Pope says. "Today there's nothing a woman can't do. What does a man have left to identify himself as masculine? Few women can bench-press 300lb, so the body remains the last refuge of masculinity."

It seems that, these days, just about every aspect of male behaviour is explained as some kind of scared response to the growing equality of women. But it's interesting to note that the rise of muscle-building culture occurred in America during the 50s, a time not noted for its emancipation of women. Was Charles Atlas really scared of the social advancement of Mrs Atlas - or, as legend has it, was he tired of having sand kicked in his face by men? Anyone who has seen a bunch of guys in a gym pumping iron will know that they are flexing their pecs to impress other men. I would argue that the most body-obsessed people in the world are homosexual men. Are they, too, responding to the empowerment of women?

Most men, here and in America, do not believe that muscularity equals masculinity. Look at the success of Arnold Schwarzenegger in the 80s. He took the serious-tough-guy-real-man stuff out of muscle building and injected a new note of playful irony. Here was the muscle man who invited you to laugh at his image - and not envy it.

If you actually look at the images associated with masculine perfection, stars like Tom Cruise or Brad Pitt, you will see that they are in good physical shape, but none of them looks like a serious body builder. And what about little Leonardo DiCaprio? The world's sexist star has far less muscle on him than Madonna.

I suspect that men today are more concerned about their body appearance than ever before, but not because they are suffering from a crisis of masculinity or a fear of women. On the contrary, they no longer fear being seen as effeminate or homosexual every time they try a new facial scrub or dye their hair. Conversely, women like Madonna who spend a lot of their time building their muscles are no longer dismissed as sad sacks trying to look like men.

We no longer live in a world in which there are such rigid divisions between feminine and masculine, heterosexual and homosexual. I have no doubt that men today are more concerned about the state of their bodies than ever before and it is crucial to a man's sense of self-esteem. But then our whole culture has become far more body aware. The great mass of people have more time, leisure and income than ever before to spend on looking good. Is that new-found freedom something we should fear, as the authors of The Adonis Complex suggest, or sit back and enjoy?

fields.headline: Ooh la la!
fields.standfirst: Julie Street reports from Paris on the latest row over France's so-called porn chic ad campaigns
fields.trailText: Julie Street reports from Paris on the latest row over France's so-called porn chic ad campaigns.
fields.body:
Dressed in a slinky seethrough apron, brandishing a whisk in one hand and a wooden spoon in the other, Babette, the star of a controversial new ad campaign for double cream, has come storming in from nowhere to replace supermodel tax exile Laetitia Casta as le scandale du jour in France. Currently appearing on billboards up and down the country to promote Babette double cream, the punning caption on her pinny has sparked public outrage. It reads: "Babette: Je la lie, je la fouette et parfois elle passe à la casserole." When referring to the product, this means: "Babette: I thicken it, I whip it and sometimes it goes into the saucepan." But the witty double entendre can also take on a blatantly sexual connotation: "Babette: I tie her up, I whip her and sometimes she gets laid."

The campaign has been branded "porn chic", currently much in vogue in French advertising. While Candia, the company that makes Babette, has expressed surprise at the furore, Nicole Péry, the Minister for Women's Rights, has publicly condemned the campaign, declaring: "Under the cover of humour, these advertisements totally trivialise violence against women."

Péry is not alone in her concern. Viviane Monnier, spokesperson for the Fédération Nationale Solidarité Femmes, which runs a helpline for battered women, has called the new porn chic "as dangerous and degrading to women as any other type of porn". She is seeing whether legal action can be brought against Candia for incitement to violence and rape, and is calling for a boycott of all the company's products.

This week, Candia have defended themselves by saying the campaign was dreamt up by an all-women team, but it comes as no surprise to find it was a male director who pulled Babette's apron strings. Christophe Corsand, a creative director at French ad agency D'Arcy, says he is "stunned" by the reaction. "Babette is meant to be a modern, active woman. She comes across as smart, sassy and assertive, not submissive. I think the ad is a lot less demeaning to women than the classic washing powder ads that depict Little House On The Prairie-style housewives."

Corsand's argument that Babette is a self-confident, provocative woman is hard to swallow when she doesn't even have a head ("We had to crop the picture to fit in the long slogan on the apron!"). But the most significant part of the debate is why this ad has managed to spark such controversy when ads of a similarly offensive nature have been plastered over French billboards for the past 10 years. Bare breasts have masqueraded as melons and tomatoes, and olive oil has been promoted with the slogan: "She's 16, she's a virgin and she's great at cooking!" In one interactive campaign, a pouting babe in underwear promised "Tomorrow I'll take off my top!" (cue bare breasts the next day) and "Next week it's the bottom!" (Metro-users were treated to a bum shot the following week).

Vladimir Donn, producer of Culture Pub, a French TV show that goes in for witty deconstruction of ads, claims French campaigns are often shocking to Anglo-Saxon eyes because the French do not share the same taboos about naked bodies. "I find the Babette ad extremely funny," Donn says. "People who accuse it of inciting domestic violence are missing the S&M connotations."

A quick poll of French friends reveals that many find the ad "subtle", "sophisticated" and "pretty funny". "It's not offensive," insists Pauline, a graphic designer in her 30s: "I mean, it's not as if you've got some guy standing there saying it to her!"

However, British friends do take offence. Anne-Marie Harper, Parisian publishing executive and working mother of two, says she is constantly shocked at the way women are portrayed in French advertising. "When I moved here 10 years ago, I found the whole thing really upsetting," she says. "I was particularly irritated by a campaign for a clothes chain called La City which had this totally gratuitous shot of a naked girl. It was almost laughable - I mean, nowhere on the poster did you get the slightest idea of what La City's clothes were like."

Stephanie Theobald, author of Biche, a new novel that does for Paris what Armistead Maupin did for San Francisco, blames Babette-style advertising on general French attitudes to sex. "Basically, the French get away with what we call sexism because sex in France, from the Marquis de Sade right through to Bernard Henri-Lévy, has always been marketed as some sort of cerebral, philosophical activity." In a country in which even the sleaziest wife-swapping clubs are euphemised as "thétres de la sexualité", it is perhaps little wonder that poor old Babette has been swallowed up by a slick advertising pun.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week.
fields.body:
"Maybe I should try and sleep with her. That'll get Antonio's attention. But seriously, when I know someone is married with kids, it's like they're wearing some funny mask. They're just not a sexual person to me because I think that's so beautiful"

Actress Angelina Jolie on Melanie Griffith, Woman's Journal

"Melanie Griffith has been showing distressing signs of that painful condition known as CHAPS - Cool Husband, Anxious Partner Syndrome. At the age of 42, our Melanie should be able to relax, let go a little, have a Hobnob. But there is no rest for the woman who has got herself hitched to a love god"

Allison Pearson, Evening Standard

"In many ways I feel sorry for them. It's not simple any more. And even some of the younger ones have still been brought up to think they're the centre of the universe and that a woman will be cooking when she's just spent a day out at work"

Kathleen Turner on men, Hello!

"It took two blondes to get me pregnant - David Bowie and Christie Brinkley. In Africa, there's a tradition that when a woman wants to conceive ... she should hold another woman's baby. And Christie and I were on a set shooting for Vogue last year ... and she let me hold her baby all day long"

Supermodel Iman explains the custom that helped her conceive, Evening Standard

"Princess Anne has emerged from the style doldrums to become this season's surprise fashion icon. You may find it hard to believe but the 49-year-old royal is the inspiration for the hottest looks on the high street. 'Ladylike chic' is one of this season's trendy looks - putting the Princess's dress sense at the forefront of fashion"

Fashion editor Catherine Westwood, Sun

"We are nervous about age, but fierce in the protection of our young ... The idea of 'schoolgirl pregnancies' strikes us with horror and disgust. We believe that maturity is to be reckoned with by chronological age. We maintain that 15 and 3/4 is too young for sex, but 16 is OK ... Education, education, education comes the answer; forget that the de facto age of consent in Holland is 12; that to the rebellious young, what is forbidden is alluring"

Fay Weldon, New Statesman

fields.headline: No: 1619
fields.standfirst: Paul Allen
fields.trailText: Paul Allen
fields.body:
Age: 46.

Appearance: Chubby, gnomish insurance salesman.

Occupation: Professional billionaire and rock star.

Never heard of him. Oh come on, he's one of the grown men!

You mean he's an ageing rocker who should know better but pretends he doesn't? Does he look like Ronnie Wood to you?

No, he looks like a businessman. You're getting warmer. He is a businessman - the co-founder of Microsoft, to be exact, worth something like £30bn and America's third-richest man. And one of the grown men.

The incredibly loaded men, you mean. That too. But when he wasn't locked up in a garage with Bill dreaming up a new world order and eating too many Twinkies, Allen was practising his best riffs on his rhythm guitar and forming a band called the Grown Men. This week they launched their first, eponymous, album.

Let me guess, the first track is a trance version of the Berry Gordy classic Money (That's What I Want)? No, it's a dark, paranoid little ditty called Whirlpool. It's not all sunshine in Paul Allen's world, you know.

Well, what's it like? Read those heartbreaking lyrics and weep: "I was born without much charm / Set off every false alarm / Combed my slick hair back / No one would cut me a bit of slack / Everything I do may seem wrong / But my heart, my heart beats strong."

I'm weeping, believe me. Any other insights into the mind of a multibillionaire? "When you follow the instructions to the letter / That just means it never works / If you looked deep in the mirror / We could imagine peace on earth."

If he looked deep in the mirror he could imagine the end to world poverty. Yes, but "poverty" doesn't rhyme with much and, let's face it, it's not very rock'n'roll.

Why not? Because he said it first. And he can afford a better lawyer.

You mean he's an ageing rocker who should know better but pretends he doesn't? Does he look like Ronnie Wood to you? No, he looks like a businessman. You're getting warmer. fields.headline: Raymond Grosset
fields.standfirst: For 50 years he ran a leading photo agency from his family home in the heart of Paris
fields.trailText: Raymond Grosset, who has died aged 89, ran the last of the family photo agencies - Rapho - for over 50 years, working with, among others, Bill Brandt and Eugene Smith. Through the agency he combined his greatest loves - work, wife and children.
fields.body:
Raymond Grosset, who has died aged 89, ran the last of the family photo agencies - Rapho - for over 50 years, working with, among others, Bill Brandt and Eugene Smith. Through the agency he combined his greatest loves - work, wife and children. Although he retired over a decade ago, the agency continued to be his home from home. Quite naturally so, since it occupied the entire third floor of the family house on the Rue d'Alger in Paris's first district. Rapho was derived from Charles Rado, a Hungarian Jew who pitched up in Paris in the late 1920s, and fell in with such photographic luminaries as Kertesz, Brassai and Ergy Landau, a young woman who Grosset happened to meet on holiday in 1930.

Fascinated, possibly by her and certainly by her brand new miniature Rolleiflex, as a keen amateur photographer, Grosset was also keen to meet Charles Rado. He followed the initial fortunes of the original Rado-Photo enterprise as he pursued his own training as a film technician. By 1939 he was running a laboratory in Finland for Paramount, meeting Greta Garbo, and watching anxiously as hostilities commenced

A year later, France fell to the Germans and Grosset was in London, among the first to join de Gaulle's Free French forces. Returning home after the war he found the optimistic "new vision" of his film years obsolete, and the prospect of joining his father's metal-manufacturing company even less attractive. Charles Rado had long since fled to New York, but Ergy Landau was still around, along with many of the others.

Several of that generation of reportage journalists had also participated in the Resistance: there was suddenly much in common with Willy Ronis, Edouard Boubat and, above all, with Robert Doisneau. Rado had established Rapho-Guillemette, and was eager for Grosset to buy out the Paris base.

Grosset did this by dint of his demob money, his family inheritance, and some murky sleuthing to recover the pre-war picture archive from a former collaborator. It was soon esconced, along with a secretary, in his sister's maison de couture in the heart of Paris. The next generation was also drawn to him, with a taste for romantisme a la francaise that burgeoned in Nouvelle Vague cinema as in editorial photography. Jean Dieuzaide, Sabine Weiss, Jean-Philippe Charbonnier and Janine Niepce joined, each epitomising a photography style that became synonymous with both "new humanism" - and a charm and grace that proved internationally recognisable.

The combination of quintessential Frenchness and foreign appeal was a winning one. Through Charles Rado, Doisneau and the others saw their work syndicated to Life and Time. Conversely, Grosset's Rapho-Paris began to expand to take in more overseas photographers, particularly North American ones. Grosset even assumed the European production of Time magazine.

Raymond Grosset's hallmark was mutual respect; he would never permit the sale of a picture the agency could not all be proud of. When photographer Sandford Roth followed James Dean on his fated last ride, he took a shot of the crash and the corpse - but it went only to the family.

He was also immensely hospitable: the atmosphere in the office crowded with folders and photos, "afternoon tea" and the fug of Disques Bleus, was that of a comfortable and welcoming club. Even children were admitted, including his grandchildren, with whom he recently champagne-celebrated his 89th birthday.

Grosset's collaborations with Eugene Smith in the States and Bill Brandt in London led to a series of books by contemporary photographers and to equally committed lifelong friendships. In one instance, friendship became marriage as Barbara Byrne, sent to Paris as an intern, became Grosset's young wife. He was devastated at her early death, in 1987.

Grosset was always for making selective changes and fresh advances. In the 1950s he raised the profile of the medium by instigating the Nadar and the Niepce prizes; in the 60s and 70s, he promoted "new colourists", expanding magazine photography through the colour initiatives of Georg Gerster, Hans Sylvester, Sabrina Michaud and others.

It was therefore appropriate that last week Paris Match should honour him as "the photographer's advocate, ferociously defending their work and perpetuating the humanist tradition".

Raymond Grosset is survived by two daughters and a son, two of whom continue to run the Rapho photo agency.

Raymond Grosset, photographic agent, born February 21 1911; died April 6 2000

fields.headline: Linda Biran
fields.standfirst: Modest power behind a community's regeneration
fields.trailText: Linda Biran, who has died aged 59, played a hidden but powerful part in the recent regeneration of Leeds, which has seen the once-dour industrial centre become one of the liveliest regional cities in the country.
fields.body:
Linda Biran, who has died aged 59, played a hidden but powerful part in the recent regeneration of Leeds, which has seen the once-dour industrial centre become one of the liveliest regional cities in the country.

Through the innovative local Civic Trust and a highly targeted waterfront partnership which has transformed the local river Aire, she showed how much a determined and imaginative "ordinary person" can do for a community.

In official terms, she ranked modestly as the trust's vice-chair and newsletter editor, and her preferred job description at Eye on the Aire would have come somewhere between factotum and dogsbody. But in practice she ran the engine room of both organisations, turning her hand to everything from lobbying to stuffing envelopes, and galvanising others because of the strength, and charm, of her own enthusiasm.

Biran inherited a particular sense of purpose from her father, a BBC radio engineer who was a conscientious objector during the second world war. He and her mother encouraged her independence, at a time when professional horizons for women were still circumscribed , and nurtured her eagerness for new opportunities and ideas which lasted all her life.

Her education typified this; although she trained as a teacher at Edge Hill College, Liverpool, and qualified with distinction, she was unable to raise enough money to realise her hopes of studying for a university degree. She took a theology diploma and went into teaching, but the dream stayed with her, and in the 1970s she achieved it through the Open University.

Working as a research fellow in medical education at Dundee University, she then stimulated her own students with a particular, winning enthusiasm based on wanting others to share the excitement and enjoyment which she had found. Her husband Leonard Biran, also studying at Dundee and later a GP and senior lecturer in general practice at Leeds University, became used to the almost inevitable, eager, first question from new colleagues: "Are you anything to do with Linda Biran?"

Her regeneration role was also triggered by her interest in lifelong learning, when she enrolled in 1987 on an adult education course on the history of Leeds given by the Civic Trust's director Dr Kevin Grady. It was a meeting of like minds which led to 13 years of extremely effective work, in partnership with the city council and a raft of lively but civic-minded developers and entrepreneurs.

Linda's good nature and uninterest in personal kudos, which eased many potential glitches and disagreements, owed much to the warmth of her life at home. Leonard's stints working for the United Nations took her, to her delight, to Ghana and Italy and the couple travelled frequently with their son and daughter, especially to cities, always returning to Leeds with ideas for civic improvement.

When cancer was first diagnosed, she determined not to let it affect her work, and her final year saw Leeds Civic Trust more active than ever.

Linda Biran, lecturer and civic activist, born May 31 1940; died April 7 2000

fields.headline: Gaje Ghale
fields.standfirst: Gurkha sergeant whose courage in a key action in Burma won him the Victoria Cross
fields.trailText: In May 1943 Gaje Ghale, who has died aged 81, was serving as a havildar (sergeant) with the 2nd battalion, 5th Royal Gurkha Rifles. It was during the 17th Indian Division's bitter and bloody struggle with the Japanese 33rd Division on the Tiddim Road in Burma, in the final phase of the Indian division's withdrawal through the Chin Hills.
fields.body:
In May 1943 Gaje Ghale, who has died aged 81, was serving as a havildar (sergeant) with the 2nd battalion, 5th Royal Gurkha Rifles. It was during the 17th Indian Division's bitter and bloody struggle with the Japanese 33rd Division on the Tiddim Road in Burma, in the final phase of the Indian division's withdrawal through the Chin Hills.

The Japanese occupied a crucial position on the Basha East Hill, the approach to which was a narrow ridge little more than 15 ft wide. Two attempts to take the position faltered in the face of withering fire from Japanese machine-gun nests and artillery and mortars concealed in the jungle. On May 25, Gaje, now in command of his company's D platoon, was ordered to take the position.

Encouraging his riflemen and shouting the Gurkha's battle-cry "Ayo Gurkhali!" (the Gurkhas are upon you), Gaje attacked. Although badly wounded by a Japanese grenade, he led his men along the ridge and, apparently oblivious to the fire-power raining down, closed with the enemy in a bitter hand-to-hand fight.

It was an action which won him the Victoria Cross, and as the citation put it, Gaje "dominated the fight" with "his outstanding example, dauntless courage and superb leadership. Hurling grenades and covered in blood from his own wounds, he led assault after assault." The young Gurkhas, "spurred on by the irresistible will of their leader to win, stormed and carried the hill by a magnificent effort and inflicted heavy casualties on the Japanese." Having gained the position, Gaje held it, despite continued heavy fire, refusing to have his wounds dressed until ordered to do so by an officer.

Born in Barpak village in western Nepal, Gaje, a Gurung of the Ghale tribe, enlisted in the Indian army in 1934. Following training, he joined the 2nd battalion, 5th Royal Gurkha Rifles (Frontier Force), subsequently serving in Waziristan and in operations against that now-forgotten thorn in the side of the British Raj, the Fakir of Ipi. From 1939 to 1942, Gaje served as an instructor at the regimental depot in Abbotabad.

With the Japanese invasion of Burma, Gaje's battalion was despatched to Rangoon with the 48th Indian Infantry brigade, joining the 17th Indian Division at the Sittang Bridge in February, 1942. During the seemingly inexorable Japanese advance towards India, Gaje, always at the forefront of the fighting, distinguished himself on numerous occasions as the 17th Indian Division made its heroic withdrawal. Then came his VC-winning action.

In 1944 the Viceroy of India, Field Marshal Lord Wavell, presented Gaje Ghale with his VC at an investiture at the Red Fort in Delhi before a crowd of more than 5,000. In 1946, Gaje paid the first of many visits to London, taking part in the victory parade.

Following independence in 1947, Gaje, promoted Subadar Major, stayed with his battalion, which became part of the new Indian Army as the 5th Gorkha Rifles. He later saw service with the United Nations in the Congo in 1962-63. On his retirement from active service he was awarded the Star of Nepal at a special ceremony held in Kathmandu.

Granted the honorary rank of Captain, Gaje Ghale re tained close links with former regimental colleagues and was a frequent and very welcome guest in Britain, regularly attending reunions of the Victoria Cross and George Cross Association. With other Gurkha VCs, he attended the opening of the Gurkha Museum at Winchester in 1990, and was present at ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of VJ Day in London in 1995. Those who were privileged to meet this remarkable man will long remember his striking presence and smiling countenance. Gaje Ghale, VC, was, indeed, one of "The Bravest of the Brave."

He was married with four sons and five daughters (one of whom predeceased him).

Gaje Ghale, VC, soldier, born August 1 1918; died March 28 2000.

fields.headline: Ricky's luck
fields.standfirst: Tonight in EastEnders, Ricky Butcher finally leaves Albert Square. And he'll do it the only way he knows how: in utter desperation.  Charlie Brooker  pays his own tribute to Walford's unluckiest man
fields.trailText: Tonight in EastEnders, Ricky Butcher finally leaves Albert Square. And he'll do it the only way he knows how: in utter desperation. Charlie Brooker pays his own tribute to Walford's unluckiest man.
fields.body:
It's bye bye to TV's Mr Boo Hoo. After twelve years of unrelenting gloom, Ricky Butcher - Walford's human raincloud - has finally had enough. "There's nothing left for me here," he keeps muttering, intermittently performing that funny swallowing, gulping, staring-from-side-to-side thing he does whenever he wants us to know he's really upset. He's leaving Albert Square the only way he could: in unfettered misery.

Ricky stumbled onto our screens in 1988, and fate has pissed mercilessly into his eyes ever since. It's been nothing but disappointment, heartbreak, humiliation and plodding, battleship-grey drudgery. And while he may not have suffered with dignity - there's nothing dignified about him - he has at least avoided pulling an "Arthur Fowler" and plunging into full-blown mental unhingery. Until now.

Previously, Ricky coped with life's bleaker interludes by slumping morosely on the special "crisis" bench in Albert Square gardens, peering into the depths of an abyss he's simply too dim to understand. Now, with pro-am cuckolder Dan contesting ownership of his dad's pub, and estranged wife Bianca happily settled in Manchester with baby Liam, Ricky's finally overdosing on despair.

Tuesday night's episode in particular contained scenes of harrowing indignity on a par with the infamous male rape scene from the film Scum: Ricky on his hands and knees cleaning a pub toilet; Ricky watching his own sister flirt with Dan; Ricky having his IQ compared to that of a mop by the notoriously half-witted Barry Evans, while the entire population of the square stood laughing in his face. All that was missing was a sequence in which he found himself unpleasantly surprised by an empty toilet roll dispenser, and forced to frog-hop around the Vic in search of a crumpled beer mat to wipe himself with.

In tonight's episode, Ricky finally breaks down and confesses to feeling suicidal. And what precisely does he have to live for anyway?

Not love. There are backward farmhands with more successful private lives. It's hard to see why. Despite having all the charm of a bit of old flannel hanging off a bush, Ricky is at least blessed with intriguing looks. Constant failure has battered his face into an amalgam of glum dejection and astonished distress. Despite the bruiser's physique - the sour mouth, the flattened nose - there's something childlike about his permanent state of upset: Ricky has the sorrowful eyes of a small boy watching a clown die in a grotesque circus accident. He also does a very good line in tireless devotion. Compared to, say, Phil, he's quite a catch.

Nevertheless, he always lucks out. First he fell for Sam Mitchell (Daniella Westbrook), younger sister to Phil and Grant, who soon twigged she'd got herself hitched to the human equivalent of a Little Chef gammon steak, eventually deserting him on the grounds that he was simply too dull to actually matter. Then he met Bianca (Patsy Palmer). She spent years tirelessly henpecking him into teary-eyed bewilderment, before launching into a pointless and doomed affair with her mother's surly boyfriend. Finally, in the most glamorous moment of Ricky's life, their marriage came to a tearful halt on a grimy Euston concourse.

Leaving Walford is clearly a good move, even if he has to do it in a box. You'll have to tune in this evening to find out what happens, but here's an alternative ending which, while admittedly outlandish, is at least in keeping with Ricky's luck thus far. But be warned: the following paragraph contains scenes not suitable for viewers of a nervous disposition...

So, then. Seeking a new life, Ricky Butcher boards a coach bound for Amsterdam, carrying all his worldly possessions with him - three sets of overalls and an old teaspoon. But 20 miles out of London, a baby lamb runs into the road and the vehicle overturns. The other passengers die horribly, but Ricky miraculously survives. Dazed and bleeding, yet largely unharmed, he is slowly counting his lucky stars on the fingers of one hand when the wreckage catches fire. Trapped in his seat, he gapes in horror as the flames rage towards him. Unable to face the prospect of a fiery death, he grabs the teaspoon from his knapsack and rams it into his eye in a desperate attempt to pierce his brain and finish himself off. But alas! Seconds later a rescue team arrives to douse the blaze. Surgeons at the nearby hospital are unable to remove the spoon, leaving Ricky to walk around with the handle jutting from his head like a miniature diving board. Monumentally depressed, he returns to Walford to continue his job as a mechanic - with the protruding spoon repeatedly pranging against the underside of every vehicle he tries to fix. Finally, after five months of unbearable clattering, Ricky dies of a violent headache.

OK, so that's absurdly grim and unfair. But, hey, it's also very Ricky Butcher.

 EastEnders, tonight, 7.30pm, BBC1; EastEnders Revealed: Ricky Butcher Special, BBC Choice, tonight, 8pm

There are backward farmhands with more successful private lives. It's hard to see why. Despite having all the charm of a bit of old flannel hanging off a bush, Ricky is at least blessed with intriguing looks. Constant failure has battered his face into an amalgam of glum dejection and astonished distress. Despite the bruiser's physique - the sour mouth, the flattened nose - there's something childlike about his permanent state of upset: Ricky has the sorrowful eyes of a small boy watching a clown die in a grotesque circus accident. He also does a very good line in tireless devotion. Compared to, say, Phil, he's quite a catch. Nevertheless, he always lucks out. First he fell for Sam Mitchell (Daniella Westbrook), younger sister to Phil and Grant, who soon twigged she'd got herself hitched to the human equivalent of a Little Chef gammon steak, eventually deserting him on the grounds that he was simply too dull to actually matter. Then he met Bianca (Patsy Palmer). She spent years tirelessly henpecking him into teary-eyed bewilderment, before launching into a pointless and doomed affair with her mother's surly boyfriend. Finally, in the most glamorous moment of Ricky's life, their marriage came to a tearful halt on a grimy Euston concourse. Leaving Walford is clearly a good move, even if he has to do it in a box. You'll have to tune in this evening to find out what happens, but here's an alternative ending which, while admittedly outlandish, is at least in keeping with Ricky's luck thus far. But be warned: the following paragraph contains scenes not suitable for viewers of a nervous disposition... So, then. Seeking a new life, Ricky Butcher boards a coach bound for Amsterdam, carrying all his worldly possessions with him - three sets of overalls and an old teaspoon. But 20 miles out of London, a baby lamb runs into the road and the vehicle overturns. The other passengers die horribly, but Ricky miraculously survives. Dazed and bleeding, yet largely unharmed, he is slowly counting his lucky stars on the fingers of one hand when the wreckage catches fire. Trapped in his seat, he gapes in horror as the flames rage towards him. Unable to face the prospect of a fiery death, he grabs the teaspoon from his knapsack and rams it into his eye in a desperate attempt to pierce his brain and finish himself off. But alas! Seconds later a rescue team arrives to douse the blaze. Surgeons at the nearby hospital are unable to remove the spoon, leaving Ricky to walk around with the handle jutting from his head like a miniature diving board. Monumentally depressed, he returns to Walford to continue his job as a mechanic - with the protruding spoon repeatedly pranging against the underside of every vehicle he tries to fix. Finally, after five months of unbearable clattering, Ricky dies of a violent headache. OK, so that's absurdly grim and unfair. But, hey, it's also very Ricky Butcher.  EastEnders, tonight, 7.30pm, BBC1; EastEnders Revealed: Ricky Butcher Special, BBC Choice, tonight, 8pm

fields.headline: 'No winners or losers' in compromise
fields.trailText: For Britain and Spain the colony of Gibraltar has always been a troublesome "stone in the shoe" that soured their relations.
fields.body:
For Britain and Spain the colony of Gibraltar has always been a troublesome "stone in the shoe" that soured their relations.

Yesterday instead of trumpeting news of the agreement, which followed nine months of convoluted negotiations, every effort was made by Spanish officials to play it down.

The fate of the tiny two-and-a-half square mile rocky promontory and its 29,000 inhabitants still stirs passions and carries a risk of negative fallout for those who tinker with it.

"There are no winners or losers," insisted Spanish Government spokesman Josep Pique, assuring Spaniards that the agreement carried "no implied renunciation" of Spain's claim to regain sovereignty over Gibraltar.

But talk of Spain is anathema to the Gibraltarians. Peter Caruana, the colony's chief minister, assured his voters yesterday that there had been no concessions to Spain.

Instead, he said, the agreement would settle a long-running row over Gibraltar-issued passports, identity cards and driving licences, which had led to long delays at the border.

There would also be greater police cooperation over the straits between Gibraltar, Spain and North Africa - a key route for illegal immigrants and drugs and tobacco smugglers.

In return, however, Gibraltar's attempts to operate independently from Britain within the EU have been squashed. Gibraltarians have always been adamant that they did not want to be Spanish but an increasing number no longer feel British either.

Under the agreement Britain will have to rubber-stamp all financial activity in the colony after Spain refused to recognise the competence of financial regulation in Gibraltar.

This has calmed Spanish worries that Gibraltar was dealing directly with other EU countries in a move towards independence.

The sensitivities are such that the agreement has shirked any mention of the question of sovereignty.

But diplomats on both sides hope it may build confidence which could, in the long run, bring a settlement closer.

"It's one step further in the right direction," said Mr Pique, making it clear that, for Madrid, the right direction remains one that will see the Spanish flag flying over the Rock.

fields.headline: Wolf's last stand
fields.trailText: "I always wanted to reach something that was top of its field," Valerio Viccei once said, at a peak of glamour and infamy a lifetime away from the moment a terrified traffic cop became his nemesis. His death has shaken Italy.
fields.body:
It ended beneath a grey sky at a bend in a road he knew well. His prey would have to slow down and Valerio Viccei would pounce. A mask in one hand, a .357 Magnum in the other, an accomplice at his side, he parked in front of the farmhouse and waited.

But what turned the bend was a traffic patrol with two curious policemen. They were suspicious when they saw two strangers watching an isolated road. A call to base revealed the Lancia to be stolen. Enzo Baldini stepped from the patrol car and crunched over gravel towards Viccei.

He was 30ft away when the strangers raised their revolvers and fired. The first shot missed but three followed. The policeman crumpled as a bullet tore into his leg. He grasped his sub-machine gun as a figure raced towards him, pointing a revolver. Baldini loosed 15 rounds and the figure twirled and toppled. There was no scream; Viccei was dead before he hit the ground.

"I always wanted to reach something that was top of its field," he once said, at a peak of glamour and infamy a lifetime away from the moment a terrified traffic cop became his nemesis. His death has shaken Italy. Viccei was not supposed to be sitting armed in a stolen car waiting to ambush a bank security van. He was technically serving time but was allowed out during the day to work in a publisher's office.

The story behind Tuesday's shootout may write the epitaph for Italy's penal lenience, for Viccei, 45, was no ordinary gangster. It was he who masterminded the £40m Knightsbridge safe deposit robbery in July 1987, a spectacular heist dubbed the crime of the century. Security guard uniforms, metal cutting equipment, walkie-talkies and the owner's complicity enabled his gang to clear 114 boxes in under two hours. The victims were royalty, celebrities, millionaires and criminals. No shots were fired and no one was injured.

Viccei, a playboy and serial seducer, had come to London in search of a big life and he had found it. "I had a passion for weapons, beautiful women and fast cars," he said. When he was caught a few days later at the wheel of his Ferrari, traced by a fingerprint, he became a folk hero. The Italian Stallion, the Wolf, the gentleman thief - he exulted in all his nicknames.

In reality, he was an arrogant, vain thug. The son of a libel lawyer and boutique-owning mother from Ascoli Piceno, a town near his final shootout, he craved adulation and never hesitated to use violence. A thief by 16, he went to university in Rome to study philosophy in the 70s but fell under the influence of the neo-fascist terrorist leader Gianni Nardi. He joined the youth group Fronta Della Giuventu, daubing swastikas on public buildings before graduating to bombings. He racked up a suspected 54 robberies as politics became a distant motive.

Viccei wanted to be a star. He modelled himself on Al Pacino's Scarface, which he reputedly watched 58 times. He had a gold key-ring in the shape of a shotgun. The combination number for his £700 Louis Vuitton briefcase was 357, after the .357 Magnum. He moved to Britain in the 1980s and didn't allow broken English to inhibit chasing women or five armed robberies. Once captured, he played the master villain. Suave, athletic, sunglasses, permanent grin, jokes and boasts. Newspapers drooled over his cunning and charm.

Less attention was paid to dissenters from the myth. "I found him boring, showing off his Rolex watch and talking about his fast cars," said Justine Marr, secretary to the Parvez Latif, who owned the security deposit. A detective was equally dismissive. "He wanted to be known as the mastermind of the world's biggest robbery. He has an ego the size of the Old Bailey." It mattered not. A star was born. He told the judge: "Maybe I am a romantic lunatic but money was the last thing on my mind." Only £10m was ever recovered.

Sentenced to 22 years, he languished in Parkhurst on the Isle of Wight. He wore a T-shirt emblazoned with the slogan "I love Knightsbridge" around a clown's face with dollar signs for eyes. Then in November 1992, the Wolf bounded to freedom, although it was called extradition.

Under the Treaty of Strasbourg, he was transferred to a jail in Pescara on the Adriatic coast to finish his sentence. Declaring himself a reformed character, he tried to buy freedom by claiming to know the truth about Roberto Calvi, "God's banker", who was found hanging under Blackfriars bridge in London in 1982. It was a bluff, but it did not matter. Within three years, he was strolling the beachside cafes on his way to work at a publisher's office, visiting his flat and returning to jail at 10.30 every night.

He told Britain: "The legal system in Italy may look softer than yours but it is not. The only difference is that the rehabilitation programme does not discriminate like in your country." An autobiography seemed to complete the rehabilitation and Viccei slid into obscurity, effectively free until gaining parole in 2003. But in prison, he had befriended Antonio Malatesta, a member of the Puglia mafia, known as the Sacred United Heart, which specialises in kidnappings, armed hold-ups and smuggling. Malatesta was also free to roam while serving time because he had become a supergrass (a pentito) which is a fast-track to reduced sentences and priviliges.

Italian justice has made supergrasses and rapid releases for "model prisoners" central to its fight against organised crime. Since the first mafioso broke the code of omerta in 80s and started talking, thousands have followed. The mafia reeled but cracks are forming. Dozens of prison ers enjoying semi-liberty have been caught murdering and robbing. Pentitis are manipulating prosecutors to ensnare rival clans. Appeals courts are throwing out their testimony. The system is breaking down. Tuesday's shootout could be the last straw. Opposition politicians branded it a scandal. Only by fluke had justice prevailed. They want Viccei's epitaph to be the abolition of supergrasses.

Police yesterday said the pair were planning to either rob a bank security van or kidnap a scion from one of the area's three industrialist families. Malatesta tried to flee after they opened fire but was shot, wounded and caught. Viccei, hair flicked with grey, dressed in blue jeans and a green jacket, was said by police to have approached the prostrate Baldini with the intention of finishing him off when the hail of bullets spun him round; he landed on his back, blood seeping from his eyes, nose and mouth.

Reinforcements arrived and dozens of police stood above the corpse. None recognised him. The master robber was mistaken for an Albanian bandit. Only hours later was his identity discovered. By Viccei's own criterion, he died a failure: "The rule of this game is that if they don't catch you, you are a genius. But if they do, you are a miserable nobody."

fields.headline: Why so inert?
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe is a Commonwealth issue

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Over Zimbabwe the Commonwealth is once again being tried and found wanting. Since the 1991 Harare statement, members are bound to uphold fundamental human rights. It is not an entirely barren account.
fields.body:
Over Zimbabwe the Commonwealth is once again being tried and found wanting. Since the 1991 Harare statement, members are bound to uphold fundamental human rights. It is not an entirely barren account. Credit was claimed for the downfall of the Abacha regime in Nigeria. The secretariat's low-profile diplomacy may have limited conflict inside Bangladesh, Kenya and Guyana; after the military coup Pakistan was suspended without appeal last autumn.

But there, yesterday, was new secretary-general, New Zealander Don McKinnon, broker of peace in Bougainville, playing Mr Anodyne and speaking only, it seemed, after the secretary-general of the United Nations had used his moral authority to urge a return to dialogue. To Mr McKinnon were ascribed the words "both white people and African people". It is bad phrasing. Within southern Africa that formula looks backwards: if its whites are not also Africans, the region faces dark days.

Of course it confronts large residual issues of equity - some of them are being directly addressed in the UK's assistance on land transfer in Zimbabwe. But multiracialism and respect for the Harare declaration are intimately linked. Its rights include toleration of opposition and observance of due process of law. They do not exclude nationalisation; they must include protection against gang violence.

Yesterday Mr McKinnon said Commonwealth observers would only look to elections in Zimbabwe if invited by Harare and contestant parties. That confirms how the Commonwealth remains locked within a doctrine of state sovereignty, which finds unilateral condemnation of abuses hard to deliver and even harder to translate into remedial action. The trappings of colonialism are to be trampled on - except the inviolable integrity of the nation state. Last year in Durban, Commonwealth leaders could not agree on a new remit for the Commonwealth ministerial action group, its spearhead on rights: which explains its absence from Harare.

So the ball lands in South Africa's court. It is President Mbeki who is leading the review group supposed to be examining the Commonwealth's future, to report till next year. South Africa is also the lynchpin of the Southern African development community and, de facto, arbiter of Zimbabwe's economic destiny. The sooner Mr McKinnon gets from New Delhi to Pretoria, the better.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Drink-drive TV reporter sent to jail
fields.body:
Drink-drive TV reporter sent to jail

A former television presenter was yesterday jailed for two months after she was found slumped at the wheel of her car, more than five times the legal drink-drive limit.

Philippa Gant, 31, was spotted weaving in and out of traffic on the M6 in Cheshire on Christmas Eve last year by an HGV driver who informed the police, Mold crown court heard.

The former MUTV - Manchester United's cable channel - and Live TV journalist, of Tooting, south London, pleaded guilty to drink-driving and dangerous driving on the motorway near Sandbach services.

Recorder Quentin Querelle said her alcohol reading was so high it was "astonishing" she was still alive. The court was told how Gant had been "binge drinking" in the two weeks before the incident.

A breath test showed she had 179 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath - more than five times the legal limit of 35.

James Pickup, defending, said since the incident Gant had felt shock and remorse.

She had suffered panic attacks and depression since the death of her mother in 1992. Gant had developed an addiction to alcohol, beta blockers, tranquillisers and anti-depressants.

Gant was also disqualified from driving for three years.

Inquiry after RUC kill armed man

An inquiry was launched yesterday after police in Northern Ireland shot dead a man armed with a wrench, knife and hammer during a call to a domestic incident in Newtonabbey, Co Antrim.

An officer opened fire once as James Cornhill, 30, assaulted him. RUC personnel are routinely armed, and the watchdog will investigate whether the officer was too quick to resort to using his gun.

Police received a call at 2.15am from a distressed woman, believed to be Mr Cornhill's live-in girlfriend.

Brian McClelland, chief executive of the independent commission for police complaints, will oversee the investigation.

The area police chief, Superintendent Campbell Dixon, said two police officers were confronted by an armed man with several weapons when they arrived at the couple's cottage. He struck one of them on the head.
John Mullin

Telescope eavesdrops on universe

Just 40 years after the first search began for extraterrestrial intelligence, Californian scientists yesterday launched a new kind of telescope to eavesdrop on messages from life around other stars.

Seven satellite dishes will grow into hundreds of small aerials linked together in a 10,000sq metre array near an observatory run by the University of California, Berkeley.

The One Hectare telescope - unveiled by the university and the Seti Institute, a private organisation devoted to the search for life on other planets - is only a prototype: a bigger version will be built in 2002 and the $25m final array, at Hat Creek, 290 miles northeast of San Francisco, will be operational in 2005.

"This prototype launches the next generation of Seti research," said Dr Jill Tarter, research directorat the institute. The world astronomy community is paying close attention to this project."
Tim Radford

UK doubts on Europe increase

Public opposition to Britain adopting the euro and doubts about the benefits of European Union membership have gradually increased in the past year, an opinion poll showed yesterday.

The survey, carried out by the European commission, asked over 16,000 Europeans what they thought about the EU and found that just 25% of Britons would be happy to see the UK adopt the euro, while 59% strongly oppose such a move.

In the last commission survey, released last July, the comparable figures were 28% and 55%.

The new survey shows that overall support for Britain's membership of the EU has fallen to 29% from 31%.

Britons' poor foreign language skills were also highlighted, with just 19% of those polled saying they were capable of holding a conversation in a foreign language.

By contrast 97% of Luxembourgers and 91% of Dutch speakers claimed they could converse in another language.
Andrew Osborn

Model wins £93,000 for ruined looks

A former male model who claimed his looks were ruined by inappropriate cosmetic surgery yesterday won damages totalling £93,400 at the high court in London.

Mark Russell, 36, had sued Harley Medical Centre Ltd and the surgeon Alan Kingdon over liposuction he received at the Harley Street clinic in 1989.

After the ruling, Mr Russell, who had claimed £1.3m compensation, was "desperately unhappy". He said: "I would have made a success as a model and would have been rich."

Mr Justice Wright said Mr Russell, of Leeds, worked as a fashion model in Manchester between 1988 and 1990 when his career petered out.

He consulted the clinic when he was 26 after finding it difficult to keep his weight down in order to maintain the slim facial features thought desirable for success.

The defendants admitted failing to give proper advice, warning or counselling about the likely outcome of such treatment and that the surgery was wholly inappropriate and unnecessary.

But they denied it was negligently performed, that there was any discernable difference in Mr Russell's appearance and that his prospects were adversely affected.

The judge ruled that Mr Russell had established negligence and breach of contract on the part of both defendants, and said he was entitled to £5,000 for the pain and distress involved.

"This prototype launches the next generation of Seti research," said Dr Jill Tarter, research directorat the institute. The world astronomy community is paying close attention to this project." Tim Radford UK doubts on Europe increase Public opposition to Britain adopting the euro and doubts about the benefits of European Union membership have gradually increased in the past year, an opinion poll showed yesterday. The survey, carried out by the European commission, asked over 16,000 Europeans what they thought about the EU and found that just 25% of Britons would be happy to see the UK adopt the euro, while 59% strongly oppose such a move. In the last commission survey, released last July, the comparable figures were 28% and 55%. The new survey shows that overall support for Britain's membership of the EU has fallen to 29% from 31%. Britons' poor foreign language skills were also highlighted, with just 19% of those polled saying they were capable of holding a conversation in a foreign language. By contrast 97% of Luxembourgers and 91% of Dutch speakers claimed they could converse in another language. Andrew Osborn Model wins £93,000 for ruined looks A former male model who claimed his looks were ruined by inappropriate cosmetic surgery yesterday won damages totalling £93,400 at the high court in London. Mark Russell, 36, had sued Harley Medical Centre Ltd and the surgeon Alan Kingdon over liposuction he received at the Harley Street clinic in 1989. After the ruling, Mr Russell, who had claimed £1.3m compensation, was "desperately unhappy". He said: "I would have made a success as a model and would have been rich." Mr Justice Wright said Mr Russell, of Leeds, worked as a fashion model in Manchester between 1988 and 1990 when his career petered out. He consulted the clinic when he was 26 after finding it difficult to keep his weight down in order to maintain the slim facial features thought desirable for success. The defendants admitted failing to give proper advice, warning or counselling about the likely outcome of such treatment and that the surgery was wholly inappropriate and unnecessary. But they denied it was negligently performed, that there was any discernable difference in Mr Russell's appearance and that his prospects were adversely affected. The judge ruled that Mr Russell had established negligence and breach of contract on the part of both defendants, and said he was entitled to £5,000 for the pain and distress involved.

fields.headline: Good Friday two years on
fields.standfirst:
An uneasy Easter in Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Those who believe that April 1998 represented Northern Ireland's best chance in a generation should not give up hope just yet.
fields.body:
Tomorrow is the second anniversary of the Good Friday agreement. On that extraordinary day the people of Northern Ireland, through their elected representatives, thrashed out an age-old conflict during long days and sleepless nights until they had forged an accord they could all accept. Of course there were cracks that had to be papered over - but that is in the nature of a peace negotiation. By the end, standing in the Easter snow, men who had once been blood enemies stood together, having brokered a new way to live together. A month later the citizens of Northern Ireland endorsed the agreement with a 71% vote. Those were heady days indeed.

Now the mood is much bleaker. There are no glimpses of negotiating teams hugging in Castle Buildings, no Sinn Fein spokesmen emerging to declare "a beautiful day". Instead the Good Friday agreement is on life support, each one of the parties who ought to be propping it up feeling shaky. The Ulster Unionist leader is hemmed in by a party that has almost given up on him and on the peace process. At their last council meeting they voted to have nothing to do with self-rule - a cornerstone of the agreement - unless the IRA gave up its guns and London abandoned its plans to rename the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Against that backdrop, and surrounded by party bigwigs plotting against him - and a former UUP activist threatening to challenge him in his own parliamentary seat - there is little movement David Trimble can make. He could offer a concession - only to have his party refuse to budge. Most observers reckon the UUP leader can only go back to his party with a back-me-or-sack-me ultimatum once more. He cannot waste that one shot.

The republican side is looking slightly stronger, but it too has problems. At the last party conference, hardliner Gerry McGeough was elected to a senior post: that seemed like a warning to Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness that the fundamentalists have not gone away. The IRA ceasefire is safe, but the organisation is not about to hand over its arsenal any time soon.

One other player is also looking peaky. The secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, is now under constant attack from both sides. Unionists are angry at recent speeches which they have interpreted as pressure to drop their demand for IRA guns. Republicans still cannot forgive his February decision to collapse the executive. On one thing both sides agree: Mr Mandelson, they say, is too touchy, too concerned with his own image to cope in the gloves-off politics of Northern Ireland. Many interpreted Tony Blair's visit to Belfast this week as a sign that the prime minister felt he had to step in, to get a grip on the situation himself.

Despite all that, the optimists have not quite given up. They note that Mr Blair and the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern are due to meet again today, in London: that would not happen unless they had something to say to each other. Dublin has been working hard to get the IRA to build on the more constructive statement it gave to John de Chastelain's commission on decommissioning in February. There are reports of progress - persuading republicans not only to produce new language ("the war is over") but deeds, too. This might have been what Mr Blair wanted to float with Mr Trimble in their talks on Tuesday. Either way, all those who believe that April 1998 represented Northern Ireland's best chance in a generation should not give up hope just yet. Good Friday once brought good luck to Northern Ireland - it just might do it again.

fields.headline: Telephone riddle in Dando hunt
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Police investigating the murder of Jill Dando yesterday revealed that a man telephoned a woman with the same surname asking for details about the TV presenter months before she was killed.
fields.body:
Police investigating the murder of Jill Dando yesterday revealed that a man telephoned a woman with the same surname asking for details about the TV presenter months before she was killed.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, who is leading the inquiry, said the anonymous call lasted for 10 minutes.

The woman, whose initial is J, had no connection with Dando, but the man tried to extract as much information as he could.

"It was a very polite, respectful call," he said. "She described him as a white person with no foreign accent."

That call was made in December 1998 but calls to the utilities made by a man claiming to be Dando's brother were made in February 1999.

Dando, 37, was killed by a single bullet to the head outside her home in Fulham, west London almost a year ago

Last night, police used the BBC Crimewatch programme to appeal for information about a new suspect, and to ask Dando's killer to give himself up.

Mr Campbell said he thought the killer was waiting near Dando's home on the day of the murder for an opportunity to strike.

The programme focused on a man seen hanging around near Dando's home before she died and on two previous Mondays.

A dozen witnesses say they saw a man in his 30s to 40s, wearing a dark suit, who appeared agitated.

Mr Campbell said of the killer: "I cannot say whether his fixation is transferred to someone else. The killing of Miss Dando has not resolved anything.

"My view is that the interest this person has in Jill Dando would not have developed in the months before her murder. It will be somebody who has had this interest developing over some time."

He said he could not rule out a contract killing "but what I have described here is far more compelling".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Brazilian Dream | Nightwaves
fields.body:
Two half-hour programmes seems a paltry celebration of the 500th anniversary of a country as huge and culturally and geographically diverse as Brazil. Nevertheless The Brazilian Dream (Radio 4, 8.0pm), presented by Jan Rocha, goes right to the heart of two aspects of the country's national identity. In this first programme he visits Salvador, the capital of Bahia, where the largest black population outside Africa lives. Unlike the descendants of slaves elsewhere in the New World, the people of Bahia have not only hung on to their cultural identity, but racial tension seems remarkable by its absence. Rocha looks back at Brazil's black history, and wonders why the black experience in Brazil is so different from that of the United States.

Nightwaves (Radio 3, 9.30pm) gives its verdict on Ravelstein, Saul Bellow's new novel, and looks at Sunshine, a new film from Hungarian director Istvan Szabo which chronicles a Jewish-Hungarian family over 50 years.
