fields.headline: Who's kidding who?
fields.trailText: As the chair of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, I was disappointed at the letter (April 12) from Liv O'Hanlon criticising BAAF's chief executive, Felicity Collier, for "claiming" the Adoption Forum's idea of a national register to facilitate adoption.
fields.body:
As the chair of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, I was disappointed at the letter (April 12) from Liv O'Hanlon criticising BAAF's chief executive, Felicity Collier, for "claiming" the Adoption Forum's idea of a national register to facilitate adoption. It is a fact that BAAF set up a national computerised database of approved adopters, BAAFLink, in 1995, which provides details to social workers seeking families for particular children. It is used by many agencies, including nearly all voluntary adoption agencies, and BAAF has been seeking to encourage all local authorities to enter approved adopters on this register and has campaigned to this effect.

The "pompous flea in the ear" to which Liv O'Hanlon refers must refer to BAAF's criticism of the Adoption Forum's use of the term "register of adaptable children", which BAAF said "portrays children as a commodity, reflecting adult wishes rather than the needs of children". Terminology is of vital importance in protecting society's most vulnerable children, children without families, from exploitation.

Adoption is a hugely emotive issue and BAAF continues to hope that the Adoption Forum will work with us in promoting greater collaboration in the interests of children.
Marjorie Cooper
The Children's Society

 Thank you Dr Penelope Leach (Letters, April 13). Is Blair a goat? The self-worth of children was denigrated when they became kids.
Marjorie Cooper
Wetherby, W Yorks

fields.headline: Drought steals lives and livelihoods
fields.standfirst:
Nomads driven into the towns as plains turn into dustbowl
Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Shugri Farah cradles and rocks her six-month-old son Kayt, brushing away the flies that buzz incessantly around them. She does what little she can to help him, but what he really needs is food, and that she cannot give.
fields.body:
Shugri Farah cradles and rocks her six-month-old son Kayt, brushing away the flies that buzz incessantly around them. She does what little she can to help him, but what he really needs is food, and that she cannot give.

She looks far from healthy herself, but unlike little Kayt she has more than just skin on her bones and more than the last flicker of life in her eyes.

Shugri Farah lost a daughter to starvation last month as three years of consecutive drought began to take its toll on the people of south-eastern Ethiopia. Now she is preparing herself for the death of her son.

An estimated 70% of the 3.5m people living in the region are nomadic. Even at the best of times they live on the very edge. They build up their herds of livestock during the good times, and trek this barren and seemingly inhospitable land in search of pasture and water.

They have lived like this for centuries and have adapted to the harshness of their environment.

Their herds - composed of sheep, goats camels and, increasingly cattle, which bring in the most profit but are less drought-resistant - enable them to cope when the rains fail.

But after three years without rain their animals have died or been sold to buy food. With their assets gone, many of them are migrating to the area's towns, their survival dependent on the goodwill of the outside world.

In Armale, 25 miles north of Gode, the waterholes on the edge of the village have been dry for longer than 33-year-old Ahmed Aideed can remember. "It is bad here," he said. "Very bad."

His wife Halima gave birth to twins two months ago but stopped lactating a week ago. The little water that her husband is able to salvage from the dirty puddles that remain is the twin's only source of sustenance.

This is a pattern repeated throughout the region as reports come in from one village after another of desperate people subsisting on the last of their resources and in urgent need of help.

Aid agencies plan to set up supplementary feeding centres right across the area but the inhabitants of villages like Armale, which is not served by the main road, fear that they will be forgotten by the relief effort.

"Everything is lost. We have nothing left and if God doesn't help us then we will die," said Mr Aideed.

These fears are further compounded by a deep concern that chronic insecurity in the region will further delay the prompt delivery of emergency aid.

Rebel fighters

The insecurity is mainly caused by the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF), which is fighting a secessionist campaign against the government. The group is not a serious threat to the state but it is capable of discriminatory acts of banditry designed to keep its fighters alive and the campaign going.

The presence of armed ONLF fighters and Somali bandits competing for the same resources as the hungry is of great concern to the international aid agencies.

There have been 17 serious incidents involving aid agencies operating in the region since last August. Bandits have ambushed aid convoys, drivers have been killed and aid workers kidnapped.

One international aid worker, who asked not to be identified, said that the Ethiopian government was opposed to a large international aid presence in the area, despite the crisis.

"They are very worried that if there are any serious incidents involving foreign aid workers then the agencies would withdraw en masse, which could jeopardise the whole relief effort."

"Due to insecurity United Nations staff members are not allowed to stay more than a few hours on the ground and cannot travel overland from one village to the next," said Roberta Rossi, a spokeswoman for the World Food Programme (WFP).

"This means we depend on local aid organisations and have very little first- hand information."

WFP say that there is enough relief food in the pipeline to meet the needs of the affected areas until the end of July, but the long term prognosis for the people of the Ogaden and other drought stricken areas of the country depends on how quickly the newly pledged aid gets into the country.

WFP, in conjunction with the Ethiopian government, is currently conducting a new assessment of the Ogaden to estab lish how many people are at risk and it expects the number to be even higher than the previous estimate of 1.2m people.

The future for Ethiopians like Ahmed Aideed, his wife and their newborn twins, and millions of other people in the country, now lies with the international relief effort, and the speed with which the relief organisations can act on their promises.

fields.headline: A bogus argument
fields.trailText: Paul Barber (Letters, April 19) believes he does not become a bogus job seeker just because his application is rejected. But that presumes he has not misrepresented himself.
fields.body:
Paul Barber (Letters, April 19) believes he does not become a bogus job seeker just because his application is rejected. But that presumes he has not misrepresented himself. If he applied for a job as a graphic designer when he was, in fact, an electrician, then he would be a bogus graphic designer. To qualify as a genuine asylum seeker you must have a well-founded fear of persecution. Those who make unsubstantiated claims are guilty of masquerading. They are bogus asylum seekers.
Alistair McConnachie
Glasgow

 The BNP's statement for its London mayoral candidate makes liberal use of the Tory's description of asylum seekers as "bogus". No mention of detention camps yet though. Well done, Mr Hague, "clear blue water" between the Tories and the BNP.
Saul Walker
London
saul.walker@nat.org.uk

 Tony Blair leads a Labour party which presented a bogus platform at the last election. Fortunately they have to apply again and their application can then be rejected.
Paul Knutson
Northwood, Middx
paul@knutson.demon.co.uk

 Would supporters of women who wish to breastfeed in Commons' committees (MPs to challenge breastfeeding ban, April 15 and Oona King MP's letter, April 18) want a surgeon to be breastfeeding while she was carrying out an operation? Or an airline pilot in the middle of a flight? Why then permit MPs, whose work affects the lives of so many more people, to have their concentration divided?
Catriona Graham
Edinburgh

 I was interested to read "dubber" meant a lady of ill repute (Letters, April 14). After 43 years of marriage, I am seriously considering reverting to my maiden name.
Monica Dubber
Earley, Berks

fields.headline: I'll keep the tube public
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone writes: I was astonished to read that I have changed my position on the question of tube privatisation (Livingstone retreat on key pledges, April 18). My manifesto makes clear: "We should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grant."
fields.body:
I was astonished to read that I have changed my position on the question of tube privatisation (Livingstone retreat on key pledges, April 18). My manifesto makes clear: "We should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grant." That is, on grounds of safety and cost, I am totally opposed to the government's public private partnership plan to split up and partially privatise the tube and will do everything possible to prevent it being implemented.

The report on the Southall rail crash concluded that the fragmentation caused by privatisation had contributed to the undermining of safety systems. My manifesto makes clear that no conflict of interests should be allowed to jeopardise tube safety.

The second problem is that under PPP tube passengers will be expected to shoulder additional costs - the dividends of the PPP companies and the higher costs involved in borrowing by private companies. This would result in higher fares, when those of London Underground are already among the highest in the world.

My commitment to keeping the tube as a unified service in the public sector is therefore absolutely unequivocal. Furthermore, if devolution is to have real content, the decision on this, and similar matters, must be taken by those who will have to live with the consequences - the people of London. That is why I welcomed Tony Blair's indication that the government might have to reconsider its plans if London elected a mayor clearly opposing them.
Ken Livingstone MP

 I served for 12 years as the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority's financial adviser and designed the financing programme still in place today (Mind the gap, April 19). Jean Shaoul's recognition that there will always be a "funding gap" in a properly structured mass transit system, and that in London this means that government will in effect use tax money to fund the profits of the "private" side of the PPP is an important contribution.

In structuring its financing programme, New York recognised that the principal beneficiaries of the system should bear the brunt of the financial burden, not Californians or Alaskans. Thus commuters pay roughly half, the other half comes from carefully targeted taxes imposed on the other beneficiaries: businesses and property owners in the region served by the system. Thus, for example, New York businesses pay taxes on their rent payments and on telephone calls and the proceeds flow directly to the subway.
Robert A Gerard
London
rag@gng.co.uk

 Bonds wouldn't be a panacea because of the tube's need for subsidies. But something like the Livingstone bonds will end up being a vital element in the tube's future. London

My manifesto makes clear that no conflict of interests should be allowed to jeopardise tube safety. fields.headline: Vouching for Von Trapp
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has misunderstood Oxfam's concerns about the asylum-seeker voucher scheme (Straw tells 3,000 Kosovans to leave, April 18). Oxfam is fully aware each pack of vouchers has different denominations. However, the mix is determined by government and leaves the asylum seeker with a money management problem no other shopper has.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has misunderstood Oxfam's concerns about the asylum-seeker voucher scheme (Straw tells 3,000 Kosovans to leave, April 18). Oxfam is fully aware each pack of vouchers has different denominations. However, the mix is determined by government and leaves the asylum seeker with a money management problem no other shopper has. The mix of a small amount of cash plus £5, £1 and 50p vouchers still means that people shopping with vouchers risk paying more for their shopping.

Most people who pop round to the corner shop for milk with only 50p in their pocket expect to get change. People surviving on vouchers already get less than 70% of normal benefit levels. It is appalling to think that even a small part of their meagre benefits can be pocketed by retailers just because they are unable to juggle the vouchers to meet the exact cost.
Michael Vincent
Oxfam

 "Senior Tory sources" justify their prejudices by using the Von Trapp family to illustrate the virtue of asylum seekers settling in the first country reached (Diary, April 19). William Hague may have seen the film, but he really should read the book. The Von Trapp family actually fled to the US. They settled there and, by all accounts, did very well whilst enriching the cultural base of their chosen country. What next? Quotes from Oklahoma in order to illustrate Tory agricultural policy?
Peter Thornton
Kendal, Cumbria

fields.headline: Bad maxim
fields.trailText: Trefor Lloyd and the Men's Health Forum did not blame lad magazines for the rise in male suicides ('Laddish ideal' helps drive men to suicide, April 19). The magazine for which I work takes suicide seriously and deals with it appropriately.
fields.body:
Trefor Lloyd and the Men's Health Forum did not blame lad magazines for the rise in male suicides ('Laddish ideal' helps drive men to suicide, April 19). The magazine for which I work takes suicide seriously and deals with it appropriately. Suicide is a social problem, not one that can be laid at the door of magazines. Particularly, it is a class issue reflecting the increasing gap between rich and poor in this country.

Men in social class five commit suicide nearly four times as often as those in classes one and two - a greater disparity than for any terminal disease. That's the real story and a new one. I'm surprised at the Guardian peddling that old politician's excuse "blame the media".
Jim Pollard
Health editor, Maxim
Jimandbela@aol.com

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chocolate risk to dogs
fields.body:
Chocolate risk to dogs

Chocolate contains a toxic chemical harmless to humans but potentially fatal for dogs, the National Canine Defence League said yesterday.

Theobromine causes vomiting and convulsions in dogs and can kill if eaten in sufficient doses, the charity said.

75th wedding celebration

Reg Attwater, 99, and his wife Win, 94, of Smallfield, Surrey, have received an entry in the Guinness Book of Records for being married for 75 years.

Drug case child dies

The three-year-old girl suffering from a suspected methadone overdose has died, police said yesterday. Natalia Mujahid, from Blackburn, Lancashire, lost her fight for life after she and her baby brother Darnish were taken to hospital.

Six years for counterfeiter

A printer who made hundreds of thousands of pounds of fake £5 notes was at Manchester crown court yesterday sentenced to six years in prison.

Anthony Flynn, 54, of Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester, was found guilty in February on four charges.

Weighing their words

The Publishers Book Clearance company in Edinburgh has taken to selling stock by weight. Customers can buy reading matter for £1.69 per lb.

fields.headline: Royal rumours
fields.standfirst: DNA tests get to the heart of a 200-year-old mystery
fields.trailText: Genetic experts claimed yesterday that they had solved a 205-year-old mystery surrounding the fate of the boy-king Louis XVII, by proving that he died in prison in 1795, aged 10.
fields.body:
Genetic experts claimed yesterday that they had solved a 205-year-old mystery surrounding the fate of the boy-king Louis XVII, by proving that he died in prison in 1795, aged 10.

The results of DNA tests on a heart (right, in its crystal vase container) presumed to be his contradict the myth that the boy - the son of Louis XVI and Queen Marie-Antoinette - did not die of TB but was smuggled out of prison after his parents were guillotined, and that another child's body was placed in his bed.

It is claimed that he then founded a new dynasty before dying in Holland in 1845. The legend has led to claims by at least 100 pretenders to the Bourbon regal inheritance.

Thousands of articles and 600 books have kept the myth alive, but the geneticists, Jean-Jacques Cassiman and Bernd Brinkmann, said that DNA from the heart matched samples from locks of hair cut from Marie-Antoinette.

Although royal pretenders believe that the heart, which resembles a piece of dark stone, had been mishandled over the years and could not provide proof, the genetic evidence appeared to be conclusive.

The historian Philippe Delorme, who launched the affair, said science had confirmed the verdict of history, and there was no doubt that it was the boy-king who died in 1795.

"There is no longer an enigma around Louis XVII."

The results of earlier examinations had already persuaded Prof Cassiman, from Louvain University in Belgium, and Prof Brinkmann, from Münster University in Germany, that the most likely living pretender, Charles de Bourbon, Duke of Normandy, was not related to the royal family.

Among the many previous investigators was the late French president François Mitterrand, who went to Germany and Holland in a failed attempt to disprove the story that the royalist doctor who carried out a post-mortem examination on the boy in 1795 saved the heart when the rest of the body was thrown into a common grave.

The heart, which the doctor pickled, was later stolen by a medical student, and when it was eventually recovered it was rejected by the Bourbon family as a fake. It was preserved by the Spanish Bourbon line before being transferred to the royal crypt in Saint-Denis, a suburb of Paris, in 1975.

The latest scientific findings are unlikely to quash counter-claims.

Another historian, Philippe Boiry, said that it was impossible to draw conclusions from a heart that "had lived through a lot after being lost, stolen, found and then taken from its reliquary after being kept in alcohol for years".

webTitle: Holiday traffic jams whatever the weather

fields.headline: Holiday traffic jams whatever the weather
fields.trailText: Do not bother with a car journey over Easter unless you want to be stuck in traffic during Britain's biggest bank holiday getaway.
fields.body:
Do not bother with a car journey over Easter unless you want to be stuck in traffic during Britain's biggest bank holiday getaway.

Traffic will be a problem if the weather is fine or foul, according to AA Roadwatch. If it is sunny, roads to the coast and countryside will be choked with traffic, but if it is raining, motorists will head to shopping malls instead.

Problems have been exacerbated by the combination of a very late Easter break and the May bank holiday the following week which means many people have extended their holidays.

Among the most congested motorways will be the M25 near Heathrow, the A40 and M4 heading out of London and the M6 around Birmingham.

Traffic will also be brought to a standstill on the M1 in Hertfordshire and on main routes to the Metro centre, Gateshead, and the Meadowhall centre in Sheffield.

Michael Johnson, of AA Roadwatch, said: "The problem is there is no way around this traffic unless you take the very bold step of breaking with tradition and staying at home."

Many roadworks have been suspended by the highways agency to avoid further snarl-ups on the motorways.

A spokesman for Trafficmaster, a traffic information company, said it expected holiday routes to become busy from 1pm today, particularly the M5 from the west midlands, the A31 towards the Hampshire and Dorset coast, routes towards the west country, the A55 along the north Wales coast and around the M55 junction with the M6 north of Preston.

There will also be a build-up of traffic on May 1 as holiday-makers return.

fields.headline: Joyous mob greets freed Lebanese
fields.trailText: Thirteen Lebanese detainees released by Israel headed home yesterday after Red Cross officials escorted them out of the Israeli occupation zone in south Lebanon.
fields.body:
Thirteen Lebanese detainees released by Israel headed home yesterday after Red Cross officials escorted them out of the Israeli occupation zone in south Lebanon.

Hundreds of joyful relatives and villagers mobbed the bus carrying the men into the frontline village of Kfar Tibnit, 50 miles south-east of Beirut, which was decked out with flags and welcoming banners.

The release came an hour after the Israeli high court rejected a last-minute petition from the relatives of a missing Israeli airman to keep the Lebanese as bargaining counters for a possible swap.

The men, held without trial for more than a decade, were turned over by prison officials to the Israeli army, which handed them on to the Red Cross over at the border town of Metulla.

The army, fearing possible artillery fire from the zone, kept relatives well clear of the checkpoint, since villagers on the fringes of the occupied area are often caught in the crossfire.

Before their arrival, locals festooned the streets of Kfar Tibnit with Lebanese flags and banners, as excited and anxious relatives of the detainees' milled about clutching pictures and bouquets.

Although an Israeli court ruling last week made it illegal for Israel to hold prisoners for barter, the release had been delayed twice and could have been postponed again if the court had approved the petition by the family of the missing Israeli airman Ron Arad.

Despite the uncertainty, local politicians and officials held court in the village, while members of Hizbullah, whose guerrillas are fighting Israel's occupation of the south, bussed scores of supporters to the site to set up speakers broadcasting patriotic anthems.

"I've been waiting to hug him for 13 years. I can't imagine it," said Zeinab Yassin, whose brother Mohammed was among those released. "I just can't put my feelings into words."

Lebanese human rights groups say the detainees were taken during clashes with Israeli troops and their militia allies, the South Lebanon Army, or snatched from their homes in the occupied zone.

"He's the hero of heroes and I am so proud of him," said Amal, the fiancee of detainee Ahmed Taleb. "Isn't it enough that he fought against the enemy and is now coming home?"

But not all who gathered at Kfar Tibnit were joyful. Holding a picture of her missing son, Nasrah Shehadi said she was waiting for the detainees to ask them if they had seen him. "He's been gone for 10 years. Each time they bring over bodies, he's not among them, so I can only hope he is still alive."
Reuters

webTitle: MPs press Blair on misery of third world schools

fields.headline: MPs press Blair on misery of third world schools
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was presented yesterday with a stark picture of schooling in Africa, where children write with twigs in the dust for want of a pencil or an exercise book.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was presented yesterday with a stark picture of schooling in Africa, where children write with twigs in the dust for want of a pencil or an exercise book.

The backbench MP Oona King and MEP Glenys Kinnock told the prime minister about their recent visit to Zambia, where they saw children being taught under the trees because schools lack classrooms. They asked Mr Blair to put the crisis in third world schools at the top of the international agenda.

Ms Kinnock said that she had been shocked by the level of deprivation she had seen. "They were desperate even for chalk," she said. "We visited one school where we saw a teacher sitting outside on the ground and the pupils forming their letters in the dust because there were no blackboards."

Zambian schools have some of the worst facilities in sub-Saharan Africa. But the pupils who make it to class are the lucky ones - a third of all school-age children are unable to attend because they cannot afford the fees.

Teachers go unpaid for months and many cannot afford to support their families. Ms Kinnock said she asked one little boy what he wanted most for his school. "He told me he wanted his teacher not to be hungry."

Mr Blair disappointed third world education campaigners recently by deciding not to attend the world education forum, which starts in Dakar, Senegal, next week.

Aid agencies are worried that without high-profile figures like Mr Blair, Dakar may prove to be another worthy talking shop where international pledges on education are reaffirmed without any commitment to additional resources.

A campaign led by Oxfam is calling on the conference to adopt an $8bn (£5.1bn) programme aimed at getting the 125m children who are out of school in the third world into the classroom.

"The governments, UN agencies and World Bank officials attending the forum have all identified education as the key to human development," an Oxfam official said.

"All of them have made high-sounding pronouncements on the need for a renewed effort to achieve education for all.

"Yet they have collectively failed to display the vision and commitment needed to translate good principles into practice."

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Matt Lucas, comedian
fields.trailText: Matt Lucas, comedian.
fields.body:
I was on the London Underground with a friend about seven years ago when that fine actress Anna Wing, then known to EastEnders viewers as the battleaxe Lou Beale, sat down next to me. In an immaculate lilac coat, with matching shoes and handbag, she chatted away to a young gentleman who had helped her onto the train in the poshest voice I have ever heard.

Unlike her TV character she was full of good cheer and amazing grace as she endured - and politely pretended not to notice - the barely hidden tears of mirth that swam down our cheeks. We shook and we sobbed at the very sight of her. I can only imagine this uncontrolled outburst was provoked by the wild discrepancy between her TV character and her real-life persona, a nervous response to the deep shock of being presented with something completely familiar out of its context.

I'll never forget this incident, for two reasons. Firstly because it was an utterly joyous moment in my life, when, despite the embarrassment I clearly should have felt, and doubtless caused poor Miss Wing, I became hysterical. You could have arrested me there and then for making a public nuisance of myself and I would have laughed all the way to the cells. Secondly, this incident stays in my mind because I am now on the receiving end of it myself several bloody times a day! The fact that (like that distinguished actress, who had ended her stint on Britain's most popular show some years before) we haven't filmed an episode of Shooting Stars for nearly three years, is hardly relevant. I signed the covenant. I belong to you now and your vain half-hearted attempts to hide your guffaws at the sight of the baby drummer, once resplendent in romper, now cowering in cords, fool no-one. You laugh in my face as I, an artist, sit there, in silence, cursing this bastard B-list fame. Karma.

fields.headline: Private eyes on the state
fields.trailText: That government efforts to privatise state education services may be moving on apace in Bradford (Education body to go private, April 17) should not surprise anyone.
fields.body:
That government efforts to privatise state education services may be moving on apace in Bradford (Education body to go private, April 17) should not surprise anyone. The structures are in place to gradually infiltrate business into education, health and local government services. This side of the election, there will be no further legislative moves. After the election there will be a series of cases where the government will have to step in to save recipients of these services from "the forces of conservatism". Everyone can be encouraged to be against bureaucrats, who only seem work in the public sector. In the private sector, guys and girls in suits doing identical jobs, at £10k more pay, are deemed to be contributing to the dynamism of the business.

The experience of the US demonstrates that those aspects of these services that generate no profit are left in the public arena. There is a fortune to be made in mature economies from the dismantling of state provision. There will be no competition and best value will have no meaning when there is no competition. Last month's wheeze of "front line first" in centrally funding hospitals, and schools and the constant dictation of ends without providing the means will propel public opinion to the conclusion that a radical change is called for.

Nick Ridley couldn't see the point of councils meeting more than twice a year: once to dish out the contracts and once to monitor their provision. Many in the civil service agree. The higher reaches of the parliamentry Labour party are just as keen. Managerialism is in the air. Who could put up a sensible argument in favour of messy old democracy and be taken seriously?

We also propose strengthening the health select committee to make sure it would be able to take advantage of the more open governance of the NHS.

webTitle: Will paper be forced to fold?

fields.headline: Will paper be forced to fold?
fields.standfirst:
Sarah Kidner looks at electronic alternatives to the printed page that could eventually provide 
a newspaper that rewrites itself every day
fields.trailText: Sarah Kidner looks at electronic alternatives to the printed page that could eventually provide a newspaper that rewrites itself every day
fields.body:
We are on the brink of the biggest information revolution for 5,000 years with a social and technological impact that will quite literally re-write the book. What is this great invention that will grip the nation? It is the electronic or e-book.

The technology was thrown into the limelight recently when horror writer, Stephen King, decided to publish his latest novella, Riding the Bullet, exclusively on the internet, a decision that sent shock waves through the $70bn (£44.6bn) publishing industry. Within the first 24 hours of the promotion Barnes and Noble received more than 200,000 requests for the novella. That's the equivalent of selling 2.5 books per second. Check out the Barnes and Noble library on the internet at www.bn.com and you will find a whole selection of them. On-screen there's little to distinguish them from the printed word but they are a lot harder to read on a computer display or liquid crystal display (LCD), hence King published a novella rather than a full-blown novel.

BN has provided software designed to make the e-books easier to read: download the imaginatively titled e-book reader and the Glassbook reader from the site and install them for what the company claims is a paper-like display.

You can also purchase a Rocket Book device to carry the e-books around. Software mogul, Bill Gates, has already recognised the potential of the technology and Microsoft's researchers have produced similar software designed to give a paper-like quality to text on an electronic screen, called ClearType font-enhancing technology.

The software was designed following a study of how letters and words appear on the printed page and attempts to recreate those images on-screen. "It fixes the problem of word recognition," says Scottish born Bill Hill, one of the co-inventors of ClearType, who hit upon the idea while animal tracking in America. "Animal tracking is a bit like reading. If you recognise the pattern it's easy. But if it isn't clear enough or sharp enough we have to work it out," he says.

Hill believes that the impact of ClearType and technology like it will have as dramatic a social impact as the dawn of the first printing press. "The move towards screen readable information will change society just as much as the invention of the printing press but it will do it in five years rather than 500," he says.

But even Hill will admit that there's a lot more to be done before we'll want to read an entire novel on-screen. "The book is a most complex technology. It is the most mature information interface that we have and in order to understand how it works we have to do a lot more."

Others agree that the Rocket Book/ClearType approach is primitive. "Electronic books that you can buy right now such as the Rocket Book are still, from a technological point of view, using existing technology. It is basically just a laptop computer with a standard LCD display," says Pierre Wiltzius, technical manager for Lucent/Bell Labs.

Is there an alternative? Imagine a substance that looks and feels like paper, with the qualities of a computer screen, allows you to download electronic content but which you can roll-up and put in your pocket. If you think it sounds like science fiction, think again - Xerox, the document company, believes it has come up with exactly that. What's more it won't even require a separate power source while you read it.

The basis of this e-paper already exists in the company's Palo Alto Research Centre (Parc), ironically, the same outfit that brought us the laser printer, in the form of an electronic pulp called Gyricon. Gyricon is basically a thin sheet of plastic made up of millions of tiny beads, a bit like the toner particles found in traditional printers.

The beads are double-sided, one black and one white. Each fits loosely into its own oil-filled cavity and still has the freedom to rotate. Electricity passed through the Gyricon causes the beads to rotate, showing either their black or white side in a series of patterns that form words and/or pictures.

Only a small charge is needed to "print" on the paper. The researchers at Parc claim that it is possible to create a printer-type device to do the trick that would be small enough to fit into your wallet or purse. The company even has plans to weave further magic with its own design for an electronic "wand", a tube that acts as a printer, copier, fax and scanner in one.

Other solutions are on the horizon too from Lucent/Bell Labs. The company's goal is to replace the expensive silicon-based technology used in the Rocket Book with a plastic that it says will look and feel like paper.

"Our goal is to make a paper-like film that is as flexible and easy to read as ink on paper," says Wiltzius. He also hopes his plastic will be 100 times cheaper than the silicon chip based readers. Lucent is not stopping with electronic paper. The company hopes its paper-like film will work with a separate technological development, called E-Ink, invented by an American start-up of the same name. Electronic Ink is a coloured liquid made up of millions of tiny spheres called microcapsules.

Each microcapsule has a clear outer surface and is filled with a blue dye and microscopic chips of white pigment which carry a positive charge. The ink is sandwiched between two transparent conductive sheets and the white pigment is made to rise or fall by electronic charges, creating blue or white dots which can be formed into letters and pictures. To see a graphic representation of this technology, visit www.electronic-ink.com/technology/flash.htm.

Together the companies believe they have produced a truly paper-like solution that will overcome reader's previous cynicism about electronic replacements for paper. "The reality is that if people had wanted to read novels on screen they could have done it 10 years ago," says Russ Wilcox, vice president and general manager of E-Ink.

While the partners are not quite ready to release tabloid-sized versions of the e-paper, billboard-sized Immedia boards based on E-Ink's technology have been on trial in high-street shops for some time. They could be on widespread display later this year.

When will you be leafing through your electronic Guardian? The answer could be sooner than you think. Xerox claims it has already had a lot of interest from the newspaper publishing community. "There's been a large amount of interest from the newspaper publishing companies to find alternative methods of publishing. In the case of paper there's a lot of cost in print and distribution," says Nick Sheridon, developer of Gyricon.

Microsoft has started to address the wider issues of copyright protection and is planning a range of products that will offer "digital rights management to protect internet property," according to Hill. A 5,000-year-old technology will not be replaced overnight, but an electronic alternative is just around the corner. As Xerox's Sheridon says: "This is something that is going to happen, and if the right people get involved it could happen within three years."

Pick up your pen and scribble a few lines across the internet
Let's say you're leafing through the Sunday magazine and you spot an advert selling flowers. Within the advert is a space for you to write a special message to your loved one, a space for the address - where to send the flowers - and the usual boxes for your credit card details. No need to worry about cutting out the coupon, then finding envelopes or stamps. Simply fill in the details using an Anoto pen and the flowers are on their way.

It's just one of the possible applications for the invention of the newly formed Anoto company, which is aiming to breathe fresh life into one of the world's oldest communications mediums - the pen and ink.

For the application form to work as described, it would have to be printed on Anoto's digital paper. This is not much different to traditional paper except that it has a series of small dots imprinted in the page, which gives the paper a slightly off-white appearance.

These dots are arranged in a proprietary pattern and set out in a grid. The grid expresses a set of X and Y co-ordinates, commands or services: in this case, the command would be 'send flowers to'. Anoto claims these commands can be accurate to within a third of a millimetre.

A tiny digital camera stored within the tip of the pen records the letters and words that you form using the Anoto pen, for example the message you want sent with the flowers. These images are processed within the pen using a dedicated image processor.

The next step is to transfer these images, your flower order, to the outside world. This is done using a transceiver and an internet phone both equipped with the Bluetooth wireless technology. Once the information has been transferred to the phone it is sent out to Anoto's gateway to the internet then on to the flower supplier.

They'll receive an exact copy of your order straight to their PC Another possibility through the company's partnership with Time Manager is that if you write in your digital paper-based diary, the appointment could be automatically transferred through your phone, and it would appear in your electronic diary at work. "This is technology which I hope will change the world," says Christer Fahraeus, founder member of Anoto.

Tomorrow's world could come sooner than you think: the company already has working prototypes of the technology, and is planning to launch the paper and pen next year. It will cost slightly more than your average Biro with an expected price tag of around $100.

Or if you're lucky, you could get one free with your Ericsson phone, since the mobile phone giant owns an 18% stake in Anoto.

fields.headline: He's a big Boy now
fields.standfirst: Greg Howson sees an old low-tech device get a new lease of life
fields.trailText: Greg Howson sees an old low-tech device get a new lease of life
fields.body:
It is built around the same processor as the ZX Spectrum and can display only 56 colours, but the Nintendo Game Boy is outselling the market-leading Sony PlayStation. The handheld console has sold more than 6 million units in its 10-year life and boasts an upcoming release list littered with big names such as Metal Gear Solid, Tomb Raider and Rainbow Six.

Despite its weedy sound effects and basic visuals the Game Boy has always boasted some excellent software. Up until recently the puzzle game Tetris was synonymous with the console. Its deceptive simplicity and addictive gameplay helped shift the vast majority of original machines but a recent upgrade to colour has lead to more ambitious software.

Cameron Sheppard, MD of Rainbow Six developers Crawfish, is impressed with what it can do. "It's an incredible machine; even though it's 10 years old it constantly amazes us how much it can do, which drives us to push it into doing stuff we never thought possible - in Rainbow Six, for instance, we've included motion capture."

The biggest driver of hardware sales has been the Pokemon phenomenon. This collect-'n'-nurture game has bolstered the playground presence especially as two machines are needed in order to trade or battle the little monsters. Veteran developer Jon Hare, now based at Codemasters, agrees: "It is the perfect marketing gimmick for that age group, a lesson that Nintendo have long learned about children and character-based titles."

It's not just Pokmon that has helped to boost sales. Retro conversions of old games are helping mine a rich seam of gaming nostalgia. Hare is keen. "The Game Boy Color offers a brilliant conversion platform for old 16-bit titles, something which is particularly good news for all our old Sensible Software hits that were originally mainly written on the Amiga. It is amazing to see Cannon Fodder on the Game Boy; it looks almost identical to the Amiga version."

Big name franchises have appeared and the coming months will see titles like Tomb Raider and Metal Gear Solid coming over to the system. Although bearing little graphical comparison to their PlayStation versions, both titles are similar to play. MGS in particular offers a stealthy, sneaky gameplay style not seen before on the handheld. It also includes a multiplayer option - a growing area thanks to the Pokmon-inspired sales of the link cable.

The reasons for the ageing console's continued success are varied. Sheppard feels it appeals to adults as well as children. "It's easy to mistake the Game Boy for a kid's toy but take a look around and you'll see adults of all ages taking it to work, on holiday and playing with it at home. Its sheer ease of use and portability are key factors." He points to the large variety of titles available as evidence of a wider appeal. Hare likes the fact that you can "play Game Boys on your own" and "in a secret and out of the way place, as opposed to having to be by the telly where your Mum can catch you and tell you to go and finish your homework." Cheaper development costs also help. Despite the restrictions of cart production, the Game Boy can be a profitable place for developers.

Hare agrees. "When you only need two programmers and one graphic artist it's got to be easier than the teams of 50+ that we are used to working with these days."

Next year should see the release of the 16bit Game Boy Advance (Nintendo release dates are frustratingly vague). This successor to the Game Boy will be backwards compatible, allowing access to all the current titles, though, perhaps more interestingly, there is the possibility of online gaming and email through a mobile connection. It seems that the Game Boy could finally be growing up.

fields.headline: Show me the naked truth
fields.standfirst: Ukrainian photographer Boris Mikhailov pays his homeless subjects a month's pension to strip off and pose.  Justina Hart  reports
fields.trailText: Ukrainian photographer Boris Mikhailov pays his homeless subjects a month's pension to strip off and pose. Justina Hart reports.
fields.body:
Crouching on the floor of the Photographers' Gallery in central London are a tousled man in his 60s and a younger woman with glasses and blonde hair tied in a ponytail. The Ukrainian photographer Boris Mikhailov and his second wife, Vita, are poring over a giant, photographic poster of a homeless man with a diseased penis.

"Boris is very nervous about the show. He's in the middle of an argument with his wife about where the pictures should go - he wanted to hang all his own work," explains the curator, Jeremy Millar, the day before the show opens. In other words, our interview is off. Mikhailov, with his deep, dancing eyes, gets up to shake my hand and then disappears. Vita was to have acted as translator.

There is something incongruous about the way this ageing man in his cheap clothes has been given free rein to scrabble on the floor of a smart, paint-fresh gallery. Mikhailov, who for 30 years has explored the role of the individual within the ideology of the state (communist and now capitalist), seems dwarfed by fashionable London. Just as the homeless subjects of his 1999 Case History series - made to reveal the nakedness of their neglected and deformed bodies - are lost in the brutal new world that is capitalism in the former USSR.

In Case Study, homeless people drag away animal carcasses to chew; children sniff glue; sexual or physical abuse and death are omnipresent. The red of wounds leaks into snow before the vulgar red backdrop of Coca-Cola ads, which have replaced the red communist slogans and banners of Mikhailov's earlier work.

Mikhailov had intended to take pictures of the wealthy entrepreneurs of the post-communist era, but when he witnessed the emergence of a parallel, newly impoverished class, he was determined to seize the day. It was important for him to capture images of the orphans of Chernobyl and those who had lost their jobs while they were still "normal", before they had "hardened" into an underclass, he writes in the book that accompanies the show.

Through his work, Mikhailov is compensating for the ban on photographing disasters in Soviet times: for example, there are no pictures of the Ukrainian famine of the 30s when millions of people died. In a sense, Mikhailov is empowering homeless people by allowing their bodies to stand as testament to the disaster that is being inflicted upon them by the new state.

The often shocking nakedness of Mikhailov's subjects is central to the impact of the series. Under the communists, photographing the naked body was equated with pornography, and nakedness still has a subversive power. Mikhailov himself worked as an engineer until, in the late 60s, the KGB found some nude pictures he had taken of his first wife and he was sacked. Nudity is a way for Mikhailov to bring out a humanity that can be obscured by filthy clothes.

Critical reaction to the show - which encompasses work not only from the recent series, but from the past four decades - has been a kind of hysterical silence. Although Mikhailov has been described as one the best artists to emerge from the former USSR (along with his close friend Ilya Kabakov), the press has been fearful of going beyond the superficial assumption that Case History represents exploitative voyeurism. Mikhailov has come to be blamed by association for the horror of his subjects' lives. Like the Ukrainian woman who said, "Do you have nothing to do?" to him as he helped a homeless man up off the street, this critical cold-shouldering has served to further distance and dehumanise his subjects.

"The first time I saw Mikailhov's book, I thought it was a classic photography work, like Robert Frank's The Americans," counters Millar. "Usually pictures of the homeless allow you to feel better about yourself because you can display the correct liberal emotions. What is striking here is that you feel worse. You don't want to identify with the deformed bodies. You can't identify with Mikhailov as a humanist because he forces you to take part in the transaction." Mikhailov made himself complicit with the state by asking his subjects to strip off for the price of a month's pension; often they do so bit by bit in an unrelenting, freak-show striptease. The viewer, like the subject, is abandoned with no place for moral or emotional refuge. There is no one in these pictures to identify with.

But Mikhailov is not to be confused with the rich exiled artist or the street photographer who snipes at others' misery. He has been based in Berlin for a few months since he was hospitalised due to a heart condition, but normally lives in a shabby flat in Kharkov, eastern Ukraine, where he was born in 1938. It was here that he took the dispossessed to bathe, drink and pose - while they were merely abused by most passers-by.

Ukraine, whose population knew immense suffering throughout the 20th century, is beginning the new century in turmoil. Independence in 1991 brought economic chaos and a rise in violent crime against women and children. Surveys show that around 15% of women have been raped and 25% physically abused. There has been a massive increase in the numbers of homeless children. There is little room for compassion for the homeless in Ukraine, since you - the passer-by - might be next. "The three of them whose photos are placed in the beginning of the book died within two months," Mikhailov writes. "And when I took their photos I had the feeling that it was already impossible to help them." Photographic evidence means that this time the disaster cannot be denied.

 Boris Mikhailov: Case History is at the Photographers' Gallery, London WC2 (020-7836 9704), till May 21. The accompanying book is published by Scalo at £35.

webTitle: 'I get great audiences. I get the real hip and groovy funky people'

fields.headline: 'I get great audiences. I get the real hip and groovy funky people'
fields.standfirst: But Ute Lemper still finds plenty to complain about.  Adam Sweeting lends an ear
fields.trailText: But Ute Lemper still finds plenty to complain about. Adam Sweeting lends an ear.
fields.body:
Ute Lemper has become inextricably linked with Kurt Weill and the cabaret songs of the Weimar Republic, yet pinning her down is like trying to cram a mattress into the neck of a wine bottle. The New York Times captured one aspect of her performing self with the observation, "Ms Lemper gleefully carries the role of cabaret singer to the edge of stylised madness", but that's only part of the story. She'll add a new chapter when she brings the songs from her recent album, Punishing Kiss, to British stages at the beginning of May. For once, these will be pieces by current writers, including Tom Waits, Nick Cave, Elvis Costello and The Divine Comedy, rather than music written under the gathering storm of Nazi Germany.

In conversation with the woman, you get the impression that inside that impossibly long, slim body, there are at least half a dozen Lempers trying to get out. She delivers a string of tirades and monologues, as she rages about her pet hates and obsessions then soberly evaluates her life and career.

For instance, she hates the two-faced smugness of the Royal Family. She watched Sarah Ferguson being interviewed on CNN by Larry King, and saw red. "She says, 'I respect and honour the royal family', but she doesn't at all," snaps Lemper. "Why doesn't she say, 'I think the royal family is infamous. They are mean people, they caused a lot of pain for Diana and me, and they're racists' - there are no black people working at Buckingham Palace. Why doesn't she just say this? She's hypocritical for the sake of her fucking title. It's just unbearable."

In Lemper-world, Hitler and the Nazis come in for regular hammerings, as do Germany and German culture in general. The hypocrisy and closet anti-semitism of the British also get her goat. So does the new financial apartheid she sees developing in Europe, as the rich EU countries gang up against the smaller ones with unreliable currencies. What French audiences consider to be humour is a perpetual source of bafflement to her. It's some kind of therapy: she deals with her emotions by ranting them to a standstill.

She can't understand why the British critics put the boot into her one-woman show, Life's a Swindle, when she brought it to the Queen's Theatre in London last year. In her mind, she can still see rows of repressed middle-aged men scrawling derogatory comments. "The show worked really well in the US and in Paris, and the only bad reviews I got were here in England," she grumbles. "In the first week, I got this very stiff-upper-lip British conservative audience who didn't know what the heck was happening with that show, because it was so outside the conventions of a West End performance. But in the second week I got a great audience, I got the real hip and groovy funky people."

The choice of words is a giveaway here. Behind her cool and haughty exterior, which makes her look like the killer queen of old Berlin, a large chunk of Lemper is an old-fashioned radical with hippy tendencies. Born in Munster in the mid-60s, she found herself suffering - not unlike Germany itself - from a divided soul. As she grew up, Germany was beginning to reassert itself after its period of post-war reconstruction, but Lemper has always felt conflicting emotions about her homeland, and has looked outwards to France, Britain and the United States. Her marriage to the Jewish writer and comedian David Tabatsky, with whom she lives in New York with their two children, was an implicit condemnation of everything she disliked about Germany.

Her attachment to the works of Brecht and Weill grew out of the same soil. "Brecht had all those spirits I was looking for. He was violent sometimes. He created a universe of sailors and whores and love and passion and the outcasts of society, again always anti-establishment and anti-capitalism. It expressed a lot of what I wanted to express while I was growing up."

Life's a Swindle marked a change of direction for Lemper. She admits that the first night was heavy with her most intimate neuroses, especially the long monologue about a return trip she made to Germany and her attempt to throw off the baggage of her Catholic upbringing, but the most striking aspect was its acid humour. Lemper has always viewed the world darkly and through a distorting lens, but finally she was finding a way of expressing that in direct, personal terms, not just through performances of other writers' material.

"David has really helped me a lot," she explains. "I only took the role of Velma Kelly in Chicago because he convinced me to do it. He said, 'It will be fine, I'll run the household. Do this, it will be good for you.' Plus he encouraged me to explore comedy and introduce humour into a performance, which I wouldn't do 10 years ago. So I'm proud of the Life's a Swindle show, because in the end it did find its audience. I'm even proud of the bad reviews because they proved the show was anti-conservative and these reviewers were pretty conservative - though I'll acknowledge there were a couple of mistakes on the first night."

Lemper's forthcoming Punishing Kiss performances will see her in a different guise. The album was the fruition of a long-cherished ambition to break away from the Weimar Republic and record some more modern songs. "I was always hoping that this might happen, but sometimes I don't seize the initiative enough to say, 'Right, this has to happen now!' " Lemper admits. "There are always so many other projects waiting on my doorstep, usually in the cabaret or contemporary classical fields."

While she enjoyed recording the new songs, her main goal was to find material for performance. It's in front of a live audience that Lemper feels she really finds herself.

"What I love so much about the stage is that you are isolated and you go down to the naked nothing of existence," she explains. "You go into the dark areas of life, and all questions are there. Where do I go? Where do I come from? Why are relationships not working out? Why am I so isolated even though I live inside a big society? That's really why I want to perform. OK, you can give the schtick and the fun and the movement, but I need to go all the way down to that deep dark area. That is when I become fulfilled as a performer."

 Ute Lemper plays the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on May 3, and Bridgewater Hall, Manchester (0161-907 9000), on May 5.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Gorge - then pick your teeth | Scorched earth
fields.body:
Gorge - then pick your teeth
The tooth, one of 1.8 million years' worth of trove from the Olduvai Gorge in Tanza nia, had tiny parallel lines scored along its sides. The size, shape and orientation of the grooves pointed to someone shoving something narrow into a small space between their teeth, Peter Ungar, University of Arkansas, told the American Association of Physical Anthropology in San Antonio, Texas. "Teeth are not well designed for eating meat, so our early ancestors had to use toothpicks," he said. Only humans did such things. "I can't think of another behaviour, other than chewing, that leaves its record on the teeth of such a broad range of members of our genus, Homo."

Fifty reasons for more GM
The Biologist, journal of the Institute of Biology, is 50 years old, and its anniversary issue is as provocative as ever. "It is inconceivable that even in 20 years' time, most people will challenge the idea that GM technology is vital for human health and happiness," writes Sir John Beringer, dean of science at Bristol, and a veteran player in the game of advising governments. And that means GM crops too, which could increase yield and nutritional quality for developing world farmers without the use of expensive imported chemicals. "As long as we remain overfed, and expenditure on food is only a minor part of our cost of living, we can afford to be complacent. However, very poor and hungry people need methods to harvest more food and become self-sufficient." He goes on: "The redistribution of food we so often hear about as a solution is a political irrelevance. What country would choose to make itself dependent on another for food, thereby making itself subject to external political control?"

Scorched earth back in business
Next month will mark the 20th anniversary of the eruption of Mt St Helens, which on May 18, 1980, wiped its environs clean of life with billions of tons of boiling lava. "There was no biological legacy left," says John Bishop of Washington State University. "Plants, animals, bacteria and organic matter were all blown away, burned or buried by rock." In 1981 a solitary lupin plant sprouted in the plains of pumice on the mountain's north side. Today there are 20 acres of the leguminous Lupinus lepidus. But the growth rate is being slowed by hungry caterpillars. "A lot of things like to eat lupin," said Prof Bishop. "I found insects were preventing lupins from reproducing so fast. They were running the revegetation show."

fields.headline: Cisco kids ride high
fields.standfirst: Jack Schofield looks at how a university project became a world-dominating business
fields.trailText: Jack Schofield looks at how a university project became a world-dominating business
fields.body:
Cisco - a shortened form of San Francisco - shot to fame this year when it briefly overtook Microsoft as the world's most valuable company. And for many, that came as a bit of a shock.

Microsoft might be small, but almost everyone is familiar with its Windows and Office software. Cisco's products are largely invisible, but form part of the basic plumbing of the internet. Given its 80% market share, it's virtually certain that all your email and web pages have at some point been forwarded by a Cisco router. In fact, some analysts have seen Cisco for years as the third element in a notional triumvirate called Wintelcis. Today's world of networked computers depends at least as much on Cisco routers as it does on Microsoft's Windows software and Intel's processors. All three companies have fought hard to achieve and maintain their monopoly market shares, and of the three, Cisco most closely resembles a cult.

"Cisco employees happily toil away like robots on Prozac, cocooned by the all-consuming lifestyle," notes Paul Bunnell in the first book about the company, published this week. It's a slim book compared with familiar blockbusters about Apple, IBM, Microsoft and other industry powers, but it tells a story that few people know.

Like hundreds of Silicon Valley success stories from Sun Microsystems to Yahoo!, Cisco started at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Califor nia. In the early 1980s, the campus had thousands of computers connected together in networks, but no convenient way of connecting the separate networks together. Working without permission and without an official budget, Sandy Lerner, director of computing at the Stanford University Business School, her boyfriend Len Bosack and other engineers just went ahead and did it. Sandy and Len didn't invent routers - which basically work like electronic post offices, forwarding packets of data instead of packets of paper.

They didn't invent TCP/IP, the internet protocol that defines how the packets travel. They didn't write the interface software that made the whole thing run. But they did help create a system that got an incredibly useful job done. When word of their success spread across the internet, other universities and some businesses wanted to use Stanford's "black box" to solve the same problem. However, the university wasn't interested in supplying demand, nor did it want Sandy and Len using its facilities for that purpose. So late in 1984, the couple mortgaged their house and used their credit cards to start 'cisco (with a small c in those days) in their living room at 199 Oak Grove Avenue, Atherton, California. Sandy based the company logo on the Golden Gate bridge. Cisco was a success, but the founders soon lost control. Their venture capitalist backer, Don Valentine, brought in a management team, and in 1990, seven vice presidents presented him with an ultimatum: it was Sandy or them.

Sandy was out, and Len quit soon afterwards. But at that point, the man most responsible for making Cisco a superpower, John Thomas Chambers, hadn't even joined the company. Chambers, a former IBM salesman, turned Cisco from a company with only 500 employees and annual sales of $183m in 1991 into today's powerhouse, with 21,000 employees and sales worth about $15bn a year. (It reported $8.3bn in sales for the last six months of 1999.)

One of the secrets of Chambers' success has been to expand rapidly by buying in new technologies. He's become known for paying very high prices for small start-up companies - in one case, Cerent, it came to $25m per employee. Manda Rigby, the UK director of marketing, says: "We don't buy people for large market share, we don't buy them to take competitive technologies out and then not develop them, we buy young companies with cutting-edge technology, and we buy people."

Rigby reckons that Cisco has taken over 57 companies, including 11 so far this year. But, she adds, about 75% of the former chief executives whose companies have been taken over are still with Cisco, "and it can't be because they need the money".

The idea is simple: find out what customers need next and buy the best of the companies starting to supply it. Or in Cisco's case, buy half a dozen of them, if necessary. But it requires an agnosticism that, at crucial times, has proven beyond all too many technology companies, including IBM and Apple. Unlike them, Cisco has not fought religious wars based on an arrogant belief in its own superiority, to the detriment of its customers' businesses.

Of course, Cisco does have a "big idea": its belief in the ultimate triumph of IP, the internet protocol. Chambers bet the company on the success of the internet, and the belief that it would subsume or displace other forms of networking. Big bet, big win. The question now is whether Cisco can expand its dominance of internet technologies both downwards into the small business/home market, and upwards into the telecommunications business. In the small business/home market, Cisco will eventually run into Intel, which has earmarked networking as a major area for its future growth. Indeed, Intel wants to commoditise the networking business by providing cheap "building block" technologies that will do the same jobs as high-priced equipment like Cisco's. Intel wants to make it as easy to assemble routers, hubs and switches as it is to assemble PCs.

In the telecommunications market, Cisco will run into industry giants such as Lucent (formerly part of the US phone company, AT&T) and Nortel (originally the Canadian phone company, Northern Telecom). Although "pure IP" networks - carrying voice calls as well as data - might be the future, the phone companies have already invested billions in existing systems using different technologies, such as ATM (Asynchronous Transfer Mode communications).

They aren't going to throw it out, and it takes them decades to update their infrastructure. As Bunnell points out: "The internet industry in which Cisco thrives is built on a tradition of rapid development at the expense of reliability and tolerance of flaws that would be insufferable in the phone industry." Like Intel and Microsoft, its business has been built on the rapid development and deployment of new features, rather than fixing the technology for years and concentrating on reliability. Still, Chambers believes the world's networks are going to converge into one giant, global telecommunications system carrying voice, data and anything else that can be digitised. Maybe Cisco won't end up with 80% of it, but it wont be for want of trying.

 Making the Cisco Connection: The Story Behind the Real Internet Superpower by David Bunnell (John Wiley & Sons, £16.50).

So late in 1984, the couple mortgaged their house and used their credit cards to start 'cisco (with a small c in those days) in their living room at 199 Oak Grove Avenue, Atherton, California. Sandy based the company logo on the Golden Gate bridge. Cisco was a success, but the founders soon lost control. Their venture capitalist backer, Don Valentine, brought in a management team, and in 1990, seven vice presidents presented him with an ultimatum: it was Sandy or them. Sandy was out, and Len quit soon afterwards. But at that point, the man most responsible for making Cisco a superpower, John Thomas Chambers, hadn't even joined the company. Chambers, a former IBM salesman, turned Cisco from a company with only 500 employees and annual sales of $183m in 1991 into today's powerhouse, with 21,000 employees and sales worth about $15bn a year. (It reported $8.3bn in sales for the last six months of 1999.) One of the secrets of Chambers' success has been to expand rapidly by buying in new technologies. He's become known for paying very high prices for small start-up companies - in one case, Cerent, it came to $25m per employee. Manda Rigby, the UK director of marketing, says: "We don't buy people for large market share, we don't buy them to take competitive technologies out and then not develop them, we buy young companies with cutting-edge technology, and we buy people." Rigby reckons that Cisco has taken over 57 companies, including 11 so far this year. But, she adds, about 75% of the former chief executives whose companies have been taken over are still with Cisco, "and it can't be because they need the money". The idea is simple: find out what customers need next and buy the best of the companies starting to supply it. Or in Cisco's case, buy half a dozen of them, if necessary. But it requires an agnosticism that, at crucial times, has proven beyond all too many technology companies, including IBM and Apple. Unlike them, Cisco has not fought religious wars based on an arrogant belief in its own superiority, to the detriment of its customers' businesses. Of course, Cisco does have a "big idea": its belief in the ultimate triumph of IP, the internet protocol. Chambers bet the company on the success of the internet, and the belief that it would subsume or displace other forms of networking. Big bet, big win. Indeed, Intel wants to commoditise the networking business by providing cheap "building block" technologies that will do the same jobs as high-priced equipment like Cisco's. Intel wants to make it as easy to assemble routers, hubs and switches as it is to assemble PCs. In the telecommunications market, Cisco will run into industry giants such as Lucent (formerly part of the US phone company, AT&T) and Nortel (originally the Canadian phone company, Northern Telecom). Although "pure IP" networks - carrying voice calls as well as data - might be the future, the phone companies have already invested billions in existing systems using different technologies, such as ATM (Asynchronous Transfer Mode communications). They aren't going to throw it out, and it takes them decades to update their infrastructure. As Bunnell points out: "The internet industry in which Cisco thrives is built on a tradition of rapid development at the expense of reliability and tolerance of flaws that would be insufferable in the phone industry." Like Intel and Microsoft, its business has been built on the rapid development and deployment of new features, rather than fixing the technology for years and concentrating on reliability. Still, Chambers believes the world's networks are going to converge into one giant, global telecommunications system carrying voice, data and anything else that can be digitised. Maybe Cisco won't end up with 80% of it, but it wont be for want of trying.  Making the Cisco Connection: The Story Behind the Real Internet Superpower by David Bunnell (John Wiley & Sons, £16.50).

fields.headline: Let them eat smog
fields.standfirst: The pollution problems of Tokyo and other cities may be solved by walls with strange appetites, writes  David Bradley
fields.trailText: The pollution problems of Tokyo and other cities may be solved by walls with strange appetites, writes David Bradley
fields.body:
A material that can eat smog whatever the weather has been developed by Japanese scientists. The material based on a mixture of the "whiter than white" pigment titanium dioxide, used in cosmetics and dyes, and activated graphite could be incorporated into construction materials for buildings, bridges and motorway sound baffles to cut down pollution.

Dr Koji Takeuchi and his research team at the National Institute of Resources and Environment in Ibaraki have found that titanium dioxide powder mixed with graphite can soak up nitrogen and sulphur oxide gases - NOx and SOx - from the air. These gases are a major source of pollution from vehicle exhausts and accumulate in busy cities and along motorways. "Purifying the air is not as simple as purifying polluted water," explains Takeuchi. "It is impossible to hold air in one place and wind and air currents spread and dissipate airborne pollutants."

There are filters on the ventilation towers of many tunnels and underground carparks in Japan, but these use a lot of energy to scrub the polluted air emerging into the atmosphere. A cheaper solution based on simply absorbing the gases into an active material would be much more environmentally friendly.

Absorbing the gases is not enough to be useful though so Takeuchi has experimented by shining ultraviolet light on test materials that had absorbed the polluting gases.

Even weak UV light activated the titanium dioxide to break down the NOx and SOx into weak solutions of nitric and sulphuric acid, which cannot evaporate into the air. Takeuchi says that incorporating this smog-eating material into construction components such as cladding for high-rise buildings could act as a pollution sponge, soaking up noxious gases from even the most heavily polluted cities. Sunlight, on the cloudiest of winter days, is enough, he claims, to make the material work. The panels would in effect be self-cleaning and so stay white. At the chemical level, the graphite, which is powdered to produce an enormous surface area in a small volume, acts as a sponge absorbing the pollutants from the air.

The titanium dioxide activated by UV light from the sun releases highly reactive oxygen and hydroxy "radicals" - molecules with an extra electron. These radicals race around inside the material reacting with the absorbed pollutant molecules and zapping them into non-volatile acids.

But what about getting rid of the acids? The material regenerates itself when it comes into contact with water, so when it rains the acids are flushed off into gutters where they can be neutralised by addition of alkali lime in the drainage inlet system, leaving refreshed walls ready to eat yet more smog. However, Takeuchi points out, alkali components in the atmosphere also help neutralise the acids as they form, so the lime might not be needed.

T o make a smog-eating panel the team coated a sheet of fluorocarbon plastic, similar to Teflon, with a thin layer of the titanium dioxide mixture. The fluorocarbon makes a very tough backing that can resist the weather. Because it is difficult enough to make anything stick to it in the first place it becomes almost impossible for the titanium layer to come off.

Accelerated weathering tests show the panels should last at least five years. A panel just one metre square weighs half a kilo and can absorb and destroy several grams of NOx and SOx before it needs to be regenerated, which is enough to last a week or so in even the most polluted of Japan's cities.

Large-scale trials are now under way in Tokyo, Takeuchi said, and if they work as well as he hopes the materials will become widely used in the construction industry for panelling buildings and pavements, be built into motorway sound barriers or tunnel and carpark ventilation towers. He adds that the panels would effectively be maintenance free, requiring only a little sun and a spot of rain once a week, or so. Early results from tests show that the panels can remove up to 30% of the pollution from the notoriously polluted Tokyo air.

This simple modification to the urban landscape might be a far more preferable approach to dealing with pollution than simply introducing ever stricter regulations on vehicle use. It might even be possible to reduce traffic volumes enough without a blanket ban to compete with Takeuchi's system.

He and his team are now working on paints that could simply be sprayed on to suitable surfaces, thus avoiding the need for panels. He is also tweaking the formulation so that the material works in normal light and not just UV, this he says, would boost the effect 10 times.

 Takeuchi's work is reported in the current issue of the Journal of Environmental Monitoring.
