webTitle: A few weeks to stop, stare and refresh your English

fields.headline: A few weeks to stop, stare and refresh your English
fields.standfirst: Max de Lotbinière finds that short, summer training courses can bring teachers unexpected benefits
fields.trailText: Max de Lotbinière finds that short, summer training courses can bring teachers unexpected benefits
fields.body:
The menu of short teacher training courses available over the summer months in Britain and other English-speaking countries is enough to make any teacher's mouth water. From the traditional refresher courses, offering teachers the chance to repair their own language skills bruised by years of exposure to students' garbled English, to highly specialised courses focusing on the newest in methodology, the choice is as wide as it is rich.

But few teachers will decide to enrol on a course of this kind lightly. Not only are they expensive - employers will need to be convinced that the combination of fees and travel expenses is justified - but they also eat into most teachers' well-earned summer vacation. For those teachers with families it can be even harder to find child-care during the school holidays. So most teachers will need to plan this kind of training well in advance, particularly if they seek sponsorship. (Secondary school teachers from the 30 countries eligible for funding from the European Union's Lingua funding must apply three months in advance.) They must also be sure that the course they choose will serve their needs, and getting that right can often be the hardest part of the process.

Rosemary Wilson runs the Bell Teacher Training Institute based in Cambridge, England. She finds that participants fall into two broad categories: those that are seeking to develop their own language skills and those who want to focus on a specific aspect of methodology. There is nothing to stop teachers doing both, she says, but first of all they must be sure that the course they choose allows them to do so.

The first and most obvious advice Wilson gives prospective participants is to ask for detailed information about the course and to study this carefully. "Teachers can be reticent about asking for more information," says Wilson, "but the teachers we are looking for are the ones who are prepared to ask questions."

At Pilgrims, the teacher training centre in Canterbury, courses are divided into three categories: language, methodology and specialist courses, but Glen Stephen, who runs the programme, still believes that no matter how focused teachers are on specific skills, they all share the same basic need. "If they are teaching English outside an English-speaking country," he says, "they believe they have got out of touch with the language and above all they want to refresh their use of English."

In recognition of this Stephen has designed an element of language practice into all the courses. Participants engage in discussion and negotiation sessions and they are encouraged to use new language.

But while teachers will gain exposure to new language during their course, it is not always possible for trainers to present concepts or skills that will be entirely new to them. Both Stephen and Wilson note that teachers can have unrealistic expectations about the kind of knowledge that will be revealed during the course and also how they will use it when they return to their classrooms.

"Because ELT issues have become so global, teachers will be coming to us from countries where many of the ideas we are covering are already current and they are left asking, 'What's new about this?'," says Wilson.

To compensate for this, Wilson stresses that the unique experience offered by short courses is the chance to encounter and exchange ideas with teachers from other countries and backgrounds. Finding out what participants have in common, and the mutual support they develop, creates an environment which lets them reflect on their professional life.

According to Wilson, it can be "two weeks to stop and stare". And thanks to email, the close bonds many participants forge during their courses continue as they share and discuss ideas when they return home.

These kinds of experiences and the chance to familiarise themselves with contemporary life in an English-speaking country are the most frequently cited benefits of short courses by teachers. Yet, rewarding as they may be, most teachers will also be under pressure to demonstrate that they have acquired new skills on their return.

Stephen advises patience. "Putting into practice what they have learnt doesn't happen immediately. We introduce them to new ways of teaching, but it can take six to eight months to adapt these to their own circumstances. It is the beginning of a process of personal development."

webTitle: Culture shock of new campus life

fields.headline: Culture shock of new campus life
fields.standfirst: Foreign students have more to adjust to than just language, says Jane Pearson
fields.trailText: Foreign students have more to adjust to than just language, says Jane Pearson
fields.body:
At the launch earlier this year of UK Education, the British government's $8m marketing campaign designed to attract 50,000 more international students into higher education by 2005, the minister responsible, Baroness Blackstone, promised: "Changes have been introduced to improve our welcome and the affordability of British study." But one aspect of that welcome that may need special attention is the provision of support in language and study skills.

Even international students whose first language is English can find themselves struggling to understand an alien academic culture. The problems are very familiar to Maggie Ward Goodbody, out-going chair of the British Association of Lecturers in English for Academic Purposes (BALEAP). "Students' first problems are often with listening skills," she explains. "They may feel nervous about this and it is certainly a steep learning curve. They need structured listening experience, for instance how to pick out the main ideas. They also need help with academic reading -how to approach an article or book, how to skim read and make notes."

However, as students' confidence in listening skills grows, it is in the area of academic writing where more serious cultural differences become apparent. Much of British education is based on essay writing, but this may be a demanding task to students from other cultures. Suddenly they are faced with the need to express their own ideas, develop their opinions and evaluate different issues, all in polished English.

Yet for some, the concept of originating this kind of written discourse can prove problematic, and they may find themselves scoring low marks because of plagiarism, or reproducing someone else's ideas. In Britain plagiarism is regarded as academic theft, though this is not always the case in other countries. Students are expected to do research in a library before tackling an assignment, and simply regurgitating lecture notes is also not acceptable.

Group discussions can be another ordeal, and not just because a student's grasp of English is still unsure. In some Asian cultures speaking out in a group is not encouraged, nor is asking questions, which can be construed as criticism of the tutor.

But according to Richard Fay, lecturer in education at Manchester University, "much of what we expect from international students is implicit, for instance the relationship between students and their tutors. International students have to discover what is appropriate, and it is not necessarily dealt with on pre-sessional courses."

The best way to overcome these hurdles is to be prepared. The first step is to take a test to assess the English language skills needed to cope with the issues of academic culture. The leading tests are IELTS (International English Language Testing System) or TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language).

If an IELTS or TOEFL test indicates that a student's language skills are not sufficient to embark on a university degree, the next step is to consider pre-sessional courses, generally at the university where the student will take a degree. These can last from three weeks to an academic year, so it is wise for students to be realistic about their needs. It is generally accepted that approximately 200 hours of study are needed to improve by one IELTS band-score.

Once embarked on a degree course, Martin Kenworthy, director of the Language Services Unit at the University of Leicester, also stresses the value of good quality in-sessional training, preferably linked to subject areas. "We go into the departments and work with students in their lectures. We also encourage departments to give formative assignments early in the course to avoid disaster for a student later, when assignments count."

Some of the "new" universities -those formed from polytechnics in 1992 - are experimenting with new styles of pre-sessional and foundation courses. Elspeth Jones, director of the Centre for Language Study at Leeds Metropolitan University, explains: "Our courses are monthly, and so students from parts of the world with a different academic year can enrol at any time. The General English courses can also become credit-bearing modules in the Credit Accumulation and Transfer Scheme (CATS) and therefore part of a student's degree."

She feels that language training in new universities is generally more flexible than in older institutions. "Universities like ours can take students with lower IELTS grades and can put them through a programme that will bring them up to the required standard - though we cannot guarantee how long it will take."

Faced with the variety of courses on offer, Andrew Waite, Vice-Chair of the British Association of State English Language Teaching (BASELT) urges caution. "One problem is that some institutions clearly need to further improve their support for international students. Students need to do research and find out about language centres. Have they been externally assessed under the English in Britain accreditation system, is one question to ask."

BALEAP runs a self-regulatory accreditation system which, like English in Britain, ensures courses meet high standards, not just in teaching, but in all areas including management, welfare, course design, staffing and assessment.

However, if language tutors are right to issue warnings about some current provision, what will be the effect of Education UK? Ros Richards, head of English for Academic Purposes at the University of Reading, feels the remedy lies in careful planning. "Increased provision for pre-sessional and in-sessional English language programmes will be needed. In their academic departments greater numbers of international students are likely to need more supporting material for their courses, and more explicit feedback on content and language. This will require more time from academic staff. Institutions need to be addressing this issue now and planning its effective resourcing for the future."

For more information

English in Britain, information is available from local British Council offices

webTitle: Sudden rush of blood defies language debate

fields.headline: Sudden rush of blood defies language debate
fields.standfirst: Jean Aitchison explains how new brain scans reveal our skill with language to be far more complex than linguists imagined
fields.trailText: Jean Aitchison explains how new brain scans reveal our skill with language to be far more complex than linguists imagined
fields.body:
Is language a daisy chain, with words added on like flowers one after another? Or is it a wreath, with the overall structure implicitly known beforehand?

The chain versus wreath controversy has been chugging on for centuries, swinging to and fro like the perpetual ding-dong battle raging between the brothers Tweedledum and Tweedledee in Lewis Carroll's Through The Looking-Glass.

The debate hotted up in the second half of the 20th century. In the 1950s, behaviourist psychologists took the daisy chain view, claiming that language was a cumulative set of habits. In the 1960s Noam Chomsky disagreed. He argued that we are all preprogrammed with an outline knowledge of language.

Gradually Chomsky has honed his views, claiming that humans know not only underlying linguistic principles, such as how far chunks of sentence can be moved, but, in addition, they are aware of crucial basic options that have to be decided on: it is as if language learners had to discover whether to drive on the left of the road, or the right, a choice which has crucial consequences, such as which way to go round roundabouts.

Once a linguistic decision has been made, then a number of consequences follow: if a language has verbs preceding its objects, as in English "eat apples", it will also have auxiliaries in front of the main verb, as in "will eat". A language such as Turkish does the reverse, and says, as it were "apples eat, eat will". Is this preprogrammed knowledge, as Chomsky argues, or do humans just prefer consistent solutions to puzzles?

At one stage Chomsky appeared to have won the day, especially when his views were backed up and publicised by Steven Pinker in his best-seller The Language Instinct (Allen Lane, 1994). Yet Chomsky's opponents continue to argue. Geoffrey Sampson in his book Educating Eve (Continuum, 1997), for example, claims that Eve, our first human ancestor, was "not a born know-all. She was a good learner".

So who is right? And does it matter? Well yes, it matters for language learners. It's important to know how much pre-ordained knowledge about language humans may possess, or whether they simply have to roll up their sleeves and string together the daisies. Recent work is starting to solve the problem.

Both sides are right, it turns out. An outline wreath needs to be there, before the daisy-chainers can add the daisies. Language, unsurprisingly, is a highly complex phenomenon. It is a patchwork quilt of different abilities, which emerged around 100,000 years ago.

Increasingly those working on language origin are rolling the starting date back even further. A pre-linguistic proto-language predated "real' language by tens of thousands of years, many now assume. And language, like the human race itself, possibly originated in Africa.

Our linguistic leap-forward was a stitch-and-patch job. Language was cobbled together out of multiple existing bits and pieces to form a coherent interlocking system, a true case of the whole being more than a sum of the parts. Evolutionists sometimes use the term "convergence" for this coming together of skills.

At the very least it is an ability to put oneself into another person's shoes, as it were, a so-called "theory of mind", converged with an ability to make distinct sounds, possibly enabled by walking upright. This was backed up by an interest in knowing who did what to who. This plaiting together of different pieces allowed humans simultaneously to talk about absent people and events, to place words in a consistent order, and to pronounce them clearly.

Language, then, is a complex tapestry that has been embroidered over the years, with its principles gradually integrated into our minds. Recent brain scans show that multiple parts of the brain are active in any linguistic interaction: verbs may be stored in the frontal lobe (according to one view), and nouns and adjectives in the temporal lobe. Yet these parts of speech have to interact in almost any conversation.

Increasingly, the brain is recognised as a gigantic beehive, with multiple bees buzzing simultaneously. Language "areas" are now thought to be zones in which neurons relating to linguistic activity cluster to a greater extent than elsewhere, but these areas are not totally isolated from the rest of the brain's activities.

Yet all this simultaneous buzzing and whirring should not be such a surprise: for centuries, humans have realised that language is like an overactive octopus, with numerous different types of activity co-existing. Verbs have at least two different modes of behaviour, for example. So-called "regular" verbs have predictable endings, such as "banged", "buzzed". These contrast with "irregular" unpredictable ones, such as "sat", "stood".

Neurolinguistic research has confirmed that these behave in different ways. Blood surges in the brain when someone uses language, just as extra blood is pumped into the legs when someone rides a bicycle: the brain, it appears, relies on tactics similar to a cyclist's muscles, with an increase in oxygen in any area where neurons show extra activity. Regular and irregular verbs show different blood-flow patterns, and this can be captured on brain scans.

The variety of different activities pullulating in the mind at any one time show that no single solution applies to something as complex as language. The mind works by means of massive parallel processing, and interweaves different types of ability. Slowly, we are beginning to unravel the tangled web of language - but much remains to be done.

To return to Looking-Glass land, we are finding that as the White Queen asserted, much to Alice's surprise, one's memory works in more than one way.

The debate hotted up in the second half of the 20th century. In the 1950s, behaviourist psychologists took the daisy chain view, claiming that language was a cumulative set of habits. In the 1960s Noam Chomsky disagreed. He argued that we are all preprogrammed with an outline knowledge of language. Gradually Chomsky has honed his views, claiming that humans know not only underlying linguistic principles, such as how far chunks of sentence can be moved, but, in addition, they are aware of crucial basic options that have to be decided on: it is as if language learners had to discover whether to drive on the left of the road, or the right, a choice which has crucial consequences, such as which way to go round roundabouts. Once a linguistic decision has been made, then a number of consequences follow: if a language has verbs preceding its objects, as in English "eat apples", it will also have auxiliaries in front of the main verb, as in "will eat". A language such as Turkish does the reverse, and says, as it were "apples eat, eat will". Is this preprogrammed knowledge, as Chomsky argues, or do humans just prefer consistent solutions to puzzles? fields.headline: The best physician scene
fields.standfirst: Any Given Sunday
fields.trailText: Any Given Sunday
fields.body:
Strolling discreetly from locker room to office, the Miami Sharks' head doctor Harvey Mandrake (James Woods) and owner Christina Pagniacci (Cameron Diaz) discuss the futures of injured veterans Cap Rooney and Shark LaVey. Mandrake lowers his voice to a near-whisper.

"Rooney's so freaked out about Beaman taking his place," he says, "he'd probably play with a fractured neck."

"Could you slow him down, Harvey?" asks Christina. "Just tell him he's not responding to rehab well enough. Let's give Beaman a shot."

"Well," Mandrake ponders, "everyone knows herniated discs are iffy."

"What about Shark?"

"He's still woozy, he's got bad migraines, post-concussive syndrome..."

"Can you clear him?"

The doctor looks aghast.

"Christina, the guy's had three concussions in five months. There's just no way to predict what another head hit would do to this guy. Look, I don't think anything's going to happen, but I have some kind of conscience. All right?"

"I'm not trying to screw him. But I'd like to have him in the play-offs."

"And long-term?"

Pagniacci wanders into a side room, closing the door behind her and Mandrake.

"Bottom line - we'll cut him in the close season. The word's out, everyone's seen him take the hits. Nobody's going to sign a $2 million concussion case. You do the math, doctor."She pauses.

"What you save us now, we won't forget at contract time."

See also: Bride Of Frankenstein, Mad Love, and Les Yeux Sans Visage.

Don't see also: Patch Adams.

Pointless trivia: James Woods claims to have an IQ of 180.
